4. Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter", "this article", "this section", etc., as the case may be, or to
"sections to " (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated
into the code); and
5. Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the code; but in no case may
any change be made in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the code. (2009 Code)
Chapter 3
RULES AND DEFINITIONS
1-3-1: RULES OF CONSTRUCTION:
A. In the construction of this code and of all ordinances, the rules and definitions set out in this chapter shall be observed unless such construction would
be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the board of trustees. The rules of construction and definitions set out herein shall not be applied to any
section of this code which shall contain any express provision excluding such construction or where the subject matter or the context of such section
may be repugnant thereto.
B. All general provisions, terms, phrases and expressions contained in this code shall be liberally construed in order that the true intent and meaning of the
board of trustees may be fully carried out. In the interpretation and application of any provision of this code, they shall be held to be the minimum
requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any provision of the code
imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than the other provisions of the code, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation
shall be deemed to be controlling. (2009 Code)
1-3-2: DEFINITIONS:
BOARD, BOARD OF TRUSTEES OR VILLAGE BOARD: The board of trustees of the village of Lake Bluff, which shall consist of the president and
trustees.
CODE OR THIS CODE: The Lake Bluff municipal code as designated in section 1-1-1 of this title.
COMPREHENSIVE FEE SCHEDULE: That certain schedule that is annually adopted by the board of trustees setting forth the applicable fees and charges
due for the various licenses, permits and services authorized by this code and by other ordinances of the village, as set out in chapter 12 of this title.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 35/493
CORPORATE AUTHORITIES: The village president and the board of trustees.
CORPORATE SEAL: The village seal shall be in circular form with the words and figures "Seal of the Village of Lake Bluff, Lake County, Illinois" on its
outer circle and in the interior of said circle the words, "Incorporated September 21, 1895".
COUNTY OR THIS COUNTY: The county of Lake, Illinois.
DATUM FOR GRADES1: A. A base or datum for the grades and levels of the village is hereby fixed at a point one hundred two and six-tenths feet (102.6')
below a cut on the top of the water table stone at the southeast corner of the village hall. The base or datum hereby established shall be known as "the
datum of the village of Lake Bluff".
B. Flood base elevations hereinafter established by the village shall be measured and fixed in accordance with and, with reference to the datum of the
village.
EMPLOYEES: Whenever reference is made in this code to a village employee by title only, this shall be construed as though followed by the words, "of the
village of Lake Bluff".
FEE: A sum of money charged by the village for the carrying on of a business, profession or occupation.
FISCAL YEAR: The "fiscal year" of the village shall begin on May 1 of each year and end on April 30 next following.
LICENSE: The permission or authority granted to carry on a business, profession, occupation or activity on public or private property.
MAYOR: That individual serving as village president of the village of Lake Bluff, who may be referred to as "mayor".
MISDEMEANOR: Any offense for which a sentence to a term of imprisonment in other than a penitentiary for less than one year may be imposed.
NUISANCE: Anything offensive, obnoxious or detrimental to the health, safety, and welfare and property values of the inhabitants of the village; or any act
or thing repugnant to, or creating a hazard to, or having a detrimental effect on the property of another person or to the community.
OCCUPANT: As applied to a building or land, this term shall include any person who occupies the whole or any part of such building or land, whether
alone or with others.
OFFENSE: Any act forbidden by any provision of this code or the omission of any act required by the provisions of this code.
OFFICERS: Whenever any officer is referred to by title, such as "village clerk", "chief of police", "president", etc., such reference shall be construed as if
followed by the words "of the village of Lake Bluff".
OPERATOR: The person who is in charge of any operation, business or profession.
OWNER: As applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant or tenant by the
entirety of the whole or of a part of such building or land.
PERSON: Shall extend and be applied to associations, clubs, and societies, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals.
PERSONAL PROPERTY: Every description of money, goods, chattels, effects, evidence of rights in action and all written instruments by which any
pecuniary obligation or right or title to property is created, acknowledged, transferred, increased, defeated, discharged or diminished and every right or
interest therein.
RETAILER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, this term shall be understood to relate to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things in small
quantities direct to the consumer.
STATE OR THIS STATE: The state of Illinois.
STREET: Shall be construed to embrace streets, avenues, boulevards, roads, alleys, lanes, viaducts and all other public ways in the village and shall
include all areas thereof embraced between property lines and dedicated to the public use.
TENANT OR OCCUPANT: As applied to a building or land, shall include any person holding a written or oral lease or who occupies the whole or a part of
such building or land, either alone or with others.
VILLAGE: The village of Lake Bluff, Lake County, Illinois.
VILLAGE PRESIDENT: The president of the village may be referred to as "mayor" or "president" of the village. The president is also a member of and
included in the definition of the "board of trustees".
WHOLESALER AND WHOLESALE DEALER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, such terms shall be understood to relate to the sale of goods,
merchandise, articles or things in quantity to persons who purchase for the purpose of resale.
WRITTEN, IN WRITING: Shall be construed to include any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by printing or otherwise. (1988 Code § 1-3-
2; amd. 2009 Code)
Chapter 4
GENERAL PENALTY
1-4-1: GENERAL PENALTY; CONTINUING VIOLATIONS; EXCEPTION:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 36/493
A. Whenever in this code, or in any ordinance of the village, any act or omission is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a
violation of this code, or whenever in such code or ordinance the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or an
offense or a violation of this code, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provision of this code or any ordinance is
hereby declared to be an offense and shall be punishable by a fine of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) and not more than seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00). A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day or part thereof on which a violation occurs or continues or is permitted
to occur or continue.
B. Whenever a minimum but no maximum fine is imposed as a penalty by any section or paragraph of this code, the court may, in its discretion, fine the
offender any sum exceeding the minimum fine, but the fine shall not exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
C. Unless otherwise provided, a separate offense shall be held to have been committed on each day that any violation of any section of this code shall
occur or continue.
D. Notwithstanding any other provision of this code or any other ordinance of the village, where service of summons in connection with any alleged code or
ordinance violation is made by certified mail pursuant to section 1-4-4 of this chapter, the maximum fine for each violation or offense shall not exceed
two hundred dollars ($200.00).
E. No provision of this code designating the duties of any village officer or employee shall be construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any
fine or penalty provided in this code for a failure to perform such duty, unless the intention of the board of trustees to impose such a fine or penalty on
such officer or employee is specifically and clearly expressed in the section creating the duty. (2009 Code)
1-4-2: CITATIONS OR COMPLAINTS:
A citation or complaint for any ordinance violation or a violation of this code may encompass more than one day. (2009 Code)
1-4-3: OFFENSES PUNISHABLE UNDER SEVERAL SECTIONS; LICENSE REVOCATION:
In all cases where the same offense is made punishable under more than one section or subsection of this code, the prosecuting officer may elect under
which to proceed, but in no case shall more than one penalty be imposed upon a person for a single offense; except, that the revocation of a license or
permit (or other civil action of a nonpenal character to enforce any provision of this code) shall not be considered a penalty so as to bar any other penalty
being imposed. (2009 Code)
1-4-4: SERVICE OF CITATIONS OR COMPLAINTS:
A. A citation or complaint for any ordinance violation or any violation of this code may be served by certified mail, return receipt requested; by personal
service by a police or fire officer of the village; or by personal service by the director or a designated employee of the village administrator.
B. Personal service of a citation shall be made either by personally delivering the citation or complaint to the defendant, or by leaving a copy at the
defendant's usual place of abode with some person of the defendant's family of the age of thirteen (13) years or older, and informing that person of the
contents thereof; provided, that a copy of the citation or complaint shall also be sent in a sealed envelope with postage fully prepaid, addressed to the
defendant at his or her usual place of abode. (2009 Code)
1-4-5: SERVICE OF SUMMONS:
A. In all actions initiated by the village for the enforcement of any provision of this code, or of any other ordinance of the village, where the fine or penalty
specified by the village for each separate offense or violation does not exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00), service of summons may be by certified
mail, return receipt requested, whether service is to be made inside or outside the state.
B. Subject to all applicable provisions of the Illinois code of civil procedure, the Illinois supreme court rules and the local rules of the circuit court, in all
actions initiated by the village for the enforcement of any provision of this code or of any other ordinance of the village, service of summons may also
be made personally by a police officer of the village. Where service of summons is made by a police officer, service of summons may be made either
by personally delivering the summons to the defendant, or by leaving a copy at the defendant's usual place of abode with some person of the
defendant's family of the age of thirteen (13) years or older, and informing that person of the contents thereof, provided the police officer making such
service on anyone other than the defendant shall also send a copy of the summons in a sealed envelope with postage fully prepaid, addressed to the
defendant at his usual place of abode.
C. Nothing in this section shall be deemed or interpreted as precluding or preventing service of summons as permitted by all applicable provisions of the
Illinois code of civil procedure, the Illinois supreme court rules and the local rules of the circuit court. (2009 Code)
1-4-6: LIABILITY OF OFFICERS:
No provision of this code designating the duties of any officer or employee shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any fine or
penalty provided for a failure to perform such duty, unless the intention of the board of trustees to impose such fine or penalty on such officer or employee
is specifically and clearly expressed in the section creating the duty. (1988 Code § 1-4-3)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 37/493
1-4-7: DEFENSE AND INDEMNIFICATION:
A. Proceedings Against Officials: The village shall defend, save harmless and indemnify its current and former trustees, commissioners, board members,
officers, employees, attorneys and any village representatives serving on other bodies who have been appointed by the Lake Bluff board of trustees
against any civil, criminal or administrative investigation, claim, action, suit or proceedings instituted or threatened to be instituted against them, based
upon any act, error or omission that could be reasonably construed to be within the exercise of their respective lawful duties or scope of employment
and against judgments, fines and other costs and liabilities, including amounts paid in settlement sustained as a result of, and reasonable expenses
(including attorney fees) incurred in connection with, the investigation, defense, adverse decision, compromise or settlement of any such investigation,
claim, action, suit or proceedings or threat thereof.
B. Actions On Behalf Of Village: This section shall not apply to providing defense or indemnification to any such trustee, commissioner, board member,
officer, employee or representative in any such investigation, claim, action, suit or proceedings instituted by or on behalf of the village against such
trustee, commissioner, board member, officer, employee or representative.
C. Rights Not Exclusive: The rights expressed in this section shall not be exclusive of any other rights which any current or former trustee, commissioner,
board member, officer, employee or representative may have as a matter of law. The foregoing rights shall, in the case of the death of a trustee,
commissioner, board member, officer, employee or representative, accrue to the benefit of his or her successors.
D. Village Liability: The liability of the village for payments under this section may be insured to the extent permitted by law, but to the extent not insured
shall be payable out of the funds and monies of the village.
E. Village Authority: Nothing in this section shall be deemed to limit or modify the authority of the village under state law to defend or indemnify parties or
persons as otherwise provided and permitted by law. (Ord. 94-17, 5-23-1994)
Chapter 5
VILLAGE PRESIDENT AND BOARD OF TRUSTEES
1-5-1: MEETINGS:
A. Regular Meetings: Regular meetings of the board of trustees shall be held on the second and fourth Monday of each month at seven o'clock (7:00)
P.M., at the village hall, unless otherwise ordered at a regular meeting. (Ord. 93-6, 5-24-1993)
B. Special Meetings: Special meetings may be held at any time on call of the village president. Such call may be in writing, signed by the village president,
and shall set forth the object of the meeting, the place of the meeting, and the time of the meeting, and shall be hand delivered or sent by United States
mail, postage prepaid, properly addressed to each trustee to his residence in the village, and shall be hand delivered or mailed at least two (2) days
prior to such meeting. Special meetings may be called in the manner aforesaid by any three (3) or more of the village trustees. Special meetings may
also be called by the village president, giving notice in person or by telephone to all village trustees, the village clerk and village administrator at least
one day in advance of a special meeting date. Special meetings may also be scheduled during any regular meeting date of the board of trustees. The
office of the village clerk shall be responsible for giving notices required under the open public meetings act of the state of Illinois1. Only that business
specified in the notice to the village trustees, village clerk, village administrator and news media may be taken up and discussed at a special meeting.
(1988 Code § 1-5-1)
1-5-2: QUORUM; ORDER OF BUSINESS:
At the hour selected for the meeting, the village clerk, or someone appointed by the village president to fill his place, shall proceed to call the roll of
members, mark the absentees and announce whether a quorum (a majority of all members elected) be present. Upon the appearance of a quorum, the
board of trustees shall be called to order, the presiding officer taking the chair, if present, and the board of trustees appointing a temporary chair, if he
should be absent. If a quorum does not appear within thirty (30) minutes of the time designated for commencement of the meeting, the board of trustees
shall thereby automatically stand adjourned, and all agenda matters for said meeting shall be set over to the next regular meeting of the board of trustees
unless a special meeting is held pursuant to the provisions of subsection 1-5-1B of this chapter. When a quorum is present, the board of trustees shall
proceed to the business before it in the order set forth on the meeting agenda unless otherwise determined by a majority vote of the board of trustees. An
opportunity for public comment and participation shall be provided on the agenda for each regular and special meeting of the board of trustees and its
committees and shall proceed pursuant to the rules concerning public comment and participation adopted by resolution of the board of trustees, which
rules shall apply equally to meetings of all village commissions and boards. (Ord. 2011-3, 4-11-2011)
1-5-3: RULES OF ORDER AND PROCEDURE:
Rule 1. All questions relating to the priority of business shall be decided by the chair, without debate, subject to appeal.
Rule 2. The presiding officer shall preserve order and decorum, and may speak to points of order in preference to other members, and shall decide all
questions of order, subject to an appeal to the board of trustees, on which appeal no member shall speak more than once without the unanimous consent
of the board of trustees.
Rule 3. While the presiding officer is putting the question or while business is being transacted, no member shall walk across or out of the board of
trustees room, except by consent of the board of trustees, unless to secure data or material required for some specific purpose to be considered by the
board of trustees, or for purposes of an emergency.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 38/493
Rule 4. Every member, previous to his speaking, making a motion, or seconding the same, shall address himself to the presiding officer, and say: "Mr.
president", or "madame president", and shall not proceed with his remarks until recognized and named by the chair.
Rule 5. When two (2) or more members shall address the chair at once, the presiding officer shall name the member who is to speak first.
Rule 6. During sessions of the board of trustees, only village officers and designated village officials and employees shall be permitted at the board of
trustees' table unless upon invitation of the president. Lobbying shall not be permitted in the board room of the trustees.
Rule 7. In case of disturbance or disorderly conduct, the presiding officer shall have power to require the chamber to be cleared, if necessary.
Rule 8. No member, without leave of the board of trustees, shall present more than one communication, petition, ordinance or other original matter, until
every member desirous of presenting any communication, petition, ordinance, or other original matter shall have presented the same.
Rule 9. No member, without leave of the board of trustees, shall speak more than once upon the same subject until every member desirous of speaking
shall have spoken, and no member shall speak longer than five (5) minutes at any one time except by consent of the board of trustees.
Rule 10. A member called to order by the chair shall immediately cease to speak, unless permitted to explain. If there be no appeal, the decision of the
chair shall be conclusive, but if the member appeals from the decision of the chair, the board of trustees shall decide on the case.
Rule 11. While a member is speaking, no member shall hold any private discourse nor pass between the speaker and the chair.
Rule 12. Every member who shall be present when a question is presented shall vote thereon unless directly interested in the question, in which case,
such member shall disclose such interest and shall not vote. In the event of a pass, failure or refusal to vote, the village clerk shall record the vote of such
a member to be the same as other members' vote on the prevailing side.
Rule 13. No member shall be allowed to leave the board of trustees while in session unless excused by the presiding officer.
Rule 14. Any matter before the board of trustees may be set down as a special order of business at a certain time, if two-thirds (2/3) of the members
present vote in the affirmative, but not otherwise. (1988 Code § 1-5-3)
Rule 15. No motion shall be put or debated unless it is seconded. When a motion is seconded, it shall be stated by the presiding officer before debate, and
every such motion shall be reduced to writing if required by a member. The maker of the motion shall be entitled to the floor. The right to vote in any
particular manner as otherwise allowed shall not be restricted in any way as a result of the board member having made or seconded the motion under
consideration. (Ord. 2002-01, 1-28-2002)
Rule 16. After a motion or resolution is stated by the presiding officer, it shall be deemed to be in possession of the board of trustees, but may be
withdrawn at any time before decision or amendment, by unanimous consent of the board of trustees. (1988 Code § 1-5-3)
Rule 17. If the question under consideration contains several distinct propositions, any member may have the same divided so as to clarify each part.
(1988 Code § 1-5-3; amd. 2009 Code)
Rule 18. In all cases where a resolution or motion is entered upon the minutes of the board of trustees, the name of the member moving the same shall be
entered also.
Rule 19. If any member requires it, the yeas and nays upon any question shall be taken and entered on the minutes, but the yeas and nays shall not be
taken unless called for previous to any vote on the question.
Rule 20. The result of all votes by yeas and nays shall be announced by the village clerk, and no individual vote shall be changed after the vote has been
announced.
Rule 21. When the question is under debate, the only motion in order shall be:
1. To adjourn to a day certain.
2. To adjourn.
3. To lay on the table.
4. To move or call for the previous question.
5. To refer.
6. To amend.
7. To substitute.
8. To postpone indefinitely or to a day certain.
Motions 2, 3 and 4 above shall be decided without debate.
Rule 22. A motion to adjourn the board of trustees shall always be in order, except:
1. When a member is in possession of the floor;
2. When the yeas and nays are being called;
3. When the members are voting;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 39/493
4. When adjournment was the last preceding motion; and
5. When it has been decided that the previous question shall be taken.
Rule 23. A motion simply to adjourn cannot be amended or debated, but a motion to adjourn to a time named may be amended and is open to debate.
Rule 24. When the previous question is moved and seconded, it shall be put in this form: "I move we vote now." If carried, all further amendments and
debates shall be excluded, and the questions and the chair shall at once state and put the question on the motion that is then immediately pending, upon
pending amendments in proper order, and then upon the main questions. (1988 Code § 1-5-3)
Rule 25. A motion simply to lay a question on the table is not debatable, but a motion to lay on the table and publish or any other condition, is subject to
amendment and debate. A motion to remove a subject matter from the table may be proposed at the same meeting, provided two-thirds (2/3) of the board
of trustees present vote therefor. (1988 Code § 1-5-3; amd. 2009 Code)
Rule 26. A motion to lay any particular proposition on the table shall apply to that proposition only.
Rule 27. When a motion is postponed indefinitely, it shall not be again taken up at the same meeting.
Rule 28. A motion to refer to a standing committee shall take precedence to a similar motion for an ad hoc committee.
Rule 29. A motion to amend an amendment shall be in order, but one to amend an amendment to an amendment shall not be entertained.
Rule 30. An amendment modifying the intention of a motion shall be in order, but an amendment relating to a different subject shall not be in order.
Rule 31. On an amendment to "strike out and insert", the paragraph to be amended shall first be read as it stands, then the words proposed to be stricken
out and those to be inserted, and finally, the paragraph as it will stand as so amended shall be read.
Rule 32. A substitute for any original proposition in debate may be entertained when further amendment is not admissible; and if accepted by the mover of
such original proposition, or by the board of trustees by vote, it shall entirely supersede such original proposition, and cut off all amendments appertaining
thereto. Any substitute proposition can be amended only by adding thereto.
Rule 33. A vote or question may be reconsidered at any time, during the same meeting, or at the first regular meeting held thereafter. A motion for
reconsideration being once made and decided in the negative, shall not be renewed, nor shall a vote to reconsider be reconsidered, unless there is
unanimous consent by the board of trustees to allow a motion to be made therefor preceding the vote on reconsideration.
Rule 34. A motion to reconsider must be made only by a member who voted with the prevailing side; provided, however, that when a motion is lost by
reason of not receiving a two-thirds (2/3) or more vote required for its passage, a motion to reconsider may be made by a member voting in the minority.
The president shall be included in the total of board of trustees members for this purpose. The seconder of such motion need not have voted with the
prevailing side on such question, or have voted at all.
Rule 35. The board of trustees shall, at all regular meetings, resume old business at the same order on which it was engaged immediately preceding the
last adjournment, unless agreed to by majority vote of the corporate authorities. (1988 Code § 1-5-3)
Rule 36. Reserved. (Ord. 2011-3, 4-11-2011)
Rule 37. Any other matters of rules of order and procedures not provided for herein or by the Illinois statutes will be governed by the latest edition of
"Robert's Rules Of Order". (1988 Code § 1-5-3)
1-5-4: COMMITTEES; REPORTS:
A. Standing Committees:
1. Established: The following shall be the standing committees of the board of trustees:
Economic development
Finance
Public safety
Public works
2. Appointment; Composition: The standing committees shall each consist of three (3) duly elected or appointed members of the board of trustees. The
village president shall have the authority to appoint, replace or remove the chairman and members of the standing committees. The village president
shall notify the board of trustees of any change in the composition of any of the standing committees at the first regular meeting of the board of
trustees after such change in composition has occurred.
3. General Purpose: The standing committees shall evaluate existing and proposed policies and practices of the village in their areas of responsibility,
and make any recommendations with respect thereto which they deem appropriate to the village president, board of trustees and village
administrator.
4. Specific Purpose: The purpose of each of the standing committees shall be as follows:
a. Economic Development: To assist and advise the village president, board of trustees and village administrator in developing, maintaining and
improving the economic vitality of commercial enterprises within the village and those that seek to relocate in the village and to solicit advice and
cooperation from such enterprises on such matters.
b. Finance: To assist and advise the village president, board of trustees and village administrator with regard to the village budget and tax levies, the
reports of independent auditors and the financial policies and practices of the village.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 40/493
c. Public Safety: To assist and advise the village president, board of trustees and village administrator in assessing and formulating policies with
respect to the village police and fire departments to maintain and protect the safety of persons within the village and to safeguard real and
personal property located in the village.
d. Public Works: To assist and advise the village president, board of trustees and village administrator in assessing and formulating the policies of the
village engineering and public works departments with regard to the orderly and efficient provision of municipal utility services, including water
distribution, sanitary and storm sewer collection, refuse and recycling collection and disposal and street and sidewalk repair and replacement.
5. Administration: The standing committees shall be staffed and administered by the village administrator or his or her designee.
6. Public Notice: All meetings of the standing committees shall be open to the public. The village administrator shall arrange for the proper public notice
of the time and place of meetings of the standing committees as requested by the chairperson or a majority of the members of the standing
committee. (Ord. 93-6, 5-24-1993)
B. Ad Hoc Committees: The president shall be empowered to appoint from time to time such select or additional committees deemed necessary and
proper.
C. Report; Discharge: On the acceptance of a final report from an ad hoc committee, the said committee shall be discharged without a vote unless
otherwise ordered.
D. Referrals To Committees:
1. When two (2) or more committees have jurisdiction, the board of trustees shall decide to which committee the subject matter shall go.
2. Standing and ad hoc committees to whom references are made shall, in all cases, report, at least once in each month, unless further time be granted
by a vote of the board of trustees, the statement of facts with their opinions thereon, signed by the members concurring therein. Separate or minority
reports of committee members may be rendered at the same time as majority reports or reports of committee chairmen.
E. Committee Reports: All reports of committees shall be addressed "To the president and board of trustees". They shall briefly describe the matter
referred and the conclusion to which the committee has arrived; which conclusion may be summed up in the form of an ordinance, order, resolution,
recommendation or some other distinct proposition. (1988 Code § 1-5-4; amd. Ord. 93-6, 5-24-1993)
1-5-5: ORDINANCES:
A. Action Upon First Proposal: No ordinance shall be acted upon at any meeting in which the same is first proposed or introduced unless this provision is
waived by a vote of at least two-thirds (2/3) of the members of the board of trustees, including the president. This provision shall not apply to
resolutions, orders and expenditures and in those instances where such an ordinance is required by law to be passed by a certain date which cannot
be complied with except by a special meeting date of the board of trustees. (Ord. 89-2, 1-23-1989)
B. Referral To Committee: All ordinances, petitions, resolutions, orders or communications shall, at the discretion of the president or the vote of four (4) or
more trustees, be referred to the appropriate committee, board or commission, as determined by the president, for their report and recommendation.
(1988 Code § 1-5-5)
1-5-6: BILLS, VOUCHERS; EXCEPTION:
All bills and vouchers shall be approved in writing. Each bill shall be accompanied by a voucher made out at the direction of the village treasurer, and
together they shall be referred, with his written approval, or otherwise, to the finance committee. Such committee shall then reexamine and rerefer all bills
thus referred to it, to the board of trustees, accompanied by the proper voucher, approved or otherwise, and the board of trustees may call upon any
village officer or officers for information concerning bills before it. The same shall then be ready for payment upon the requisite vote of the board of
trustees but not otherwise. This rule shall apply to all bills and expenses incurred by the village, except for the salaries and wages of the village officers
and employees specifically provided for and which shall be paid monthly upon such officers or employees signing the monthly payroll therefor. Any bill or
bills adversely reported by the board of trustees shall be, on request of any two (2) trustees, referred to a special committee for a further report thereon
before the same is allowed or disallowed. (1988 Code § 1-5-6)
1-5-7: BUDGET SYSTEM:
A. Adoption: The village hereby adopts the budget system of operation set forth in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-2-9.1 and 5/8-2-9.2 through 5/8-2-9.10,
as amended.
B. Effective Date: Said budget system shall take effect for the fiscal year commencing May 1, 1992, and thereafter, until said system of operation is
terminated pursuant to law.
C. Powers: The village and its designated officer shall have those powers enumerated in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-2-9.2 through 5/8-2-9.10,
inclusive. (Ord. 91-17, 12-9-1991)
Chapter 6
OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 41/493
ARTICLE A. VILLAGE CLERK
1-6A-1: ELECTION; TERM:
There shall be elected at the village election in the year 1989, and biennially thereafter, a village clerk who shall have resided within the corporate limits of
the village at least one year next preceding the election at which he is a candidate, and who shall hold the office of village clerk for a term of two (2) years
and until a successor is elected and qualified. (1988 Code § 1-6A-1)
1-6A-2: BOND AND OATH:
The village clerk shall execute, acknowledge and deliver to the village a bond in the penal sum of such amount determined by the board of trustees, but
not less than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), in the usual form, or as is, or shall hereafter be, provided by law, with good and sufficient surety to be
approved by the board of trustees, and the cost of the premium of said bond to be borne by the village, said bond conditioned upon the faithful
performance of his official duties, and the village clerk shall also take the customary oath of office before entering upon the duties of such office. (1988
Code § 1-6A-2)
1-6A-3: DUTIES:
Whenever used in this code, the term "village clerk" shall also refer to the office of the village clerk and to the deputy village clerk and such individuals who
perform duties in the office of the village clerk. Unless prohibited by statute, any duty of the village clerk may be performed by the deputy village clerk or an
employee in such office. It shall be the duty of the village clerk, in addition to all other duties prescribed by law and the ordinances of the village, to perform
the following duties:
A. Office: To maintain the office of the village clerk for the transaction of village business at the village hall, or at such place as the board of trustees may
otherwise designate.
B. Keep Corporate Seal: The village clerk shall keep the corporate seal in the office of the village clerk in the village hall and affix the same to all papers
which require it.
C. Records; Attendance At Board Meetings: The village clerk shall keep all records and papers belonging to the village, and shall attend all meetings of the
board of trustees, and shall keep a full record of its proceedings in the journal at the village hall.
D. Copy Records For Court Use: The village clerk shall make copies of all papers duly filed in the office of the village clerk and transcripts from the journals
and other records and files of his office, certified by the clerk under the corporate seal of the village, for use in evidence in courts when required.
E. Election Notices: It shall be the duty of the village clerk, within five (5) days after the result of any election is declared or appointment made, to notify all
persons elected or appointed to any village office, of their election or appointment. This notification shall be in addition to that which may be required of
the county clerk, and shall inform the individual of the time and place for the administration of the oath of office and the next scheduled meeting date for
the position to which the individual was appointed or elected.
F. Record Of Ordinances: All ordinances passed by the board of trustees shall be recorded by the village clerk in a book to be kept for that purpose, before
the next regular meeting after their passage. The village clerk shall be responsible for the publication in pamphlet form or otherwise, or posting of all
ordinances requiring the same. The village clerk shall note, at the end of the record copy of each ordinance, a memorandum of the date of such
publication or posting, the date of its passage, and the date of its approval, if approved, by the village president, and if published or posted. This record
and memorandum, or a certified copy thereof, shall be prima facie evidence of the passage and publication or posting of such ordinance for all
purposes whatsoever. The original shall be filed in the office of the village clerk with a certificate of publication attached thereto, or if posted, a
certificate under seal by the village clerk stating the same has been posted and giving the date thereof. "Publication", as used herein, shall include
publication in pamphlet form when so ordered by the board of trustees.
G. Tax Levy Ordinance: The village clerk shall, on or before the second Tuesday of September of each year, file with the county clerk a certified copy of
the tax levy ordinance showing the total amount of appropriations for all corporate purposes of the village, the levy and assessment therefor, any
resolutions for road and bridge purposes, and certification of compliance with truth in taxation statutes of the state of Illinois.
H. Communications To Board: All petitions, remonstrances, bids, bills or other communications addressed to the board of trustees shall be received by the
village clerk and read by the village clerk at the meeting of the board of trustees next succeeding their receipt, unless otherwise ordered by the board of
trustees.
I. Additional Duties: The village clerk shall perform such duties as the board of trustees may from time to time direct by resolution, order or ordinance.
(1988 Code § 1-6A-3)
1-6A-4: DEPUTY CLERK:
The village clerk may appoint, by and with the approval of the board of trustees, a deputy village clerk who shall be empowered, in the absence of the
village clerk, to perform the duties and be invested with the powers of the village clerk, and shall hold office for and during the term of office of the village
clerk. (1988 Code § 1-6A-4)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 42/493
1-6A-5: FEES:
Unless otherwise specifically provided, the village clerk is hereby authorized to demand and receive as fees the amounts as set out in section 1-12-3 of
this title. (1988 Code § 1-6A-5; amd. 2009 Code)
ARTICLE B. VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR
1-6B-1: CREATION; APPOINTMENT; TERM:
A. There is hereby created the office of village administrator, which officer shall be appointed by a two-thirds (2/3) majority vote of the board of trustees for
an indefinite term. The village administrator shall be chosen by the board of trustees who shall consider the appointee's executive and administrative
qualifications with special reference to actual experience in or knowledge of accepted practice in respect to the duties of office hereinafter set forth. At
the time of such appointment, the village administrator need not be a resident of the village, but shall move into and, during the tenure of the village
administrator, shall reside within the village. No trustee shall receive such appointment while serving in that capacity.
B. Except for the purpose of inquiry, the board of trustees and its members shall deal with the administrative personnel solely through the village
administrator. (1988 Code § 1-6B-1)
1-6B-2: BOND:
The village administrator shall furnish a surety bond in the penal sum of such amount determined by the board of trustees, but not less than ten thousand
dollars ($10,000.00), to be approved by the board of trustees, said bond to be conditioned upon the faithful performance of the duties of the village
administrator. The premium of the bond shall be paid by the village. (1988 Code § 1-6B-2)
1-6B-3: COMPENSATION:
The village administrator shall receive such compensation as shall be fixed from time to time by the board of trustees. (1988 Code § 1-6B-3)
1-6B-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The village administrator shall be the chief administrative officer of the village. The village administrator may head one or more departments and shall be
responsible to the board of trustees for the proper administration of all affairs of the village. To that end, the village administrator shall have power and
shall be required to:
A. Employees; Contract Employees: Appoint, establish contract terms if any for, and when necessary in the interests of the village, suspend or remove any
employee of the village; provided further, that the village administrator may authorize the head of a subordinate department or office to appoint,
suspend, or remove subordinates in such department or office.
B. Officers; Other Board Appointed Positions: Recommend to the board of trustees the appointment, annual compensation, contract terms if any,
suspension, or removal of the following: 1) all officers of the village, including, without limitation, the offices of the deputy village administrator, village
attorney, village treasurer, chief of police, fire chief, director of public works, health officer, plumbing inspector, building commissioner, building
inspector, coordinator of ESDA, director of finance, and any other officers that are by village ordinance or other applicable law to be appointed upon
recommendation of the village administrator by the board of trustees or its president and 2) the position of deputy chief of police, which is a contract
employee position. (Ord. 2014-4, 2-24-2014)
C. Prepare Budget: Prepare the budget annually and submit same to the board of trustees by April 15 of each year, together with a message describing
the important features and be responsible for its administration after adoption.
D. Financial Report: Prepare and submit to the board of trustees as of the end of the fiscal year, a complete report on the finances and administrative
activities of the village for the preceding year.
E. Advise Board Of Financial Condition: Keep the board of trustees advised of the financial condition and future needs of the village, and make such
recommendations as he may deem desirable.
F. Pay Schedules: Recommend to the board of trustees a standard schedule of pay for each appointive office and position in the village service, including
minimum, intermediate and maximum rates.
G. Recommend Measures For Improvement: Recommend to the board of trustees from time to time adoption of such measures as the village
administrator may deem necessary or expedient for the health, safety or welfare of the community or for the improvement of administrative services.
H. Consolidate Offices: Consolidate or combine offices, positions, departments or units under his jurisdiction, with the approval of the board of trustees.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 43/493
I. Attend Meetings: Attend all meetings of the board of trustees, unless excused therefrom, and take part in the discussion of all matters coming before the
board of trustees. The village administrator shall be entitled to notice of all regular and special meetings of the board of trustees. (1988 Code § 1-6B-4)
J. Purchase Of Materials: Supervise the purchase of all materials, supplies and equipment for which funds are provided in the budget; let contracts
necessary for operation or maintenance of village services and purchases of materials, supplies and equipment pursuant to the "Village Of Lake Bluff
Purchasing Policies And Procedures Manual", as amended from time to time, for amounts up to and including the limits set forth in the purchasing
policies and procedures manual; receive sealed bids for purchases in excess of the limits set forth in the purchasing policies and procedures manual,
and present them to the board of trustees for consideration; and advise the board of trustees on the advantages and/or disadvantages of contract and
bid proposals. No purchase shall be made, contract let, or obligation incurred for any item or service which exceeds the current budget without a
budget amendment approved by the board of trustees. No contract in excess of the limits set forth in the purchasing policies and procedures manual
shall be let except by the board of trustees. The village administrator may issue such rules governing purchasing procedures within the administrative
organization as the board of trustees shall approve. Notwithstanding anything contained herein to the contrary, the village administrator may direct the
payment of any and all lawful obligations of the village pursuant to the village cash management and investment policy, as amended from time to time.
Report of such payment shall be given to the board of trustees at the next meeting. (Ord. 2009-16, 4-27-2009, eff. 5-1-2009)
K. Enforcement Of Laws And Ordinances: See that all laws and ordinances are duly enforced.
L. Investigate Affairs Of Departments: Investigate the affairs of any department or division under his jurisdiction. Investigate all complaints in relation to
matters under the jurisdiction of the village administrator concerning the administration of the government of the village, and in regard to service
maintained by the public utilities in the village, and see that all franchises, permits and privileges granted by the village are faithfully observed.
M. Perform Other Duties: Perform such other duties as may be prescribed by the board of trustees, not inconsistent with the village ordinances. (1988
Code § 1-6B-4)
1-6B-5: AUTHORITY AS BUDGET OFFICER1:
The president and board of trustees hereby delegate authority to the village administrator (budget officer), to delete, add to, change or create subclasses
within object classes budgeted previously within all departments and/or funds. (Ord. 92-9, 4-27-1992)
1-6B-6: REMOVAL FROM POSITION:
The board of trustees may remove the village administrator at any time by a two-thirds (2/3) majority vote of its members but shall continue his/her salary
for one month following this action if said village administrator has served in that capacity for six (6) months or more, or one-half (1/2) month's salary if
service has been for less than six (6) months, or in the event such appointment is accompanied with an employment contract, any termination in office of
the village administrator shall be governed by the specific terms and conditions contained in any such employment contract. (1988 Code § 1-6B-5)
ARTICLE C. DEPUTY VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR
1-6C-1: CREATION; APPOINTMENT; TERM; QUALIFICATIONS:
A. Office Created: There is hereby created the office of deputy village administrator for the village.
B. Appointment; Term; Qualifications: The deputy village administrator shall, upon the recommendation of the village administrator, be appointed by a twothirds
(2/3) majority vote of the board of trustees for an indefinite term. Said deputy administrator shall be chosen by the village administrator and board
of trustees who shall consider the appointee's executive and administrative qualifications with special reference to actual experience in or knowledge of
accepted practice in respect to the duties of the office as hereinafter set forth. At the time of such appointment, the deputy village administrator need
not be a resident of the village, but shall, during the tenure in office of the deputy village administrator, move into and reside within the village. No
trustee shall receive such appointment while he is serving in that capacity. (1988 Code § 1-6C-1)
1-6C-2: BOND:
The deputy village administrator shall furnish a surety bond in the penal sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), to be approved by the board of trustees,
said bond to be conditioned on the faithful performance of the duties of the office of the deputy village administrator. The premium of the bond shall be paid
by the village. (1988 Code § 1-6C-2)
1-6C-3: COMPENSATION:
The deputy village administrator shall receive such compensation as shall be established from time to time by the village administrator with the approval of
the board of trustees. (1988 Code § 1-6C-3)
1-6C-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The deputy village administrator shall be the chief deputy administrative officer of the village. The deputy village administrator may head one or more
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 44/493
departments as directed by the village administrator and shall be responsible to the village administrator and the board of trustees for the proper
administration of all affairs of the village assigned to be performed by the deputy village administrator. To that end, the deputy village administrator shall
have power and shall be required to:
A. Recommendations:
1. Recommend to the village administrator the appointment, annual compensation, and when necessary for the good of the village, the suspension or
removal of any employee of the village; provided further, he may recommend to the village administrator to authorize the head of a subordinate
department or office to appoint, suspend or remove such department or office.
2. Recommend to the village administrator the appointment, annual compensation, contract terms if any, suspension, or removal of those officers and
other positions that the village administrator is responsible to recommend under subsection 1-6B-4B of this chapter. (Ord. 2014-4, 2-24-2014)
B. Assist Budget Preparation: Assist the village administrator in the annual preparation of the budget and assist in its submission to the board of trustees
by April 15 of each year, together with a message describing the important features, and be responsible to the village administrator for its
administration after adoption.
C. Assist Financial Report: Assist the village administrator in the preparation and submission to the board of trustees as of the end of the fiscal year, a
complete report on the finances and administrative activities of the village for the preceding year.
D. Assist Administrator; Make Recommendations: Assist the village administrator in keeping the board of trustees advised of the financial condition and
future needs of the village, and make such recommendations to the village administrator as he may deem desirable.
E. Recommend Pay Schedules: Prepare recommendations to the village administrator for a standard schedule of pay for each appointive office and
position in the village service, including minimum, intermediate and maximum rates.
F. Recommend Measures For Improvement: Recommend to the village administrator from time to time, adoption of such measures as the deputy village
administrator may deem necessary or expedient for the health, safety or welfare of the community or for the improvement of administrative services.
G. Assist In Development Of Policies: Assist the village administrator in the development of personnel policies, and office management plans and studies
for offices, positions, departments or units under his jurisdiction or that of the village administrator for review and action by the board of trustees.
H. Attend Meetings: Attend all meetings of the board of trustees as directed by the village administrator, unless excused therefrom, and take part in the
discussion of all matters coming before the board of trustees. The deputy village administrator shall be entitled to notice of all regular and special
meetings of the board of trustees.
I. Assist In Purchase Of Materials:
1. Assist the village administrator in the supervision and purchase of all materials, supplies and equipment for which funds are provided in the budget;
let contracts necessary for operation or maintenance of village services and purchases of materials, supplies and equipment for amounts up to and
including two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00); receive sealed bids for purchases in excess of two thousand five hundred dollars
($2,500.00) and present them to the village administrator for action, and advise the village administrator on the advantages or disadvantages of
contract and bid proposals. No purchase shall be made, contract let, or obligation incurred for any item or service which exceeds the current budget
appropriation without a supplemental appropriation by the board of trustees. No contract in excess of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00)
and no contract for new construction shall be let except by the board of trustees. The deputy village administrator shall be guided by such rules
governing purchasing procedures within the administrative organization as the board of trustees shall approve. (1988 Code § 1-6C-4)
2. In case of accident, disaster or other circumstances creating a public emergency, the deputy village administrator, with approval of the village
president, or two (2) trustees, may award contracts and make purchases for the purpose of meeting said emergency for amounts up to and including
five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), but the deputy village administrator shall promptly inform the village administrator of his action, and shall
simultaneously file promptly with the board of trustees, a certificate showing such emergency and the necessity for such action, together with an
itemized account of all expenditures. (1988 Code § 1-6C-5)
J. Enforcement Of Laws: See that all laws and ordinances are duly enforced.
K. Investigate Affairs Of Departments: Investigate the affairs of any department or division under his jurisdiction. Investigate all complaints in relation to
matters under the jurisdiction of the deputy village administrator or referred to him by the village administrator concerning the administration of the
government of the village, and in regard to service maintained by the public utilities in the village, and see that all franchises, permits and privileges
granted by the village are faithfully observed.
L. Official Duties: Devote his entire time to the discharge of his official duties.
M. Other Duties: Perform such other duties as may be prescribed by the board of trustees and village administrator, not inconsistent with the village
ordinances. (1988 Code § 1-6C-4)
1-6C-5: REMOVAL FROM POSITION:
The board of trustees, upon recommendation of the village administrator, may remove the deputy village administrator at any time by a two-thirds (2/3) vote
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 45/493
of its members, but shall continue his salary for one month following this action if he has served in that capacity for six (6) months or more, or one-half (1/2)
month's salary if he has served for less than six (6) months, or in the event such appointment is accompanied with an employment contract, any
termination in office of the deputy village administrator shall be governed by the specific terms and conditions contained in any such employment contract.
(1988 Code § 1-6C-6)
ARTICLE D. VILLAGE TREASURER
1-6D-1: APPOINTMENT; TERM; COMPENSATION:
A. Appointment; Term: There shall be appointed annually by the village president, upon the recommendation of the village administrator and by and with
the approval of the board of trustees, a village treasurer, who shall hold his office for one year and until his successor is appointed and qualified. The
village treasurer shall be a qualified elector of the village and shall have resided therein at least one year next preceding the date of his appointment.
B. Compensation: The village treasurer shall receive such compensation as shall be established by the village administrator and approved by the board of
trustees from time to time. (1988 Code § 1-6D-1)
1-6D-2: BOND AND OATH:
The village treasurer shall execute, acknowledge and deliver to the village a bond with good and sufficient sureties, to be approved by the board of
trustees, in such form, manner and sum as is or shall hereafter be provided by law or by resolution of the board of trustees. The village treasurer shall also
take the customary oath of office before entering upon the duties of such office. (1988 Code § 1-6D-2)
1-6D-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
It shall be the duty of the village treasurer, in addition to the duties prescribed by law, to perform the duties hereinafter mentioned in this article. In the
performance of such duties, the village treasurer may be assisted by such employees required therefor as approved by the village administrator. (1988
Code § 1-6D-3)
A. Village Funds:
1. Receive Monies: The village treasurer shall keep a true and accurate account of all monies paid into the treasury, by whom, and on what account
received; pay out such sums of money as may be ordered by the board of trustees, and only on warrants signed by the village treasurer, and
countersigned by the village administrator or deputy village administrator and either the village president or a trustee, and in all such cases, such
warrants must state upon what particular fund they are drawn. Any bond or interest coupon issued by the village, and due and payable, shall be
considered as a warrant duly authorized for payment by the village treasurer.
2. Deposit, Invest Funds:
a. The village treasurer shall deposit all monies belonging to the village, which shall come into his hands, with a regularly designated village
depository in the appropriate fund account within forty eight (48) business hours of the time that such monies come into his hands. Such
depository shall be designated by the board of trustees in such manner as may be required by law.
b. No person or institution shall be designated or used as a village depository excepting a properly organized bank doing business in the state of
Illinois, according to law.
c. The village treasurer is authorized to invest such funds in the working cash fund of the village in such investments as permitted by law, and to
transfer any and all interest income therefrom to the general corporate fund of the village to the credit of such fund as directed by the board of
trustees.
3. Payments From Particular Fund: No money shall be paid by the village treasurer upon any warrant, bond or coupon, except from the monies
belonging to the particular fund or appropriation upon which such warrant shall have been drawn; nor shall money be transferred by the village
treasurer from one fund to another after it has been received by him, nor appropriated to any other purpose than that for which it has been collected
or paid, without a vote of the majority of the board of trustees. (1988 Code § 1-6D-3-1)
B. Records, Accounts:
1. Books Of Accounts: The village treasurer shall keep such books of accounts as the board of trustees or village administrator shall from time to time
direct. The books which must be kept by the village treasurer shall at all times show the exact condition of the monies under his control, of each
account and appropriation and of all receipts and disbursements; and such books, together with all others belonging to the village and in his custody,
shall be by him handed over to his successor. The village treasurer shall, upon receipt of all monies, enter and appropriate the same to the credit of
the several accounts upon which such monies were paid, stating from whom they were received. The village treasurer shall keep a separate account
with each fund or appropriation, stating at the head of each account the amount so appropriated, and giving the several debits and credits belonging
thereto.
2. Special Assessments: The village treasurer shall also keep an account with each special assessment under its general description and number, and
said account shall show at its head the amount assessed for public benefits and also that for special benefits. All monies received on any special
assessment shall be held by the village treasurer as a special fund to be applied to the payment of the improvement for which the assessment was
made, and said monies shall be used for no other purpose whatever, except as may have been provided in the ordinance for the improvement.
3. Balancing; Inspections; Audits:
a. Balancing Accounts: The books of accounts provided in this article shall be properly balanced at least once in each month, in such a manner that
the same, when so balanced, shall show the true status and condition of each and every account therein shown.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 46/493
b. Inspections: The village treasurer shall keep all books, papers, vouchers, warrants, documents and all other instruments in writing, appertaining to
his office, at the village hall, which said books and documents shall at all times be open for inspection by or at the direction of the village president,
board of trustees, village clerk, village administrator or deputy village administrator.
c. Audits: The board of trustees shall appoint annually, prior to the termination of each fiscal year, and also upon the expiration of the term of office of
the village treasurer, whether caused by resignation, removal from office or otherwise, a certified public accountant or firm of certified public
accountants as an auditor to audit all books, papers, vouchers or other documents or instruments pertaining to the office of the village treasurer for
said fiscal year or for such period as may have elapsed since the previous audit has been made. Said auditor shall thereupon make a full and
complete report thereof to the board of trustees, and a copy of such report shall be made available for public inspection. Such audits shall include
all funds of the village, whether maintained by the village treasurer or not. The board of trustees may, for such cause deemed appropriate, cause
interim audits to be conducted as provided for herein. (1988 Code § 1-6D-3-2)
C. Reports:
1. Receipts And Disbursements: The village treasurer shall, at the end of each and every month, and more often if required, render an account to the
board of trustees and village administrator showing all receipts and disbursements in detail during the month, and the state or condition of every
account not closed on the village treasurer's books, the whole to be a balance sheet and a complete abstract of the financial affairs of the village.
The village treasurer shall annually, before the second Monday of May, make out and file with the village clerk a full and detailed account of all such
receipts and expenditures and of all transactions during the preceding fiscal year. Such annual report shall be presented to the board of trustees and
village administrator and shall be published or posted as may be required by law.
2. Cancel Warrants: The village treasurer shall cancel all warrants paid and redeemed by him, and upon rendering of any monthly report, shall cause
the same to be accompanied by all warrants, duplicate receipts in detail for all monies received, and such other vouchers as will fully and entirely
cover all transactions for the month of such report.
3. Finance Committee Approval: Upon examination and approval by the finance committee, the village clerk shall take charge of the village treasurer's
report, warrants and vouchers, and shall keep the same on file in the office of the village clerk. (1988 Code § 1-6D-3-3; amd. 2009 Code)
1-6D-4: DELIVER RECORDS TO SUCCESSOR; VIOLATION, PENALTY:
Whenever the treasurer's term of office shall expire, whether caused by resignation, removal from the village, removal from office by the village
administrator upon the approval of the board of trustees, the appointment of a successor or other cause, it shall be the duty of such village treasurer, or
person, to at once deliver to the successor in office of the village treasurer, or such other person as may be specially designated by the village
administrator upon approval by the board of trustees, all monies, property, books and effects of every description in the possession of the village treasurer,
belonging to the village or appertaining to his office, and the village treasurer shall, at once, account for and pay over to such successor or other person so
designated, all monies that he shall be accountable for, or owe to the village, in his capacity as village treasurer. Any person who served as village
treasurer, on the expiration of the village treasurer's term of office by any reason whatsoever, and who has violated any of the provisions of this section,
shall remain liable for all damages caused thereby, and shall further forfeit and pay to the village a penalty of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00)
nor more than the maximum penalty provided in section 1-4-1 of this title for each such violation, and each day such a violation continues shall be
considered a separate violation. (1988 Code § 1-6D-4; amd. 2009 Code)
ARTICLE E. VILLAGE ATTORNEY AND VILLAGE PROSECUTOR
1-6E-1: VILLAGE ATTORNEY:
A. Creation; Appointment; Term; Qualifications:
1. There is hereby created the office of village attorney.
2. The village attorney shall have the status of an independent contractor.
3. The village attorney shall be appointed by the village president, by and with the approval of a majority of the board of trustees.
4. The village attorney shall hold office until his successor shall be appointed and qualified.
5. The village attorney shall be a regular licensed and practicing member of the Illinois bar.
B. Compensation: The village attorney shall be compensated in the manner recommended by the village administrator and approved by the board of
trustees.
C. Duties: The duties of the village attorney shall include, without limitation, the following:
1. Provide advice to the village president and board of trustees, committees thereof, the village administrator and officers of the village on legal
questions.
2. Attend all regular meetings of the board of trustees.
3. Render legal opinions on questions submitted.
4. Draft ordinances and legal documents on behalf of the village; provided, however, that no such drafting shall commence without the authorization of
the village president, the village administrator, or three (3) or more of the members of the board of trustees.
5. Appear for and defend the village in all suits at law or in chancery to which it may be a party, and perform such other duties on behalf of the village
as pertains to the office.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 47/493
D. Removal: The board of trustees may remove the village attorney at any time by and with the approval of a two-thirds (2/3) majority vote of the members
of the board of trustees. (Ord. 93-2, 2-8-1993; amd. 2009 Code)
1-6E-2: VILLAGE PROSECUTOR:
A. Creation; Appointment; Term; Qualifications:
1. There is hereby created the office of village prosecutor.
2. The village prosecutor shall have the status of an independent contractor.
3. The village prosecutor shall be appointed by the village president, by and with the approval of a majority of the board of trustees.
4. The village prosecutor shall hold office until his successor shall be appointed and qualified.
5. The village prosecutor shall be a regular licensed and practicing member of the Illinois bar.
B. Compensation: The village prosecutor shall be compensated in the manner recommended by the village administrator and approved by the board of
trustees.
C. Duties: The duties of the village prosecutor shall include, without limitation, the following:
1. Prosecute suits or actions involving violations of this code and other ordinances of the village including, without limitation, violations of all traffic
codes and ordinances.
2. Advise officers of the police department on legal questions.
3. File with the village clerk a written monthly report showing the business transacted and the services rendered for the preceding month, and the
status of all pending litigation, unfinished business and all other material facts of public interest pertaining to the conduct of said office during the
preceding month.
D. Removal: The board of trustees may remove the village prosecutor at any time by and with the approval of a two-thirds (2/3) majority vote of the
members of the board of trustees. (Ord. 93-2, 2-8-1993)
ARTICLE F. CHIEF OF POLICE AND DEPUTY CHIEF OF POLICE1
1-6F-1: CREATION; APPOINTMENT; TERM; COMPENSATION:
A. Chief Of Police: There is hereby created and established the office of chief of police for the village. The chief of police shall be appointed by the village
president, upon the recommendation of the village administrator, by and with the approval of the board of trustees, and shall hold office for such period
of time as determined by the board of trustees. The chief of police shall be governed by and subject to the ordinances of the village relating to the
police department. The chief of police shall receive such compensation as shall be established from time to time by the village administrator and with
the approval of the board of trustees.
B. Deputy Chief Of Police: There is hereby created and established the contract employee position of deputy chief of police for the village. The deputy
chief of police and the contract terms of employment for the deputy chief of police shall be approved by the village president, upon the recommendation
of the village administrator, by and with the consent of the board of trustees, and the term of employment shall be determined by the board of trustees.
The duties of the deputy chief of police shall be determined by the village administrator and chief of police. (Ord. 2014-4, 2-24-2014)
ARTICLE G. FIRE CHIEF1
1-6G-1: CREATION; APPOINTMENT; TERM; COMPENSATION:
There is hereby created and established the position of fire chief for the village. The fire chief shall be appointed by the village president, upon the
recommendation of the village administrator, by and with the approval of the board of trustees, and shall hold office for such period of time as determined
by the board of trustees. The fire chief shall be governed by and subject to the ordinances of the village relating to the fire department. The fire chief shall
receive such compensation as shall be established from time to time by the village administrator, by and with the approval of the board of trustees. (1988
Code § 1-6G-1)
ARTICLE H. DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC WORKS
1-6H-1: CREATION; QUALIFICATIONS:
There is hereby created the position of director of public works. This position requires a high degree of training, knowledge and expertise in the field of
public works in order to plan, direct, administer and monitor all public works operations including water distribution; sanitary and storm sewer collection;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 48/493
streets, sidewalk and alley maintenance; parks and parkway maintenance; building maintenance; equipment maintenance; and other activities as
assigned. (Ord. 94-18, 6-27-1994)
1-6H-2: APPOINTMENT; TERM; COMPENSATION:
A. Appointment And Term: The director of public works shall be appointed by the village president, upon the recommendation of the village administrator
and by and with the approval of the board of trustees. The director of public works shall hold office until his successor is appointed and qualified.
B. Compensation: The director of public works shall receive such compensation as shall be established by the village administrator and approved by the
board of trustees. (Ord. 94-18, 6-27-1994)
1-6H-3: BOND AND OATH:
The director of public works shall execute, acknowledge and deliver to the village a bond with good and sufficient sureties, to be approved by the board of
trustees, in such form, manner and sum as is or shall hereafter be provided by law or by resolution of the board of trustees, and he shall take the
customary oath of office before entering upon the duties of such office. (Ord. 94-18, 6-27-1994)
1-6H-4: DUTIES:
A. Enumeration: The duties of the director of public works shall include, but not be limited to, the following:
1. Perform all duties prescribed by law or ordinance to be performed by the director of public works, formerly known as the superintendent of public
works.
2. Supervise the maintenance, cleaning and repair of the storm and sanitary sewer systems.
3. Supervise the provision of potable water and water for fire suppression to the village through monitoring, testing and implementing appropriate
regulations; maintaining and repairing water mains, hydrants, and valves; maintaining the elevated tank and pumping system; and advising residents
and commercial customers regarding connections to the village water distribution system.
4. Supervise the maintenance, cleaning and repair of village streets, sidewalks and alleys to provide safe and efficient access for residents, visitors and
emergency vehicles through snow and ice control measures; clearing of branches, trees and other results of storm damage; street sweeping; and
surface repairs.
5. Supervise the safe and efficient collection and disposal of household refuse, yard waste materials and recyclable materials.
6. Supervise the maintenance of all village buildings, grounds and other properties.
7. Advise the village president and board of trustees, the village administrator and other operating departments on appropriate matters under
consideration.
8. Report, not less than once a month, the activities of the public works department, information deemed necessary and appropriate, and information
requested by the village administrator.
9. Serve as custodian of all property provided for the use of the director of public works.
B. Additional Duties: Such duties shall include all others necessary and appropriate to those prescribed by state law, and as from time to time may be
determined and assigned by the village president, the board of trustees or the village administrator. (Ord. 94-18, 6-27-1994)
ARTICLE I. BUILDING OFFICERS
1-6I-1: BUILDING COMMISSIONER:
There is hereby created the office of building commissioner in and for the village, which officer shall be appointed by the village president, upon the
recommendation of the village administrator, by and with the consent of the board of trustees, and shall hold office for a term of one year and until his
successor shall be appointed and qualified. (1988 Code § 1-6I-1)
1-6I-2: DEPUTY BUILDING COMMISSIONER; BUILDING INSPECTOR:
The building commissioner may appoint, by and with the approval of the village administrator and board of trustees, a deputy building commissioner who
shall be employed in the absence of the building commissioner to perform all of the duties of the building commissioner, and a building inspector who shall
perform the duties hereinafter set forth. In addition thereto, the building commissioner may also appoint, by and with the approval of the village
administrator and board of trustees, a deputy building inspector who shall be empowered in the absence of the building inspector to perform all of the
duties of the building inspector. (1988 Code § 1-6I-2)
1-6I-3: COMPENSATION:
The building commissioner, deputy building commissioner, building inspector and deputy building inspector shall receive such compensation as may be
established from time to time by the village administrator with the approval of the board of trustees. (1988 Code § 1-6I-3)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 49/493
1-6I-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
A. Building Commissioner:
1. Building, Zoning Compliance; Supervise Inspector: It shall be the duty of the building commissioner to see to the enforcement of the provisions of all
village ordinances relating to building and zoning and to supervise the building inspector in the performance of the duties of said office.
2. Building Inspections: The building commissioner shall have the power to make, or cause to be made, entry at any reasonable hour into any building
or premises where the work of altering, repairing or constructing any building or structure is going on or into any other building or premises for the
purpose of making inspections.
3. Stop Work Orders: The building commissioner shall have the power to order all work stopped on buildings or structures in the course of construction,
alteration or repair, when such work is being done in violation of any provision of any ordinance relating thereto, or in violation of the zoning title.
Such work shall not be resumed after the issuance of such stop order except on written permission of the building commissioner or by order of the
village president or village administrator; provided, however, that if the stop order is oral, it shall be followed by a written stop order within one hour
thereafter. Such written stop order may be served by any police officer of the village.
4. Suspected Violators, Inspections By Commissioner: Upon the request of a tenant or owner of property which is located wholly or partly within three
hundred feet (300') of any premises in, about or upon which a violation of the village building or zoning ordinance may occur or continue, or upon the
