1-12-4: PAYMENT OF FEES, CHARGES AND RATES:
A. Payment Period: All fees, service charges, charges, rates or similar impositions (collectively referred to as "fees") required to be paid pursuant to this
Code shall be fully paid and satisfied within thirty (30) days after the Village request for payment is made by invoice or otherwise. In the event that a
shorter or longer payment period is expressly stated in this Code or otherwise established by the Village with respect to a specific fee, such shorter or
longer payment period shall govern for that specific fee.
B. Failure To Pay: The failure to pay any fee within the applicable time period for payment shall:
1. Constitute an offense by the party applying for the service, permit or matter for which the fee is imposed; and
2. Constitute an offense by the user of the service, permit or matter for which the fee is imposed; and
3. Constitute a lien on the real property, if any, to or upon which the service, permit or matter is applied or used; provided, however, that:
a. The Village Administrator shall file, or cause to be filed, a notice of such lien in the Office of the County Recorder of Deeds, or Registrar of Titles if
the property is registered under the torrens system, which notice shall consist of a sworn statement setting out:
(1) A legal or other description of the property sufficient for the identification thereof;
(2) The amount of the money due;
(3) The date when such amount became due;
(4) Notice that costs of collection, including attorney fees, will be added to the unpaid amount; and
b. No less than ten (10) days prior to the filing of the notice of lien, the Village Administrator shall mail, or cause to be mailed, by certified mail, return
receipt requested, a copy of the notice of lien to the current or last known owner of the property.
c. Any lien filed pursuant to this section may be foreclosed in the manner provided by statute for mortgages or mechanics' liens. (2009 Code)
Title 2
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
Chapter 1
BOARD OF HEALTH
2-1-1: CREATION; COMPOSITION; APPOINTMENT AND TERM; COMPENSATION:
There is hereby created and established a board of health in and for the village, which board shall consist of three (3) members appointed by the village
president, by and with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. One of such members shall be the health officer of the village who shall act as
president of the board of health. Each such member shall hold office for a term of one year, and until their successors shall be appointed and qualified. All
members of the board of health shall serve without compensation. (1988 Code § 2-1-1)
2-1-2: MEETINGS:
Meetings of the board of health may be called by the president of said board, who shall designate the time and place of such meetings. Meetings of said
board of health may also be called by the village president, who shall designate the time and place of such meetings, or by a written notice signed by the
other two (2) members of said board of health, which notice shall state the time and place of such meetings and the purpose for which they are called.
(1988 Code § 2-1-2)
2-1-3: HEALTH OFFICER:
The health officer shall be a physician licensed by the state, appointed by the village president, with the approval of the board of trustees, and shall hold
said office until the health officer's successor is duly appointed and qualified. (1988 Code § 2-1-3)
2-1-4: SECRETARY:
A. Appointment: The president shall designate one of the other two (2) members of the board to act as secretary for the board.
B. Duties: The secretary shall attend all meetings of the board of health, shall keep a record, in a book provided for that purpose, of all minutes and all
business transacted by the board of health, and shall perform such other duties as the board of trustees may direct. All official books, records and
minutes shall be maintained in the village hall, and copies of minutes of all meetings shall be turned over to the village clerk after their preparation and
approval. To assist in such duties, the board may employ the services of a stenographer at such compensation approved by the village administrator.
Such employment shall not relieve the secretary of the duties set forth herein. (1988 Code § 2-1-4)
2-1-5: POWERS AND DUTIES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 85/493
The board of health shall have the powers and perform the duties assigned to it by statute or ordinance and shall act in all cases within its jurisdiction
when other health agencies possessing similar power and authority are unable or unwilling to act. The board of health shall have power to make such
rules and regulations and to employ such measures as are necessary, including the posting of notices, to promote the health, cleanliness and sanitation of
the village, and to prevent, restrict and suppress communicable diseases. For the purpose of carrying out the provisions of this chapter, the members of
the board of health and its officers, or any of them, with proper authority, shall be permitted to enter, at any reasonable hour, any premises, store, house,
stable, manufactory or other buildings, and the board members, or any of them, shall have the right to arrest or cause to be arrested any persons who
violate any of the provisions of this chapter. (1988 Code § 2-1-5)
2-1-6: VIOLATION:
It shall be unlawful for any person to violate or refuse to obey any order of the board of health or to destroy, mutilate or conceal any notice posted by or
under the authority of said board. (1988 Code § 2-1-6)
Chapter 2
BOARD OF LOCAL IMPROVEMENTS
2-2-1: MEMBERSHIP; COMPENSATION:
The members of the village board of trustees shall act as members of the board of local improvements of the village, unless hereinafter provided by
ordinance. Said members, together with the village president, shall constitute the members of the board of local improvements of the village. The village
president shall act as president of the board of local improvements. All members of the board of local improvements shall serve without compensation.
(1988 Code § 2-2-1)
2-2-2: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The board of local improvements shall be responsible for the administration of the construction of local improvements as set forth in the Illinois statutes
and shall, when directed by the board of trustees, perform such duties and responsibilities as directed and as set forth in any local improvements
ordinance. (1988 Code § 2-2-2)
2-2-3: SECRETARY:
A. Designated: The village clerk shall act as secretary of the board of local improvements for the village.
B. Records Of Business: The secretary shall record, in a book to be kept for that purpose, before the next regular meeting after their passage, all
estimates and resolutions passed by the board of local improvements, and a record of all business transacted by the board of local improvements.
C. Communications: All petitions, remonstrances, bids, bills or other communications addressed to the board of local improvements shall be received by
the secretary and read by the secretary at the meeting of the board of local improvements next succeeding the receipt thereof by the secretary unless
otherwise ordered by said board.
D. Notification Of Meetings: It shall be the duty of the secretary to notify the village president and all members of the board of local improvements of all
special, called or adjourned meetings.
E. Custodian Of Records: The secretary shall be the custodian and keeper of all the books, records, estimates, resolutions and papers of the board of
local improvements, except as otherwise provided by law or ordinance. (1988 Code § 2-2-3; amd. 2009 Code)
Chapter 3
PLAN COMMISSION1
(Rep. by Ord. 2012-10, 4-9-2012, eff. 5-1-2012)
Chapter 4
ARCHITECTURAL BOARD OF REVIEW
2-4-1: ESTABLISHED; COMPOSITION; APPOINTMENT AND TERM; QUORUM; COMPENSATION:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 86/493
There is hereby established an architectural board of review for the village. The board shall consist of seven (7) members, to be appointed by the village
president, subject to the confirmation by the board of trustees. Each such member shall be appointed for a term of two (2) years of staggered terms. The
president shall designate the chair of the board from the membership thereof. A majority of the members appointed to the architectural board of review
shall be architects duly licensed by the state of Illinois. For purpose of a quorum, or acting upon any matter properly before the board, any four (4)
members shall constitute a quorum. The building commissioner shall be an ex officio member of the architectural board of review, and all members shall
serve without compensation. (Ord. 93-6, 5-24-1993)
2-4-2: MEETINGS:
Whenever any business is pending before the architectural board of review, they shall meet on the fourth Tuesday in each month, commencing at the hour
of seven forty five o'clock (7:45) P.M., in the board room, village hall. Special meetings of the architectural board of review shall be held on call of the chair
of the board, provided notice required by law is given of such a public meeting. (1988 Code § 2-4-2)
2-4-3: VACANCIES:
In the event of the death, resignation, retirement or inability of any architect to serve as a member of the architectural board of review, following
appointment, notwithstanding the requirement of a majority of architects on said board, during the period of time until a successor or successors are
appointed, the remaining members of the board may act on any matter with full authority, provided a quorum of those who are members of said board are
present. (1988 Code § 2-4-3)
2-4-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The architectural board of review shall also function as an architectural board of appeals. The architectural board of review shall have those powers as
provided by the ordinances of the village heretofore and hereinafter enacted, including powers granted to the architectural board of appeals. (1988 Code
§ 2-4-4)
2-4-5: SECRETARY; RECORDS:
A. The village administrator or his designee shall serve as secretary to the architectural board of review. The secretary shall keep minutes of all
proceedings, record the vote of each member upon every question and all findings of fact and keep all records of the architectural board of review. To
assist in such duties, the architectural board of review may employ the services of a stenographer at such compensation approved by the village
administrator.
B. All official books, records and minutes shall be maintained in the village hall, and copies of minutes of all meetings shall be turned over to the village
clerk after their preparation and approval. (1988 Code § 2-4-5)
Chapter 5
JOINT PLAN COMMISSION AND ZONING BOARD OF APPEALS ("PCZBA")
2-5-1: CREATION; APPOINTMENT; TERMS OF OFFICE; CHAIR; COMPENSATION:
A. Creation; Appointment: The joint plan commission and zoning board of appeals ("PCZBA") is hereby created. The PCZBA shall have seven (7)
members, except that, as of the May 1, 2012 effective date of this amendatory provision, the initial members of the PCZBA shall be the thirteen (13)
then current members of the plan commission and zoning board of appeals. Upon the resignation of an initial member of the PCZBA or the expiration
of that initial member's term, no further members will be appointed to the PCZBA unless such appointment is necessary for the PCZBA to have seven
(7) members.
B. Terms Of Office: Each initial PCZBA member shall serve for the remainder of that member's then current term with the plan commission or zoning board
of appeals. All subsequent terms of PCZBA members shall be for three (3) years.
C. Chair; Vice Chair: One PCZBA member shall be designated as chair and one PCZBA member shall be designated as vice chair by the village
president. The initial PCZBA chair shall be the then current chair of the zoning board of appeals.
D. No Compensation: All PCZBA members shall serve without compensation. (Ord. 2012-10, 4-9-2012, eff. 5-1-2012)
2-5-2: DUTIES:
A. The PCZBA shall have all the duties and responsibilities specified in this code, including, without limitation, to hear and decide any appeal from an
order, decision, or interpretation of the administrative officer charged with enforcement of, or any matter referred thereto or upon which it is required to
pass, under title 10 of this code.
B. Any reference in this code to the plan commission or the zoning board of appeals shall be construed as a reference to the PCZBA, and any duties and
responsibilities of the plan commission and the zoning board of appeals described in this code shall be considered duties of the PCZBA. (Ord. 2012-10,
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 87/493
4-9-2012, eff. 5-1-2012)
2-5-3: RULES OF PROCEDURE:
A. Chair: The chair shall preside at all public hearings and meetings of the PCZBA. In the chair's absence, the vice chair shall perform the functions of the
chair.
B. Secretary; Records:
1. The village administrator or his designee shall serve as the secretary to the PCZBA. The secretary shall keep minutes of all proceedings, record the
vote of each member, the absence or failure to vote of any member and records of hearings and other official actions. In the absence of the secretary
of the PCZBA, the village clerk or deputy village clerk shall have the duties of the secretary under this section.
2. All records of the PCZBA shall be kept in the office of the village clerk and shall be public records.
C. Minutes: Minutes of the PCZBA will be considered for approval by the PCZBA at the next available meeting after their preparation.
D. Meetings:
1. Time And Place: PCZBA meetings shall be held on the third Wednesday in each month commencing at the hour of seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. in the
board room, village hall, and at such other times and places as may be called by the chair, and at such other times as the PCZBA shall determine,
upon proper notice pursuant to the open meetings act, 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 120/1 et seq.
2. Quorum: A quorum of the PCZBA shall consist of four (4) members.
E. Appeals; Time For Filing: Appeals from orders or decisions based on the zoning regulations may be taken to the PCZBA by any person aggrieved or by
any officer or department of the village. Such appeal shall be filed in duplicate with the secretary of the PCZBA within forty five (45) days from the order
or decision, and one copy thereof shall be filed with the officer or department whose decision or order is being appealed. The notice of appeal shall
specify the particular grounds for the appeal. Upon receipt of the appeal, the officer or department from whom the appeal is taken shall transmit to the
PCZBA the record concerning the decision which is being appealed.
F. Fees: A filing fee as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code, shall be delivered to the village at the time of the filing of the application.
G. Stay Of Proceedings: An appeal to the PCZBA stays all proceedings concerning the action appealed from, unless the village determines that such stay
would cause imminent harm to the public health, safety, or welfare, in which case the proceedings shall not be stayed unless the circuit court enjoins
the proceedings.
H. Hearing On Appeals: Appeals shall be set for hearing within a reasonable time from the date of filing of a notice of appeal, upon due notice being given
to the parties, as well as any and all required notice by publication and to property owners within two hundred fifty feet (250') in all directions, excluding
public ways, streets, roads, alleys and the like, of the premises at issue. Such hearing may be continued from time to time by direction of the PCZBA.
Upon the hearing, any party may appear in person or by agent or by attorney. Within a reasonable time following the completion of hearings, the
PCZBA shall complete its consideration of the appeal by reversing, affirming, or modifying, in whole or in part, the order, requirement, decision or
determination appealed from, and to that end has all the powers of the officer from whom the appeal is taken.
I. Procedure At Hearings: The PCZBA may adopt rules of procedure to govern its hearings.
J. Final Decisions Subject To Review: All final administrative decisions of the PCZBA shall be subject to review under the Illinois administrative review act,
735 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-101 et seq. (Ord. 2012-10, 4-9-2012, eff. 5-1-2012)
Chapter 6
FIRE INSURANCE BOARD
2-6-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to establish procedures and standards for the management and administration of foreign fire insurance taxes collected by
the village pursuant to title 1, chapter 8, article F of this code and 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-10-1 and 5/11-10-2. (Ord. 93-13, 7-26-1993)
2-6-2: CREATION; COMPOSITION; TERM OF OFFICE; VACANCIES; COMPENSATION:
A. Creation; Composition; Officers: There is hereby created for the village a fire insurance board consisting of three (3) members. The fire chief shall serve
as a member of the board and shall be the president of the board. The other two (2) members of the board shall be elected by the members of the fire
department from among themselves to serve as treasurer and secretary of the board.
B. Term Of Office; Vacancies: The members so elected from the department shall serve for a term of one year. No member shall hold any office after
termination or resignation from the fire department. Any vacancy that may occur as a result of a member leaving office or expiration of a term of office
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 88/493
that has not been filled by election shall be filled for the balance of the unexpired term by appointment of the fire chief.
C. Compensation: All members of the board shall serve without compensation. (Ord. 93-13, 7-26-1993)
2-6-3: DISPOSITION OF PROCEEDS:
The village treasurer shall receive the monies paid to the village in accordance with title 1, chapter 8, article F of this code and shall pay to the treasurer of
the fire insurance board all such monies into an account designated as the "foreign fire insurance account". (Ord. 93-13, 7-26-1993)
2-6-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
A. Generally: The fire insurance board shall have the power to administer and to enter into contracts and agreements for the expenditure of monies from
the foreign fire insurance account for the maintenance, use, and benefit of the fire department. All actions of the fire insurance board shall be in
accordance with the standards for the foreign fire insurance account established by this section and all other requirements provided by law.
B. Foreign Fire Insurance Account: The foreign fire insurance account shall be administered in accordance with the following standards:
1. Use Of Funds: Expenditures may be made for furthering the training, safety, health, welfare, morale and recruitment of members as well as for the
purchase of firefighting equipment. Any firefighting equipment purchased with monies from the account shall thereupon become the property of the
village. Monies from the account shall not be used for the personal benefit of any person; or for any person's use or function not directly related to
maintenance, use and benefit of the fire department. The fire insurance board, upon a majority vote, shall refuse any request for expenditure of funds
from the account made by a majority of the members of the fire department if it does not meet the requirements of this code or other requirements
provided by law. The fire insurance board shall not enter into any contract or agreement obligating expenditures from the foreign fire insurance
account in excess of the amount of monies currently on deposit in and currently available for use from the account.
2. Designation Of Uses:
a. Meeting Required; Notice: The fire insurance board shall authorize the expenditure of money from the foreign fire insurance account only at a
meeting conducted at the fire department building and open to all members of the fire department. Notice of each such meeting shall be given at
least forty eight (48) hours in advance of such meeting by posting notice thereof in a prominent location at the fire department building.
b. Necessary Vote: An affirmative vote of a majority of the fire department members present at any duly noticed meeting shall be required to
authorize any expenditure of money from the foreign fire insurance account by the fire insurance board.
3. Payouts: All checks or other withdrawals from the account shall be signed by the fire insurance board treasurer and fire chief.
4. Investment Of Funds: Foreign fire insurance tax monies shall be deposited only in one or more of the following: checking account, interest bearing
savings account, or interest bearing time deposit of any bank insured by the banking insurance fund of the FDIC. Total deposits in any one bank may
not exceed the FDIC insured limits.
5. Records:
a. The fire insurance board treasurer shall keep accurate and current records of the foreign fire insurance account, including all deposits thereto,
withdrawals or disbursements therefrom, balances and the like.
b. The fire insurance board secretary shall keep accurate and current minutes of the meetings conducted by and decisions made by the officers of
the fire insurance board related to the foreign fire insurance account. (Ord. 93-13, 7-26-1993)
6. Reports And Audits: The fire insurance board treasurer shall report on the expenditures and balance of the funds to the members of the board and
the fire department at the monthly meeting or at any special meeting called by the fire insurance board. The treasurer shall remit a detailed list of the
withdrawals, deposits, balance and a copy of the bank statement to the director of finance within forty five (45) days after the end of each month. The
foreign fire insurance account shall be subject to review during the annual independent audit of village funds to be conducted after the end of each
fiscal year and during any special audits of village funds that may be conducted from time to time. (Ord. 93-13, 7-26-1993; amd. 2009 Code)
Chapter 7
EMERGENCY DISASTER SERVICE AGENCY
2-7-1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby created and established a department of the municipal government of the village to be known as the Lake Bluff emergency disaster
service agency (LBEDSA). (1988 Code § 8-3A-1)
2-7-2: PURPOSE:
The purpose of LBEDSA shall be to prevent, minimize, repair, and alleviate injury or damage resulting from hostile action, or from natural or manmade
disasters, in accordance with the Illinois emergency management agency act of 1992, as amended1. (1988 Code § 8-3A-2)
2-7-3: ORGANIZATION:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 89/493
The LBEDSA of the village shall consist of a coordinator, and such additional members as may be authorized by the village, and thereafter selected by the
coordinator. (1988 Code § 8-3A-3)
2-7-4: COORDINATOR:
A. Appointment: The coordinator of the LBEDSA shall be appointed by the village president and confirmed by the other members of the board of trustees,
and shall serve during the pleasure of the entire board of trustees. (1988 Code § 8-3A-4)
B. Duties:
1. The coordinator shall have direct responsibility for the organization, administration, training and operation of the LBEDSA, subject to the direction
and control of the village president, as provided by the village ordinances in such cases made and provided.
2. In the event of the absence, resignation, death or inability of the coordinator to serve, the village president, or any person designated by said
president shall be and act as director until a new appointment is made as provided in this chapter. (1988 Code § 8-3A-5)
C. Additional Duties: The LBEDSA shall perform such emergency management functions within the village as shall be prescribed in and by the state IEMA
plan and program prepared by the governor, and such orders, rules and regulations as may be promulgated by the governor, and in addition, shall
perform such duties outside the corporate limits as may be required pursuant to any mutual aid agreement with any other political subdivision,
municipality, or, quasi-municipality entered into as provided in the Illinois emergency management agency act of 1992, as amended. (1988 Code § 8-
3A-6)
2-7-5: MOBILE SUPPORT TEAMS:
A. Designation: All or any members of the LBEDSA organization may be designated as members of a mobile support team created by the director of the
state Illinois emergency management agency (IEMA) as provided by law.
B. Leader: The leader of such mobile support team shall be designated by the coordinator of the LBEDSA organization.
C. Compensation: Any member of a mobile support team who is a village employee or officer while serving on call to duty by the governor or the state
director shall receive the compensation and have the powers, duties, rights and immunities incident to such employment or office. Any such member
who is not a paid officer or employee of the village, while so serving, shall receive from the state, reasonable compensation as provided by law. (1988
Code § 8-3A-7)
2-7-6: MUTUAL AID:
The coordinator of LBEDSA may negotiate mutual aid agreements with other cities or political subdivisions of the state, but no such agreement shall be
effective until it has been approved by the president and board of trustees of the village and by the state director of IEMA. (1988 Code § 8-3A-8)
2-7-7: EMERGENCY ACTION:
If the governor of Illinois proclaims that a disaster emergency exists in the event of actual enemy attack upon the United States or the occurrence within
the state of Illinois of a major disaster resulting from enemy sabotage or other hostile action, or from manmade or natural disaster, it shall be the duty of
the LBEDSA to cooperate fully with the state IEMA and with the governor in the exercise of emergency powers as provided by law. (1988 Code § 8-3A-9)
2-7-8: COMPENSATION:
Members of the LBEDSA who are paid employees or officers of the village, if called for training by the state director of IEMA, shall receive for the time
spent in such training, the same rate of pay as is attached to the position held; members who are not such village employees or officers shall receive for
such training time, such compensation as may be established from time to time by the president and board of trustees of the village. (1988 Code § 8-3A-
10)
2-7-9: REIMBURSEMENT OF EXPENSES:
The village treasurer may receive and allocate to the appropriate fund, any reimbursement by the state to the village for expenses incident to training
members of the LBEDSA as prescribed by the state director of IEMA, compensation for services and expenses of members of a mobile support team
while serving outside the village in response to a call by the governor or state director of IEMA, as provided by law, and any other reimbursement made by
the state incident to LBEDSA activities as provided by law. (1988 Code § 8-3A-11)
2-7-10: PURCHASES AND EXPENDITURES:
A. Contracts: The village president may, on recommendation of the village coordinator of LBEDSA, authorize any purchases or contracts necessary to
place the village in a position to combat effectively any disaster resulting from the explosion of any nuclear or other bomb or missile, and to protect the
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 90/493
public health and safety, protect property and provide emergency assistance to victims in the case of such disaster, or from manmade or natural
disaster.
B. Materials: In the event of enemy caused or other disaster, the coordinator of LBEDSA is authorized, on behalf of the village, to procure such services,
supplies, equipment, or material as may be necessary for such purposes, in view of the exigency without regard to the statutory procedures or
formalities normally prescribed by law pertaining to village contracts or obligations, as authorized by the Illinois emergency management agency act of
1992, as amended; provided, that if the village board meets at such time, the coordinator shall act subject to the directions and restrictions imposed by
that body. (1988 Code § 8-3A-12)
2-7-11: OATH OF OFFICE:
Every person appointed to serve in any capacity in the LBEDSA organization shall, before entering upon his or her duties, subscribe to the following oath,
which shall be filed with the coordinator:
I, , do solemnly swear (or affirm), that I will support and defend and bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of the United States and the
Constitution of the State of Illinois, and the territory, institutions, and facilities thereof, both public and private, against all enemies, foreign and domestic;
that I take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties upon which I
am about to enter. And I do further swear (or affirm) that I do not advocate nor am I nor have I been a member of any political party or organization that
advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this State by force or violence; and that during such time as I am affiliated with the
Lake Bluff Emergency Disaster Service Agency organization, I will not advocate nor become a member of any political party or organization that advocates
the overthrow of the government of the United States or of the State of Illinois by force or violence.
(1988 Code § 8-3A-13)
2-7-12: OFFICE FACILITIES:
The village president is authorized to designate space in a village building or elsewhere, as may be provided by the village president, for the LBEDSA as
its office. (1988 Code § 8-3A-14)
2-7-13: APPROPRIATIONS AND TAX LEVIES:
The president and board of trustees may make an appropriation for LBEDSA purposes in the manner provided by law and may levy, in addition, for
LBEDSA purposes only, a tax as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code, under the category "taxes", which said tax shall be in addition to all other taxes, as
provided by the Illinois emergency management agency act of 1992, as amended. (1988 Code § 8-3A-15; amd. 2009 Code)
Chapter 8
ATTENDANCE OF COMMISSION MEMBERS
2-8-1: AUTOMATIC RESIGNATION FOR REPEATED ABSENCES:
Any member of a commission who, for no valid reason, is absent from, or fails to attend, either: a) three (3) consecutive meetings of the applicable
commission, or b) at least sixty five percent (65%) of the total of all meetings of the applicable commission commenced during any one year period, shall,
effective as of the date set forth in section 2-8-4 of this chapter, be deemed to have resigned from the commission and that member's office shall,
automatically and without further action, be deemed to be vacant as of such date. (Ord. 2012-18, 8-13-2012)
2-8-2: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter:
COMMISSION: Any board, commission, committee or other group whose members are appointed by the village president or the village board.
ONE YEAR PERIOD: January through the following December 31.
VALID REASON: Only as determined by the village board in accordance with section 2-8-5 of this chapter. (Ord. 2012-18, 8-13-2012)
2-8-3: WRITTEN WARNING NOTICE:
The village administrator, or his designee, shall, prior to the next regularly scheduled meeting of the applicable commission, deliver a written warning
notice to any member who, by failing to attend any future regular or special meeting of the commission during the remainder of the applicable year, is at
risk of automatic removal pursuant to section 2-8-1 of this chapter. The failure of a member to receive such written notice shall not constitute a valid reason
for absence from a meeting. (Ord. 2012-18, 8-13-2012)
2-8-4: EFFECTIVE DATE OF RESIGNATION AND VACANCY:
The member's resignation, and the vacancy of the member's office, shall be effective on the date that is ten (10) days after the date of the final absence
that triggers the removal action set forth in section 2-8-1 of this chapter, unless a timely request for a determination of "valid reason" has been filed
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 91/493
pursuant to section 2-8-5 of this chapter, in which case the resignation and vacancy shall be effective upon final resolution of such request. (Ord. 2012-18,
8-13-2012)
2-8-5: DETERMINATION OF "VALID REASON":
Except for excused absences as described in subsection C of this section, the determination of a "valid reason" for a member to be absent from, or fail to
attend, an applicable commission meeting shall be made only by the village board, by a majority vote of those present and voting at a regular or special
meeting of the village board. The decision of the village board shall be final and binding.
A. Preabsence Determination: A member shall have the right to request that the village board determine, in advance of an anticipated absence, whether a
valid reason exists for such absence. Such request shall be made in writing and delivered to the village administrator at least seven (7) days prior to
the village board meeting.
B. Postabsence Determination: A member shall have the right, within ten (10) days after the occurrence of any absence, to request that the village board
determine whether a valid reason existed for that particular absence. Such request shall be made in writing and delivered to the village administrator at
least seven (7) days prior to the village board meeting.
C. Excused Absences: The village board will presume that a valid reason for an absence exists when the member's request demonstrates that the
absence is an excused absence due to: 1) personal illness or disability, 2) employment purposes or the business of the public body, or 3) a family or
other emergency, unless the village board determines within two (2) board meetings after receipt of the request that the member did not demonstrate
an excused absence pursuant to this subsection. (Ord. 2012-18, 8-13-2012)
Title 3
BUSINESS AND LICENSE REGULATIONS
Chapter 1
GENERAL LICENSE PROVISIONS
3-1-1: APPLICATIONS FOR LICENSES; QUALIFICATIONS OF LICENSEES:
All applications for licenses shall be made to the office of the village clerk, upon the terms specified in this chapter, and all licenses shall be issued to such
persons as shall comply in all respects with the provisions hereof, and who shall be deemed suitable and proper persons to be licensed. (1988 Code § 3-
1-1)
3-1-2: ISSUANCE OF LICENSES:
A. Village Clerk To Issue; Contents: Unless otherwise provided in this code, each and every license authorized and required by the village shall be issued
by the village clerk upon payment of the amount of the license fee or tax, and upon compliance with this chapter, and each license shall express for
what it is granted and the time it is to continue, if the license is limited as to time. (1988 Code § 3-1-2; amd. 2009 Code)
B. Expiration; Signatures Required: All licenses shall expire on or before April 30 next following, unless otherwise provided. Each license shall be signed
by the village president and countersigned by the village clerk under the corporate seal. (1988 Code § 3-1-2)
3-1-3: PRORATED FEE; NEW LICENSE APPLICATIONS:
Unless otherwise provided, any license which is issued after six (6) months have elapsed for the license period and the license was not due and payable
prior thereto, the fee therefor shall be one-half (1/2) of the yearly license fee; and provided further, that no person shall be entitled to the benefit of this
section who shall be engaged in the business for which he applies for a license at the time of his application. (1988 Code § 3-1-3)
3-1-4: LICENSE TRANSFERS:
A. Village Permission Required: No license granted under any village ordinance shall be assignable or transferable without permission of the board of
trustees, nor shall any such license authorize any person to do business or act thereunder, but the person named therein, unless otherwise provided by
ordinance. (1988 Code § 3-1-4)
B. Fee: Unless otherwise provided, the fee for transferring a license for any purpose shall be as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code, under the category
"license fees", to be paid to the village treasurer for the use of the village. (1988 Code § 3-1-4; amd. 2009 Code)
C. Duty Of New Licensee; Bond: Any person to whom any license may have been issued under any ordinance of the village who, with the permission of
the board of trustees, assigns or transfers the same to any other person than the person to whom such license was issued, or the assignee of such
license, shall surrender such license, and such assignee shall apply for a new license for the unexpired term of the old license authorizing the assignee
to carry on the same business or occupation at such place as may be named in such new license; provided, that in all cases, the party applying for
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 92/493
such new license shall give a bond with sureties, which shall conform as near as may be to the bond upon which such surrendered license was issued.
(1988 Code § 3-1-4)
3-1-5: VIOLATIONS; PENALTY; REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
All licenses shall be subject to the ordinances and regulations which may be in force at the time of issuing thereof, or which may subsequently be made by
the board of trustees, and if any person so licensed shall violate any of the provisions thereof, he shall be liable to be proceeded against for any fine or
penalty imposed thereby, and the license may be revoked at the discretion of the village president. (1988 Code § 3-1-5)
Chapter 2
LIQUOR CONTROL
3-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context otherwise requires, the following terms, as used in this chapter, shall be construed according to the definitions given below:
ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR: Includes alcohol, spirits, wine, beer and every liquid or solid, patented or not, containing alcohol, spirits, wine or beer and capable
of being consumed as a beverage by a human being. The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to any liquid or solid containing one-half of one percent
(0.5%) of alcohol by volume or less, or to liquids or solids containing in excess of one-half of one percent (0.5%) of alcohol by volume if dispensed by a
licensed pharmacy pursuant to a medical prescription.
BAR SERVICE AREA: Any public place, ancillary and accessory to, and within the same building as, a restaurant, that is kept, used, maintained,
advertised and held out to the public to be a place within which alcoholic liquor is intended to be consumed. For purposes of this chapter, "bar service
area" shall include all areas intended to be devoted to the storage, preparation, sale, service and consumption of alcoholic liquor.
BEER: A beverage obtained by the alcoholic fermentation of an infusion or concoction of barley or other grain, malt or hops in water and includes, among
other things, beer, ale, stout, lager beer, porter and the like.
BREWPUB: Premises that are subject to and maintain a valid brewpub license from the state of Illinois pursuant to section 5/5-1(n) of the Illinois liquor
control act, 235 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/5-1(n), as may be amended from time to time, and that contain facilities used for the manufacture of beer for
the purposes of: a) making sales to importing distributors, distributors, and to nonlicensees for use and consumption only; b) storing beer manufactured at
the premises, and c) conducting retail sales at the premises of beer manufactured at the premises or another designated location.
CATERING ESTABLISHMENT: A business conducted by a person, firm, or corporation for the purpose of providing food and service for a banquet or
dinner which may occur in a location other than premises leased, owned, and/or operated by the catering establishment; the recipients of such food and/or
service being persons specially invited to such banquet or dinner rather than members of the general public.
GROCERY STORE: Every building or other structure kept, used, maintained, advertised, and held out to the public to be a retail store that primarily
conducts the retail sale of food and food items and the incidental retail sale of other nonfood items.
IDENTIFICATION CARD: A written, printed or photostatic document issued by a public officer of a federal, state, county or municipal government, or
subdivision or agency thereof, in the performance of his or her official duties and evidencing the age and identity of a person, including, without limitation, a
motor vehicle operator's license, a registration certificate issued under the federal selective service act, or an identification card issued to a member of the
armed forces.
KNOWINGLY: Having general knowledge of, or reason to know, or a belief or ground for belief which warrants further inquiry or inspection.
LEGAL AGE: The minimum age designated by law of a person to whom it is lawful to sell, give or deliver a particular type of alcoholic liquor.
LEGAL GUARDIAN: A person appointed guardian, or given custody, of a minor by a circuit court of this state, but does not include a person appointed
guardian or given custody of a minor under the juvenile court act of 1987, 705 Illinois Compiled Statutes 405/1-1 et seq.
LICENSEE: Any person, firm or corporation or partnership or club holding a license under the provisions of this chapter.
MINOR: A person under the age of twenty one (21) years.
ORIGINAL PACKAGE: Any bottle, flask, jug, can, cask, barrel, keg, hogshead or other receptacle or container, whatsoever used, corked or capped, sealed
and labeled by the manufacturer of alcoholic liquor, to contain and to convey any alcoholic liquor.
OUTDOOR SERVICE AREA: Any outdoor location that is adjacent and accessory to a grocery store, restaurant or brewpub that is kept, used, maintained,
advertised and held out to the public as a place within which alcoholic liquor may be sold and consumed.
PARENT: A natural or adoptive parent or a court designated guardian.
PRIVATE CLUB: A corporation organized under the laws of this state, operated for recreational and social purposes on a private membership basis, which
may include the service of food and alcoholic liquor.
RESTAURANT: Any public place kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the public to be a place where meals are served, and where meals are
actually and regularly served, without sleeping accommodations, such space being provided with adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining room
equipment and capacity and having employed therein a sufficient number and kind of employees to prepare, cook and serve suitable food for its guests.
For purposes of this chapter, "restaurant" shall include all screened in or otherwise enclosed areas and rooms of such public place.
RETAIL SALE: The sale for use or consumption and not for resale.
SALE: Any transfer, exchange or barter in any manner or by any means whatsoever and includes all sales made by any person, whether principal,
proprietor, agent, servant or employee.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 93/493
TO SELL: Includes to keep or expose for sale and to keep with intent to sell.
UNEMANCIPATED MINOR: A minor still under the care and custody of at least one of his or her parents or a legal guardian.
VEHICLE OR PREMISES: Any privately owned and operated motor vehicle, conveyance or vessel; any house or apartment; any hotel, motel or bed and
breakfast room, or any similar premises to which the general public is not normally admitted.
WINE: Any alcoholic beverage obtained by the fermentation of the natural contents of fruits or vegetables containing sugar, including such beverages
when fortified by the addition of "alcoholic liquor" as defined in this section. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992; amd. Ord. 95-42, 12-11-1995; Ord. 96-9, 4-8-1996; Ord.
2005-4, 2-28-2005; Ord. 2009-12, 4-13-2009; Ord. 2010-19, 8-23-2010; Ord. 2011-6, 4-11-2011; Ord. 2014-23, 10-27-2014)
3-2-2: LOCAL LIQUOR CONTROL COMMISSIONER:
A. Village President Serve As: The village president is hereby authorized to be the local liquor control commissioner and shall be charged with the
administration of the liquor control act, 235 Illinois Compiled Statutes, and of such ordinances and resolutions relating to alcoholic liquor as may be
passed from time to time by the village board of trustees.
B. Assistants: The village president may appoint a person or persons to assist him in the exercise of the powers and performance of the duties provided
for such local liquor control commissioner. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-3: LICENSE REQUIRED; GENERAL CONDITIONS AND RESTRICTIONS:
A. License Required: No person shall sell or offer for sale in the village any alcoholic liquor without having a license, or in violation of the terms of such
license.
B. Conditions And Restrictions: Every license issued pursuant to this chapter shall be subject to such conditions and restrictions of operation as the local
liquor control commissioner, with approval of a majority of the board of trustees, may deem necessary and appropriate in connection with the public
health, safety, and welfare. Any such conditions and restrictions shall be approved by a resolution duly adopted by the board of trustees, which
resolution shall be incorporated by reference into the license by the local liquor control commissioner. (Ord. 96-23, 9-9-1996)
3-2-4: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; FEE:
A. Contents Of Application: Applications for such licenses shall be made to the local liquor control commissioner. Such applications shall be made in
writing and shall be signed by the applicant, if an individual, or by a duly authorized agent thereof, if a club or corporation, verified by oath or affidavit,
and shall contain the following information and statements:
1. The name, age and address of the applicant in the case of an individual; in the case of a copartnership, the persons entitled to share in the profits
thereof; and in the case of a corporation for profit or a club, the date of incorporation, the objects for which it was organized, the names and
addresses of the officers and directors and if a majority of the stock of such corporation, in interest, is owned by one person or his nominee, the
name and address of such person.
2. The citizenship of the applicant, his place of birth, and if a naturalized citizen, the time and place of his naturalization.
3. The character of business of the applicants; and in the case of a corporation, the objects for which it was formed.
4. The length of time that said applicant has been in business of that character, or in the case of a corporation, the date on which its charter was
issued.
5. The location and description of the premises or place of business which is to be operated under such license.
6. A statement as to whether the applicant has made similar application for a similar license, on premises other than described in the application, and
the disposition of such application.
7. A statement that the applicant has never been convicted of a felony and is not disqualified to receive a license by reason of any manner or thing
contained in this chapter, laws of the state or ordinances of the village. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
B. Application Fee; Liability For Costs: The applicant shall be required to pay to the village, at the time an application for a liquor license is submitted, a
nonrefundable application fee as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code, under the category "license fees". The application fee shall not apply to
applicants seeking the renewal of an existing license pursuant to section 3-2-11 of this chapter. In addition, the applicant shall be responsible for all
costs incurred by the village in the course of processing the application, including, without limitation, the cost of fingerprinting, federal bureau of
investigation charges, and legal fees. (Ord. 2010-5, 3-8-2010)
3-2-5: RESTRICTIONS ON ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
No license shall be issued to:
A. A person who is not of good character and reputation in the community in which he resides.
B. A person who is not a resident of the United States.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 94/493
C. A person who has been convicted of a felony under any federal or state law.
D. A person who has been convicted of being the keeper of or is the keeper of a house of ill fame.
E. A person who has been convicted of pandering or other crime or misdemeanor opposed to decency and morality.
F. A person whose license issued under the state act or this chapter has been revoked for cause.
G. A person who, at the time of application for renewal of any license issued hereunder, would not be eligible for such license under a first application.
H. A copartnership, unless all the members of such copartnership shall be qualified to receive a license.
I. A corporation, if any officer, manager or director thereof, or any stockholder or stockholders owning in the aggregate more than five percent (5%) of the
stock of such corporation, would not be eligible to receive a license hereunder for any reason other than citizenship and residence within the village.
J. A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager or agent unless said manager or agent possesses the same qualifications required of the
licensee.
K. A person who does not own the premises for which a license is sought, or does not have a lease thereon for the full period for which the license is to be
issued.
L. Any law enforcing public official, village president, or any member of the board of trustees, and no such official shall be interested in any way, either
directly or indirectly, in the manufacture, sale or distribution of alcoholic liquor.
M. Any person, association or corporation not eligible for a state retail liquor dealer's license. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992; amd. 2009 Code)
3-2-6: TERM OF LICENSE:
Unless otherwise stated herein to the contrary, each such license shall begin on May 1 and shall terminate on April 30 next following its issuance. (Ord.
92-7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-7: EXAMINATION OF APPLICANTS AND LICENSEES:
A. Rights Of Commissioner: The local liquor control commissioner shall have the right:
1. To examine, or cause to be examined, under oath, any applicant for a local license or for a renewal thereof, or any licensee upon whom notice of
revocation or suspension has been served as provided by statute.
2. To examine or cause to be examined the books and records of any such applicant or licensee.
3. To hear testimony and take proofs for his information in the performance of his duties, and for such purpose, to issue subpoenas which shall be
effective in any part of this state.
B. Agent Of Commissioner: For the purpose of obtaining any of the information desired by the local liquor control commissioner under this section, the
local liquor control commissioner may authorize his agent to act on his behalf, as provided by statute. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)

This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 2019-14 - LIQUOR LICENSES . Go to new ordinance.
3-2-8: CLASSES OF LICENSES:
Every person engaged in the retail sale of alcoholic liquor in the village shall possess a license of one of the following classes: (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
A. Class A, which shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquor, in the original package and not for consumption on the premises where sold, and limited
alcoholic liquor tasting activities as provided in section 3-2-20 of this chapter.
B. Class B, which shall authorize the retail sale of beer and/or wine, in the original package and not for consumption on the premises where sold, and
limited winetasting activities as provided in section 3-2-20 of this chapter. (Ord. 2007-24, 12-11-2007)
C. Class C, which shall authorize the retail sale by conference centers of alcoholic liquor by the drink for consumption:
1. On the premises of the conference center by conference center guests;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 95/493
2. In the private and public rooms of the conference center for privately sponsored parties, receptions, and similar gatherings where attendance is
limited to conference center guests or invited guests;
3. In the conference center restaurant; provided, however, that alcoholic liquor shall only be consumed within the restaurant area in which it is sold, and
the sale and service of alcoholic liquor shall be incidental and complimentary to the sale and service of a complete meal, which meal shall be served
and eaten at a table in the restaurant area;
4. In a lounge (bar service) area that is accessory to a restaurant, with or without the sale and service of a meal; provided, however, that:
a. Alcoholic liquor shall only be consumed within the lounge area;
b. The square footage of the lounge area shall not exceed two thousand (2,000); and
c. The license shall only be issued to the owner or operator of the restaurant to which the lounge area is accessory. (Ord. 2002-14, 9-23-2002)
D. Class D, which shall authorize the retail sale, by private clubs in their "restaurants" as defined in section 3-2-1 of this chapter, of alcoholic liquor by the
drink for consumption on the premises by customers of the restaurant, and which shall also authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquor for privately
sponsored parties, lunches, dinners, receptions and similar gatherings where attendance is limited to members or invited guests. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-
1992; amd. 2009 Code)
E. Class L, special events license, which shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquor by educational, political, civic, fraternal, religious or other
nonprofit organizations, at a picnic, outing, festival or other such similar special event only for consumption on the premises or within the area
specifically designated in such license and shall in no event be valid for more than forty eight (48) hours. Satisfactory evidence from the owner of the
premises shall be furnished showing the authorization to the applicant for the use of said premises, including the sale of alcoholic liquor, for the period
for which the license is requested. No applicant may apply for more than four (4) class L licenses in any calendar year. (Ord. 2016-24, 9-26-2016)
F. Class P, which shall authorize for consumption on the premises where sold, the retail sale of alcoholic beverages on the premises of property owned (or
controlled) and operated by a park district having a population of less than five hundred thousand (500,000) inhabitants organized under the provisions
of the park district code of the state of Illinois1. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
G. Class R, which shall authorize the retail sale by restaurants of alcoholic liquor; provided, that: 1) such alcoholic liquor shall be consumed only within the
restaurant premises in which it is sold; and 2) such a sale must be incidental and complementary to the sale and service of a complete meal, served
and eaten at a table within the restaurant.
H. Class S, which shall authorize the retail sale by restaurants of alcoholic liquor limited to beer and wine; provided, that: 1) such alcoholic liquor shall be
consumed only within the restaurant premises in which it is sold; and 2) such a sale must be incidental and complementary to the sale and service of a
complete meal, served and eaten at a table within the restaurant. (Ord. 96-9, 4-8-1996)
I. Class T, which shall authorize and allow the retail sale by businesses of alcoholic beverages, limited to beer and wine in original packages or containers
not for consumption on the premises where sold but packaged and made available to customers by parcel delivery service. (Ord. 95-30, 9-11-1995)
J. Class U, which shall authorize the retail sale by restaurants of alcoholic liquor in a bar service area with or without the sale and service of a meal;
provided, that: 1) such alcoholic liquor shall be consumed only within the bar service area; 2) the square footage of the bar service area shall not
exceed ten percent (10%) of the total square footage of the restaurant to which it is accessory; 3) the only public access to the bar service area shall be
through the restaurant to which it is accessory; and 4) such license shall only be issued to the owner or operator of the restaurant to which the bar
service area is accessory; provided further that, for restaurants located within a building in premises no larger than one hundred twenty (120) square
feet that do not have a bar service area and provide customer seating only in an outdoor service area, restaurants may serve alcoholic liquor in the
outdoor service area with or without the sale and service of a meal, provided that: 1) such alcoholic liquor shall be consumed only within the outdoor
service area; 2) such license shall only be issued to the owner or operator of the restaurant to which the outdoor service area is accessory; 3) the
service of alcoholic liquor in the outdoor service area is permitted only when the restaurant is open and in no case later than eleven o'clock (11:00)
P.M., and 4) the outdoor service area must be separated from pedestrian traffic on the adjoining sidewalk by the use of a fence, planters, railing, or
other barrier at least three feet (3') in height. (Ord. 2015-7, 5-11-2015)
K. Class V, which shall authorize the retail sale and service by restaurants of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises by the customers of the
restaurant, as follows:
1. In a restaurant dining area; provided that the sale is incidental and complementary to the sale and service of a complete meal, served and eaten at a
table within the restaurant; and
2. In a bar service area, with or without the sale and service of a meal; provided that the square footage of the bar service area shall not exceed ten
percent (10%) of the total square footage of the restaurant to which it is accessory; and
3. In an outdoor service area; provided that:
a. The sale and service of alcoholic liquor is incidental and complementary to the sale and service of a complete meal, served and eaten at a table in
the outdoor service area;
b. The sale and service of alcoholic liquor in the outdoor service area shall be permitted only when the main restaurant is open and in no case later
than eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M.;
c. The outdoor service area may be separated from pedestrian traffic on the adjoining sidewalk by the use of a fence, planters, railing, or other
barrier provided that any such barrier, if utilized, must be at least three feet (3') in height and that the outdoor service area must also provide any
and all additional means of emergency egress from the outdoor service area that are necessary to comply with any applicable life safety codes
and regulations;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 96/493
d. Reserved;
e. No sale or service of alcoholic liquor shall be made from the outdoor service area to any person on the adjacent sidewalk or public street;
f. No alcoholic liquor shall be removed from the outdoor service area except to the restaurant area;
g. The outdoor service area shall be supervised at all times by a restaurant employee;
h. No music or other noisemaking activity shall be permitted in the outdoor service area; and
i. No animals, except those assisting the disabled, shall be allowed in the outdoor service area.
4. This license shall only be issued to the owner or operator of the restaurant to which the bar service area and outdoor service area are accessory.
(Ord. 2010-14, 6-28-2010)
L. Caterer's license:
1. Class W annual license, which shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquor by caterers solely between the hours of eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M.
and twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight, in connection with, and as an incidental part of, the catering of food for private events at a premises not
otherwise licensed for the retail sales of alcoholic liquor. A "private event" shall be defined as an event not available to the general public except by
appointment or special invitation. A licensee with a class W annual license does not need a separate class W license for each private event.
2. Class W event license, which shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquor by caterers solely between the hours of eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M. and
twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight, in connection with, and as an incidental part of, the catering of food for a single private event at a premises not
otherwise licensed for the retail sales of alcoholic liquor. A "private event" shall be defined as an event not available to the general public except by
appointment or special invitation. A class W event license shall only be valid for an event lasting no more than forty eight (48) hours. No applicant
may apply for more than four (4) class W event licenses in any calendar year. (Ord. 2016-24, 9-26-2016)
M. Class X, available only to a restaurant that is the holder of a valid class R, S, U, or V alcoholic beverage license pursuant to this section, which shall
authorize the retail sale by restaurants only to patrons of the restaurant of beer and wine in the original packages or containers and not for consumption
on the premises where sold, provided that such sales may not exceed fifteen percent (15%) of the total retail sale and service of alcoholic beverages
by the restaurant. (Ord. 2010-5, 3-8-2010)
N. Class Y licenses, which shall authorize the retail sale at a brewpub of: 1) beer that is brewed by the licensee at the brewpub or at another designated
location for consumption on or off the premises of the brewpub, and 2) alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises of the brewpub incidental to
the retail sale of beer. Class Y licensees must provide some service of food at the brewpub incidental to the retail sale of beer or other alcoholic liquor
but need not operate as a restaurant. Class Y licensees may conduct limited beertasting activities on the premises as provided in section 3-2-20 of this
chapter. Class Y licensees may serve beer and alcoholic liquor in an outdoor service area provided that the service of beer and alcoholic liquor in the
outdoor service area is permitted only when the brewpub is open and in no case later than eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M., and that the outdoor service
area may be separated from pedestrian traffic on the adjoining sidewalk by the use of a fence, planters, railing, or other barrier at least three feet (3') in
height. (Ord. 2011-6, 4-11-2011)
O. Class Z, available only to a business that is the holder of a valid class A alcoholic liquor license pursuant to this section, which shall authorize the retail
sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises where sold. A grocery store holding a class Z license may serve alcoholic liquor in an outdoor
service area provided that:
1. The service of alcoholic liquor in the outdoor service area is permitted only when the grocery store is open and in no case later than eleven o'clock
(11:00) P.M.;
2. The outdoor service area may be separated from pedestrian traffic on the adjoining sidewalk and vehicles in any adjacent parking lot or public street
by the use of a fence, planters, railing, or other barrier at least three feet (3') in height and the outdoor service area must provide any and all
additional means of emergency egress from the outdoor service area that are necessary to comply with any applicable life safety codes and
regulations;
3. No sale or service of alcoholic liquor shall be made from the outdoor service area to any person on the adjacent sidewalk, parking area, or public
street;
4. No alcoholic liquor shall be removed from the outdoor service area;
5. The outdoor service area shall be supervised at all times by a grocery store employee;
6. No music or other noisemaking activity shall be permitted in the outdoor service area; and
7. No animals, except those assisting the disabled, shall be allowed in the outdoor service area. (Ord. 2014-23, 10-27-2014)
P. Class AA, civic special events license, which shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquor at village designated civic special events only for
consumption on the event premises or within such other area within the event premises as specifically designated in such license. The license shall be
valid only for the duration of the specified civic special event and shall be subject to such conditions as the liquor commissioner or his or her designee
may impose regarding the conduct of the civic special event, including, without limitation, that the licensee must provide the village with written
documentation, in a form approved by the village, that the licensee will indemnify, hold harmless, defend, and insure the village against any claims
arising out of or relating to the service of alcoholic liquor by the licensee at the civic special event. At least one officer of the applicant for the licensee
must be a resident of the Village and must sign the license application. (Ord. 2012-25, 8-27-2012)

3-2-9: LICENSE FEES:
A. The annual license fees for Classes A, B, C, D, L, P, S, T, U, V, W, Y, Z, and AA liquor licenses shall be as set out in section 1-12-3 of this Code under
the category "license fees". (Ord. 2012-25, 8-27-2012)
B. Fees for all liquor licenses, except Classes L and W, that are issued on or after November 1 shall be prorated on a semiannual basis. (Ord. 97-11, 4-28-
1997, eff. 5-1-1997; amd. 2009 Code; Ord. 2016-24, 9-26-2016)
