3-2-11: RENEWAL OF LICENSE:
Any licensee may renew his license at the expiration thereof; provided, that he is then qualified to receive a license, and the premises for which such
renewal license is sought is suitable for the purpose. In addition, the renewal privilege herein provided shall not be construed as a vested right which shall
in any case prevent the Village President from decreasing the number of licenses to be issued within his jurisdiction or examining the application for
renewal as provided in section 3-2-4 of this chapter. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-12: CLOSING HOURS:
No person shall:
A. Off Premises Sales: Sell or offer for sale alcoholic liquor in the original package for consumption off the premises between the hours of eleven o'clock
(11:00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. each day of the week.
B. On Premises Sales: Sell or offer for sale alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises between the hours of one o'clock (1:00) A.M. and six o'clock
(6:00) A.M. each day of the week.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 98/493
C. Restaurants: Keep open for business or admit the public to any premises in or upon which alcoholic liquor is sold at retail during the hours within which
the sale of such alcoholic liquor is prohibited; provided, that restaurant and club establishments may be kept open during such hours but no alcoholic
liquor may be sold to or consumed by the public, employees or the membership during such hours. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-13: ENTRY POWERS OF LOCAL LIQUOR CONTROL COMMISSIONER:
The Local Liquor Control Commissioner hereby is given the power to enter or to authorize any law enforcement officer to enter at any time upon any
premises licensed hereunder to determine whether any of the provisions of the Liquor Control Act, 235 Illinois Compiled Statutes, or any rules or
regulations adopted by him or by the State Liquor Commission have been or are being violated and at such time to examine the premises of said licensee
in connection therewith. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-14: RECORDS KEPT:
The local liquor control commissioner shall keep or cause to be kept a complete record of all such licenses issued by him. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-15: TRANSFER OF LICENSE:
A. Personal Privilege: A license shall be a purely personal privilege, good for not to exceed one year after issuance unless sooner revoked as in this
chapter provided, and shall not constitute property, nor shall it be subject to being encumbered or hypothecated.
B. Deceased Or Insolvent Licensee: Such license shall not descend by the laws of the testate or intestate devolution. It shall cease upon the death of the
licensee; provided, that executors or administrators of the estate of any deceased licensee, when such estate consists in part of alcoholic liquor, may
continue the business of the sale or manufacture of alcoholic liquor under order of the appropriate court, and may exercise the privileges of the
deceased or insolvent or insolvency or bankruptcy until the expiration of such license, but not longer than six (6) months, after the death, bankruptcy or
insolvency of such licensee. No refund shall be made of that portion of the license fees paid for any period in which the licensee shall be prevented
from operating under such license in accordance with the provisions of this subsection. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-16: CHANGE OF LOCATION:
A. A liquor dealer's license shall permit the sale of alcoholic liquor only in the premises described in the application and license. Such location may be
changed only upon the written permit to make such change issued by the village president.
B. No change of location shall be permitted unless the proposed new location is a proper one for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor under the statutes of the
state and this code and the ordinances of the village. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-17: SANITARY CONDITIONS OF PREMISES:
All premises used for the sale of alcoholic liquor or for the storage of such liquor for sale shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition, and shall be kept
in full compliance with this code and the ordinances regulating the condition of premises used for the storage or sale of food for human consumption, and
those statutes, regulations and directions of all governmental bodies having jurisdiction. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-18: HEALTH CONDITIONS OF EMPLOYEES:
A. No person shall employ in any premises used for the sale of alcoholic liquor any person who is afflicted with, or who is a carrier of any contagious or
infectious disease.
B. No person afflicted with or who is a carrier of any such disease shall work in or about any such premises or engage in any way in work on or about any
such premises. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-19: RESTRICTIONS; SERVING AND DRINKING ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR:
A. Compliance With Laws:
1. No person shall serve or drink any alcoholic liquor in any restaurant, dining room, lunchroom, bowling alley or other place of public resort in the
village, other than one where the sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises is permitted under license and said service takes place
during the hours permitted by the license. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
2. Nothing in this chapter shall excuse or relieve the owner, proprietor or person in charge of any tavern or other place in the village where alcoholic
liquor is sold, served or delivered from the restrictions and requirements of any other provision of this code, any ordinance of the village, or any state
or federal laws or regulations. (Ord. 95-42, 12-11-1995)
B. Drinking On Public Ways: No person shall drink any alcoholic liquor in any public street, alley, parkway, driveway or parking lot in the village, unless
authorized by an appropriate license.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 99/493
C. Bringing Liquor Into Licensed Premises: No person shall consume or be in possession of any alcoholic liquor on licensed premises other than such
premises where alcoholic liquor is sold and dispensed by the licensee. The licensee or his agent shall have the authority to order the immediate
removal of any alcoholic liquor carried onto licensed premises in violation of this subsection. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
D. Restricted Areas: With regard to all premises for which a class C, D, L, P, R, S, U or V license has been issued pursuant to this chapter, consumption of
alcoholic liquor shall be restricted to designated serving areas on the licensed premises and shall not take place in any other areas, parking lots, or
adjoining property. No person, and no licensee under this chapter, nor any officer, associate, member, representative, agent, or employee of such
licensee, shall hand, offer, deliver, carry or pass off or out of the licensed premises any alcoholic liquor, nor shall any such person cause or facilitate
any alcoholic liquor to be handed, offered, delivered, carried or passed off or out of the licensed premises. (Ord. 96-23, 9-9-1996; amd. Ord. 2005-4, 2-
28-2005)
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 2019-14 - LIQUOR LICENSES . Go to new ordinance.
3-2-20: GIVING AWAY PROHIBITED; TASTING EXCEPTED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to give away or otherwise dispense free of charge, by the drink or in any other manner, within the village, an alcoholic
beverage with the intent of promoting the sale of an alcoholic beverage; provided, however, when approved in advance by the local liquor commissioner,
upon application of a class A, class B, class L, or class Y licensee, and subject to the terms and conditions as the local liquor control commissioner may
determine necessary, that class A and class L licensees may give away alcoholic liquor on the licensed premises, and class B licensees may give away
wine on the licensed premises, and class Y licensees may give away beer on the licensed premises, without charge, in small and limited amounts for
tasting purposes only. (Ord. 2010-19, 8-23-2010)
3-2-21: HAPPY HOURS PROHIBITED:
A. Schedule Of Prices: All retail licensees shall maintain a schedule of the prices charged for all drinks of alcoholic liquor to be served and consumed on
the licensed premises or in any room or part thereof. Whenever a multiuse establishment which holds a valid retailer's license operates on its premises
more than one establishment at which drinks of alcoholic liquor are sold at retail, a multiuse establishment shall maintain at each such establishment a
separate schedule of the prices charged for such drinks at that establishment.
B. Prohibited Acts: No retail licensee or employee or agent of such licensee shall:
1. Serve two (2) or more drinks of alcoholic liquor at one time to one person for consumption by that person, except selling or delivering wine by the
bottle or carafe;
2. Sell, offer to sell or serve to any person an unlimited number of drinks of alcoholic liquor during any set period of time for a fixed price, except at
private functions not open to the general public; (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
3. Sell, offer to sell or serve any drink of alcoholic liquor to any person on any one day at a reduced price other than that charged other purchasers of
drinks on that day which such reduced price is a promotion to encourage consumption of alcoholic liquor; (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992; amd. 2009 Code)
4. Increase the volume of alcoholic liquor contained in a drink, or the size of a drink of alcoholic liquor, without increasing proportionately the price
regularly charged for the drink on that day;
5. Encourage or permit, on the licensed premises, any game or contest which involves drinking alcoholic liquor or the awarding of drinks of alcoholic
liquor as prizes for such game or contest on the licensed premises; or
6. Advertise or promote in any way, whether on or off the licensed premises, any of the practices prohibited under subsections B1 through B5 of this
section.
C. Activities Permitted: Nothing in subsection B of this section shall be construed to prohibit a licensee from:
1. Offering free food or entertainment at any time.
2. Including drinks of alcoholic liquor as part of a meal package.
3. Negotiating drinks of alcoholic liquor as part of a contract between a multiuse establishment and another group for the holding of any function,
meeting, convention or trade show.
4. Selling pitchers (or the equivalent, including, but not limited to, buckets), carafes or bottles of alcoholic liquor which are customarily sold in such
manner and delivered to two (2) or more persons at one time.
5. Increasing prices of drinks of alcoholic liquor in lieu of, in whole or in part, a cover charge to offset the cost of special entertainment not regularly
scheduled.
D. Violation; License Suspension Or Revocation: A violation of this section shall be grounds for suspension or revocation of the retailer's license as
provided herein. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-22: LOCATION RESTRICTIONS; EXEMPTIONS:
No license shall be issued for the sale at retail of any alcoholic liquor within one hundred feet (100') of any church or school; provided, that this prohibition
shall not apply to clubs, restaurants, food shops or other places where the sale of alcoholic liquor is not the principal business carried on, if such place of
business not exempt shall have been established for such purpose prior to the effective date hereof; nor to the renewal of a license for the sale of alcoholic
liquor on premises within one hundred feet (100') of any church where such church has been established within such one hundred feet (100') since the
issuance of the original license. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 100/493
3-2-23: CLEAR VIEW OF INSIDE FROM STREET REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS:
A. View Inside Premises: In premises in which the sale of liquor for consumption on the premises is licensed, other than in restaurants, hotels, or clubs, no
screen, blind, curtain, partition, article or thing shall be permitted in the windows or upon the doors of such licensed premises, not inside such
premises, which shall prevent a clear view into the interior of such licensed premises from the street, road or sidewalk at all times, and no booth,
screen, partition or other obstruction, nor any arrangement of lights or lighting, shall be permitted in or about the interior of such premises which shall
prevent a full view of the entire interior of such premises, and the entire space used by the public must be so located that there shall be a full view of
the same from the street, road or sidewalk.
B. Lighting: All rooms where alcoholic liquor is sold for consumption on the premises shall be continually lighted during business hours by natural or
artificial white lights so that all parts of the interior of the premises shall be clearly visible.
C. Violation; License Revocation: In case the view into any such licensed premises required by this section shall be wilfully obscured by the licensee or by
him wilfully suffered to be obscured or obstructed, such license may be revoked in the manner herein provided.
D. Enforcement; Filing Of Plans: In order to enforce the provisions of this section, the local liquor control commissioner shall have the right to require the
filing with him of plans, drawings and photographs showing the clearance of the view as required in this section. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-24: PROHIBITIONS REGARDING MINORS:
A. Acts Prohibited: Subject to the exceptions set forth in subsection B of this section, it shall be unlawful:
1. For any person to sell, give, deliver, dispense or furnish alcoholic liquor to any minor.
2. For any minor to purchase, obtain, receive, accept, have in his or her possession or control, sell, give, deliver, mix, dispense, serve, furnish or
consume alcoholic liquor.
3. For any minor to misrepresent his or her age to circumvent the provisions of this chapter, including, without limitation, presenting or offering to any
person any identification card that is false, fraudulent, forged or not actually his or her own.
4. For any minor to possess or use any identification card that is false, fraudulent, forged, or the identification card of another, or to obtain an
identification card by means of false information.
5. For any person to sell, give, deliver or furnish to any minor any identification card that is false, fraudulent, forged, or of another person.
6. For any person to transfer, forge, alter or deface any identification card.
7. For any retail liquor dealer's licensee, or any officer, associate, member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee, to suffer, permit or
allow any minor to be or remain on such licensee's licensed premises, or in any room or compartment adjoining or adjacent to such licensed
premises.
8. For any owner of, or other person having control over, any vehicle or premises to knowingly initiate, suffer, permit or allow one or more occupants,
invitees, visitors, guests, trespassers or other persons under the age of twenty one (21) years to assemble or be assembled in such vehicle or
premises in possession of any alcoholic liquor in violation of this section.
9. For any person to rent or pay for any hotel, motel or bed and breakfast room or facility from the proprietor or agent thereof for the purpose of or with
knowledge that such room or facility shall be used for the consumption of alcoholic liquor by any minor.
10. For any parent or legal guardian of an unemancipated minor to knowingly suffer, permit or allow such minor to violate any provision of this chapter.
B. Exceptions:
1. The possession, mixing, dispensing and serving or consumption of alcoholic liquor by a minor in the performance of a bona fide religious service or
ceremony is not prohibited by this section.
2. The possession, mixing, dispensing and serving or consumption of alcoholic liquor by a minor under the direct supervision and approval of a parent
or legal guardian in the privacy of such parent's or legal guardian's residence is not prohibited by this section; provided, however, that this exception
shall not extend to any other occupant, invitee, visitor or guest that is a minor.
3. The possession and serving of alcoholic liquor by a minor as an employee of any licensee under this chapter in such licensee's licensed premises is
not prohibited by this section; provided, however, that this exception shall not extend to those persons under the age of nineteen (19) years, nor shall
this exception extend to the mixing or dispensing of alcoholic liquor or to bartending by any minor.
4. The possession and delivery of any alcoholic liquor in its original package and not for consumption on the premises where sold by a minor as an
employee of any licensee under this chapter or pursuant to the order of his or her parent or legal guardian is not prohibited by this section.
5. The location or assembly of any minor in any retail premises licensed under this chapter or in any room or compartment adjoining or adjacent to any
such licensed premises is not prohibited by this section if such person is accompanied by his or her parent or legal guardian; or if such licensed
premises derives its principal business from the sale or service of commodities other than alcoholic liquor; or if such minor is an employee of any
licensee under this chapter in such licensee's licensed premises whose duties do not include the mixing or dispensing of alcoholic liquor or
bartending and, if under the age of nineteen (19) years, whose duties do not include the handling or serving of alcoholic liquors.
6. The action or omission to act of any person at the express lawful, or apparently lawful, direction of a law enforcement officer in the performance of
his or her official duties is not prohibited by this section.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 101/493
C. Presumptions Of Knowledge And Permission: For purposes of this chapter, a person shall be presumed, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, to
have knowingly permitted a violation of this chapter if: 1) such person is present within any vehicle or premises of which such person is the owner,
lessee, permittee, bailee, legal possessor or occupier thereof at the time that a violation of the provisions of this chapter is occurring; and 2) such
person has not informed the Lake Bluff police department thereof.
D. Reliance On Identification Card: Proof that any person demanded, was shown, and reasonably relied upon an identification card evidencing: 1) the
identity of a person; and 2) that such person is of lawful age in any transaction prohibited by this section, shall constitute an affirmative defense in any
criminal prosecution therefor, in any prosecution for a violation of this section, or in any proceedings for the suspension or revocation of any license or
the imposition of any fine or penalty based thereon; provided, however, that it shall not be an affirmative defense if such person accepted the
identification card knowing it to be false, fraudulent, forged or the identification card of another person.
E. Violation; License Revocation Or Suspension: In addition to all other fines and penalties, the local liquor control commissioner may revoke or suspend
the retail liquor dealer's license for any violation of this section. (Ord. 95-42, 12-11-1995)
3-2-25: PREVENTING VIOLATIONS BY MINORS2:
A. Warning Required: In any place in the village where alcoholic liquor is sold or distributed pursuant to a village retail liquor dealer's license, there shall be
displayed at all times, in a prominent and conspicuous place, a printed card supplied by the village clerk reading substantially as follows:
WARNING TO PERSONS UNDER 21
YOU ARE SUBJECT TO A FINE OF UP TO $750.00 UNDER THE LAWS OF THE VILLAGE OF LAKE BLUFF IF YOU PURCHASE ALCOHOLIC
LIQUOR OR MISREPRESENT YOUR AGE FOR THE PURPOSE OF PURCHASING OR OBTAINING ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR.
(Ord. 95-42, 12-11-1995; amd. 2009 Code)
B. Identification Required: If any retail liquor dealer's licensee, or any officer, associate, member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee,
believes or has reason to believe that the sale, delivery or giving of alcoholic liquor to a person, or the employment, location or assembly of a person in
such licensee's licensed premises, is prohibited by section 3-2-24 of this chapter because of the age of such person, such licensee, officer, associate,
member, representative, agent or employee shall, before making such sale, delivery or service and before allowing such person to remain on such
licensee's licensed premises, demand presentation of an identification card. In addition, the licensee shall also demand a second form of positive
identification which confirms the authenticity of the first. For purposes of preventing a violation of section 3-2-24 of this chapter, any such licensee,
officer, associate, member, representative, agent or employee may refuse to sell, deliver or give alcoholic liquor to any person who is unable to produce
a satisfactory identification card, and may refuse to allow such person to remain on such licensee's licensed premises.
C. Violation; License Revocation Or Suspension: In addition to all other fines and penalties, the local liquor control commissioner may revoke or suspend
the retail liquor dealer's license for any violation of this section. (Ord. 95-42, 12-11-1995)
3-2-26: PROHIBITIONS REGARDING OTHER PERSONS:
No retail liquor dealer's licensee, nor any officer, associate, member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee, shall sell, give, deliver, dispense
or furnish alcoholic liquor to any intoxicated person. (Ord. 95-42, 12-11-1995; amd. 2009 Code)
3-2-27: GAMBLING ON PREMISES PROHIBITED:
There shall be no card games or gambling allowed on any premises licensed to sell alcoholic liquor, except for those which have been issued a permit
from the Illinois department of revenue. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-28: REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF LICENSE:
The village president may suspend for not more than thirty (30) days or revoke for cause any liquor dealer's license for any violation of any provision
pertaining to the sale of alcoholic liquor, as provided in this chapter and in the manner provided in 235 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/7-5. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-
1992)
3-2-29: REFILLING ORIGINAL PACKAGES PROHIBITED:
A. Refilling Prohibited: Except for containers used by class Y licensees for the retail sale at a brewpub for off premises consumption of beer brewed at the
brewpub or other designated location, no person licensed under this chapter or his employee or agent shall fill or refill, in whole or in part, any original
package of alcoholic liquor with the same or any other kind or quality of alcoholic liquor.
B. Possession In Original Packages: No person shall have in his possession for sale at retail any bottles, casks or other containers containing alcoholic
liquor, except in original packages. (Ord. 2010-19, 8-23-2010)
3-2-30: DISPLAY OF LICENSE:
Every licensee shall cause his liquor license to be framed and hung in plain view in a conspicuous place on the licensed premises. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)

3-2-31: STATE LICENSE REQUIRED:
No licensee under this chapter shall operate a liquor business without having obtained a liquor license issued by the Illinois liquor control commission.
(Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-32: SOLICITATION FOR PROSTITUTION AND PURCHASE OF LIQUOR ON PREMISES PROHIBITED:
No holder of a liquor license, his agent or employee, shall allow, permit or suffer to remain on his premises any person who shall solicit for herself/himself
or for others for prostitution, or solicit any patron to purchase alcoholic beverages. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-33: REPORT BY CORPORATE LICENSEE OF INTERNAL CHANGES:
All corporations licensed under this chapter shall report to the local liquor control commissioner, within thirty (30) days, all internal changes in such
corporation pertaining to the persons whose names are indicated on the liquor license application. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-34: ADVERTISING:
A. Prohibited Advertising: It shall be unlawful for:
1. Any holder of a retail liquor license of any class to maintain any permanent sign or permanent advertising material visible from outside the licensed
premises which directs attention to specific products or brands of alcoholic liquor, beer or wine. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
2. Any holder of a class A, B, C, D, P, R, or S license to maintain more than one sign or advertising material, either permanent or temporary, on any
one side of the licensed premises visible from outside the licensed premises which directs attention to the service and availability of alcoholic liquor,
beer or wine within the licensed premises. (Ord. 93-17, 9-13-1993)
B. Sign Regulations: A permitted sign or advertising material shall not exceed a size of one square foot. Signs advertising specific products and brands of
alcoholic liquor, beer or wine maintained at licensed premises of the type governed by this section are specifically prohibited. All signs or advertising
materials not prohibited by this section shall be erected and maintained in conformity with sign ordinances of the village3. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-35: CONSUMPTION IN BUILDINGS OWNED BY LAKE BLUFF PARK DISTRICT4:
A. Authority To Sell: Pursuant to authority granted by the general assembly of Illinois by public act 82-917, 70 Illinois Compiled Statutes 1205/8-19, the
board of commissioners of the Lake Bluff park district are authorized to sell alcoholic liquors in buildings owned by the Lake Bluff park district to
persons attending events sponsored by civic, social or cultural groups or attending private parties in said buildings which shall be permitted in
conformity with the terms and provisions of statute and the ordinances, rules and regulations of the park district and in conformity with the applicable
provisions contained in this chapter.
B. Conditions For Use Of Facilities: Unless the ordinances of the Lake Bluff park district shall be hereinafter amended to prohibit the same, alcoholic liquor
may be consumed in facilities owned by the Lake Bluff park district upon the satisfaction of the following conditions:
1. Sale Of Liquor Prohibited: The sale or offering for sale of alcoholic liquor by any person and/or group using the park district facilities except pursuant
to a special permit described below is expressly prohibited.
2. Special Permit Required: All persons and/or groups proposing to exercise the privileges granted in this section, whether incorporated or
unincorporated, for profit or not for profit, shall first apply for and obtain from the director of parks and recreation of the park district a special permit to
be issued for each function on a single basis and shall strictly comply with the terms and conditions thereof, as well as all policies, rules and
regulations of the park district from time to time in effect applicable to the use of the park district facilities.
3. Limitations: Any special permit issued shall specify any limitations on the type of alcoholic liquor to be served, the hours the building may be so
utilized and any other special conditions imposed by the director of parks and recreation. All such special permit holders and attendees at functions
shall strictly abide by the laws and municipal ordinances governing the use and consumption of alcoholic liquors, including, without limitation, the
prohibitions against furnishing of alcohol to minors and intoxicated persons.
4. Notification Of Police Department: Written notification of the intended use of a park district building for the consumption of alcoholic liquors,
describing all conditions contained in said special permit, shall be given to the village police department on the first day of the month in which the
event is to occur.
5. Enforcement By Police Department: The village police department shall enforce any and all terms and limitations contained in a special permit
issued by the director of parks and recreation in addition to all other applicable regulations contained in this section. (Ord. 92-7, 4-13-1992)
3-2-36: CONSUMPTION PROHIBITED IN PUBLIC PLACES:
Except as otherwise explicitly provided in, and authorized pursuant to, section 3-2-35 of this chapter, it shall be unlawful for any person to sell, consume or
possess open containers of alcoholic liquor on any village property, or in any village building, or on any street, sidewalk, alley or other public place in the
village, or in any place open to the public, including, without limitation, parking lots; provided, however, that the sale, consumption and possession of open
containers of alcoholic liquor specifically authorized by a license issued pursuant to this chapter, confined to the premises for which such license is issued,
and otherwise in conformity with the provisions of this chapter, is not prohibited by this section. (Ord. 95-42, 12-11-1995)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 103/493
Chapter 3
PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS
3-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context otherwise requires, the following terms, as used in this chapter, shall be construed according to the definitions given below:
PEDDLER: Every person who shall sell or offer for sale, barter or exchange any goods, wares, merchandise or other commodities, while traveling from
residence to residence on, along or upon the streets and sidewalks of the village.
REGISTERED PEDDLER OR SOLICITOR: Means and includes any person who has obtained a valid certificate of registration as hereinafter provided,
and which certificate is in the possession of the solicitor on his or her person while engaged in soliciting.
RESIDENCE: Means and includes every separate living unit occupied for residential purposes by one or more persons, contained within any type of
building structure.
SOLICITING: Means and includes any one or more of the following activities:
A. Seeking to obtain orders for the purchase of goods, wares, merchandise, foodstuffs, services of any kind, character or description whatever, for any
kind of consideration whatever; or
B. Seeking to obtain prospective customers for applications or purchase of insurance of any type, kind or character; or
C. Seeking to obtain subscriptions to books, magazines, periodicals, newspapers and every other type or kind of publications; or
D. Seeking to obtain gifts or contributions of money, clothing or any other valuable thing for the support or benefit of any charitable or nonprofit
association, organization, corporation or project. (1988 Code § 3-4-1)
3-3-2: CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION:
A. Application Required: Every person desiring to engage in soliciting or peddling within the village is hereby required to make written application upon a
form provided by the office of the village administrator and filed with the office of the village administrator.
B. Contents Of Application: The applicant shall truthfully state in full the information requested on the application, as follows:
1. Name and address of present place of residence and length of residence at such address; also business address, if other than residence address;
also social security number.
2. Address of place of residence during the preceding three (3) years, if other than present address.
3. Age of applicant and marital status; and if married, the name of spouse.
4. Physical description of the applicant.
5. Name and address of the person, firm or corporation or association by whom the applicant is employed or whom he or she represents; and the
length of time of such employment or representation.
6. Name and address of each employer during the preceding three (3) years, if other than the present employer.
7. Description of the subject matter of the soliciting in which the applicant will engage or description of the commodities or articles of merchandise in
which the peddler intends to deal.
8. Period of time for which the certificate is requested.
9. The date, or approximate date, of the most recent previous application for certificate under this chapter, if any.
10. Statement whether a certificate of registration issued to the applicant under this chapter has ever been revoked.
11. Statement whether the applicant has ever been convicted of a violation of any provision of this chapter, or the ordinances of any other Illinois
municipality regulating soliciting.
12. Statement whether the applicant has ever been convicted of the commission of a felony under the laws of the state of Illinois or any other state, or
under the laws of the United States.
13. Such additional information as the village may deem necessary to process the application.
C. Statements Under Oath: All statements made by the applicant under the application or in connection therewith shall be under oath.
D. Record Of Applications: The office of the village administrator shall cause to be kept in his office an accurate record of every application received and
acted upon, together with all information and data pertaining thereto, and all certificates of registration issued under the provisions of this chapter and
of the denial of application. Applications for certificates shall be numbered in consecutive order as filed, and every certificate issued, and any renewal
thereof, shall be identified with the duplicate number of the application upon which it was issued.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 104/493
E. Ineligibility For Certificate: No certificate of registration shall be issued to any person who has been convicted of the commission of a felony under the
laws of the state of Illinois or any other state, or under the laws of the United States, within five (5) years of the date of application; nor to any person
who has been convicted of any violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, nor to any person whose certificate of registration issued hereunder
has previously been revoked as herein provided.
F. Acceptance Or Denial Of Application: The office of the village administrator, after consideration of the application and all information obtained relative
thereto, shall deny the application if the applicant does not possess the qualifications for such certificate as herein required, or if the issuance of a
certificate of registration to the applicant would not be in accord with the intent and purpose of this chapter. Endorsement shall be made by the office of
the village administrator upon the application of the denial of the application. When the applicant is found to be fully qualified, the certificate of
registration shall be issued forthwith. If the office of the village administrator fails to provide the applicant with a decision within five (5) working days of
the date of application, the application shall be deemed to have been accepted.
G. Contents Of Certificate: The certificate of registration shall state the expiration date thereof.
H. License Card:
1. Issuance: If the character, qualifications and record of the applicant are found to be in proper order, the office of the village administrator shall then
issue a license card to the applicant, signed by the village administrator and bearing the applicant's photograph similar to the one on file in the office
of the village administrator.
2. Display Of Card: Such license card, when issued, shall be worn by the solicitor and shall be visible at all times, and such solicitor shall exhibit the
same at the request of any police officer or any citizen of the village and shall exhibit such license card and properly identify himself upon making any
solicitation of a prospective purchaser. Upon the conclusion of his day's work, the solicitor shall deposit his license card with the office of the village
administrator and call for the same the following morning before commencing his day's work.
I. Revocation Of Certificate: Any certificate of registration issued hereunder shall be revoked by the office of the village administrator if the holder of the
certificate is convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, or has made a false material statement in the application, or otherwise
becomes disqualified for the issuance of a certificate of registration under the terms of this chapter. Immediately upon such revocation, written notice
thereof shall be given by the office of the village administrator to the holder of the certificate in person or by certified U.S. mail addressed to his
residence address as set forth in the application. Immediately upon the giving of such notice, the certificate of registration shall become null and void.
(1988 Code § 3-4-2)
3-3-3: LICENSE FEES:
A. Established; Payment: The fees for peddlers' or solicitors' licenses shall be paid to the village treasurer for the use of the village at the time the
application for a license shall be filed, and the license fees for each peddler or solicitor shall be as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code, under the
category "license fees", for one year or any portion thereof.
B. Refunds: Should the application for any license be denied, the fee theretofore deposited shall be refunded to the applicant. (1988 Code § 3-4-3; amd.
2009 Code)
3-3-4: RELIGIOUS OR CHARITABLE SOLICITATIONS:
A. Definition: "Religious or charitable solicitations" shall mean the request, by a person on sidewalks and at residences within the village, directly or
indirectly, of money, credit, property, financial assistance or other thing of value on the plea or representation that such money, credit, property, financial
assistance or other thing of value will be used for a religious or charitable purpose as those purposes are defined herein. These words shall also mean
and include the following methods of securing money, credit, property, financial assistance or other thing of value on the plea or representation that it
will be used for a religious or charitable purpose as herein defined:
1. Any oral or written request or exchange of religious literature for money or other thing of value.
2. The distribution, circulation, posting or publishing of any handbill, written advertisement or publication.
3. The public making of any announcement concerning an appeal, assemblage, athletic or sports event, bazaar, benefit, campaign, contest, dance,
drive, entertainment, exhibition, exposition, party, performance, picnic, sale or social gathering to be held within the village, which the public is
requested to patronize or to which the public is requested to make a contribution for any religious or charitable purpose connected therewith.
4. The sale of, offer or attempt to sell, any advertisement, advertising space, book, card, chance, coupon, device, magazine, membership,
merchandise, subscription, ticket or other thing in connection with which any appeal is made for any religious or charitable purpose or where the
name of any religious or charitable person is used or referred to in any such appeal as an inducement or reason for making any such sale, or when
or where, in connection with any such sale, any statement is made that the whole or any part of the proceeds from any such sale will go or be
donated to any religious or charitable purpose. (1988 Code § 3-4-4)
B. Waiver Of License Fee: On written request, the board of trustees may waive license fees for religious or charitable solicitors, but in no event shall such
waiver exceed two (2) days in any one calendar year. The village may impose additional restrictions and conditions on any permit for which the fee has
been waived. (1988 Code § 3-4-5)
3-3-5: APPEALS:
In the event any applicant shall be refused a license by the office of the village administrator, or shall feel otherwise aggrieved, he shall have the right to
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 105/493
appeal from the decision of the office of the village administrator to the board of trustees, which board shall have the power to reverse or otherwise modify
the decision of the office of the village administrator. Such appeal shall be in writing, addressed to the chairman or the president and board of trustees
setting forth in detail the grounds of such appeal. (1988 Code § 3-4-6)
3-3-6: EXEMPTION:
This chapter shall not be interpreted or construed to deprive any person of any right secured unto him by the constitutions of the state or of the United
States. Any person applying for a license hereunder or who shall be required by the provisions of this chapter to make such application, and who shall
claim exemption from the payment of the license fees required hereunder by virtue of any such constitutional right may apply to the office of the village
administrator for the waiver or remission of such license fee. The office of the village administrator may waive or remit any such license fee when the
infringement of any right secured by the constitution of the state of Illinois or of the United States of America shall be established to his satisfaction. This
section shall not be construed, however, to exempt any person from the requirements of section 3-3-2 of this chapter. (1988 Code § 3-4-7)
3-3-7: MOBILITY OF PEDDLERS:
All peddlers must keep moving from place to place except when in the act of showing foods or selling the goods to customers. (1988 Code § 3-4-8)
3-3-8: MISREPRESENTATION AND FRAUD BY LICENSEE:
All licensed peddlers and solicitors shall not engage in any fraud, misrepresentation or imposition, while acting as a peddler, and shall offer for sale, barter
or exchange only those goods, wares or merchandise specified in the license. (1988 Code § 3-4-9)
3-3-9: VILLAGE POLICY ON SOLICITING:
It is hereby declared to be the policy of the corporate authorities of the village that the occupant or occupants of the residences in the village shall make
the determination of whether solicitors shall be, or shall not be, invited to their respective residence. (1988 Code § 3-4-10)
3-3-10: NOTICE REGULATING SOLICITING:
A. Compliance By Solicitor: Every person desiring to secure the protection intended to be provided by the regulations pertaining to soliciting contained in
this chapter, shall comply with the directions set forth in this section.
B. Specifications: Notice of the determination by the occupant or the refusal of invitation to solicitors to any residence shall be given in the manner
following:
1. A weatherproof card or decal, at least three inches by four inches (3" x 4") (8 cm x 10 cm) in size, shall be exhibited upon or near the main entrance
door to the residence, indicating the determination by the occupant, containing the applicable words, as follows:
NO SOLICITORS INVITED
or
NO SOLICITORS
2. The letters shall be at least one-third inch (1/3") (8 mm) in height.
C. Card Sufficient Notice: Such card so exhibited shall constitute sufficient notice to any solicitor of the determination by the occupant of the residence of
the information contained thereon. (1988 Code § 3-4-11)
3-3-11: DUTY OF SOLICITORS:
A. Compliance With Notice: It shall be the duty of every solicitor, upon going onto any premises in the village upon which a "residence", as defined in
section 3-3-1 of this chapter, is located, to first determine whether the notice provided for in this chapter, if any is attached, and to further be governed
by the statement contained on the notice. If the notice states "No Solicitors Invited" or "No Solicitors", then the solicitor, whether registered or not, shall
immediately and peacefully depart from the premises.
B. Depart Upon Request: Any solicitor who has gained entrance to any residence, whether invited or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the
premises when requested to do so by the occupant. (1988 Code § 3-4-12)
3-3-12: UNINVITED SOLICITING PROHIBITED:
It is hereby declared unlawful and a trespass for any person to go upon any premises and ring the doorbell upon or near any door, or create any sound in
any manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of such residence, for the purpose of securing an audience with the occupant thereof and
engage in "soliciting", as defined in section 3-3-1 of this chapter, in defiance of the notice exhibited at the residence in accordance with the provisions of
this chapter. (1988 Code § 3-4-13)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 106/493
3-3-13: TIME LIMIT ON SOLICITING AND PEDDLING:
It is hereby declared unlawful and a nuisance for any person, whether or not registered under this chapter, to go upon any premises and ring the doorbell
upon or near any door of a residence located thereon, or rap or knock upon any door, or create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the
attention of the occupant of such residence, for the purpose of securing an audience with the occupant thereof and engage in "soliciting", as defined in
section 3-3-1 of this chapter, prior to nine o'clock (9:00) A.M., or after seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. of any weekday, Saturday, or at any time on a Sunday or a
state or national holiday. (1988 Code § 3-4-14)
3-3-14: SOLICITATIONS ON HIGHWAYS:
A. Prohibitions:
1. No person shall stand in a roadway for the purpose of soliciting a ride from the driver of any vehicle1.
2. No person shall stand on a highway for the purpose of soliciting employment or business from the occupant of any vehicle.
3. No person shall stand on a highway within the corporate limits of the village for the purpose of soliciting contributions from the occupant of any
vehicle, except as hereinafter provided. (1988 Code § 3-4-15)
B. Permit, Conditions And Requirements: The village administrator may grant a permit to solicit charitable contributions on highways, subject to the
following provisions: (1988 Code § 3-4-15; amd. 2009 Code)
1. Before the village clerk may issue any permit hereunder, the organization seeking such permit shall be required to set forth the following:
a. The name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization, and of the persons who manage such organization and who
will oversee the activity for which the permit is requested.
b. The exact use for which the permit is requested.
c. The date and times for which such permit is requested.
d. The locations of the intersections within the village for which such permit is requested.
e. The number of solicitors expected.
2. In addition, the soliciting agency shall provide evidence that:
a. It is registered with the attorney general as a charitable organization as provided by an act to regulate solicitation and collection of funds for
charitable purposes, providing for violations thereof, and making an appropriation therefor2, approved July 26, 1963, as subsequently amended;
and
b. The soliciting agency must be engaged in statewide fundraising activity; and
c. The soliciting agency must agree, in writing, to be liable for any injuries to any person or property during the solicitation which are causally related
to an act of ordinary negligence of the soliciting agent.
C. Regulations:
1. Such solicitation shall be allowed only at intersections where all traffic is required to come to a full stop and shall be limited to daylight hours only.
Solicitation shall not interfere with traffic in any way or impede or slow the flow of traffic.
2. All persons engaged in the act of solicitation, as herein described, shall be sixteen (16) years of age or older and shall be required to wear a high
visibility vest.
3. No person shall stand on or in the proximity of a highway for the purpose of soliciting the watching or guarding of any vehicle while parked or about
to be parked on a highway.
D. Liability Insurance: In addition to the above requirements, the soliciting agency shall present to the village clerk written evidence that it has obtained
insurance providing coverage for bodily injury liability, as well as property damage liability, in the amount of three hundred thousand dollars
($300,000.00) for any individual and five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for any occurrence, and said evidence shall name the village as an
additional insured. (1988 Code § 3-4-15)
E. Penalty: Any person who violates any of the terms and provisions of this section or who unnecessarily hinders, obstructs, delays or attempts to hinder,
obstruct or delay any person lawfully driving or traveling along or upon any street or thoroughfare within the village shall be guilty of a violation of this
section and shall be subject to a fine not to exceed the maximum provided in section 1-4-1 of this code. (1988 Code § 3-4-15; amd. 2009 Code)
3-3-15: PENALTIES:
A. Violators of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to a fine of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than the maximum
provided in section 1-4-1 of this code for each offense, and each day or part of a day on which such violation occurs shall constitute a separate and
distinct offense.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 107/493
B. Any person, while acting as a solicitor, who shall be guilty of any fraud, cheating, misrepresentation, or imposition, or who shall solicit orders,
subscriptions or applications, or who shall offer for sale by sample, or by description on approval, for subsequent acceptance, or for future delivery, at
retail, any publications, books, pictures, photographs, goods, wares, merchandise or services, other than stated in the license issued to such person,
shall be subject to a fine of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than the maximum provided in section 1-4-1 of this code for each such
offense. (1988 Code § 3-4-16; amd. 2009 Code)
Chapter 4
SCAVENGERS1
3-4-1: LICENSE REQUIRED; FEES; EXEMPTIONS:
A. License Required: No person, firm or corporation of any nature whatsoever, operating as a scavenger, disposal firm, collector of refuse or the cleaning
of catch basins and other outlets of refuse, or otherwise, unless contracting directly with the village as its waste disposal collector, or except as herein
provided, shall remove waste from any premises in the village or transport waste through the streets, alleys or public ways of the village, or dump,
incinerate or in any other manner dispose of waste originating within the limits of the village, or contract for or permit himself to be employed or
engaged for any such removal, transportation or disposal without first having secured a license for performing such waste disposal service from the
village. (1988 Code § 3-6-1)
B. Fees And Refunds:
1. The license shall evidence the payment to the village of a license fee as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code, under the category "license fees", for
each person operating as such for the first five (5) vehicles of such person and an additional sum as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code, under the
category "license fees", for each truck over five (5) owned or operated by or for such person. (1988 Code § 3-6-1; amd. 2009 Code)
2. License fees will be increased in the event trucks are added to those owned or operated by the licensee which would result in additional fees.
3. No refunds shall be made in the event the licensee disposes of any trucks during a license year, or discontinues operations.
C. Exemption From License And Fee: No license or permit shall be required, nor shall any fee be charged, to any person contracting directly with the
village as its waste disposal contract, or such trucks actually used exclusively for such waste disposal contract purposes for the village.
D. Term Of License: Licenses issued hereunder shall be valid for a period of one year, or any part thereof. Said one year period shall commence on May 1
of each year until April 30 of the following year. License fees shall not be prorated for a portion of the year. (1988 Code § 3-6-1)
3-4-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; ISSUANCE:
A. Application Required; Contents: Before issuing any such license, the village clerk shall require the execution of an application form, to be furnished by
him, showing:
1. The name of the person to be licensed, or in the case of a corporation, the names of the principal officers, together with the business and home
addresses and telephone numbers of each such person;
2. A copy of the license or permit required by the state or any other regulatory agency;
3. Description of the equipment to be used in such collection, transportation and disposal;
4. The list by name and address of persons for whom such removal is made and the specifications of the vehicle in which waste is transported; and
5. The site location of and the manner in which the ultimate disposition of the waste is to be accomplished.
B. Investigation Of Applicant; Eligibility For License: The application shall be referred by the village clerk to the office of the village administrator who shall
make or cause to be made an investigation into the character and responsibility of the applicant. Licenses shall be issued only to responsible persons
of good, moral character, and only to corporations whose officers are responsible persons of good, moral character.
C. Approval Of Application: The application shall then be submitted by the village clerk to, and shall be approved by, the village president and board of
trustees as a prerequisite to the issuance of such license.
D. Change In Data: Any change in the data required in the license application shall be filed with the village within ten (10) days after a change occurs.
(1988 Code § 3-6-2)
3-4-3: TRANSPORTING WASTE2:
A. No person shall transport waste, or cause waste to be transported, over the streets or other public ways in the village unless such waste being
transported is entirely and securely covered.
B. Garbage shall not be transported over or along the streets of the village or other public property thereof except in a leakproof, compaction type body
commonly referred to as a "packer type" refuse body, approved by the office of the village administrator. Such equipment shall not be permitted to
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 108/493
remain parked anywhere in the village limits when not in use, but may be stored or kept when not in use in a tightly constructed and enclosed building
or shed within the village, provided such building or structure shall conform to the requirements of the zoning title (title 10 of this code).
C. It shall be unlawful for any such vehicle to be driven through or over any street on Sunday. (1988 Code § 3-6-3)
3-4-4: DISPOSAL AND STORAGE OF WASTE:
It shall be unlawful for any scavenger to dispose of or store any refuse in any place within the village limits or within one mile therefrom except with the
permission of the board of trustees. (1988 Code § 3-6-4)
3-4-5: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
In addition to enforcing against the contractor the penalties herein provided, the village shall have the right, in case of violation of any of the provisions of
this chapter, or the provisions of any contract such contractor may have entered into, to revoke such contractor's license or permit and to cancel the
contract. (1988 Code § 3-6-5)
3-4-6: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provisions of this chapter shall be fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than the maximum provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues.
(1988 Code § 3-6-6; amd. 2009 Code)
Chapter 5
TAXICABS
3-5-1: LICENSE REQUIRED; DEFINITION:
It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate a taxicab business or to operate a public passenger vehicle for hire without having first obtained a license
therefor as herein provided. "Taxicab" is defined to include a livery or limousine service. (1988 Code § 3-7-1)
3-5-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; ISSUANCE:
A. Contents Of Application: Applications for such licenses shall be made in writing to the office of the village clerk. Each application shall state thereon the
full name, age, residence address and place of birth of the applicant, whether or not the applicant is a citizen of the United States, and the occupation
or business of the applicant for the past five (5) years with names and addresses of employers. The applicant shall obtain and attach to his application
on forms to be provided by the office of the village clerk, affidavits of his good character from two (2) reputable persons not related to him by blood or
marriage, who have known the applicant personally and observed his conduct during at least one year next preceding the date of the application.
B. Vehicle Information: The application shall also set forth the class of vehicle intended to be operated, the length of time the vehicle has been in use, the
number of persons it is capable of carrying, the motor power thereof and the most recent license number issued therefor by the state.
C. Investigation Of Applicant; Issuance Of License: Every application shall be referred by the village clerk to the office of the village administrator who shall
investigate the statements contained therein and the fitness of the applicant to conduct the business for which the license is requested and shall, within
thirty (30) days after such application is referred, make a report to the village president on such application. The village president shall then direct the
village clerk to issue the license to such persons as shall comply in all respects with the provisions of this chapter and as the village president, in his
discretion, shall deem suitable and proper persons to be so licensed. (1988 Code § 3-7-2)
3-5-3: LICENSE FEES AND TERM:
A. Taxicab Service: The annual license fee for a public passenger vehicle (taxicab) license shall be as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code, under the
category "license fees", for each company engaged in such business. Such license fee shall be in addition to any fees or licenses heretofore
established. All licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter shall be for a term not to exceed one year commencing May 1 in each year and
shall expire on April 30 in the following year. In the case of a license issued on or after November 1 in each year, one-half (1/2) of the above fee shall be
paid.
B. Livery Service: The annual license fee for a livery service license shall be as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code, under the category "license fees", for
each company engaged in such business. Such license fee shall be in addition to any fees or licenses heretofore established. All licenses issued under
the provisions of this chapter shall be for a term not to exceed one year commencing May 1 in each year and shall expire on April 30 in the following
year. In the case of licenses issued on or after November 1 in each year, one-half (1/2) of the above fee shall be paid. "Livery", as used herein, shall
include all public passenger vehicles (taxicabs) with a capacity of seven (7) or more adult individuals including the driver thereof, and must comply with
all of the provisions of ordinances applicable to public passenger vehicles (taxicabs). (Ord. 89-16, 3-20-1989; amd. 2009 Code)
3-5-4: INSURANCE REQUIRED; COMPLIANCE WITH STATE LAW:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 109/493
A. Insurance Requirements: It shall be unlawful to conduct such a business or so operate a public passenger vehicle, and no license therefor shall be
issued, until such applicant shall cause to be issued and kept in full force and effect a policy of insurance in a solvent and responsible company
authorized to do business in the state insuring such applicant against liability for any injury to, death of, or damage to the property of any person
resulting from the negligence of such applicant or his agent in the operation of such vehicle. Said policy of insurance shall insure and bond such
applicant as provided in the amount established by statutes of the state, but in no event less than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for each accident
or less than three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for death or injury to any one person or five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for
death or personal injury of more than one person in a single accident. Said policy shall further indemnify and hold harmless the village, its officers and
employees from any liability, and a copy of such policy shall be delivered to the village. Said insurance policy shall provide that the insurance carrier or
surety on any bond may not withdraw from such bond or cancel said insurance until after serving ten (10) days' previous notice in writing upon the
village by registered mail. Whenever any such policy shall be so canceled or bond withdrawn, said applicant shall furnish a new policy of insurance or
bond in accordance with the provisions of this chapter before continuing to exercise any of the authority granted by this chapter.
B. Certificate Of Compliance: All applicants applying for a license shall, at the time the license is issued, deposit with the village clerk a certificate from the
secretary of state of compliance with statutory requirements of the state for the operation of a taxicab. (1988 Code § 3-7-4)
3-5-5: RATES AND CHARGES; TAXIMETER:
A. Schedule Of Rates; Posting Required: Every person licensed to operate taxicabs shall file a schedule of the rates and charges for such taxicabs with
the village clerk from time to time and within five (5) days of any change or amendments thereto. The taxicabs shall also have affixed thereon inside or
outside of each cab and in a conspicuous place where it may be easily and conveniently read by any passenger, a card upon which shall be printed in
plain legible type the rates of fare. (1988 Code § 3-7-5)
B. Taximeters: Every taxicab licensed to operate in the village shall be equipped with an accurate and dependable taximeter designed or intended to
measure the distance traveled, register the time the vehicle is waiting, and record the charge of fare therefor. The taximeter must be placed so as to be
readily visible to passengers and shall be maintained in good operating condition. The taximeter shall be inspected and sealed by a representative of
the police department on complaint. (1988 Code § 3-7-5; amd. 2009 Code)
C. Receipt: Any passenger paying a fare shall be entitled to a receipt showing the amount paid, if requested by the passenger at the time of payment.
(1988 Code § 3-7-5)
3-5-6: PAYMENT OF FARE; TRANSPORTING PASSENGERS:
Every driver of a public passenger vehicle shall have the right to demand payment of the fare in advance and may refuse employment unless so prepaid,
but no driver of a public passenger vehicle shall otherwise refuse or neglect to convey any orderly person or persons upon request anywhere in the village
unless previously engaged or unable to do so. No driver of a taxicab shall carry any other person than the passenger first employing such vehicle without
the consent of the passenger. (1988 Code § 3-7-6)
3-5-7: VEHICLE REQUIREMENTS; INSPECTIONS:
All vehicles used for taxicabs or for the conveyance of passengers for hire must be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and must be properly equipped
with brakes, lights, warning signals and such other devices or items of safety as required by the state. (1988 Code § 3-7-5; amd. 2009 Code)
3-5-8: CONDUCT OF DRIVERS:
It shall be unlawful for any person driving a taxicab or public passenger vehicle to act in other than a proper manner at all times while so occupied or while
in charge of a vehicle. It shall be unlawful for any such driver to shout to prospective passengers or to drivers or operators of other vehicles, or to be guilty
of using profane or boisterous language. (1988 Code § 3-7-8)
3-5-9: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
Any license issued under the provisions of this chapter may be revoked by the village president for a violation of any provision hereof or upon proof
satisfactory to the village president that the business of the licensee was conducted in a manner detrimental to the public safety, health or morals. Such
revocation may be in addition to the imposition of a fine or other penalty for a violation of any provision of this chapter, and shall be no defense to a
prosecution for such violation. (1988 Code § 3-7-9)
3-5-10: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than the maximum provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues.
(1988 Code § 3-7-10; amd. 2009 Code)
Chapter 6
GASOLINE STATIONS
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 110/493
3-6-1: DEFINITIONS:
GASOLINE STATION: Any building, structure, premises, enclosure or other place within the village where containers or tanks, either portable or stationary,
and containing alcohol, gasoline, kerosene, ethyl gasoline or other vehicular fuels and lubricants, having a flashpoint below one hundred sixty five degrees
Fahrenheit (165°F), are kept or located for the purpose of selling, offering for sale or distributing any such liquids from such containers or tanks; provided,
however, that the provisions of this chapter shall not apply to any place where such inflammable liquids are kept or sold for medicinal or household
purposes only. The term "gasoline station" shall also exclude any facility maintained by the village for the purpose of servicing village owned vehicles.
STREET: Means and includes such highways as have been dedicated by either common law or statutory dedication as public streets and are actually in
use as such, and shall not be construed to include or mean service highways which are commonly known as alleys. (1988 Code § 3-8-1)
3-6-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall erect or alter any building or structure or install any tank, vessel or other container in or upon any premises in the village to use, operate
and maintain the same as a gasoline station, nor shall any person operate or maintain any of the existing gasoline stations in the village, without first
having obtained a license therefor. Gasoline stations with self-service must also offer full service to its customers. (1988 Code § 3-8-2)
3-6-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; PLANS AND SPECIFICATIONS:
Applications for licenses shall be made to the village clerk, in writing, over the signature of the owner or his agent, on printed blanks to be furnished by the
village. Every application shall be accompanied by complete plans and specifications, signed by the owner, which shall be in conformity with the Lake Bluff
building code (title 9, chapter 2 of this code). If such plans provide only for the installation of a tank, vessel or other container, the location, the space
desired to be used, the length, breadth and depth, together with the measurement in feet from the surface of the ground to the top of such tank, its
connections, fittings, openings and safety appliances, shall be shown therein. All plans shall be subject to review by the village fire chief. (1988 Code § 3-
8-3)
3-6-4: CONSENT OF LANDOWNER REQUIRED:
No gasoline station shall be constructed, operated or maintained in the village unless there is first obtained the written consent of the owners of a majority
of the land, measured by frontage along the public streets in the village, within the squared area, the center of which shall be the center of the proposed
location, and the sides of which shall be one thousand feet (1,000') long and at right angles to and parallel with the boundary of the street upon which such
gasoline station location abuts. (1988 Code § 3-8-4)
3-6-5: SITE INSPECTIONS; LICENSE FEE:
A. Initial Inspection; Fee: Before issuing such license, the building commissioner shall inspect or cause to be inspected the site of such proposed gasoline
station, and if the same is satisfactory and such use thereof is permitted by the ordinances of the village pertaining thereto, he shall so certify to the
village clerk, and thereupon, the applicant shall pay to the village clerk a license fee as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code, under the category
"license fees". The fee shall be paid prior to the issuance of such license and shall cover the cost of inspection thereof. (1988 Code § 3-8-5; amd. 2009
Code)
B. Other Inspections: No tank, container or other vessel located in or upon such site shall be covered over or used until the installation, material and
workmanship have been finally inspected, approved and certified by the building commissioner. All such facilities shall be subject to inspection by the
village fire chief at any time during business operations. (1988 Code § 3-8-5)
3-6-6: TERM OF LICENSE:
All licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter shall expire on April 30 following the date of issuance. If, at the time of the application for a license
under the provisions of this chapter, six (6) months or more have expired, the applicant shall be required to pay one-half (1/2) of such license fee. (1988
Code § 3-8-6)
3-6-7: NO SMOKING SIGNS:
The owner, occupant or lessee of any gasoline station shall install and maintain signs worded "No Smoking" in such numbers and locations as the fire
chief or building commissioner may require. (1988 Code § 3-8-7)
3-6-8: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
If any person obtaining a license hereunder shall at any time fail or neglect to comply with the terms of this chapter, then such license as may have been
issued may or shall be revoked by the fire chief or the building commissioner. (1988 Code § 3-8-8)
3-6-9: EFFECT ON BUILDING REQUIREMENTS:
Nothing herein contained shall be construed as in any way modifying the building code, requirements of the village ordinances relative to fees for building
permits and all ordinances amendatory thereto. (1988 Code § 3-8-9)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 111/493
3-6-10: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than the maximum provided in
section 1-4-1 of this code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed for each day during or on which such violation occurs or
continues. (1988 Code § 3-8-10; amd. 2009 Code)
Chapter 7
FOOD AND BEVERAGES
ARTICLE A. RESTAURANTS AND FOOD STORES
3-7A-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this article:
EMPLOYEE: Any person who shall handle food or drink during preparation, serving or sale, or who comes in contact with eating or cooking utensils, or
who is employed in a room in which food or drink is prepared, served or sold.
FOOD DEALER: Includes "restaurant", "itinerant restaurant", "food store" and "itinerant vendor" as defined herein.
FOOD STORE: Grocery store, butcher store, delicatessen store, confectionery store, bakery store, milk store, butter and egg store, fruit and vegetable
store, fish store, drugstore, ice cream store, or any combination of the foregoing, or any place where food or drink is prepared, handled, stored, offered for
sale or sold at wholesale or retail, and all vending and dispensing machines which contain or dispense such products.
HEALTH OFFICER: The health officer of the village or his authorized representative duly appointed by the health officer by and with the consent and
approval of the board of trustees, except as to sections 3-7A-2 and 3-7A-3 of this article where such term shall mean only the duly appointed health officer
of the village.
ITINERANT RESTAURANT: A restaurant operating for a temporary period in connection with a fair, carnival, circus, public exhibition or other similar
gathering.
ITINERANT VENDOR: Any person traveling from place to place who shall deal in, sell or offer for sale any article of food or drink at wholesale or retail in
the village and who does not operate within the village a regular, established store or warehouse for the merchandising of foods, and who does not
operate a restaurant or food store.
PERSON: Any individual, partnership, corporation or association.
RESTAURANT: Restaurant, coffee shop, cafeteria, short order cafe, luncheonette, tavern, sandwich stand, soda fountain, school lunch, kitchen, and all
other establishments where foods or drinks are sold, as well as kitchens or other places in which foods or drinks are prepared for sale elsewhere.
UTENSILS: Any kitchenware, tableware, glassware, cutlery, utensils, containers or other equipment with which food or drink comes in contact during
storage, preparation or serving. (1988 Code § 3-9A-1)
3-7A-2: PERMITS AND LICENSES REQUIRED; FEES:
A. Permits: It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a restaurant or food store in the village who does not possess an unrevoked permit from the
health officer, and any other governmental or regulatory body having jurisdiction. Only persons who comply with the requirements of this article and
such rules and regulations as may be adopted by the board of health shall be entitled to receive and retain such a permit. A person conducting an
itinerant restaurant, or an itinerant vendor, shall also be required to secure a permit. Permits shall not be transferable. Such a permit may be
temporarily suspended by the health officer as herein provided upon the violation by the holder of any of the terms of this article or of the rules and
regulations adopted by the board of health, or may be revoked after an opportunity for a hearing by the board of health upon serious or repeated
violations. (1988 Code § 3-9A-2)
B. Licenses: Each person keeping, maintaining or operating a "restaurant" or "food store" in the village, and each "itinerant restaurant" and each "itinerant
vendor", as defined in section 3-7A-1 of this article, shall annually, on or before May 1 of each year or prior to the commencement of such operations if
such operations are commenced after May 1 of the license year, procure a permit issued by the health officer as provided in this section and the county
health department, and shall pay to the village clerk, for each such establishment or privilege, a license fee as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code,
under the category "license fees"; whereupon, the village clerk shall issue a license to such person, which license shall be for a period not to exceed
one year ending the following April 30 unless otherwise revoked prior thereto. The fee for such license shall be as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code,
under the category "license fees", for each year or part thereof. (1988 Code § 3-9A-2; amd. 2009 Code)
3-7A-3: SAMPLING BY HEALTH OFFICER; RIGHT TO PROHIBIT SALE:
A. Examine Samples: Samples of food or drink offered for human consumption in the village may be taken and examined by the health officer or his
designee as often as may be necessary for the detection of unwholesomeness or adulteration. The health officer shall forbid the sale of any food or
drink found by him to be unwholesome, adulterated or unfit for human consumption, and shall cause the same to be forthwith removed from sale or
destroyed.
B. Sale Of Unwholesome Food Prohibited: No unwholesome or adulterated food or drink, or food or drink unfit for human consumption, shall be prepared,
stored, served or sold. (1988 Code § 3-9A-3)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 112/493
3-7A-4: INSPECTIONS BY HEALTH OFFICER:
A. Inspection Schedule; Reports: At least once every six (6) months the health officer shall inspect food stores, restaurants, itinerant restaurants and
itinerant vendors. One copy of the inspection report shall be given to the licensee. Another copy of the inspection report shall be filed with the records
of the health department.
B. Second Inspection; Degrading And Suspension: In case the health officer discovers the violation of any item of sanitation required for the grade then
held, he shall make a second inspection after the lapse of such time as he deems necessary for the defect to be remedied, and the second inspection
shall be used in determining compliance with the grade requirements of this article. Any violation of the same item of this article on such second
inspection shall justify immediate degrading or suspension of permit.
C. Applicants To Allow Inspections: The applicant for permit or the licensee shall, upon request of the health officer, permit inspection by the health officer
of the food or drink establishment, food or drink utensils, machinery, fixtures, furniture, conveyances and records used in connection therewith, and the
health officer shall have power to do so. (1988 Code § 3-9A-4)
3-7A-5: PREMISES SANITATION REQUIREMENTS:
A. Grade A: All grade A restaurants and food stores shall comply with all of the following items of sanitation:
1. Floors: The floors of all food and drink establishments, as defined in section 3-7A-1 of this article, shall be of such construction as to be easily
cleaned, shall be smooth and shall be kept clean and in good repair.
2. Walls And Ceilings: Walls and ceilings in all food and drink establishments, as defined in section 3-7A-1 of this article, shall be finished with
washable surfaces up to the level reached by splash or spray, and shall be kept clean and in good repair.
3. Doors And Windows: When insects are prevalent, all openings into the outer air in the food or drink establishment, as defined in section 3-7A-1 of
this article, shall be effectively screened and doors shall be self-closing, unless other effective means are provided to prevent the entrance of insects.
4. Lighting: All rooms in which food or drink are stored or prepared, or in which utensils are washed, shall be well lighted.
5. Ventilation: All rooms in which food or drink are stored, prepared or served, or in which utensils are washed, shall be well ventilated.
6. Toilet, Lavatory And Washroom Facilities: Adequate and conveniently located toilets and lavatories shall be provided for employees of restaurants
and food stores. The toilet rooms and lavatories shall be separate and apart from the room or rooms where the process of production, preparation,
manufacture, packing, storing, canning, selling and distributing is conducted. In establishments hereafter constructed, toilet rooms shall not open
directly into any room in which food, drink or utensils are handled or stored. Lavatories and washrooms shall be adjacent to toilet rooms and shall be
supplied with soap, running water and towels other than common towels which are prohibited hereby. The doors of all toilet and lavatory rooms shall
