trustees, and the cost of the premium of said bond to be borne by the village, said bond conditioned on the faithful performance of his official duties.
2. Oath: The chief of police shall also take the customary oath of office before entering upon the duties of such office.
3. Powers And Duties: The chief of police shall:
a. Be the commanding officer of all sworn police officers and civilian personnel employed by the village in the police department. The chief of police
shall perform such duties as are imposed upon him by law or ordinance and, in addition thereto, such other duties as may be assigned to him by
the village administrator. He shall, under the supervision of the village administrator, pursuant to guidance from the village board of trustees, have
full management and control of the police department, and all regulations and orders of the police department shall be promulgated through him.
The chief of police shall see that all members of the police department are prompt and faithful in the discharge of their duties and that they take
such measures as may be deemed expedient for the preservation of peace and good order and the enforcement of the laws and ordinances of the
village.
b. Cause the public peace to be preserved and to see that the laws and ordinances are enforced, and whenever any violation thereof shall come to
his knowledge, or be reported to him, he shall attend to the prosecution of the offender.
c. Be the custodian of all property provided for the use of the police department and shall also be the custodian of all stolen goods or other property
received and retained by police authority.
d. Be the keeper of the village public safety building and its jail and shall have the custody of all persons incarcerated therein.
e. Report to the village attorney all breaches of the village ordinances as in his judgment require village attorney attention, and shall aid the attorney
in the prosecution thereof.
f. Pay to the proper custodian thereof, all monies collected by him within two (2) days after receiving the same.
g. Report in writing to the village administrator at the beginning of each month, the activities of the police department, and such other information he
deems necessary or appropriate, and such other information requested by the village administrator.
B. Deputy Chief Of Police:
1. Oath: The deputy chief of police shall take the customary oath of office before entering upon the duties of such office.
2. Powers And Duties: The deputy chief of police shall:
a. Have those powers, duties, and responsibilities as established by the chief of police in consultation with the village administrator, pursuant to the
rules and regulations of the police department.
b. Have, in the absence of the chief of police, all of the powers, duties, and responsibilities of the chief of police as authorized by state statute and
this code.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 144/493
C. Residency: All newly appointed chiefs of police and deputy chiefs of police of the village shall reside within the village within twelve (12) months after
the date of their appointment unless otherwise authorized by the board of trustees. (Ord. 2014-4, 2-24-2014)
5-1-3: POLICE OFFICERS:
A. Qualifications:
1. All members of the police department shall be United States citizens and meet such additional qualifications as established from time to time by the
board of fire and police commissioners.
2. Police personnel shall reside either in the village limits or within a radius of ten (10) miles of the village limits within twelve (12) months after the date
of their appointment to the police department.
B. Neglect Of Duty: Any sworn member of the police department who shall neglect or refuse to perform any duty required by ordinance of the village or
who, in the discharge of his duties, shall be guilty of fraud, extortion, oppression, favoritism, wilful wrong or injustice, shall be subject to disciplinary
action before the board of fire and police commissioners of the village. (1988 Code § 7-1A-3)
5-1-4: AUXILIARY POLICE:
A. Appointment: The village administrator may, with the advice and consent of the village board of trustees, appoint auxiliary police officers in such number
as the village administrator shall from time to time deem necessary.
B. Supervisory Authority: Such auxiliary police officers shall at all times during the performance of their duties be subject to the direction and control of the
chief of police.
C. Duties: Such auxiliary police officers shall not be members of the regular police department. Such auxiliary police officers shall not supplement
members of the regular police department in the performance of their assigned and normal duties, except as otherwise provided herein. Such auxiliary
police officers shall only be assigned to perform the following duties:
1. To aid or direct traffic.
2. To aid in control of natural or manmade disasters.
3. To aid in case of civil disorder as directed by the chief of police; provided, that in cases which render it impractical for members of the regular police
department to perform the normal and regular police duties, the chief of police is hereby authorized to assign auxiliary police officers to perform such
normal and regular police duties.
D. Identification: Identification symbols worn by such auxiliary police officers shall be different and distinct from those used by members of the regular
police department.
E. Firearms: Such auxiliary police officers shall not carry firearms except with the permission of the chief of police, and while in uniform and in the
performance of their duties.
F. Conservators Of The Peace: Such auxiliary police officers when on duty shall also be conservators of the peace and shall have the powers as specified
in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3.1-15-25.
G. Training: Auxiliary police officers, prior to entering upon any of their duties, shall receive a course of training in the use of weapons and other police
procedures as shall be appropriate in the exercise of the powers conferred upon them under this section, which training and course of study shall be
determined and provided by the chief of police.
H. Fingerprinting; Background Check: Prior to the appointment of any auxiliary police officer, fingerprints shall be taken, and no person shall be appointed
as such auxiliary police officer if he has been convicted of a felony or other crime involving moral turpitude. (1988 Code § 7-1A-4)
5-1-5: POLICE PENSION FUND CONTRIBUTIONS:
A. Employee contributions to the police pension fund shall be paid by the village on behalf of all employees enrolled in the fund upon receipt of a ruling
from the internal revenue service that, pursuant to section 414(h) of the United States internal revenue code, such employer paid contributions are not
included as gross income until they are distributed or made available.
B. The payment shall be made by reducing the gross earnings payable to employees by the amount of the contributions and by making payment of such
amount directly to the fund.
C. Contributions, although designated as employee contributions, are being paid by the employer in lieu of contributions by the employee.
D. The employee does not have the option of choosing to receive the contributions directly instead of having them paid by the employer to the plan. (Ord.
92-31, 11-23-1992)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 145/493
5-1-6: PENALTY:
Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than the
maximum provided in section 1-4-1 of this code for each and every offense. (1988 Code § 7-1A-5; amd. 2009 Code)
Chapter 2
FIRE DEPARTMENT
5-2-1: ESTABLISHED; COMPOSITION; DUTIES:
A. Department Established; Composition: There is hereby established a department of the municipal government of the village which shall be known as
the fire department and which shall embrace one fire chief, fire officers, a secretary, a treasurer and the members of the fire department. (1988 Code
§ 8-1-1)
B. Duties Generally: The fire department shall respond and assume control of all fires and other situations that threaten the lives or property of the
residents of the village, except those that are the duties of the police department. (1988 Code § 8-1-1; amd. 2009 Code)
5-2-2: COMPENSATION:
The board of trustees may, from time to time, by resolution or ordinance, provide for such compensation for the fire chief and members of the fire
department as it deems just and reasonable. (1988 Code § 8-1-2)
5-2-3: FIRE CHIEF1:
A. Employment And Dismissal:
1. Term Of Employment: A person shall be employed by the village as fire chief and shall be the head of the fire department. Such employment shall be
by ordinance or resolution of the board of trustees and shall continue until a successor shall be employed.
2. Authority To Discharge: The village president shall have the right to discharge the fire chief; provided, that the president shall report such discharge
to the board of trustees at their next regular meeting. If such discharge is not concurred by a majority of the members present at said meeting, the
fire chief shall be reemployed.
B. Powers And Duties:
1. Manage Department; Employ And Remove Members: The fire chief shall have the management and control of all matters and things pertaining to
said fire department. The fire chief shall employ and remove officers and members of the fire department. Appeals to the termination of any officer or
member may be made to the village administrator.
2. Authority And Control: The fire chief shall have sole and absolute control and command over all persons connected with the fire department of the
village while on duty.
3. Establish Rules And Regulations: The fire chief shall possess full power and authority over the fire department organization, government and
discipline, and to that end may prescribe and establish, from time to time, such rules and regulations as deemed advisable, subject to the approval of
the village administrator.
4. Custody Of Equipment: The fire chief shall have the custody of the engines, equipment and property belonging to the fire department.
5. Investigate Fires; Right Of Entry: The fire chief or other fire department members as designated by the fire chief shall investigate the cause and
origin of all fires and other incidents responded to by the fire department, as well. The fire department shall have the right to enter upon the premises
where an emergency has occurred to perform such investigation.
6. Submit Reports: The fire chief shall submit a monthly report to the board of trustees, via the village administrator, listing the number and types of fire
department responses, training received by the fire department members, and any unusual occurrences. In addition, an annual report shall be
submitted in January of each year to the board of trustees through the village administrator, showing the total annual responses by the fire
department by category, description of buildings and property destroyed or damaged, and any other information, statistics or suggestions the fire
chief feels the board of trustees should know regarding the response capabilities of the fire department, and the causes and origins of fires
responded to by the fire department.
7. Attend Fires: It shall be the duty of the fire chief, if the chief is able, to attend all fires happening in the village, and in case of the absence of the fire
chief from any fire, it shall be the duty of another officer to take charge of the department, and during the absence of the chief, such officer shall have
and exercise all the powers of the fire chief.
8. Examine Dangerous Buildings: The fire chief shall examine all buildings or walls reported dangerous or damaged by fire or accident and shall,
whenever necessary, make a report of the condition thereof to the board of trustees.
9. Prescribe Limits At Emergency Scene: The fire chief, or other officer in command, may prescribe limits in the vicinity of any emergency scene, within
which only those given permission by a fire department officer may go, and the police department shall, on request of the fire chief or other officer in
command, enforce the provisions of this subsection B9.
10. Remove Property: The fire chief, or other officer in command, may cause the removal of any property whenever it shall become necessary for the
preservation of such property from fire, or to prevent the spreading of fire, or to protect adjoining property. The fire chief may direct the members of
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 146/493
the fire department to cut down or remove any building, erection, fence or trees for the purposes of checking the progress of any fire. (1988 Code
§ 8-1-3)
5-2-4: OFFICERS OF DEPARTMENT:
A. Secretary: A secretary of the fire department shall be elected by the members of the fire department at a meeting to be held in May of each year. The
secretary shall keep a record of all meetings of the fire department and perform such other duties as directed by the fire chief.
B. Treasurer:
1. Election And Duties: A treasurer of the fire department shall be elected by the members of the fire department at their regular meeting held in May of
each year. The treasurer shall keep a record of all monies received on account of the foreign fire insurance tax and keep such monies separate and
apart from all other funds. The proceeds of said foreign fire insurance tax shall be paid out only on checks signed by the fire chief and treasurer after
an authorization vote of the majority of members present at a regular or special fire department meeting. (1988 Code § 8-1-5)
2. Bond: The village shall secure a bond to be executed by the treasurer to the village. The premiums for such bond shall be paid for by the village. The
penal sum of said bond shall be equal to twice the amount of the funds expected to be produced from the foreign fire insurance tax. The treasurer
shall submit all records for the foreign fire insurance tax to the auditors designated by the village board whenever requested. (1988 Code § 8-1-5;
amd. 2009 Code)
5-2-5: FEES FOR SERVICES OUTSIDE CORPORATE LIMITS:
A. Services Provided On Fee Basis: Subject to the provisions contained in subsection C of this section, fire protection service shall be afforded on a fee
basis as provided for herein to those residents and entities in those portions of Shoreacres, Arden Shore North and Arden Shore South not situated
within the corporate limits of the village. (Ord. 92-15, 7-13-1992)
B. Fees:
1. Responses And Services: The fees for the following responses and services shall be pursuant to the service agreement:
a. Each fire engine dispatched to an out of district emergency.
b. Each pickup truck dispatched to an out of district emergency.
c. Each individual dispatched to an out of district emergency.
d. The cost of any supplies used or expended during an emergency incident including, but not limited to, foam, salvage covers, etc.
e. Notwithstanding anything contained herein to the contrary, minimum charge for calls, whether genuine or false. (Ord. 92-15, 7-13-1992; amd. 2009
Code)
2. Proration: No proration will be made for a part of an hour on any of the above fees.
C. Response At Discretion Of Department Officer: No response will be made by the fire department to fire calls from owners of property outside the
corporate limits of the village in the event of prior or coincident fire calls involving property located in the village, or if, for any reason, in the judgment of
the officer then in charge at the headquarters of the fire department, such response would jeopardize fire protection service to the village. (Ord. 92-15,
7-13-1992)
5-2-6: PROHIBITED ACTS:
A. Refuse To Obey Orders; Hindering Firefighters: All persons who are present at an incident shall be subject to the orders of the fire chief and other
officers of the fire department. In case any person shall refuse to obey any such orders, such person shall be fined as provided for herein. Any person
who shall wilfully offer any hindrance to any officer or firefighter in the performance of his duty at an emergency incident, or who injures, destroys or
defaces any fire department equipment shall, for each offense, be fined as provided for hereinafter.
B. Driving Over Fire Hose: No person shall drive any vehicle over unprotected equipment of the fire department unless directed or permitted by a member
of the fire department. Any person violating any of the provisions of this subsection shall be responsible for the cost of damage or repair or replacement
of such equipment, and the fine provided in section 5-2-7 of this chapter.
C. Obstructing Fire Hydrants: No person shall in any manner obstruct the use of any fire hydrant, or have or place any material within five feet (5') in any
direction of said fire hydrant. Any person violating any of the provisions of this subsection shall be fined as provided in section 5-2-7 of this chapter.
(1988 Code § 8-1-3)
5-2-7: PENALTY:
Any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with any provisions of this chapter shall be subject to a fine of not less than
seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more than the maximum provided in section 1-4-1 of this code. (1988 Code § 8-1-6; amd. 2009 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 147/493
Chapter 3
FIRE PREVENTION BUREAU
5-3-1: ESTABLISHED; COMPOSITION:
There is hereby established in the village a bureau of fire prevention. The members of the bureau of fire prevention shall consist of the chief of the fire
department, fire inspectors of the fire department, and village trustees who are members of the public safety committee. (1988 Code § 8-2-1)
5-3-2: DUTIES:
A. Enforce Laws: It shall be the duty of the bureau of fire prevention to enforce all laws and ordinances of the village having as their object, or relating to,
the prevention of fires and the preservation of lives and property of the residents of the village.
B. Recommendations To Village Board: It shall be the further duty of the bureau of fire prevention to investigate and to recommend to the board of trustees
such additional ordinances or amendments to existing ordinances as shall be deemed necessary for safeguarding life and property in the village.
C. Investigations: The bureau of fire prevention shall cause to be made an investigation of all buildings, structures or places used for manufacturing,
storage or commercial purposes, or occupied or frequented by large numbers of people, including, but not limited to, all school buildings, public halls,
churches, hospitals, theaters, hotels, apartment buildings and all other places of amusement, recreation or employment, for the purposes of
determining the safety of the occupants of such buildings, structures or places, in the event of fire, panic or accident.
D. Review Building Plans And Specifications:
1. Review Of Plans: The bureau of fire prevention shall cause to be reviewed all plans for new or altered premises in the village, with the exception of
single-family or two-family residences, and determine if any occupancy permit may be issued prior to occupancy of such premises.
2. Noncompliance; Notice To Remedy: In case it shall be found that any village ordinance is not being complied with, the fire inspector shall give written
notice to the owner, occupant, lessee or person in charge or control of such premises to make such changes or alterations to bring the premises into
compliance with village ordinances within fifteen (15) days from date of notice.
3. Issue Citation: In case such violations are not corrected within the specified time shown on the notice of violation, a citation shall be issued to the
violator by the inspector.
4. Right Of Entry: For the purposes of inspection, a fire inspector may enter any building or premises within the village for the purpose of inspection
under the provisions of this chapter.
E. Require Key Boxes: Whenever access to a structure will be unduly difficult because of secured openings, and where immediate access will be required
for lifesaving and fire protection purposes, the chief of the fire department or the fire prevention bureau may require a key box to be installed in a
readily accessible location. The key box shall be of a type approved by the chief of the fire department or the fire prevention bureau. (1988 Code § 8-2-
2)
5-3-3: FIRE PREVENTION CODE ADOPTED:
In order to provide for rules and regulations for the purpose of enforcement of this title, and establishment of the standards of safety, and the protection
against fire and other hazards, there is hereby adopted by this chapter, the fire prevention code of the National Fire Protection Association, NFPA, 2004
edition, and its incorporated standards and codes as published in the national fire codes of the National Fire Protection Association and listed in annex A
of the NFPA fire prevention code for the year 2004. The same are hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein, except as
otherwise provided herein to the contrary. Whenever the term "fire prevention code of the National Fire Protection Association, NFPA", is used herein, such
reference shall be to said code currently in effect, and all amendments thereto. Not less than one copy of the adopted issue of the fire prevention code of
the National Fire Protection Association, NFPA, and the adopted standards and codes of the national fire code shall be filed in the office of the village
clerk, and the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the village. (1988 Code § 8-2-3; amd. 2009 Code)
5-3-4: EXEMPTIONS:
Except as provided in subsection 5-3-2D of this chapter to the contrary, the provisions of this chapter shall not apply to one- or two-family dwellings. (1988
Code § 8-2-4)
5-3-5: POLICE POWERS OF VILLAGE:
This chapter shall be deemed in the exercise of the police powers of the village for the preservation and protection of the public health, peace, safety and
welfare and all the provisions hereof shall be liberally construed for that purpose. (1988 Code § 8-2-5)
5-3-6: HAZARDOUS WASTE REGULATIONS ENFORCEMENT:
A. Fire Prevention Bureau: It shall be the duty and responsibility of the fire prevention bureau of the village to administer the hazardous materials
ordinances and regulations of the village1.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 148/493
B. Fire Chief: The fire chief shall manage, control and command all persons in carrying out such responsibilities and, in coordination with the chief of
police, shall enforce the ordinances and regulations of the village. (Ord. 88-21, 4-25-1988)
5-3-7: PROSECUTION DOES NOT RELIEVE COMPLIANCE:
Prosecution of any owner or occupant of any violation of this chapter shall not relieve such person from compliance with this chapter or any provision
hereof. (1988 Code § 8-2-6)
5-3-8: VIOLATIONS; PENALTY:
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter or the code hereby adopted, or who shall fail to comply therewith or who shall build in
violation of any details, statements, specifications or plans submitted or approved thereunder, or shall operate not in accordance with the provisions of any
certificate, permit or approval issued thereunder, or who shall fail to comply with any order of the bureau of fire prevention or its inspectors, shall, upon
conviction thereof, be fined in an amount not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more than the maximum provided in section 1-4-1 of this code.
The imposition of a penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation, nor shall the violation be permitted to continue. Each and every day a violation
is allowed to continue or exist shall be deemed a separate violation of this chapter. (1988 Code § 8-2-7; amd. 2009 Code)
Chapter 4
AUTHORIZED EMERGENCY VEHICLES
5-4-1: DESIGNATION OF AUTHORIZED EMERGENCY VEHICLES:
Pursuant to section 1-105 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-105, the Village Administrator shall have the authority to
designate vehicles operated by the Village's Police and Fire Chiefs and Deputy Chiefs as "authorized emergency vehicles", as defined by the Illinois
Vehicle Code. Upon a vehicle's designation as an authorized emergency vehicle, such vehicle shall have the authorities and rights granted to authorized
emergency vehicles by the Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-101, et seq., and any other applicable State Statutes. The Village
Administrator shall also have the authority to revoke such designation. (Ord. 2018-28, 11-12-2018)
5-4-2: NOTICE TO VILLAGE BOARD PRIOR TO DESIGNATING AN AUTHORIZED EMERGENCY VEHICLE:
The Village Administrator shall notify the Village Board within seven (7) days upon designating a vehicle an authorized emergency vehicle pursuant to
section 5-4-1 of this chapter. Upon receipt of the notice submitted by the Village Administrator, or any time thereafter, the Village Board shall have the
authority to revoke such designation by resolution duly adopted. (Ord. 2018-28, 11-12-2018)
Chapter 5
CIVIL EMERGENCIES
5-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
CIVIL EMERGENCY: A. A riot or unlawful assembly characterized by the use of actual force or violence or any threat to use force if accompanied by
immediate power to execute by three (3) or more persons acting together without authority of law; or
B. Any natural disaster or manmade calamity, including flood, conflagration, cyclone, tornado, earthquake or explosion within the corporate limits of the
village, resulting in the death or injury of persons or the destruction of property to such an extent that extraordinary measures must be taken to
protect the public health, safety and welfare.
CURFEW: A prohibition against any person walking, running, loitering, standing or motoring upon any alley, street, highway, public property or vacant
premises within the corporate limits of the village, excepting officials of any governmental unit and persons officially designated to duty with reference to
said civil emergency. (1988 Code § 8-3B-1)
5-5-2: PROCLAMATION OF EMERGENCY:
A. Issuance By President: Whenever an emergency, as defined in section 5-5-1 of this chapter, exists, the village president shall declare the existence by
means of a written proclamation setting forth the facts which constitute the emergency.
B. Posting And Publication: Upon issuing the proclamation herein authorized, the chief of police shall notify the news media situated within the village, and
shall cause three (3) copies of the proclamation declaring the existence of the emergency to be posted at the following places within the village: the
village hall, the police station and the post office.
C. Effect Of Proclamation: The proclamation herein authorized shall be effective for a period of forty eight (48) hours unless sooner terminated by a
proclamation of the village president indicating that the civil emergency no longer exists. The village president shall have the power to reproclaim the
existence of a civil emergency at the end of each forty eight (48) hour period during the time the said civil emergency exists. (1988 Code § 8-3B-2)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 149/493
5-5-3: CURFEW:
After proclamation of a civil emergency by the village president, he may order a general curfew applicable to such geographical areas of the village or to
the village as a whole, as he deems advisable, and applicable during such hours of the day or night as he deems necessary in the interest of the public
safety and welfare. The provision of this code relating to curfew on minors1 shall be superseded by the provisions of this section when a curfew is imposed
pursuant to the provisions contained herein. (1988 Code § 8-3B-3)
5-5-4: ADDITIONAL ORDERS:
After the proclamation of a civil emergency, the village president may also, in the interest of public safety and welfare, make any or all of the following
orders:
A. Closing Liquor Establishments: Order the closing of all retail liquor stores, including taverns and private clubs or portions thereof, wherein the
consumption of intoxicating liquor and beer is permitted.
B. Restrictions On Sale Of Liquid Flammables: Order the discontinuance of selling, distributing or giving away gasoline or other liquid flammable or
combustible products in any container other than a gasoline tank properly affixed to a motor vehicle.
C. Discontinue Firearms And Ammunition Sales: Order the discontinuance of selling, distributing, dispensing or giving away of any firearms or ammunition
of any character whatsoever.
D. Issue Other Orders: Issue such other orders as are imminently necessary for the protection of life and property. (1988 Code § 8-3B-4)
5-5-5: EFFECT ON POLICE AND FIRE DEPARTMENTS:
Nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed to impair the powers contained in this code giving powers to the police and fire departments, but shall
be construed together with existing ordinances now in effect for the safety and welfare of the citizens of the village. (1988 Code § 8-3B-5)
5-5-6: PENALTY:
Any person violating the provisions of this chapter or executive order issued pursuant hereto shall be guilty of an offense against the village, and shall be
punishable by a fine not to exceed the maximum provided in section 1-4-1 of this code. (1988 Code § 8-3B-6; amd. 2009 Code)
Chapter 6
ALARM SYSTEMS
5-6-1: TITLE:
This chapter shall be known as the ALARM PERMIT ORDINANCE OF THE VILLAGE OF LAKE BLUFF. (1988 Code § 7-5-1)
5-6-2: PURPOSE AND SCOPE:
The purpose of this chapter is to set forth regulations concerning alarm systems located within, or causing alarms to be transmitted to, any facility of the
village, the establishment of fees therefor and the fines for violations thereof. This chapter shall be applicable to new and existing alarms and alarm
systems. (1988 Code § 7-5-2)
5-6-3: DEFINITIONS:
ALARM SYSTEM: Any mechanical, electrical, electronic or other type of devices (or interconnected group of devices serving one location) of any nature or
description, which act as a method of detecting fire, the discharge of gases, unauthorized access into a building, structure, facility, area, or property, real or
personal, which, when actuated, emit a sound or transmit a signal or message by any means of communication, and all other warning systems for smoke,
fire, gas, or emergency conditions, except for interior smoke, heat or gas alarms or detectors that do not transmit a message outside of the premises or
emit an exterior signal or alarm, and audible alarms affixed to motor vehicles and motorcycles.
DIRECTLY CONNECTED ALARM SYSTEMS: Any alarm system which is directly connected to, by dedicated wires, or similar equipment, and causes an
alarm to be displayed at any facility of the village or any other municipality or agency which provides alarm monitoring services for the village.
FALSE ALARM: Any alarm which is caused by equipment malfunction, by the setting off, intentionally or unintentionally, of an alarm by a member,
occupant, employee, invitee, or licensee of the premises, or an alarm call from a dispatching facility or another governmental agency or private entity,
without any existing emergency. (1988 Code § 7-5-3)
5-6-4: ALARM SYSTEM PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 150/493
A. Permit Required; Renewal: An alarm system permit shall be obtained prior to the installation of any alarm system within the village or which is designed
to cause an alarm to be transmitted to any facility of the village, and shall be renewed annually as of May 1 of each calendar year.
B. Application For Permit: Application for an alarm system permit shall be made at the village hall on such forms as are prescribed by the village.
Application forms shall require the applicant to provide the name, address and telephone number of the person or persons who will render service or
repairs during any hour of the day or night, and if more than one individual is designated, the hours of contact for such individual and the names and
current addresses and current telephone numbers of at least three (3) individuals who have keys or access to the premises in the event of any
emergency. In addition, applicants for such permits shall agree to furnish any changes in the information provided in an application within ten (10) days
after such change occurs.
C. Separate Applications And Fees; Records Confidential: Separate application forms and fees shall be required for each alarm system. All applications
and permits shall be further subject to all ordinances, resolutions and administrative directives of the village; provided further, that all such applications
and permits shall be considered confidential, and all records thereon shall be maintained only in the office of the police department. (1988 Code § 7-5-
4)
5-6-5: STANDARDS OF CONSTRUCTION AND MAINTENANCE:
Standards for the construction and maintenance of alarm systems shall be as promulgated by the village. These standards and regulations shall include
adherence to the electrical and building regulations of the village, and any other related ordinances. All alarm systems shall be constructed and maintained
so as to distinguish between a police alarm type call, a fire alarm type call, or a medical emergency. Whenever technically feasible, all alarm systems shall
contain devices which will enable monitoring personnel to ascertain whether an alarm is actuated by trouble in the system or whether it is a true alarm.
(1988 Code § 7-5-5)
5-6-6: BUILDING PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
A. Filing Of Plans: No alarm system shall be installed within the village unless a building permit is issued therefor by the building commissioner. Except for
single-family residences, plans for fire alarms shall also be forwarded to the fire department for its review and approval. Except for single-family
residences, no directly connected alarm systems shall be allowed into village facilities for fire alarms unless a Knox Box of such type as specified by
the fire chief is provided by the alarm permit holder. No plans need be filed or reviewed for alarms on single-family residences, except the same shall
be made available for review by the building inspector prior to and during installation. Building permit fees shall be waived for alarm systems installed in
single-family residences.
B. Bond: Unless waived by the village, building permit application forms shall be accompanied by a surety bond from the installer for the applicant to the
village, for the benefit of the village and the applicant, in an amount not less than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) conditioned upon the faithful
performance by the installer of his duties and obligations to the license applicant. (1988 Code § 7-5-6)
5-6-7: ENTERING PREMISES DURING EMERGENCY:
The filing of an application for an alarm system permit shall constitute consent for police and fire department personnel to take whatever action is
reasonable and necessary to gain access to the premises for which an alarm has been received to ascertain the nature and extent of any emergency. No
liability shall be imposed upon the village or its police or fire department personnel in the event any damages to the premises, or any person therein, result
due to failure to gain access, or in the event damages result in the process of gaining access. The permit applicant shall certify that he or she has full
power and authority to execute such consent, or shall have the signature of the property owner or tenant affixed to the permit request. (1988 Code § 7-5-7)
5-6-8: FEES AND CHARGES:
The following permit fees are hereby established for the issuance and renewal of alarm system permits:
A. Within Village: An annual registration fee in the amount as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code, under the category "alarm fees", shall be paid for the
issuance and renewal of each permit for an alarm system located in the village.
B. Outside Village: An annual registration fee in the amount as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code, under the category "alarm fees", shall be paid for the
issuance and renewal of each permit for an alarm system located outside of the village. No such permits shall be issued without the approval of the
village administrator.
C. Initial Connection Fee: In addition to the fees provided in subsections A and B of this section, the fees in the amounts as set out in section 1-12-3 of this
code, under the category "alarm fees", shall be paid for the issuance and renewal of each permit for a directly connected alarm system. (1988 Code
§ 7-5-8; amd. 2009 Code)
D. Exceptions To Connection Fees And Maintenance Charges:
1. When any alarm system for which a connection fee, relay deposit fee or maintenance charge is imposed, is connected directly into the system of
another municipality, or agency, the connection fee, relay deposit fee, and maintenance charge of such other municipality shall be paid to that
municipality, and shall not be due to the village; provided further, that such alarm shall also be registered annually with the village, and the fee paid
therefor.
2. No fee shall be due for registration of an alarm system for individual medical emergency purposes only.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 151/493
E. Proration Of Fees: No proration of fees for any permit shall be made except as specifically provided for herein. (1988 Code § 7-5-8)
5-6-9: MAINTENANCE REQUIREMENTS:
All holders of alarm system permits shall maintain their alarms in serviceable condition at all times. All alarms emitting an audible sound outside the
premises shall be equipped with an automatic reset system which shall stop the alarm after ten (10) minutes of warning sounds if not otherwise manually
reset. All other alarm systems shall have a reset function which prevents a continuous alarm from being activated for a period in excess of thirty (30)
minutes. (1988 Code § 7-5-9)
5-6-10: PENALTIES; EXEMPTIONS:
A. The village shall determine and assess penalties for false alarms or malfunctions in accordance with the following provisions:
1. Definition: The term "twelve (12) month period", as used in this subsection, shall mean the twelve (12) months beginning on January 1 and ending
on December 31 of any one year.
2. False Alarms; Permit Holders Liable:
a. For the first four (4) false alarms in a twelve (12) month period, a written warning notice will be given to the permit holder. A similar warning notice
will be given to the property owner of the premises, its tenant, and/or the person in control of the premises. (1988 Code § 7-5-10)
b. For the fifth false alarm in a twelve (12) month period, a penalty as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code, under the category "alarm fees", will be
assessed against the permit holder.
c. For the sixth false alarm in a twelve (12) month period, a penalty as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code, under the category "alarm fees", will be
assessed against the permit holder.
d. For the seventh false alarm in a twelve (12) month period, a penalty as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code, under the category "alarm fees", will
be assessed against the permit holder.
e. For the eighth false alarm in a twelve (12) month period, a penalty as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code, under the category "alarm fees", will be
assessed against the permit holder.
f. For the ninth false alarm in a twelve (12) month period, a penalty as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code, under the category "alarm fees", will be
assessed against the permit holder.
g. For every false alarm over nine (9) in a twelve (12) month period, a penalty as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code, under the category "alarm
fees", will be assessed against the permit holder. (1988 Code § 7-5-10; amd. 2009 Code)
3. Property Owner Or Occupant Liability: In addition thereto, the property owner of the premises, its tenant or person in control shall also be subject to
the respective penalties set forth in subsection A1 of this section.
4. Malfunction, Excused Alarm: In any instance where an alarm malfunctions, and the permit owner, property owner of the premises, tenant or person
in control has the same repaired, and the repair facility certifies that the cause of the malfunction has been corrected, said alarm shall be considered
an excused alarm and not a false alarm.
5. Continuous Ringing: The permit of any directly connected alarm system that malfunctions and rings for a period of two (2) or more hours shall be
subject to suspension or revocation.
6. Penalty: Any person who fails to secure or maintain a current alarm system permit for an alarm system located within the village, or an alarm system
which causes an alarm to be received by the police or fire department of the village shall be subject to a fine in the amount of twenty five dollars
($25.00) for the first violation thereof, and fifty dollars ($50.00) for the second and subsequent violations thereafter within any twelve (12) month
period. Each day that an alarm is not registered after notice of the second violation thereof shall constitute a separate offense for which a separate
and additional penalty may be recovered. All penalties shall be paid within ten (10) days after written notice. (1988 Code § 7-5-10)
B. Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter, for which a specific fine is not otherwise prescribed, shall, upon conviction thereof, be
fined in the amount of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than the maximum provided in section 1-4-1 of this code. (1988 Code § 7-5-12; amd.
2009 Code)
C. No penalty shall be assessed for any false alarm caused by contractors working in or near premises where the alarm is located. (1988 Code § 7-5-11)
Chapter 7
GENERAL OFFENSES
5-7-1: OFFENSES AGAINST PERSONS:
5-7-1-1: ASSAULT:
No person shall commit an assault in the village. A person commits assault when, without lawful authority, he engages in conduct which places another in
reasonable apprehension of receiving a battery. (1988 Code § 7-2-1-1)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 152/493
5-7-1-2: BATTERY:
No person shall commit a battery in the village. A person commits battery if he intentionally or knowingly without legal justification and by any means:
A. Causes bodily harm to an individual; or
B. Makes physical contact of an insulting or provoking nature with an individual. (1988 Code § 7-2-1-2)
5-7-1-3: SOLICITING A MISDEMEANOR:
A. Elements Of The Offense: No person shall solicit a misdemeanor within the village. A person commits solicitation when, with intent that an offense be
committed, other than a felony, he commands, encourages or requests another to commit that offense. (1988 Code § 7-2-1-3)
B. Penalty: A person convicted of solicitation may be fined not to exceed the maximum provided by section 1-4-1 of this code. (1988 Code § 7-2-1-3; amd.
2009 Code)
5-7-1-4: ATTEMPT:
A. Prohibition: No person shall attempt to commit any offense defined in this chapter.
1. Elements Of The Offense: A person commits an attempt when, with intent to commit a specific offense, he does any act which constitutes a
substantial step towards the commission of that offense.
2. Impossibility: It shall not be a defense to a charge of attempt that because of a misapprehension of the circumstances it would have been impossible
for the accused to commit the offense attempted.
B. Sentence: A person convicted of an attempt may be fined not to exceed the maximum provided for the offense attempted. (1988 Code § 7-2-1-4)
5-7-1-5: RECKLESS CONDUCT:
No person shall engage in any reckless conduct in the village. A person who causes bodily harm to or endangers the bodily safety of an individual by any
means commits reckless conduct if he performs recklessly the acts which cause the harm or endangers safety, whether they otherwise are lawful or
unlawful. (1988 Code § 7-2-1-5)
5-7-2: OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY:
5-7-2-1: THEFT UNDER THREE HUNDRED DOLLARS:
It is unlawful to commit the offense of theft under three hundred dollars ($300.00) in the village. A person commits theft when, with respect to property
having a value less than three hundred dollars ($300.00), he knowingly:
A. Obtains or exerts unauthorized control over property of the owner; or
B. Obtains by deception, control over property of the owner; or
C. Obtains by threat, control over property of the owner; or
D. Obtains control over stolen property knowing the property to have been stolen or under such circumstances as would reasonably induce him to believe
that the property was stolen, and:
1. Intends to deprive the owner permanently of the use or benefit of the property; or
2. Knowingly uses, conceals or abandons the property in such manner as to deprive the owner permanently of such use or benefit; or
3. Uses, conceals or abandons the property knowing such use, concealment or abandonment probably will deprive the owner permanently of such use
or benefit. (1988 Code § 7-2-2-1)
5-7-2-2: RETAIL THEFT:
A. Elements Of The Offense: A person commits the offense of retail theft when he or she knowingly:
1. Takes possession of, carries away, transfers, or causes to be carried away or transferred, any merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for sale
in a retail mercantile establishment with the intention of retaining such merchandise or with the intention of depriving the merchant permanently of the
possession, use or benefit of such merchandise without paying the full retail value of such merchandise; or
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 153/493
2. Alters, transfers, or removes any label, price tag, marking, indicia of value, or any other markings which aid in determining value affixed to any
merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for sale in a retail mercantile establishment and attempts to purchase such merchandise personally or
in consort with another at less than the full retail value with the intention of depriving the merchant of the full retail value of such merchandise; or
3. Transfers any merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for sale in a retail mercantile establishment from the container in or on which such
merchandise is displayed to any other container with the intention of depriving the merchant of the full retail value of such merchandise; or
4. Underrings with the intention of depriving the merchant of the full retail value of the merchandise; or
5. Removes a shopping cart from the premises of a retail mercantile establishment without the consent of the merchant given at the time of such
removal with the intention of depriving the merchant permanently of the possession, use or benefit of such cart; or
6. Represents to a merchant that he or another is the lawful owner of property knowing that such representation is false, and conveys or attempts to
convey that property to a merchant who is the owner of the property in exchange for money, merchandise credit, or other property of the merchant;
or
7. Uses or possesses any theft detection shielding device or theft detection device remover with the intention of using such device to deprive the
merchant permanently of the possession, use or benefit of any merchandise displayed, held, stored, or offered for sale in a retail mercantile
establishment without paying the full retail value of such merchandise; or (1988 Code § 7-2-2-2)
8. Obtains or exerts unauthorized control over property of the owner and thereby intends to deprive the owner permanently of the use or benefit of the
property when a lessee of the personal property of another fails to return it to the owner, or if the lessee fails to pay the full retail value of such
property to the lessor in satisfaction of any contractual provision requiring such, within ten (10) days after written demand from the owner for its
return. A notice in writing, given after the expiration of the leasing agreement, by registered mail, to the lessee at the address given by the lessee and
shown on the leasing agreement shall constitute proper demand; and (2009 Code)
9. The value of the merchandise does not exceed one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). (1988 Code § 7-2-2-2)
B. Presumptions: If any person conceals upon his or her person or among his or her belongings, unpurchased merchandise displayed, held, stored or
offered for sale in a retail mercantile establishment, and removes that merchandise beyond the last known station for receiving payments for that
merchandise in that retail mercantile establishment, such person shall be presumed to have possessed, carried away or transferred such merchandise
with the intention of retaining it or with the intention of depriving the merchant permanently of the possession, use or benefit of such merchandise
without paying the full retail value of such merchandise.
C. Detention:
1. Any merchant who has reasonable grounds to believe that a person has committed retail theft may detain such person, on or off the premises of a
retail mercantile establishment, in a reasonable manner and for a reasonable length of time for all or any of the following purposes:
a. To request identification.
b. To verify such identification.
c. To make reasonable inquiry as to whether such person has in his possession unpurchased merchandise and to make reasonable investigation of
the ownership of such merchandise.
d. To inform a peace officer of the detention of the person and surrender that person to the custody of a peace officer.
e. In the case of a minor, to inform a peace officer, the parents, guardian or other private person interested in the welfare of that minor of this
detention and to surrender custody of such minor to such person.
2. A merchant may make a detention as permitted herein off the premises of a retail mercantile establishment only if such detention is pursuant to an
immediate pursuit of such person.
3. A merchant shall be deemed to have reasonable grounds to make a detention for the purposes of this section if the merchant detains a person
because such person has in his possession either a theft detection shielding device or a theft detection device remover. (2009 Code)
5-7-2-3: LIBRARY THEFT:
No person shall commit the offense of library theft within the village. A person commits the offense of library theft when such person:
A. Knowingly and intentionally removes any library material having an aggregate value of less than three hundred dollars ($300.00) from the premises of a
library facility without authority to do so; or
B. Knowingly and intentionally conceals any library material having an aggregate value of not more than three hundred dollars ($300.00) upon his or her
person or among his or her belongings, while still in the premises of a library facility, and in such manner that the library material is not visible through
ordinary observation although there may be some notice of its presence, and removes such library material beyond the last point in the premises of
that library facility at which library material may be borrowed in accordance with procedures established by that library facility for the borrowing of
library material; or
C. With the intent to deceive, borrows or attempts to borrow any library material having an aggregate value of not more than three hundred dollars
($300.00) from a library facility by: 1) use of a library card issued to another without the other's consent; or 2) use of a library card knowing that it is
revoked, canceled or expired; or 3) use of a library card knowing that it is falsely made, counterfeit or materially altered; or
D. Borrows from a library facility library material which has an aggregate value of fifty dollars ($50.00) or more pursuant to an agreement with or procedure
established by the library facility for the return of such library material, and wilfully, without good cause, fails to return the library material so borrowed in
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 154/493
accordance with such agreement or procedure, and further, wilfully, without good cause, fails to return such library material within thirty (30) days after
receiving written notice by registered mail from the library facility demanding the return of such library material. (1988 Code § 7-2-2-3)
5-7-2-4: MUTILATION AND VANDALISM OF LIBRARY MATERIAL:
No person shall mutilate and vandalize any library material within the village. A person commits the offense of mutilation and vandalism of library material
when such person knowingly tears, marks on, maliciously renders imperfect or otherwise damages or destroys library material having an aggregate value
of three hundred dollars ($300.00) or less. (1988 Code § 7-2-2-4)
5-7-2-5: CRIMINAL DAMAGE TO PROPERTY:
It shall be unlawful for any person to criminally damage property of another within the village. A person commits an illegal act when such person:
A. Knowingly damages any property of another without his consent, if the damage to property does not exceed three hundred dollars ($300,00); or
B. Recklessly, by means of fire or explosive, damages property of another, if the damage to property does not exceed three hundred dollars ($300.00); or
C. Knowingly starts a fire on the land of another without his consent, if the damage to property does not exceed three hundred dollars ($300.00); or
D. Knowingly injures a domestic animal of another without his consent, if the damage to property does not exceed three hundred dollars ($300.00); or
E. Knowingly deposits on the land or in the building of another, without his consent, any stink bomb or any offensive smelling compound and thereby
intends to interfere with the use by another of the land or building; or
F. Damages any property, if the damage to property does not exceed three hundred dollars ($300.00), with intent to defraud an insurer; or
G. Knowingly damages the property of another without his consent by defacing such property by the use of paint or any other similar substance, if the
damage to property does not exceed three hundred dollars ($300.00). (1988 Code § 7-2-2-5; amd. 2009 Code)
5-7-2-6: CRIMINAL DAMAGE TO FIREFIGHTING APPARATUS, HYDRANTS OR EQUIPMENT:
It shall be unlawful for anyone to wilfully and maliciously cut, injure, damage, tamper with or destroy or deface any fire hydrant or any fire hose or any fire
engine, or other public or private firefighting equipment, or any apparatus appertaining to such equipment, or intentionally open any fire hydrant without
proper authorization. (1988 Code § 7-2-2-6)
5-7-2-7: CRIMINAL TRESPASS TO VEHICLES:
It shall be unlawful for anyone to knowingly and without authority to enter any part of or operate any vehicle, aircraft, watercraft or snowmobile of another.
(1988 Code § 7-2-2-7)
5-7-2-8: CRIMINAL TRESPASS TO REAL PROPERTY:
A. It shall be unlawful to: 1) knowingly and without lawful authority enter or remain on the land or a building of another; 2) enter upon the land or a building
of another, after receiving prior to such entry, notice from the owner or occupant that such entry is forbidden; 3) remain upon the land or in a building of
another after receiving notice from the owner or occupant to depart; or 4) present false documents, or falsely represent his or her identity or purpose for
entry orally to the owner or occupant of a building or land in order to obtain permission from the owner or occupant to enter or remain in the building or
on the land.
B. A person has received notice from the owner or occupant within the meaning of subsection A of this section if he has been notified personally, either
orally or in writing, or if a printed or written notice forbidding such entry has been conspicuously posted or exhibited at the main entrance to such land
or the forbidden part thereof. (Ord. 2018-4, 2-26-2018)
5-7-2-9: CRIMINAL TRESPASS TO GOVERNMENT SUPPORTED LAND:
A. Any person who shall enter upon land supported in whole or in part with government funds administered or granted through government agencies or
any building on such land, after receiving, prior to such entry, notice from the appropriate governmental authority or its representative to depart, and
who thereby interferes with another person's lawful use or enjoyment of such building or land, commits the offense of criminal trespass to government
supported land.
B. A person has received notice from the governmental authority within the meaning of subsection A of this section, if he has been notified personally,
either orally or in writing, or if a printed or written notice forbidding such entry to him or a group of which he is a part, has been conspicuously posted or
exhibited at the main entrance to such land or the forbidden part thereof. (1988 Code § 7-2-2-9)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 155/493
5-7-3: OFFENSES AGAINST MORALITY:
5-7-3-1: PUBLIC INDECENCY:
A. Any person of the age of seventeen (17) years and upwards who performs any of the following acts in a public place commits the offense of public
indecency:
1. An act of sexual penetration or sexual conduct.
a. "Sexual penetration" means any contact, however slight, between the sex organ or anus of one person by an object and the sex organ, mouth or
anus of another person, or any intrusion, however slight, of any part of the body of one person or of any animal or object into the sex organ or anus
of another person, including, but not limited to, cunnilingus, fellatio or anal penetration. Evidence of emission of semen is not required to prove
sexual penetration.
b. "Sexual conduct" means any intentional or knowing touching or fondling of the victim by the accused, either directly or through clothing, of the sex
organs, anus or breast of the victim by the accused, or any part of the body of a child under thirteen (13) years of age, for the purpose of sexual
gratification or arousal of the victim or the accused.
2. A lewd exposure of the body done with the intent to arouse or to satisfy the sexual desire of the person.
B. Breast feeding of infants is not an act of public indecency.
C. "Public place", for purposes of this section, means any place where the conduct may reasonably be expected to be viewed by others. (1988 Code § 7-
2-3-1; amd. 2009 Code)
5-7-3-2: PROSTITUTION:
A. It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in any act of prostitution within the village. (1988 Code § 7-2-3-2; amd. 2009 Code)
B. Any person who performs, offers or agrees to perform any act of "sexual penetration", as defined in subsection C of this section, for any money,
property, token, object, or article or anything of value, or any touching or fondling of the sex organs of one person by another person for any money,
property, token, object, or article or anything of value for the purpose of sexual arousal or gratification, commits an act of prostitution.
C. "Sexual penetration" means any contact, however slight, between the sex organ or anus of one person by an object, the sex organ, mouth or anus of
another person, or any intrusion, however slight, of any part of the body of one person or of any animal or object into the sex organ or anus of another
person, including, but not limited to, cunnilingus, fellatio or anal penetration. Evidence of emission of semen is not required to prove sexual penetration.
(2009 Code)
5-7-3-3: SOLICITATION FOR PROSTITUTION:
Any person who performs any of the following acts commits the offense of soliciting for a prostitute:
A. Solicits another for the purpose of prostitution; or
B. Arranges or offers to arrange a meeting of persons for the purpose of prostitution; or
C. Directs another to a place knowing such direction is for the purpose of prostitution. (1988 Code § 7-2-3-3)
5-7-3-4: KEEPING A PLACE OF PROSTITUTION:
Any person who has or exercises control over the use of any place which could offer seclusion or shelter for the practice of prostitution who performs any
of the following acts commits the offense of keeping a place of prostitution:
A. Knowingly grants or permits the use of such place for the purpose of prostitution; or
B. Grants or permits the use of such place under circumstances from which he could reasonably know that the place is used or is to be used for purposes
of prostitution; or
C. Permits the continued use of a place after becoming aware of facts or circumstances from which he could reasonably know that the place is being used
for purposes of prostitution. (1988 Code § 7-2-3-4)
5-7-3-5: PIMPING:
Any person who receives money, property, token, object, or article, or anything of value from a prostitute, not for a lawful consideration, knowing it was
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 156/493
earned in whole or in part from the practice of prostitution, commits the offense of pimping. (1988 Code § 7-2-3-5; amd. 2009 Code)
5-7-3-6: RESISTING OR OBSTRUCTING A PEACE OFFICER:
It shall be unlawful for any person to resist or obstruct a peace officer. A person commits the offense of resisting or obstructing a peace officer when such
person knowingly resists or obstructs the performance by one known to the person to be a peace officer of any authorized act within his official capacity.
(1988 Code § 7-2-3-11)
5-7-3-7: HARASSMENT BY TELEPHONE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to harass another by telephone. It shall be unlawful for any person to commit the offense of harassment by telephone.
For purposes of this section, harassment by telephone is use of telephone communications for any of the following purposes:
A. Making any comment, request, suggestion or proposal which is obscene, lewd, lascivious, filthy or indecent with an intent to offend; or
B. Making a telephone call, whether or not conversation ensues, with intent to abuse, threaten or harass any person at the called number; or
C. Making or causing the telephone of another repeatedly to ring, with intent to harass any person at the called number; or
D. Making repeated telephone calls, during which conversation ensues, solely to harass any person at the called number; or
E. Knowingly permitting any telephone under one's control to be used for any of the purposes mentioned herein. (1988 Code § 7-2-3-12)
5-7-3-8: TRANSMISSION OF OBSCENE MESSAGES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to transmit any obscene messages. A person who sends messages or uses language or terms which are obscene, lewd
or immoral with the intent to offend by means of or while using a telephone or telegraph facility, equipment or wires of any person, firm or corporation
engaged in the transmission of news or messages to or from the village commits the offense of transmission of obscene messages. (1988 Code § 7-2-3-
13)
5-7-4: OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC PEACE:
5-7-4-1: DISORDERLY CONDUCT:
It shall be unlawful to engage in disorderly conduct within the village. A person commits disorderly conduct when such person knowingly:
A. Does any act in such unreasonable manner as to alarm or disturb another and to provoke a breach of the peace.
B. Transmits in any manner to the fire department of any city, town, village or fire protection district a false alarm of fire, knowing at the time of such
transmission that there is no reasonable ground for believing that such fire exists.
C. Transmits in any manner to another a false alarm to the effect that a bomb or other explosive of any nature is concealed in such place that its explosion
would endanger human life, knowing at the time of such transmission that there is no reasonable ground for believing that such bomb or explosive is
concealed in such place.
D. Transmits in any manner to any peace officer, public officer or public employee a report to the effect that an offense has been committed, knowing at the
time of such transmission that there is no reasonable ground for believing that such an offense has been committed.
E. Enters upon the property of another and for a lewd or unlawful purpose deliberately looks into a dwelling on the property through any window or other
opening in it.
F. While acting as a "collection agency" as defined in the collection agency act1 or as an employee of such collection agency, and while attempting to
collect an alleged debt, makes a telephone call to the alleged debtor which is designed to harass, annoy or intimidate the alleged debtor.
G. Transmits a false report to the department of children and family services under section 4 of the abused and neglected child reporting act2. (1988 Code
§ 7-2-4-1)
H. Knowingly transmits a false report to the department of public health under the nursing home care act3. (1988 Code § 7-2-4-1; amd. 2009 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 157/493
I. Transmits in any manner to the police department or fire department of any municipality or fire protection district or any privately owned and operated
ambulance service, a false request for an ambulance, emergency medical technician/ambulance or emergency medical technician/paramedic knowing
at the time there is no reasonable ground for believing that such assistance is required. (1988 Code § 7-2-4-1)
J. Transmits a false report under article II of an act in relation to victims of violence and abuse, approved September 16, 1984, as amended. (1988 Code
§ 7-2-4-1; amd. 2009 Code)
5-7-4-2: POSSESSION OF ILLEGAL DRUGS; UNLAWFUL ASSEMBLY INVOLVING ILLEGAL DRUGS:
A. Definitions: The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except
where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
CANNABIS: Any substance as defined in section 3 of the cannabis control act, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 550/1 et seq., as the same may, from
time to time hereafter, be amended.
CONTROLLED SUBSTANCE: Any substance as defined and included in the schedules of article II of the controlled substances act, 720 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 570/201 et seq., as the same may, from time to time hereafter, be amended.
DRUG PARAPHERNALIA: All equipment, products, and materials as defined in the drug paraphernalia control act, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 600/1
et seq., as the same may, from time to time hereafter, be amended.
ILLEGAL DRUGS: Any controlled substance, cannabis, or unprescribed drug.
KNOWINGLY: Having general knowledge of, or reason to know, or a belief or ground for belief which warrants further inquiry or inspection.
UNPRESCRIBED DRUG: Any drug as defined in paragraph (b) of section 3 of the pharmacy practice act of 1987, 225 Illinois Compiled Statutes 85/1
et seq., as the same may, from time to time hereafter, be amended, that is obtained without a prescription or otherwise in violation of the law.
VEHICLE OR PREMISES: Any privately owned and operated motor vehicle, conveyance or vessel; any house or apartment; any hotel, motel, or bed
and breakfast room or any similar premises to which the general public is not normally admitted.
B. Possession Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person to possess illegal drugs or drug paraphernalia in the village, except as, and only to the extent,
otherwise explicitly authorized by state or federal law.
C. Responsibility Of Owner: It shall be unlawful for any owner of, or other person having control over, any vehicle or premises to knowingly initiate, suffer,
permit, or allow one or more occupants, invitees, visitors, guests, trespassers, or other persons to assemble or be assembled in such vehicle or
premises in possession of any illegal drugs or drug paraphernalia.
D. Responsibility Regarding Renting Premises: It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly rent, or pay for, any hotel, motel, or bed and breakfast room
or facility from the proprietor or agent thereof for the purpose of using such room or facility for the consumption or intake of illegal drugs.
E. Presumptions Of Knowledge And Permission: For purposes of this section, a person shall be presumed, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, to
have knowingly permitted a violation of this section if: 1) such person is present within any vehicle or premises of which such person is the owner,
lessee, permittee, bailee, legal possessor, or occupier thereof at the time that a violation of the provisions of this section is occurring; and 2) such
person has not informed the Lake Bluff police department thereof. (Ord. 95-42, 12-11-1995)
5-7-4-3: CERTAIN ASSEMBLIES; PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for groups of two (2) or more people to assemble in any public park or on any public property in the village and engage in loud talking,
yelling, noisy games or other activity calculated to disturb the peaceful and proper enjoyment by others of said public or any private property without a
permit issued therefor by the appropriate authority. (1988 Code § 7-2-4-4)
5-7-4-4: DISTURBING RELIGIOUS ASSEMBLIES:
It shall be unlawful to disturb any congregation or assembly met for religious worship by making any noise or by rude or indecent behavior or profane
discourse within any place of worship or so near to the same as to disturb the order or solemnity of the meeting. (1988 Code § 7-2-4-5)
5-7-4-5: RESIDENTIAL PICKETING:
It is unlawful to picket before or about the residence or dwelling of any person, except when the residence or dwelling is used as a place of business.
However, this section does not apply to a person peacefully picketing his own residence or dwelling and does not prohibit the peaceful picketing of the
place of holding a meeting or assembly on premises commonly used to discuss subjects of general public interest. (1988 Code § 7-2-4-6)
5-7-4-6: MOB ACTION:
It shall be unlawful for any person to commit the offense of mob action in the village. Mob action consists of any of the following:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 158/493
A. The use of force or violence disturbing the public peace by two (2) or more persons acting together and without authority of law; or
B. The assembly of two (2) or more persons to do an unlawful act; or
C. The assembly of two (2) or more persons, without authority of law, for the purpose of doing violence to the person or property of anyone supposed to
have been guilty of a violation of the law, or for the purpose of exercising correctional powers or regulative powers over any person by violence. (1988
Code § 7-2-4-7)
5-7-4-7: FALSE PERSONATION4:
It shall be unlawful to commit the offense of false personation in the village. A person commits the offense of false personation when such person:
A. Falsely represents himself to be an attorney authorized to practice law or a public officer or a public employee.
B. Falsely represents himself to be a member of any police, fraternal or veterans' organization, including the Illinois Police Association, or a representative
of any charitable organization or when any person exhibits or uses in any manner, any decal, badge or insignia of any police organization when not
authorized to do so by such police organization. (1988 Code § 7-2-4-8)
5-7-4-8: PUBLIC DEMONSTRATIONS:
It is unlawful for any person, group or organization to conduct or participate in any march, assembly, meeting on any public place in the village, or
gathering on roadways in more than one specific area of or location in the village on any one given day unless a demonstration permit is issued by the
village, or if not, with the permission of the police chief. (1988 Code § 7-2-4-9)
5-7-5: WEAPONS OFFENSES:
5-7-5-1: UNLAWFUL POSSESSION OF FIREARMS OR AMMUNITION:
It shall be an offense for any person to unlawfully possess any firearms or firearms ammunition in the village. A person commits the offense of unlawful
possession of firearms or firearm ammunition when:
A. He is under eighteen (18) years of age and has in his possession any firearm of a size which may be concealed upon the person; or
B. He is under twenty one (21) years of age, has been convicted of a misdemeanor other than a traffic offense or adjudged delinquent and has any firearm
or firearm ammunition in his possession; or
C. He is a narcotic addict and has any firearms or firearm ammunition in his possession; or
D. He has been a patient in a mental hospital within the past five (5) years and has any firearms or firearm ammunition in his possession; or
E. He is mentally retarded and has any firearms or firearm ammunition in his possession; or (1988 Code § 7-2-5-1)
F. He has in his possession any "explosive bullet". For purposes of this subsection, "explosive bullet" means the projectile portion of an ammunition
cartridge which contains or carries an explosive charge which will explode upon contact with the flesh of a human or an animal. "Cartridge" means a
tubular metal case having a projectile affixed at the front thereof and a cap or primer at the rear end thereof, with the propellant contained in such tube
between the projectile and the cap. (1988 Code § 7-2-5-1; amd. 2009 Code)
5-7-5-2: MINORS:
A. Furnishing Firearms To: It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, loan or furnish to any minor any gun, pistol or other firearm within the limits of the
village.
B. Air Guns, BB Guns; Persons Under Thirteen Years: It shall be unlawful for any parent or guardian or other person to purchase for, or furnish to, give to
or permit the possession by, any child under the age of thirteen (13) years within the village any air gun, air rifle, air pistol, spring gun, spring pistol,
pellet gun, BB gun, or any implement that is not a firearm which impels a pellet constructed of hard plastic, steel, lead or other hard material with a
force that reasonably is expected to cause bodily harm. (1988 Code § 7-2-5-2)
5-7-5-3: CARRYING OR TRANSPORTING FIREARMS:
It shall be unlawful to carry or transport any gun, pistol, fowling piece or other firearm, or any air gun, air pistol or slingshot within the corporate limits of the
village which contains any explosive substance, nor shall any such weapon be carried or transported unless in a case, dismantled or broken down. Any
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 159/493
weapon so broken must have a cord, strap or cloth tied around the weapon in such manner as to render it incapable of being discharged without first
removing such cord, strap or cloth. (1988 Code § 7-2-5-3)
5-7-5-4: CANNONS AND ARTILLERY; PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to discharge or fire any cannon or piece of artillery within the corporate limits of the village without written permission from the village
administrator. (1988 Code § 7-2-5-4)
5-7-5-5: DISCHARGING FIREARMS PROHIBITED:
No person shall at any time discharge or set off anywhere within the village, or carry the same for such purpose, any firearm, gun, pistol, rifle, air rifle,
cannon, or any other gun that discharges projectiles either by air, spring, explosive substance or any other force. The prohibitions contained herein shall
also apply to the discharge of toy firearms and toy cannons of any nature or description, but shall not apply to the carrying of unloaded toy firearms and toy
cannons, or the carrying or discharge of toy water pistols and cap guns. (1988 Code § 7-2-5-5)
5-7-5-6: POSSESSING, USING OR DISCHARGING WEAPONS:
A. "Weapons", as used in this section, includes firearms, but also includes bludgeons, blackjacks, slingshot, sand club, sandbag, metal knuckles, throwing
stars, or any knife commonly referred to as a switchblade knife, which has a blade that opens automatically by hand pressure applied to a button,
spring or other device in the handle of the knife, or a ballistic knife which is a device that propels a knifelike blade as a projectile by means or a coil
spring, elastic material or compressed gas, a dagger, dirk, billy, straight razor, stiletto, broken bottle or other piece of glass, stun gun or taser,
nunchaku, tear gas gun projector or bomb or any object containing noxious liquid, gas or substance, other than an object containing a nonlethal
noxious gas or substance designed solely for personal defense carried by a person eighteen (18) years or older. (1988 Code § 7-2-5-6; amd. 2009
Code)
B. No person shall possess any weapon, gun, pistol, rifle, shotgun, or firearm of any nature or description, or slingshot, crossbow, bow and arrow or
explosive bullets or projectiles the possession of which is prohibited by the state. No person shall discharge or carry any firearm or weapon described
herein, or other devices prohibited by the laws of the state within the corporate limits of the village. (1988 Code § 7-2-5-6)
5-7-5-7: EXCEPTIONS TO POSSESSION AND DISCHARGE OF FIREARMS:
The restrictions on the possession and discharge of firearms shall not apply to police officers of the village in the performance of their duties, nor to officers
of any court whose duty it is to serve warrants or make arrests, nor to those individuals exempted under 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-2 who comply
with the provisions of said statute and use such weapons in accordance therewith. Nothing contained in this section shall prohibit the possession and
discharge of a weapon when such use is in self-defense of a person, home or of property. (1988 Code § 7-2-5-7)
5-7-6: FIREWORKS:
5-7-6-1: DEFINITION:
The term "fireworks" shall mean and include any combustible or explosive compositions or any substances or articles prepared for the purpose of
producing a visible or audible effect by combustion, explosion, deflagration or detonation. (Ord. 92-29, 11-9-1992)
5-7-6-2: RESTRICTIONS:
It shall be unlawful to at any time sell, offer for sale, give away, possess, store, discharge or otherwise use fireworks of any kind within the village;
provided, however, that upon a permit being issued therefor by the board of trustees, fireworks may be stored and used for public exhibitions. (Ord. 92-29,
11-9-1992)
5-7-6-3: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provisions of this section 5-7-6 shall be punished by a fine of not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more than the
maximum provided in section 1-4-1 of this code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during which such violation
occurs and continues. (Ord. 92-29, 11-9-1992; amd. 2009 Code)
5-7-7: MISCELLANEOUS VIOLATIONS:
5-7-7-1: INTERFERENCE WITH EMERGENCY COMMUNICATION:
It shall be unlawful to interfere with any emergency communication in the village.
