A. A person commits the offense of interference with emergency communication when he knowingly, intentionally and without lawful justification interrupts,
disrupts, impedes, or otherwise interferes with the transmission of a communication over any mode of communication, the purpose of which
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 160/493
communication is to inform or inquire about an emergency.
B. For the purpose of this section, "emergency" means a condition or circumstance in which an individual is, or is reasonably believed by the person
transmitting the communication to be, in imminent danger of serious bodily injury or in which property is, or is reasonably believed by the person
transmitting the communication to be, in imminent danger of damage or destruction. (1988 Code § 7-2-6-1)
5-7-7-2: LITTERING:
A. Definition: "Litter", as used herein, means any discarded, used or unconsumed substance or waste. "Litter" may include, but is not limited to, any
garbage, trash, refuse, debris, rubbish, grass clippings or other lawn or garden waste, newspaper, magazines, glass, metal, plastic or paper containers
or other packaging construction material, abandoned vehicles, motor vehicle parts, furniture, oil, carcass of a dead animal, any nauseous or offensive
matter of any kind or any object likely to injure any person or create a traffic hazard, or anything else of an unsightly or unsanitary nature, which has
been discarded, abandoned or otherwise disposed of improperly.
B. Deposits Prohibited; Exception: It shall be unlawful for any person to dump, deposit, drop, throw, discard, leave, cause or permit the dumping,
depositing, dropping, throwing, discarding or leaving of litter upon any public or private property in the village, or upon or into any river, lake, pond or
other stream or body of water in the village, unless:
1. The property has been designated by the state or the village for the disposal of litter, and the litter is disposed of on that property in accordance with
the applicable rules of the Illinois pollution control board of the state, and the ordinances of the village; or
2. The litter is placed into a receptacle or other container intended by the owner or tenant in lawful possession of that property for the deposit of litter; or
3. The person is the owner or tenant in lawful possession of the property or has first obtained the consent of the owner or tenant in lawful possession,
or unless the act is done under the personal direction of the owner or tenant, and does not create a public health or safety hazard, a public nuisance
or a fire hazard; or
4. The person is acting under the direction of proper public officials during special cleanup days; or
5. The person is lawfully acting in or reacting to an emergency situation where health and safety is threatened, and removes and properly disposes of
such litter when the emergency situation no longer exists.
C. Deposits From Vehicles And Property: No person shall dump, deposit, drop, throw, discard or otherwise dispose of litter in the village from any motor
vehicle upon any public highway, upon any public or private property or upon or into any river, lake, pond, stream or body of water except as permitted
under subsection B of this section; nor shall any person transport by any means garbage or refuse from any dwelling, residence, place of business,
farm or other site and deposit such material in, around or on top of trash barrels or other receptacles placed along public highways at any point.
D. Accumulations Of Litter: No person shall allow litter to accumulate upon real property, of which the person charged is the owner or tenant in control, in
such a manner as to constitute a public nuisance or in such a manner that the litter may be blown or otherwise carried by the natural elements onto the
real property of another person.
E. Abandoned Vehicles: No person shall abandon a motor vehicle in the village on any highway or road, on any public property or on any private property
of which he is not the owner or tenant in lawful possession in the village. The person to whom last was issued the certificate of title to the vehicle by the
secretary of state of Illinois is presumed to be the person to have abandoned that vehicle, but such presumption may be rebutted.
F. Vehicle Operator Presumed Guilty: Whenever litter is thrown, deposited, dropped or dumped from any motor vehicle not carrying passengers for hire,
the presumption is created that the operator of the motor vehicle committed the act, but that presumption may be rebutted.
G. Places Of Public Assembly; Receptacles Required:
1. In order to assist the public in complying with this section, the owner or person in control of any property which is held out to the public as a place for
assemblage, the transaction of business, recreation or as a public way shall cause to be placed and maintained receptacles for the deposit of litter, of
sufficient volume and in sufficient numbers to meet the needs of the number of people customarily coming on or using the property.
2. For purposes of this subsection, property held out to the public for the transaction of business includes, but is not limited to, commercially operated
parks, campgrounds, drive-in restaurants, automobile service stations, business parking lots, car washes, shopping centers, marinas, boat launching
areas, industrial parking lots, boat moorage and fueling stations, piers, beaches and bathing areas, shopping malls, and property held out to the
public for assemblage, recreation or as a public way and includes, but is not limited to, any property that is publicly owned or operated for any of the
purposes stated in this subsection G2 for property held out to the public for the transaction of business, but excludes state highway rights of way.
(1988 Code § 7-2-6-2)
5-7-7-3: VANDALISM:
A. Prohibited Acts: It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully, maliciously, or negligently break, deface, injure, or destroy any property within the village,
whether such property is owned by the state, county, village, or any other governmental body, or owned by any private person. Acts prohibited under
this section include, but are not limited to, the following:
1. Injury To Public Or Private Grounds: To cut, injure, mark, or deface any building not his own or any tree, grass, shrub, or walk in any public or private
grounds or any sewer, water pipe, or hydrant laid or placed by the village; provided, further, that an abutting property owner or tenant is authorized to
mow grass, and trim trees and shrubs on parkway property adjacent to his property.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 161/493
2. Paint, Mark Or Mutilate: To paint or mark on, cut into or deface, or mutilate in any manner any public sidewalk, street, or any other public property
without permit issued therefor by the village.
3. Lights And Utilities: To break, deface, disturb, interfere with, carry away, or in any way injure or destroy any electric light globe or any part or
appurtenance to any lamp or light of any kind used in, upon, or about any street, public or private place in the village, or any telephone, electric,
cable television, communications or telegraph wire, or any appurtenances thereto at any place within the limits of the village.
4. Stones And Missiles: To throw or cast any stone or other missile upon or at any building, railroad car, tree, or other public or private property, or upon
or at any person, in any public or private place, or to aid or abet in the same. (Ord. 95-42, 12-11-1995)
5. Damage To Buildings And Property: To engage in the knowing infliction, without consent, of damage to: a) any church, synagogue, or other building,
structure, or place used for religious worship or other religious purpose; b) any cemetery, mortuary, or other facility used for the purpose of burial or
memorializing the dead; c) any school, educational facility, or community center; d) any grounds adjacent to, and owned or rented by, any such
institution, facility, building, structure, or place; or e) any personal property contained in any such institution, facility, building, structure, or place, by
reason of the actual or perceived race, color, creed, religion, national origin, ancestry, gender, sexual orientation, or physical or mental disability of
another individual or group of individuals. (Ord. 95-42, 12-11-1995; amd. 2009 Code)
B. Parental Responsibility:
1. Definitions: The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except
where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
KNOWINGLY: Having general knowledge of, or reason to know, or a belief or ground for belief which warrants further inquiry or inspection.
LEGAL GUARDIAN: A person appointed guardian, or given custody, of a minor by a circuit court of this state, but does not include a person
appointed guardian or given custody of a minor under the juvenile court act of 1987, 705 Illinois Compiled Statutes 405/1-1 et seq.
MINOR: A person under the age of eighteen (18) years.
PARENT: A natural or adoptive parent or a court designated guardian.
UNEMANCIPATED MINOR: A minor still under the care and custody of at least one of his or her parents or a legal guardian.
WILFUL: Proceeding from a conscious and voluntary intentional motion of the will.
2. Parental Responsibility For Failure To Supervise: It shall be unlawful for any parent or legal guardian of an unemancipated minor to knowingly suffer,
permit, or allow such minor to wilfully or maliciously damage or destroy any property or to injure any person or animal.
3. Parental Responsibility For Damages: The parent or legal guardian of an unemancipated minor shall be liable to the full extent permitted by law, for
actual damages for: a) such minor's acts of vandalism occurring within the village; and b) the wilful or malicious acts of such minor that occur within
the village and that cause injury to a person, animal, or property. (Ord. 95-42, 12-11-1995)
5-7-7-4: UNLAWFUL EXCAVATIONS OF PUBLIC WAYS:
It shall be unlawful to dig, cut or remove any sod, gravel, sand or earth from any of the public streets or property of the village without authority of the
village administrator, or from any private lot or tract of land without the consent of the owner thereof. (1988 Code § 7-2-6-5)
5-7-7-5: LADDERS; SCAFFOLDS; TOOLS:
It shall be unlawful to place any scaffolds or ladders in such a position that they overhang or can fall upon any public street, alley or other public way in the
village unless such ladder or scaffold shall be firmly and properly constructed and safeguarded; and it shall be unlawful to place or leave any tools or
articles on any such scaffold or ladder in such a manner that such tools or articles can fall upon such street, alley or other public way from a greater height
than four feet (4'). (1988 Code § 7-2-6-8)
5-7-7-6: CURFEW5:
A. Beaches Or Lake Front Property: Notwithstanding anything contained in this section to the contrary, it shall be unlawful for any person, other than
municipal officials and employees conducting official business, to be or remain upon any and all public beaches or public lake front property in the
village between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and five o'clock (5:00) A.M. the following day, without a written permit issued by or pursuant to the
proper authority.
B. Village Green Vacant Property: Notwithstanding anything contained in this section to the contrary, it shall be unlawful for any person, other than
municipal officials and employees conducting official business, to be or remain upon any other public property in the village except for the streets,
alleys, sidewalks, and public rights of way, nor any vacant property or any part thereof between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and five o'clock
(5:00) A.M. of the following day, without a written permit issued by or pursuant to the proper authority. (1988 Code § 7-2-6-10)
C. School Curfew For Minors:
1. Definitions: The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this subsection, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection C1,
except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
KNOWINGLY: Having general knowledge of, or reason to know, or a belief or ground for belief which warrants further inquiry or inspection.
LEGAL GUARDIAN: A person appointed guardian, or given custody, of a minor by a circuit court of this state, but does not include a person
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 162/493
appointed guardian or given custody of a minor under the juvenile court act of 1987, 705 Illinois Compiled Statutes 405/1-1 et seq.
MINOR: A person under the age of eighteen (18) years.
PARENT: A natural or adoptive parent or a court designated guardian.
UNEMANCIPATED MINOR: A minor still under the care and custody of at least one of his or her parents or a legal guardian.
WILFUL: Proceeding from a conscious and voluntary intentional motion of the will.
2. Curfew Imposed; Exceptions: It shall be unlawful for any minor who is enrolled in any public, private, or parochial school to be present at or upon, or
to loiter, wander, stroll, or play in or upon, any street, alley, sidewalk, parkway, park, playground, or other public place, or in or on any public building,
place of amusement or entertainment, or any vacant lot in the village, other than school, during any hours when school is in session during the
regular school term, unless such minor is:
a. Traveling to or from school by the most direct route; or
b. Engaged in school related activities with written approval of school authorities or as otherwise authorized by written school policy; or
c. Engaged in personal business, including, without limitation, employment, medical care, and religious activities, with prior written consent from a
parent, legal guardian, or other adult having lawful custody or supervision of such person to school authorities; or
d. Accompanied and supervised by a parent, legal guardian, or other adult having lawful custody or supervision of such person.
3. Investigatory Detention: Any police officer may stop and detain a person whom the police officer reasonably suspects to be violating this subsection
for purpose of verifying the detained person's identity, age, school enrollment and authority to be absent from school. The police officer shall
immediately inform the detained person of the reason for the detention and that he or she will be released upon verification of authorization to be
absent from school. If the detained person refuses to provide the police officer with the necessary information, or if authorization to be absent from
school cannot be verified within fifteen (15) minutes of the detention, the detained person shall, if practicable, be taken to school authorities or a
parent or legal guardian or other adult having lawful custody or supervision of such person. (Ord. 95-42, 12-11-1995)
4. First And Subsequent Violations: Any person who violates this subsection shall be warned by any police officer forthwith to comply with such
provisions, and such officer shall also, without delay, report such violation to his or her superior officer, who shall cause a written notice to be served
upon the parent, legal guardian or other adult having lawful custody or supervision of such person, setting forth the manner in which this subsection
has been violated. In case any person under the age of eighteen (18) years, after such warning, shall again violate any of the provisions of this
subsection, he or she shall be taken into custody as a juvenile delinquent and dealt with as provided under the juvenile court act of 1987, 705 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 405/1-1 et seq. (Ord. 95-42, 12-11-1995; amd. 2009 Code)
5. Parental Responsibility: It shall be unlawful for any parent or legal guardian of an unemancipated minor to knowingly suffer, permit, or allow such
minor to violate any provision of this subsection. (Ord. 95-42, 12-11-1995)
5-7-7-7: RENDERING AID TO OFFICERS REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person in the village, when called upon by the chief of police or any member of the police department or by any officer of the
Village possessing police powers, to refuse to promptly aid and assist him in the execution of his duties. (1988 Code § 7-2-6-11)
5-7-7-8: IMPERSONATING POLICE OFFICERS6:
It shall be unlawful for any person, other than a member of the Police Department or one legally vested with police powers, to assume to act as a police
officer in any capacity within or without the Village. A person commits the offense of impersonating when such person uses a star, badge or other similar
device identifying such person to be a member of the Lake Bluff Police Department or one legally authorized to act on behalf of the Police Department,
and such person is not a member of the Police Department. (1988 Code § 7-2-6-12)
5-7-7-9: GAMBLING PROHIBITED:
Except as expressly permitted by the Village pursuant to title 3, chapter 14 of this Code and the State of Illinois pursuant to the Charitable Games Act, 230
Illinois Compiled Statutes 30/1 et seq., there shall be no gambling of any kind allowed within the Village, including use of any gambling device. A
"gambling device" is any clock, tape machine, slot machine or other machines or device for the reception of money or other thing of value on chance or
skill or upon the action or which money or other thing of value is staked, hazarded, bet, won or lost, including, but not limited to, any video gaming terminal,
as defined in the Video Gaming Act, 230 Illinois Compiled Statutes 40/5; or any mechanism, furniture, fixture, equipment or other device designed primarily
for use in a gambling place. A "gambling device" does not include: (Ord. 2017-11, 6-12-2017)
A. A coin in the slot operated mechanical device played for amusement which rewards the player with the right to replay such mechanical device, which
device is so constructed or devised as to make such result of the operation thereof depend in part upon the skill of the player and which returns to the
player thereof no money, property or right to receive money or property.
B. Vending machines by which full and adequate return is made for the money invested and in which there is no element of chance or hazard. (Ord. 2009-
24, 10-26-2009)
5-7-8: OFFENSES AGAINST ANIMALS:
5-7-8-1: CRUELTY TO ANIMALS7; ANIMAL FIGHTS; IMMORAL DISPLAY OF ANIMALS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 163/493
It shall be unlawful to commit any cruel act towards animals, instigate, cause or procure any fights between animals, or in any manner instigate, cause,
procure or assist in any indecent or immoral show or exhibition of any animal. (1988 Code § 7-2-7-1)
5-7-8-2: KILLING OR WOUNDING BIRDS:
It shall be unlawful to kill or wound or attempt to kill or wound, by use of any firearms, slingshot, bow and arrow or otherwise, any bird within the limits of
the Village, or to shoot any arrow or throw a stone or club or other missile at any bird within any private or public grounds, or take the eggs or young of any
such bird, or enter upon any private enclosure or public ground for the purpose of doing any act prohibited by this section. (1988 Code § 7-2-7-2)
5-7-9: PENALTY:
Unless otherwise provided, any person violating any provision of this chapter or committing an "offense", as defined herein, shall be fined not less than fifty
dollars ($50.00) nor more than the maximum provided in section 1-4-1 of this Code for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on
each day on which a violation occurs or continues and for each separate offense committed. (1988 Code § 7-2-8-1; amd. 2009 Code)
Chapter 8
MINORS
5-8-1: CURFEW1:
A. Age And Hour Restrictions: It is unlawful for a person less than eighteen (18) years of age to be present at or upon any public assembly, building, place,
street, or highway at the following times unless one of the exceptions listed in subsection B of this section applies:
Between one minute after twelve o'clock (12:01) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M., Saturday;
Between one minute after twelve o'clock (12:01) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M., Sunday; and
Between eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. on Sunday to Thursday, inclusive, and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. on the following day.
B. Exemptions: This section shall not apply to any person less than eighteen (18) years of age who is:
1. Accompanied and supervised by a parent, legal guardian, or other responsible companion at least eighteen (18) years of age;
2. Engaged in a business or occupation which the laws of Illinois authorize a person less than eighteen (18) years of age to perform;
3. Attending or traveling to or from an official school, religious, or civic activity;
4. Attending or traveling to or from any assembly activity for which a permit has been lawfully issued;
5. Involved in an emergency involving the protection of a person or property from an imminent threat of serious bodily injury or substantial damage; or
6. Traveling between states or internationally from a location outside of Illinois to another location outside of Illinois.
C. Enforcement Restrictions: A police officer shall not take any enforcement action under this section unless the police officer reasonably believes that a
violation of this section has occurred and that no exception listed in subsection B of this section is applicable.
D. Responsibility Of Parent, Guardian Or Other Persons: It is unlawful for a parent, legal guardian, or other person to knowingly permit a person in his or
her custody or control to violate this section. (Ord. 2004-13, 4-26-2004)
5-8-2: ALCOHOL2:
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, give, deliver or make available alcoholic liquor to another person under the age of twenty one (21) except in the
performance of a religious ceremony or service. This prohibition shall not apply to the consumption of alcoholic liquor by a minor under the direct
supervision and approval of the parents or legal guardians of such minor in the privacy of the home of said parents or legal guardians. (1988 Code § 7-3-2)
5-8-3: PARENTAL RESPONSIBILITY:
A. Definitions: The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection except
where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
KNOWINGLY: Having general knowledge of, or reason to know, or a belief or ground for belief which warrants further inquiry or inspection.
LEGAL GUARDIAN: A person appointed guardian or given custody of a minor by a circuit court of this state, but does not include a person appointed
guardian or given custody of a minor under the juvenile court act of 1987, 705 Illinois Compiled Statutes 405/1-1 et seq.
MINOR: A person under the age of twenty one (21) years.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 164/493
PARENT: A natural or adoptive parent or a court designated guardian.
UNEMANCIPATED MINOR: A minor still under the care and custody of at least one of his or her parents or legal guardian.
WILFUL: Proceeding from a conscious and voluntary intentional motion of the will.
B. Inciting Violations By Minors: It shall be unlawful for any person, including a parent or legal guardian, to knowingly or wilfully cause, aid or encourage
any minor to violate or attempt to violate any state or federal law or municipal ordinance or to knowingly or wilfully act in such a manner as to directly
tend to cause a minor to violate or attempt to act in such a manner as to directly tend to cause a minor to violate or attempt to violate any state or
federal law or municipal ordinance.
C. Parental Responsibility For Violations By Minors: It shall be unlawful for any parent or legal guardian or an unemancipated minor to knowingly suffer,
permit or allow such minor to violate any provision of this code.
D. Parental Responsibility For Unpaid Penalties: The parent or legal guardian of an unemancipated minor shall be liable for any fine, condition or
restriction or reparation imposed by a court upon such minor for a violation of any provision of this code, but only if: 1) such minor has not paid the fine
or made restitution or reparation within the time ordered by the court; and 2) said parent or legal guardian has been served with summons or notice to
appear in the original cause as provided by law.
E. Improper Supervision Of Minors: It shall be unlawful for any parent or legal guardian of an unemancipated minor to fail to make all reasonable efforts to
prevent such minor from violating any of the provisions of this code, including specifically, but without limitation, provisions concerning vandalism,
curfew for minors, alcoholic liquor and illegal drugs.
F. Presumptions Of Knowledge And Permission:
1. Knowingly Permitting: The parent or legal guardian of an unemancipated minor shall be presumed, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, to
have knowingly permitted such minor to have committed a violation of this code if:
a. Such minor shall have either: 1) been adjudicated to be in violation of; 2) incurred nonjudicial sanctions from an official public agency resulting
from an admission of guilt of violation of; or 3) received a written warning or citation by the Lake Bluff police department of a potential or probable
violation of any provision of this code concerning vandalism, curfew for minors, alcoholic liquor or illegal drugs; and
b. The parent or legal guardian shall have received a written notice from the village police department of such adjudication, sanction, or warning; and
c. Within three (3) years following receipt of the notice set forth in subsection F1b of this section, such minor either: 1) is adjudicated to have violated
the same provision of this code; or 2) shall have incurred nonjudicial sanctions from an official public agency resulting from an admission of guilt of
violation of the same provision of this code.
2. Not Knowingly Permitting: Notwithstanding the foregoing, such parent or legal guardian shall not be presumed to have knowingly permitted such
minor to have committed such violation if such parent or legal guardian shall have, prior to the occurrence of the repeated violation: a) delivered
written notice to the village chief of police of his or her inability to prevent such continued or repeated violation; and b) requested the village chief of
police, or the proper public authority, to take the necessary legal proceedings toward having such minor declared and dealt with as a delinquent
minor. All notices required to be delivered pursuant to this subsection shall be delivered either by certified or registered mail, return receipt
requested, or by personal service, with a certificate of personal service returned.
G. Persons Or Entities Entitled To Enforce Provisions: The village is entitled to enforce the liability imposed by this section.
H. Common Law Damages: This section shall not affect the recovery of damages in any other cause of action where the liability of the parent or legal
guardian is predicated on a common law basis. (Ord. 95-42, 12-11-1995)
5-8-4: TOBACCO PRODUCTS AND E-CIGARETTES:
A. Definitions: For the purposes of this section, the following terms, phrases, and words shall have the meanings given to them in this subsection. All
terms, phrases, and words used in this section but not defined in this subsection shall have the meanings given to them elsewhere in this code.
E-CIGARETTE: An electronic device that typically includes a mouthpiece, a heating element or atomizer, a battery, and electronic circuits; provides a
gas derived from a liquid that includes nicotine, propylene glycol, or similar substance and perhaps other substances; and is inhaled by a user in a
manner that simulates or resembles smoking. The term "e-cigarette" includes all manner of these devices, regardless of the details of a device's
appearance or marketed name, that are manufactured to resemble a cigarette, cigar, pipe, or other smoking device. The term "e-cigarette" includes the
cartridges and component parts of an e-cigarette, individually or in any combination.
MINOR: A person under the age of eighteen (18) years.
TOBACCO PRODUCT: Any item, product, or substance containing tobacco leaf, including specifically, but without limitation, cigarettes, cigars, snuff,
and pipe, chewing, or dipping tobacco.
B. Sale By Minors: It shall be unlawful for any minor to sell, give, dispense, furnish, or otherwise distribute any tobacco product or e-cigarette to any person
or business within the corporate limits of the village.
C. Sale To Minors: It shall be unlawful for any person or business to sell, give, dispense, furnish, or otherwise distribute any tobacco product or e-cigarette
to any minor within the corporate limits of the village.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 165/493
D. Purchase By Minors: It shall be unlawful for any minor to purchase or otherwise acquire any tobacco product or e-cigarette within the corporate limits of
the village.
E. Possession And Use By Minors: It shall be unlawful for any minor to possess or use a tobacco product or e-cigarette within the corporate limits of the
village; provided, however, that the possession or use of any tobacco product or e-cigarette by any minor under the direct supervision and control of the
parent or guardian of any such minor in the privacy of such parent's or guardian's home shall not be unlawful.
F. Notice Required:
1. It shall be unlawful for any person or business to engage in the sale or distribution of tobacco products or e-cigarettes within the corporate limits of
the village unless such person or business prominently displays as part of every display of tobacco products or e-cigarettes offered for sale the
following notice:
THE PURCHASE OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS OR E-CIGARETTES BY ANY PERSON UNDER AGE OF 18 IS PROHIBITED BY LAW.
2. Such notice shall be displayed in red letters at least one inch (1") in height on a white background.
G. Responsibility For Agent Or Employee: Any act constituting a violation of this section by an agent or employee of any person or business shall be
deemed and held to be the act of such person or business, and such person or business shall be punishable in the same manner as if such act had
been done by such person or business personally.
H. Penalties:
1. Any minor who violates any provision of this section shall be punished by a fine not to exceed twenty five dollars ($25.00) for a first offense, fifty
dollars ($50.00) for a second offense, and one hundred dollars ($100.00) for a third or subsequent offense.
2. Any person, other than a minor, who violates any provision of this section shall be punished by a fine not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00) for
a first offense, four hundred dollars ($400.00) for a second offense, and six hundred dollars ($600.00) for a third or subsequent offense. (Ord. 2015-
15, 9-28-2015)
Chapter 9
ANIMAL CONTROL
ARTICLE A. GENERAL PROVISIONS
5-9A-1: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
The provisions of this article shall apply to all fowl and animals, domestic or nondomestic, except for dogs or cats as defined in articles B and C,
respectively, of this chapter. (1988 Code § 7-4A-1)
5-9A-2: INHUMANE TREATMENT1:
No person shall inhumanely beat, underfeed, overload, abandon or otherwise cruelly treat any animal in the village. (1988 Code § 7-4A-2)
5-9A-3: RUNNING AT LARGE:
The running at large of horses, cattle, swine, sheep, goats and fowl of all kinds within the limits of the village is hereby prohibited. (1988 Code § 7-4A-3)
5-9A-4: DISTURBING THE PEACE:
It shall be unlawful to harbor or keep any animal which disturbs the peace by loud noises at any time of the day or night. (1988 Code § 7-4A-4)
5-9A-5: ANIMAL HOUSES2:
No owner of any animal shall cause or permit any stable or place where any cow, horse or other animal or fowl is kept to become unclean, filthy or
unwholesome, nor shall such owner allow any animal or fowl infected with a contagious disease to remain therein without the permission of the health
officer. (1988 Code § 7-4A-5)
5-9A-6: LOCATION RESTRICTIONS:
A. Horses: It shall be unlawful to keep, harbor or house any horse in any place in the village that is:
1. Within fifty feet (50') of any dwelling or building used for human habitation.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 166/493
2. On any lot or parcel of land that is less than five (5) acres in size.
3. On any lot or parcel of land of any size where the same presents a health hazard or nuisance of any kind.
B. Other Animals: It shall be unlawful to keep, harbor or house any sheep, goat, swine, cattle or poultry in any place in the village that is:
1. Within two hundred feet (200') of any dwelling or building used for human habitation.
2. On any lot or parcel of land that is less than ten (10) acres in size.
3. Within one hundred feet (100') of the lot line of any adjacent parcel of real estate.
4. On any lot or parcel of land of any size where the same presents a health hazard or nuisance of any kind.
C. Exceptions: The foregoing restrictions shall not apply to domestic household pets that are kept indoors in the residence or garage of the owner thereof
at all times, and that do not otherwise constitute or create a nuisance or health hazard and that are not raised or kept for monetary gain or benefit of
any kind. (1988 Code § 7-4A-6)
5-9A-7: RABIES CONTROL:
A. Inoculation Required; Certificate: Every owner of a domestic animal in the village that can carry rabies shall have such animal inoculated for rabies by a
veterinarian, duly licensed as such by the state, as soon after he becomes the owner of such animal as it is practicable, and at least once a year
thereafter, and shall procure and have a certificate of such veterinarian setting forth the date on which said animal was so inoculated for rabies. Such
inoculations shall initially be performed within thirty (30) days from the effective date hereof, unless otherwise performed. Rabies vaccine shall conform
to and comply with the provisions and requirements established by the state department of agriculture. Failure to have such animal inoculated shall be
deemed a violation of this section.
B. Owner Responsibility: Notwithstanding any of the provisions contained herein, it shall be the duty and responsibility of every owner, keeper or custodian
of any animal in the village subject to the provisions of this section to ensure proper inoculation of such animal at all times.
C. Animal Bites: Any such animal who shall have bitten any person shall be immediately confined by the owner or custodian of such animal for a period of
ten (10) days after such biting with a licensed veterinarian at the expense of the owner, and if, upon examination, such animal is found to be rabid, it
shall immediately be destroyed by the chief of police or a person designated by him, or by a licensed veterinarian, at the expense of the owner or
custodian of such animal.
D. Destruction Authorized: Any member of the police department may destroy any vicious or rabid animal found at large within the village which poses an
immediate threat of physical injury to the residents, and which cannot be taken up and impounded without undue risk or threat of physical injury or
harm.
E. Compliance Required: Nothing contained herein shall relieve the owner, keeper or custodian of any animal from having to comply with regulations,
statutes or ordinances of any governing body or agency, when any such provisions are more stringent than those contained in this section. (1988 Code
§ 7-4A-7)
5-9A-8: VICIOUS, DANGEROUS OR NONDOMESTICATED ANIMALS:
No person shall keep or allow to be kept on any premises in the village, any type of vicious, fierce or dangerous animals or nondomestic pets or any type
of poisonous snake or other type of reptile at any time whether or not under guard, control or security. (1988 Code § 7-4A-8)
5-9A-9: DESTROYING DANGEROUS ANIMALS:
The members of the police department, or any person in cases of emergency, are authorized to kill dangerous animals of any kind when necessary for the
protection of any person or property. (1988 Code § 7-4A-9)
5-9A-10: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than the maximum provided in section 1-
4-1 of this code for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which the violation occurs or continues. (1988
Code § 7-4A-10; amd. 2009 Code)
ARTICLE B. DOGS
5-9B-1: DEFINITIONS:
AT LARGE: Off the premises of the owner or custodian of the dog and not held by leash, nor under the control of the owner or custodian of the dog or a
member of his immediate family of the age of fifteen (15) years or older.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 167/493
ATTACK: To chase any person under any circumstances, including, but not limited to, chasing a person on a bicycle or tricycle upon any street or sidewalk
or to otherwise charge at or upon any person with apparent intent to bite or otherwise injure or molest such person.
DOG: All animals of the canine species, both male and female, wild and domesticated, singular and plural.
LEASH: A cord or chain not more than six feet (6') in length, by which a dog is controlled by the person accompanying it. (1988 Code § 7-4B-1)
5-9B-2: REGISTRATION AND COUNTY LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE:
Every owner of an unlicensed dog shall register the same with the county department of health within five (5) days after he becomes the owner or keeper
of such dog, and each year as required by the county. At the time of registration, the owner shall produce evidence of inoculation as required in section 5-
9B-3 of this article by a veterinarian certifying the inoculation for rabies is valid for a period of at least one year and secure a county license by the payment
of the annual or alternative county license fee as provided in the county animal/rabies control ordinance. (Ord. 97-8, 4-14-1997; amd. 2009 Code)
5-9B-3: RABIES VACCINATION REQUIRED:
A. Inoculation Requirements: Every owner of a dog in the village shall have such dog inoculated for rabies as soon after he becomes the owner of the dog
as is practicable, by a veterinarian duly licensed as such by the state, or if given by a veterinarian of another state, the veterinarian must possess
professional qualifications similar to those required by the state of Illinois, and shall have in his possession at all times a certificate of such veterinarian
setting forth the date on which such dog was inoculated for rabies. Except as otherwise provided herein, such inoculations shall be performed before
May 1 of each year, and shall be valid for such period of time as certified by the state department of agriculture or its successor agency. Rabies
vaccines administered shall comply with the requirements established by the state department of agriculture, and of rabies vaccine approved by the
United States department of agriculture and the state department of agriculture. Failure to have such inoculations performed and reported to the village
clerk shall be deemed a violation of this article, and shall subject the owner or custodian of such dog to penalty as provided herein.
B. Age Of Dog: Unless provided otherwise by laws, rules or regulations of the state department of health, state department of agriculture and the United
States department of agriculture and the county health department, no dog of less than four (4) months of age shall be required to be immunized. The
owner or keeper of a dog who reaches four (4) months of age shall immediately cause such dog to be immunized and file certification thereof with the
village clerk within ten (10) days after any such dog reaches four (4) months of age. (1988 Code § 7-4B-4)
5-9B-4: COLLAR AND TAGS:
A. Every owner of a licensed dog shall maintain a collar or harness around the neck of such dog with the current county license tag securely attached
thereto, and, in addition thereto, a metal tag bearing the name of the dog and the name and address of the owner thereof. No person shall remove or
take away the collar or harness or license tag or ID tag from any dog.
B. It shall be unlawful for any owner or custodian of any dog to possess, harbor or keep any dog in the village without a current county license tag attached
to its collar or harness, or to harbor, keep or possess any dog for which a license has been revoked. (1988 Code § 7-4B-5; amd. 2009 Code)
5-9B-5: TERM OF LICENSE:
All dogs shall be licensed by the county department of health as provided in the county animal/rabies control ordinance. No county license shall be valid
for a period in excess of the duration of the effectiveness of the rabies inoculation. (Ord. 97-8, 4-14-1997; amd. 2009 Code)
5-9B-6: RUNNING AT LARGE; IMPOUNDMENT PROCEDURES:
A. Prohibited; Females In Heat:
1. Leash Required: It shall be unlawful for the owner or custodian of any dog to permit such dog to run at large within the village at any time off the
premises of its owner or custodian. No female dog in heat shall be permitted to be out of doors, except when controlled by the owner or custodian or
other person authorized by him, and firmly held upon an adequate hand leash, and any female dog in heat not so held and controlled shall be
deemed at large.
2. Nuisance Declared; Impoundment: Any dog running at large in violation of this section is hereby declared a public nuisance and may be picked up
and impounded in such place as is designated by the chief of police, if it is licensed; or if unlicensed, shall be disposed of by the police department.
3. Disposal By Police Department: Any dog found at large within the village without a current county license tag attached to its collar or harness or for
which a county license has been revoked shall be deemed a nuisance and shall be disposed of by the police department.
B. Notice Requirements: The provisions relative to notice upon impounding, redemption, county license fee, impounding fees and costs and inoculation as
set forth in subsection C of this section shall apply, provided nothing contained herein shall relieve the owner of any impounded dog from prosecution
for violation of this article or any portion hereof. (1988 Code § 7-4B-7)
C. Redemption; Fees: Upon the impounding of any dog by the police department, the owner or custodian of such dog shall be immediately notified, if the
same can be determined, and redemption shall be permitted subject to limitations provided herein and in other sections of this article; provided such
redemption is made within three (3) days of impounding; and, further provided, that the owner or custodian shall pay any county license fee required,
together with an amount as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code for the cost of impounding such dog, and if the dog is in the village pound, an amount
as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code for the keeping of such dog, or when in such other designated facility, the actual cost charged for keeping such
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 168/493
dog. The owner or custodian of any dog impounded who cannot produce evidence of current inoculation shall cause such dog to be properly inoculated
at the time of making redemption of said dog. (Ord. 94-11, 4-11-1994; amd. 2009 Code)
D. Third Impound: Upon the third impounding of any dog for running at large in the village, said dog shall be declared a nuisance and the dog license of its
owner revoked by the village clerk, and said dog shall be permanently removed from the village.
E. Disposition Of Unredeemed Dog: If any dog is unredeemed at the end of three (3) days after notice to the owner or custodian thereof or three (3) days
after reasonable efforts have been concluded by the police department to determine and notify such owner or custodian, it shall be the duty of the chief
of police or other person designated by him to deliver the dog to a recognized animal welfare shelter or to make such other disposition of the dog.
F. Hindering Enforcement Officials Prohibited: It shall be unlawful to hinder or molest any police officer, animal warden or other authorized person engaged
in the enforcement of this section. (1988 Code § 7-4B-7)
5-9B-7: NUISANCE DOGS:
A. Prohibition: It shall be unlawful for any owner or custodian of a dog to suffer or permit such dog to bark or howl in a disturbing degree, to attack other
animals or persons, to damage public or private property or otherwise create a public nuisance.
B. Investigation And Hearing: Notwithstanding any of the provisions of this article, the chief of police may, upon investigation and hearing, determine a dog
to be a nuisance and to pose a threat to the health, welfare and safety of the village.
C. Revocation Of Dog License; Disposition Of Dog: On making such a determination, the village clerk may, in his discretion, revoke the dog license issued
for such dog and direct the owner or custodian to remove such dog permanently from the village or direct the chief of police or his representative to
take possession of such dog and dispose of it as deemed necessary by the chief of police.
D. Custody Of Police Department: If deemed essential to the public protection, the village president or village administrator may direct the chief of police or
his representative to take immediate possession of, and hold custody of, any such dog pending investigation under this section. (1988 Code § 7-4B-8)
5-9B-8: VICIOUS, DANGEROUS DOGS:
A. Determination Of Threat; Disposition Of Dog: Notwithstanding any other provisions of this article, the chief of police may, on investigation, determine a
dog to be vicious and/or dangerous and to pose a threat of physical injury to the person. Upon such determination, such vicious dog shall be confined
as provided in subsection B of this section, or the village clerk may, in his discretion, direct the owner or custodian to remove such dog permanently
from the village or direct the chief of police or his representative to take possession of such dog and dispose of it as deemed necessary by the chief of
police. If deemed essential to the public protection, the village president, village clerk or village administrator may direct the chief of police or his
representative to take immediate possession of, and hold custody of, any such dog pending investigation under this section.
B. Confinement; Impoundment; Redemption: Any vicious and/or dangerous dog shall be confined by its owner on the owner's premises at all times in such
manner that it cannot reach persons who may have occasion to lawfully enter upon said premises. Any such dog which is not confined on its owner's
premises as provided herein is hereby declared to be a public nuisance, and such dog may be apprehended and impounded upon the order of the
chief of police or any person charged with the enforcement of this article, and the village clerk shall revoke the county license for such dog. The owner
shall have no right to redeem such dog unless he shall remove the same from the village immediately upon redemption and shall not thereafter keep,
harbor or maintain such dog in the village at any time. A dog which has, without provocation, either bitten or attacked any person shall, for a period of
twenty four (24) months thereafter, be presumed to be a dangerous dog for the purposes of this section. (1988 Code § 7-4B-9)
5-9B-9: DESTRUCTION OF CERTAIN DOGS:
Any member of the police department may destroy any vicious or rabid dog found at large within the village which poses an immediate threat of physical
injury to the residents and which cannot be taken up and impounded without undue risk of physical injury. (1988 Code § 7-4B-10)
5-9B-10: RABIES CONTROL:
A. Proclamation Of Emergency:
1. Notice To Confine Dogs: Whenever deemed necessary for reasons of public health, or whenever danger from hydrophobia or rabies is deemed to
exist in the village, the village president, by proclamation or notice published in one or more newspapers having a general circulation in the village,
may notify all persons owning or keeping dogs, whether licensed or not, to keep them confined within an enclosure from which escape is impossible,
or to keep them securely muzzled or restrained by a leash composed of chain or other indestructible material for such time as may be designated by
the proclamation or notice. (1988 Code § 7-4B-11)
2. Impoundment; Redemption; Fee: The running at large of any dog during the period set forth in the proclamation or notice is hereby declared a
nuisance, and any dog found running at large shall be impounded in the manner herein provided for unlicensed dogs; provided, that the redemption
fee for cost of impounding hereunder shall be an amount as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code.
3. Unmuzzled Dogs: The provisions of impounding, redeeming and disposing of unlicensed dogs shall also apply to such unmuzzled dogs except as
specifically modified in this subsection. (1988 Code § 7-4B-11; amd. 2009 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 169/493
B. Dog Bites; Confinement:
1. Confinement And Observation; Examination By Veterinarian: It shall be unlawful for the owner of any dog, when notified by the village or the police
department that such dog has bitten any person or animal, to sell or give away such dog or to permit or allow such dog to be taken beyond the limits
of the county. It shall be the duty of such owner of a biting dog, upon receiving notice from the village, to deliver said dog within twenty four (24)
hours to a licensed veterinarian for confinement and observation, at the expense of the owner, for a period of ten (10) days. If, however, the dog is
examined by a licensed veterinarian within twenty four (24) hours after notification by the village and found to be free of signs of rabies and the
licensed veterinarian is presented evidence that such dog has been inoculated against rabies more than thirty (30) days prior to the biting and less
than one year if a one year vaccine is used, or less than three (3) years if a three (3) year vaccine is used, and such veterinarian certifies that such
dog is, in his opinion, free of rabies, such dog shall, in lieu of veterinary hospital confinement, be confined in the house of its owner in a manner that
will prohibit said dog from escaping or from biting any person or animal for the ten (10) day period, if the licensed veterinarian adjudges such
confinement satisfactory. At the end of the ten (10) day confinement period, the owner shall present the dog for reexamination by the licensed
veterinarian. Should the dog become ill, die or escape during the ten (10) day period, the owner shall immediately notify the village police
department.
2. Escape From Confinement: Any dog that escapes or is allowed to escape during a period of home confinement shall, for the remainder of any
confinement period, be confined with a licensed veterinarian at the expense of the owner.
C. Destruction Of Rabid Dogs: Any dog found to be rabid upon examination by a veterinarian shall immediately be destroyed by the chief of police or a
person designated by him, or a licensed veterinarian, at the expense of the owner or custodian of such dog. (1988 Code § 7-4B-12)
5-9B-11: DEFECATION RESTRICTIONS:
It shall be unlawful for the owner or custodian of a dog to suffer or permit such dog, whether on leash or not, to perform any bowel movements or
eliminations of any kind on any public property or upon any private property not owned by the owner or custodian of such dog. (1988 Code § 7-4B-13)
5-9B-12: VIOLATIONS; PENALTIES:
A. Fines For Certain Violations: Any person violating any of the provisions of section 5-9B-4, subsection 5-9B-6A or subsection 5-9B-10B or C of this
article, excepting the harboring or keeping of a dog for which a license has been revoked, who complies with the provisions of this article before the
impoundment of his dog, may pay a fine without prosecution, by mailing or delivery of the fine by check, money order or currency to the police
department. The fine for the first ticket on any dog shall be ten dollars ($10.00). The fine for a second violation by the same dog within any one hundred
eighty (180) day period of any prior violation shall be twenty dollars ($20.00). The fine for a third violation by the same dog within any one hundred
eighty (180) day period of any prior violation shall be thirty five dollars ($35.00). The fine for a fourth or subsequent violation within any one hundred
eighty (180) day period shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). All of the fines herein enumerated, except that for a fourth or subsequent violation within any one
hundred eighty (180) day period, may be paid to the police department, together with a signed plea of guilty and waiver of hearing, and must be made
within forty eight (48) hours after receipt of notice of the violation. Upon the occurrence of a fourth or subsequent violation, and upon conviction thereof
within any one hundred eighty (180) day period, the owner or custodian of the dog will be required to show cause, if any he can, before the village
president and board of trustees or any committee therefrom designated by the board, why the dog should not be declared a public nuisance and
removed from the village.
B. Failure To Timely Pay; Fine Escalation: Upon the failure of the violator to pay said fine within said forty eight (48) hour period, a second notice may be
sent, no earlier than five (5) days after the first notice of violation, and the fine therefor may be paid in the same manner, but shall be in the amount of
fifteen dollars ($15.00) for the first violation as defined herein, thirty dollars ($30.00) for the second violation as defined herein and in the amount of fifty
dollars ($50.00) for a third violation as defined herein, provided said fines are paid within ten (10) days after the date of the second notice of violation.
Upon the failure of the violator to pay said fine after a second notice within ten (10) days thereafter, a final notice may be sent, no earlier than twelve
(12) business days after the second notice of violation, and the fine therefor may be paid in the same manner, but shall be in the amount of twenty
dollars ($20.00) for a first violation, and in the amount of forty dollars ($40.00) for a second violation, and in the amount of seventy five dollars ($75.00)
for a third violation of this article as defined herein. Nothing contained herein shall be deemed to require the giving of any additional notices after the
first notification is made. The transmittal of a notice by registered or certified mail shall be deemed sufficient notice, if mailed to the last known address
of the violator, and notice shall be deemed to have been accomplished even if there is a failure or refusal of the individual to whom said notice is sent to
receipt or accept the same.
C. Payment Without Prosecution: Any owner or keeper of an unlicensed dog may pay a fine without prosecution by mailing or delivery of the fine by check,
money order or currency to the police department. The fine shall be five dollars ($5.00) if paid within forty eight (48) hours after receipt of the
notification of the violation. Upon the failure of the violator to pay said fine within forty eight (48) hours, a second notice may be sent, no earlier than five
(5) days after the first notification of violation, and the fine therefor may be paid in the same manner, but shall be in the amount of ten dollars ($10.00),
provided said fine is paid within ten (10) days after the date of the second notice of violation. Upon the failure of the violator to pay said fine after a
second notice within ten (10) days thereafter, a final notice may be sent, no earlier than twelve (12) days after the second notice of violation, and the
fine therefor may be paid in the same manner, but shall be in the amount of fifteen dollars ($15.00), provided the same is paid within ten (10) days after
the date of any such notice. Nothing contained herein shall be deemed to require the giving of any additional notice after the first notification is made.
The transmittal of a notice by registered or certified mail shall be deemed sufficient notice if mailed to the last known address of the violator, and notice
shall be deemed to have been accomplished even if there is a failure or refusal of the individual to whom the notice is sent to receipt or accept the
same. All fines paid pursuant to the provisions contained herein shall be accompanied by a signed plea of guilty and a waiver of hearing.
D. General Penalty: Unless otherwise provided herein, any owner or person who violates any provision of this article, or any section hereof, shall, upon
conviction, be fined in the sum of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) for the first offense, not less than twenty dollars ($20.00) for a second offense within
any ninety (90) day period, not less than thirty five dollars ($35.00) for a third offense within any ninety (90) day period, and not less than fifty dollars
($50.00) for a fourth or subsequent offense during any ninety (90) day period, nor more than the maximum provided in section 1-4-1 of this code for
each offense. (Ord. 96-21, 8-26-1996; amd. 2009 Code)
ARTICLE C. CATS
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 170/493
5-9C-1: DEFINITIONS:
AT LARGE: Off the premises of the owner or custodian of the cat and not under the control of the owner or custodian of the cat or a member of his
immediate family.
ATTACK: To chase any person under any circumstances, including, but not limited to, chasing a person on a bicycle or tricycle upon any street or sidewalk
or to otherwise charge at or upon any person with apparent intent to bite or otherwise injure or molest such person.
CAT: All animals of the feline species, both male and female, wild and domesticated, singular and plural. (1988 Code § 7-4C-1)
5-9C-2: REGISTRATION AND COUNTY LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE:
Every owner of an unlicensed cat shall register the same with the county department of health within five (5) days after he becomes the owner or keeper of
such cat, and each year as required by the county. At the time of registration, the owner shall produce evidence of inoculation as required in section 5-9C-
3 of this article by a veterinarian certifying the inoculation for rabies is valid for a period of at least one year and secure a county license by the payment of
the license fee as provided in the county animal/rabies control ordinance. (Ord. 97-8, 4-14-1997; amd. 2009 Code)
5-9C-3: RABIES VACCINATION REQUIRED:
A. Inoculation Requirements: Every owner of a cat in the village shall have such cat inoculated for rabies as soon after he becomes the owner of the cat as
it is practicable, by a veterinarian duly licensed as such by the state, or if given by a veterinarian of another state, the veterinarian must possess
professional qualifications similar to those required by the state of Illinois, and shall have in his possession at all times, a certificate of such veterinarian
setting forth the date on which such cat was inoculated for rabies. Except as otherwise provided herein, such inoculations shall be performed before
May 1 of each year, and shall be valid for such period of time as certified by the state department of agriculture or its successor agency. Rabies
vaccines administered shall comply with the requirements established by the state department of agriculture, and of rabies vaccine approved by the
United States department of agriculture and the state department of agriculture. Failure to have such inoculations performed and reported to the chief
of police and the village clerk shall be deemed a violation of this article, and subject the owner or custodian of such cat to penalty as provided herein.
B. Age Of Cat: Unless provided otherwise by laws, rules or regulations of the state department of health, state department of agriculture and the United
States department of agriculture and the county health department, no cat of less than four (4) months of age shall be required to be immunized. The
owner or keeper of a cat who reaches four (4) months of age shall immediately cause such cat to be immunized and file certification thereof with the
village clerk within ten (10) days after any such cat reaches four (4) months of age. (1988 Code § 7-4C-4)
5-9C-4: COLLAR, TAGS AND BELL:
A. Every owner of a licensed cat shall maintain a collar or harness around the neck of such cat with the current county license tag securely attached
thereto, and in addition thereto, a metal tag bearing the name of the cat and the name and address of the owner thereof. No person shall remove or
take away the collar or harness or county license tag or ID tag from any cat.
B. It shall be unlawful for any owner or custodian of any cat to possess, harbor or keep any cat in the village without a current county license tag attached
to its collar or harness, or to harbor, keep or possess any cat for which a license has been revoked.
C. There shall also be attached to such cat a bell or other device capable of making noise to serve as a warning to birds. (1988 Code § 7-4C-5; amd. 2009
Code)
5-9C-5: TERM OF LICENSE:
All cats shall be licensed by the county department of health as provided in the county animal/rabies control ordinance. No license shall be valid for a
period in excess of the duration of the effectiveness of the rabies inoculation. (Ord. 97-8, 4-14-1997)
5-9C-6: STRAY CATS; RUNNING AT LARGE; IMPOUNDMENT PROCEDURES:
A. Stray Cats; Running At Large:
1. Stray Cats Declared A Nuisance: Stray cats are a menace to public health and endanger bird life, and the running at large of any cat within the limits
of the village is hereby declared to be a nuisance and prohibited. Any cats not equipped with a tag around their collar identifying the owner thereof, or
without a bell or other device capable of making a noise shall be deemed a stray cat.
2. Running At Large Prohibited; Impoundment: It shall be unlawful for the owner or custodian of any cat to permit such cat to run at large within the
village at any time off the premises of its owner or custodian. Any cat running at large in violation of this section is hereby declared a public nuisance
and may be picked up and impounded in such place as is designated by the chief of police, if it is licensed. If unlicensed, said cat shall be disposed
of by the police department.
3. Disposal By Police Department: Any cat found at large within the village without a current license tag attached to its collar or harness or for which a
license has been revoked shall be deemed a nuisance and shall be disposed of by the police department.
B. Notice Requirements: The provisions relative to notice upon impounding, redemption, license fee, impounding fees and costs and inoculation as set
forth in subsection D of this section shall apply, provided nothing contained herein shall relieve the owner of any impounded cat from prosecution for
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 171/493
violation of this article or any portion thereof. (1988 Code § 7-4C-7)
C. Redemption; Fees: Upon the impounding of any cat by the police department, the owner or custodian of such cat shall be immediately notified, if the
same can be determined, and redemption shall be permitted subject to limitations provided herein and in other sections of this article, provided such
redemption is made within three (3) days of impounding; and, further provided, that the owner or custodian shall pay any license fee required, together
with the sum as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code for the cost of impounding such cat, and if the cat is in the village pound, the sum as set out in
section 1-12-3 of this code for the keeping of such cat, or when in such other designated facility, the actual cost charged for keeping such cat. The
owner or custodian of any cat impounded who cannot produce current evidence of inoculation shall cause such cat to be properly inoculated at the time
of making redemption of said cat. (Ord. 94-11, 4-11-1994; amd. 2009 Code)
D. Third Impound: Upon the third impounding of any cat for running at large in the village, said cat shall be declared a nuisance and the cat license of its
owner revoked by the village clerk, and said cat shall be permanently removed from the village.
E. Disposition Of Unredeemed Cat: If any cat is unredeemed at the end of three (3) days after notice to the owner or custodian thereof or three (3) days
after reasonable efforts have been concluded by the police department to determine and notify such owner or custodian, it shall be the duty of the chief
of police or other person designated by him to deliver the cat to a recognized animal welfare shelter or to make such other disposition of the cat as is
approved by the village president. (1988 Code § 7-4C-7)
F. Female Cats In Heat: No female cat in heat shall be permitted to be out of doors, except when controlled by the owner or custodian or other person
authorized by the owner or custodian of the age of fifteen (15) years or older, and firmly held upon an adequate hand leash, and any female cat in heat
not so held and controlled shall be deemed at large. (1988 Code § 7-4C-7; amd. 2009 Code)
G. Hindering Enforcement Officials Prohibited: It shall be unlawful to hinder or molest any police officer, animal warden or other authorized person
engaged in the enforcement of this section. (1988 Code § 7-4C-7)
5-9C-7: NUISANCE CATS:
A. Prohibition: It shall be unlawful for any owner or custodian of a cat to suffer or permit such cat to meow in a disturbing degree, to attack other animals or
persons, to damage public or private property or otherwise create a public nuisance.
B. Investigation And Hearing: Notwithstanding any of the provisions of this article, the chief of police may, upon investigation and hearing, determine that a
cat is a nuisance and poses a threat to the health, welfare and safety of the village.
C. Revocation Of Cat License; Disposition Of Cat: On making such a determination, the village clerk may, in his discretion, revoke the cat license issued
for such cat and direct the owner or custodian to remove such cat permanently from the village or direct the chief of police or his representative to take
possession of such cat and dispose of it as deemed proper by the chief of police. (1988 Code § 7-4C-9)
D. Custody Of Police Department: If deemed essential to the public protection, the village president or village administrator may direct the chief of police or
his representative to take immediate possession of, and hold custody of, any such cat pending investigation under this section. (1988 Code § 7-4C-9;
amd. 2009 Code)
5-9C-8: VICIOUS, DANGEROUS CATS:
A. Determination Of Threat; Disposition Of Cat: Notwithstanding any other provisions of this article, the chief of police may, upon investigation, determine
that a cat is vicious and/or dangerous and poses a threat of physical injury to the person. Upon such determination, such vicious cat shall be confined
as provided in subsection B of this section, or the village clerk may, in his discretion, direct the owner or custodian to remove such cat permanently
from the village or direct the chief of police or his representative to take possession of such cat and dispose of it as deemed proper by the chief of
police. If deemed essential to the public protection, the village president or village administrator may direct the chief of police or his representative to
take immediate possession of, and hold custody of, any such cat pending investigation under this section. (1988 Code § 7-4C-10; amd. 2009 Code)
B. Confinement; Impoundment; Redemption: Any vicious and/or dangerous cat shall be confined by its owner on the owner's premises at all times in such
manner that it cannot reach persons who may have occasion to lawfully enter upon said premises. Any such cat which is not confined on its owner's
premises as provided herein is hereby declared to be a public nuisance, and such cat may be apprehended and impounded upon the order of the chief
of police or any person charged with the enforcement of this article, and the village clerk shall revoke the license for such cat. The owner shall have no
right to redeem such cat unless he shall remove the same from the village immediately upon redemption and shall not thereafter keep, harbor or
maintain such cat in the village at any time. A cat which has, without provocation, either bitten or attacked any person shall, for a period of twenty four
(24) months thereafter, be presumed to be a dangerous cat for the purposes of this section. (1988 Code § 7-4C-10)
5-9C-9: DESTRUCTION OF CERTAIN CATS:
Any member of the police department may destroy any vicious or rabid cat found at large within the village which poses an immediate threat of physical
injury to the residents and which cannot be taken up and impounded without undue risk of physical injury. (1988 Code § 7-4C-11)
5-9C-10: RABIES CONTROL:
A. Proclamation Of Emergency:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 172/493
1. Notice To Confine Cats: Whenever deemed necessary for reasons of public health, or whenever danger from hydrophobia or rabies is deemed to
exist in the village, the village president, by proclamation or notice published in one or more newspapers having a general circulation in the village,
may notify all persons owning or keeping cats, whether licensed or not, to keep them confined within an enclosure from which escape is impossible,
or to keep them securely muzzled or restrained by a leash composed of chain or other indestructible material for such time as may be designated by
the proclamation or notice. (1988 Code § 7-4C-12)
2. Impoundment; Redemption Fee: The running at large of any cat during the period set forth in the proclamation or notice is hereby declared a
nuisance, and any cat found running at large shall be impounded in the manner herein provided for unlicensed cats; provided, that the redemption
fee for cost of impounding hereunder shall be an amount as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code.
3. Unmuzzled Cats: The provisions of impounding, redeeming and disposing of unlicensed cats shall also apply to such unmuzzled cats except as
specifically modified in this subsection. (1988 Code § 7-4C-12; amd. 2009 Code)
B. Cat Bites:
1. Owner Requirements And Restrictions: It shall be unlawful for the owner or keeper of any cat or other animal, when notified that such cat or animal
has bitten any person, to sell or give away such cat or animal or to permit it to be taken beyond the control of the village. It shall be the duty of the
owner or keeper, upon receiving notice from the police department that the cat or animal has bitten any person, to deliver such cat or animal to a
licensed veterinarian pursuant to the provisions of subsection B2 of this section for confinement, observation and examination, and if the cat or
animal is determined to be rabid, for destruction as provided in said subsection. (1988 Code § 7-4C-8)
2. Confinement And Observation; Examination By Veterinarian: It shall be unlawful for the owner of any cat, when notified by the village or the police
department that such cat has bitten any person or animal, to sell or give away such cat or to permit or allow such cat to be taken beyond the limits of
the county. It shall be the duty of such owner of a biting cat, upon receiving notice from the village, to deliver said cat within twenty four (24) hours to
a licensed veterinarian for confinement and observation, at the expense of the owner, for a period of ten (10) days. If, however, the cat is examined
by a licensed veterinarian within twenty four (24) hours after notification by the village and found to be free of signs of rabies, and the licensed
veterinarian is presented evidence that such cat has been inoculated against rabies, more than thirty (30) days prior to the biting, and less than one
year if a one year vaccine is used, or less than three (3) years if a three (3) year vaccine is used, and such veterinarian certifies that such cat is, in
his opinion, free of rabies, such cat shall, in lieu of veterinary hospital confinement, be confined in the house of its owner in a manner that will prohibit
said cat from escaping or from biting any person or animal for the ten (10) day period, if the licensed veterinarian adjudges such confinement
satisfactory. At the end of the ten (10) day confinement period, the owner shall present the cat for reexamination by the licensed veterinarian. Should
the cat become ill, die or escape during the ten (10) day period, the owner shall immediately notify the police department.
3. Escape From Home Confinement: Any cat that escapes or is allowed to escape during a period of home confinement shall, for the remainder of any
confinement period, be confined with a licensed veterinarian at the expense of the owner.
C. Destruction Of Rabid Cat: Any cat found to be rabid upon examination by a veterinarian shall immediately be destroyed by the chief of police or a
person designated by him, or a licensed veterinarian, at the expense of the owner or custodian of such cat. (1988 Code § 7-4C-13)
5-9C-11: DEFECATION RESTRICTIONS:
It shall be unlawful for the owner or custodian of a cat to suffer or permit such cat to perform any bowel movements or eliminations of any kind on any
public property or upon on any private property not owned by the owner or custodian of such cat. (1988 Code § 7-4C-14)
5-9C-12: VIOLATIONS; PENALTIES:
A. Fines For Certain Violations: Any person violating any of the provisions of section 5-9C-4, subsection 5-9C-6A or G or subsection 5-9C-10B or C of this
article, excepting the harboring or keeping of a cat for which a license has been revoked, who complies with the provisions of this article before the
impoundment of his cat, may pay a fine without prosecution by mailing or delivery of the fine by check, money order or currency to the police
department. The fine for the first ticket on any cat shall be ten dollars ($10.00). The fine for a second violation by the same cat within any one hundred
eighty (180) day period of any prior violation shall be twenty dollars ($20.00). The fine for a third violation by the same cat within any one hundred
eighty (180) day period of any prior violation shall be thirty five dollars ($35.00). The fine for a fourth or subsequent violation within any one hundred
eighty (180) day period shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). All of the fines herein enumerated, except that for a fourth or subsequent violation within any one
hundred eighty (180) day period, may be paid to the police department, together with a signed plea of guilty and waiver of hearing, and must be made
within forty eight (48) hours after receipt of notice of the violation. Upon the occurrence of a fourth or subsequent violation, and upon conviction thereof
within any one hundred eighty (180) day period, the owner or custodian of the cat will be required to show cause, if any he can, before the village
president and board of trustees or any committee therefrom designated by the board, why the cat should not be declared a public nuisance and
removed from the village.
B. Failure To Pay: Upon the failure of the violator to pay said fine within forty eight (48) hours, a second notice may be sent, no earlier than forty eight (48)
hours after the first notice of violation, and the fine therefor may be paid in the same manner, but shall be in the amount of fifteen dollars ($15.00) for
the first violation as defined herein, thirty dollars ($30.00) for the second violation as herein defined herein and fifty dollars ($50.00) for a third violation
as defined herein, provided said fines are paid within ten (10) days after the date of the second notice of violation. Upon the failure of the violator to pay
said fine after a second notice within ten (10) days thereafter, a final notice may be sent, no earlier than twelve (12) business days after the second
notice of violation, and the fine therefor may be paid in the same manner, but shall be in the amount of twenty dollars ($20.00) for the first violation, and
in the amount of forty dollars ($40.00) for a second violation, and in the amount of seventy five dollars ($75.00) for a third violation of this article as
defined herein. Nothing contained herein shall be deemed to require the giving of any additional notices after the first notification is made. The
transmittal of a notice by registered or certified mail shall be deemed sufficient notice, if mailed to the last known address of the violator, and notice
shall be deemed to have been accomplished even if there is a failure or refusal of the individual to whom said notice is sent to receipt or accept the
same.
C. Payment Without Prosecution: Any owner or keeper of an unlicensed cat may pay a fine without prosecution, by mailing or delivery of the fine by check,
money order or currency to the police department. The fine shall be five dollars ($5.00) if paid within forty eight (48) hours after receipt of the
notification of the violation. Upon the failure of the violator to pay said fine within forty eight (48) hours, a second notice may be sent, no earlier than five
(5) days after the first notification of violation, and the fine therefor may be paid in the same manner, but shall be in the amount of ten dollars ($10.00),
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 173/493
provided said fine is paid within ten (10) days after the date of the second notice of violation. Upon the failure of the violator to pay said fine after a
second notice within ten (10) days thereafter, a final notice may be sent, no earlier than twelve (12) days after the second notice of violation, and the
fine therefor may be paid in the same manner, but shall be in the amount of fifteen dollars ($15.00), provided the same is paid within ten (10) days after
the date of any such notice. Nothing contained herein shall be deemed to require the giving of any additional notice after the first notification is made.
The transmittal of a notice by registered or certified mail shall be deemed sufficient notice, if mailed to last known address of the violator, and notice
