shall be deemed to have been accomplished even if there is a failure or refusal of the individual to whom the notice is sent to receipt or accept the
same. All fines paid pursuant to the provisions contained herein shall be accompanied by a signed plea of guilty and a waiver of hearing.
D. General Penalty: Unless otherwise provided herein, any owner or person who violates any provision of this article, or any section hereof, shall, upon
conviction, be fined in the sum of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) for the first offense, not less than twenty dollars ($20.00) for a second offense within
any ninety (90) day period, not less than thirty five dollars ($35.00) for a third offense within any ninety (90) day period, and not less than fifty dollars
($50.00) for a fourth or subsequent offense during any ninety (90) day period, nor more than the maximum provided in section 1-4-1 of this code for
each offense. (Ord. 96-21, 8-26-1996; amd. 2009 Code)
Title 6
MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC
Chapter 1
TRAFFIC CODE; GENERAL PROVISIONS; ENFORCEMENT
6-1-1: ILLINOIS VEHICLE CODE ADOPTED:
Except insofar as the application thereof is clearly impractical or inappropriate, in view of the context of purposes or penalty as provided, all of the
definitions, requirements, regulations, prohibitions, provisions and sections of the Illinois vehicle code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-100 et seq., as
amended, are hereby adopted by the village. Any and all violations thereof shall be considered violations of this title, and each such violation shall subject
the violator thereof to penalty provisions under this title if proceeded hereunder. (2009 Code)
6-1-2: RIDING ON CERTAIN VEHICLES OR PARTS OF VEHICLES:
A. Bicycles, Toy Vehicles, Skates:
1. Bicycles, Motorcycles, Toy Vehicles: It shall be unlawful for any person riding a bicycle, motorcycle or any toy vehicle on any street, to cling to or to
attach himself or his vehicle to any moving motor vehicle or wagon. (1970 Code § 25.29)
2. Skates, Coasters: It shall be unlawful for any person upon skates, rollerblades, skateboards1, line skates, a coaster, sled or other toy vehicle to go
upon any roadway other than at a crosswalk. (1970 Code § 25.30; amd. 2009 Code)
B. Riding On Fenders, Running Boards: It shall be unlawful for any person to ride upon the fenders, running board or outside step of any vehicle. (1970
Code § 25.31)
6-1-3: SNOW EMERGENCY; ONE-WAY TRAFFIC:
A. Authority To Restrict Usage:
1. Village President: Whenever deemed necessary, due to an accumulation of snow upon any street or roadway within the village, the village president,
or in his absence, the president pro tem, shall be empowered to restrict usage thereof to one-way vehicular traffic. (Ord. 79-1, 1-29-1979)
2. Absence Of Village President: The member of the board of trustees with the greatest seniority on the board of trustees, who is present in the area
and able to act, is hereby empowered and authorized to act as the president pro tem for the purposes of this section, during the period of absence of
the village president, or during the period of his inability to act. (Res. 79-3, 2-13-1979)
B. Time Period: Such restrictions shall continue until two-way traffic can be reestablished, but in no event shall it exceed twenty one (21) days unless
approved by the board of trustees.
C. Posting Signs: The village administrator shall, upon direction by the village president or the president pro tem, cause the posting of emergency traffic
guidance signs on such streets and roadways as deemed necessary during the period of such declaration of emergency.
D. Noncompliance A Violation: It shall be a violation of this section for any owner or operator of a vehicle to operate or permit the operation of any such
vehicle upon any such street or roadway during such period of emergency, contrary to the posted traffic guidance signs. (Ord. 79-1, 1-29-1979)
6-1-4: VIOLATIONS; PENALTIES:
A. Police Authority To Enforce: It shall be the duty of the chief of police and the police officers of the village to patrol the streets in the village and to make
arrests for violations of the provisions of this title. (1970 Code § 25.54)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 174/493
B. Penalties And Fines Imposed:
1. Misdemeanor Violation: It is a misdemeanor for any person to violate any of the provisions of this title unless such violation is by any other act or law
of this state declared to be a felony.
2. Misdemeanor Penalty:
a. Penalty: Every person found guilty of a misdemeanor for a violation of any of the provisions of this title for which another penalty is not provided
shall be punished by a fine of not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than the maximum provided in section 1-4-1 of this code for each offense.
(1970 Code § 25.55; amd. 2009 Code)
b. Remittance Of Fines; Failure To Pay: Fines shall be remitted in the amount of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for any such offense. Upon the failure of
the violator to pay said fine within five (5) village business days, a second notice may be sent no earlier than ten (10) days after the first notification
of violation, and the fine therefor may be paid in the same manner, but shall be in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00). Upon failure of the violator to
pay said fine after a second notice within twenty (20) days thereafter, a final notice may be sent, no earlier than thirty (30) days after the second
notice of violation, and the fine therefor may be paid in the same manner, but shall be in the amount of seventy five dollars ($75.00). Nothing
contained herein shall be deemed to require giving of any additional notice after the first notification is made. The transmittal of a notice by
registered or certified mail shall be deemed sufficient notice, if mailed to the last known address of the violator, and notice shall be deemed to have
been accomplished even if there is a failure or refusal of the individual to whom the notice is sent to receipt or accept the same. All fines paid
pursuant to the provisions contained herein shall be accompanied by a signed plea of guilty, and a waiver of hearing. (Ord. 96-21, 8-26-1996)
c. Suspension Of Driving Privileges: In addition to any fines or penalties herein provided for the violation of provisions of this title, any court of record
may, upon conviction therefor in such court, enter an order prohibiting such person so convicted from driving a motor vehicle in this state for a
period not exceeding one year. A violation of such order shall constitute a contempt of court and may be punished accordingly. (1970 Code
§ 25.55)
d. Excess Load Limits; Fine Pursuant To Statute: Any person violating any of the load limit provisions of section 6-7-5 of this title shall be fined in the
amount as set forth in the provisions of the Illinois motor vehicle code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes, in effect from time to time for the excess load
limits, but not to exceed the amount otherwise permitted by the statutes of the state for violations of municipal ordinances. (Ord. 78-18, 7-24-1978)
C. Disposition Of Fines And Penalties; Duties Of Officials:
1. Fines and penalties recovered under the provisions of this title shall be paid over to the village treasurer.
2. Failure, refusal, or neglect on the part of any judicial or other officer or employee receiving or having custody of any such fine or forfeiture to account
for or pay over any such fine or forfeiture to the village treasurer shall constitute misconduct in office and shall be grounds for removal therefrom.
(1970 Code § 25.56)
D. Liability Of Owner Or Operator: It is unlawful for the owner or any other person employing or otherwise directing the driver of any vehicle to require or
knowingly to permit the operation of such vehicle upon a street of the village in any manner contrary to this title. (1970 Code § 25.57)
Chapter 2
VEHICLE LICENSES
6-2-1: LICENSE REQUIRED; LIABILITY OF VEHICLE OWNER OR LESSEE:
A. License Required: It shall be unlawful for any person residing within the village to use or cause or permit any of its agents or employees to use any
wagon or motor vehicle upon the streets, avenues or alleys of the village unless such wagon or vehicle be licensed as hereinafter provided. (1970
Code § 26.01)
B. Owner Or Lessee Liable: The housing, garaging or otherwise keeping of any wagon or motor vehicle in the village, or its usage primarily in the village,
shall subject the owner of said vehicle to the provisions of this title. The registration of a wagon or motor vehicle with the state of Illinois with an address
in the village shall be prima facie evidence of the usage, keeping, housing or garaging of said wagon or motor vehicle in the village. The provisions of
this chapter shall apply to both the owner of a wagon or motor vehicle and the lessee thereof, and its registration to a leasing company or lessor
outside of the corporate limits of the village shall not relieve the owner or lessee for responsibility of registration thereof. (Ord. 75-20, 12-9-1975)
6-2-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; ISSUANCE:
A. Application: Any person desiring a license for any such wagon or vehicle shall file an application with the village clerk upon a form to be provided by
him, setting forth the following:
1. The name and address of the applicant;
2. A description of the wagon or vehicle for which the license is desired;
3. The place where such wagon, or vehicle for which the license is desired, is usually kept when not in use and the place where such animal or animals
drawing such wagon or vehicle is or are to be kept;
4. The number and kinds of other wagons or vehicles kept by said applicant at such place;
5. In case the application is made for a license for a motor vehicle, whether or not such motor vehicle is used or is to be used for pleasure; and
6. Such other information as may be prescribed.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 175/493
B. Issuance Of License: Upon the payment by the applicant of the license fee hereinafter provided to the village clerk, the village clerk shall issue or cause
to be issued a license authorizing the use of such wagons or vehicles within the village until the expiration of such license. (1970 Code § 26.02)
6-2-3: LICENSE TERM AND FEES:
A. Term Of License: Commencing April 1, 1984, the annual license period for all motor vehicles, trucks, motorcycles and motorized bicycles, tricycles and
vehicles of every other nature and description shall be for the period beginning on April 1 of each year and ending on March 31 of the following year.
(Ord. 82-13, 10-25-1982)
B. Fees Imposed: The license fee, as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code, under the category "license fees", to be paid annually to the village clerk, shall
be for the following:
Motor vehicles.
Each vehicle registered in the name of the person for persons sixty five (65) years of age or older.
Trucks.
Motorcycles, motorized bicycles, or motorized tricycles and other motorized vehicles. (Ord. 97-9, 4-24-1997; amd. 2009 Code)
C. Prorate Fee: If an owner or operator comes into possession of any such vehicle after the expiration of six (6) months of the license period, he shall pay
one-half (1/2) of the annual fee. (Ord. 82-13, 10-25-1982)
D. Reduced Fee For College Students: Notwithstanding anything contained in this chapter to the contrary, whenever any such vehicle is located outside
the village, for over six (6) months of any year, and used by a college or university student at such college or university, a reduced fee equal to one-half
(1/2) of the license fee set forth herein shall be paid for a vehicle sticker for such automobile, subject to the following terms and restrictions:
1. The reduced fee is applicable to one vehicle only, per student, and shall be available only for that year or years of enrollment as a full time college or
university student.
2. Applications must be accompanied by proof of registration in a full time curriculum in a college or university located outside the village, and certified
by such institution. (Ord., 12-12-1978)
E. Failure To Pay Fee:
1. Notification Of Violation; Payment Of Fine: Any person violating any of the provisions of this section, who complies with the provisions of this section
before prosecution therefor, may pay a fine without prosecution by mailing or delivery of the fine by check, money order, or currency to the
department of police of the village. The fine shall be five dollars ($5.00) if paid within five (5) days after receipt of the notification of the violation.
Upon the failure of the violator to pay said fine within five (5) days, a second notice may be sent, no earlier than ten (10) days after the first
notification of violation, and the fine therefor may be paid in the same manner, but shall be in the amount of ten dollars ($10.00), provided said fine is
paid within ten (10) days after the date of the second notice of violation. Upon the failure of the violator to pay said fine after a second notice within
ten (10) days thereafter, a final notice may be sent, no earlier than twelve (12) days after the second notice of violation, and the fine therefor may be
paid in the same manner, but shall be in the amount of twenty dollars ($20.00), provided the same is paid within ten (10) days after the date of any
such notice. Nothing contained herein shall be deemed to require the giving of any additional notice after the first notification is made. The transmittal
of a notice by registered or certified mail shall be deemed sufficient notice if mailed to the last known address of the violator, and notice shall be
deemed to have been accomplished even if there is a failure or refusal of the individual to whom the notice is sent to receipt or accept the same. All
fines paid pursuant to the provisions contained herein shall be accompanied by a signed plea of guilty and a waiver of hearing, an application for
license accompanied by the required fee therefor, and the penalty described in subsection E2 of this section.
2. Penalty Added To Annual Fee: A penalty of fifty percent (50%) will be added to the annual license fee of the above described vehicles and trucks
unless payment therefor is made on or before May 1 of the year for which such license is required. (Ord. 88-2, 2-8-1988)
F. Sale Of Vehicle; License Transfer Fee: When any such motor vehicle, truck, motorcycle, motor bicycle or motor tricycle, or other motorized vehicle is
sold, any valid existing and outstanding vehicle sticker issued therefor shall be automatically revoked. The new owner of such vehicle, if subject to
licensing by the village, shall make application for a vehicle license in accordance with the provisions of this section. If such motor vehicle is traded in
or otherwise exchanged by the owner thereof, for a new or used vehicle of the same category, upon application for a vehicle license, a new license
shall be issued to such owner for the remainder of the unexpired term of the existing license at a charge as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code, under
the category "license fees", for transfer of such vehicle license. (Ord. 82-13, 10-25-1982; amd. 2009 Code)
6-2-4: STICKERS REQUIRED:
A. Issuance Of Sticker; Display Required: Upon the issuance of said license, the village clerk shall deliver to the applicant a sticker bearing the name of
the village and the number and name of the class to which said wagon or vehicle belongs and the year for which said license is issued; and it shall be
the duty of such applicant to affix such sticker in a conspicuous place upon the front of such wagon or vehicle or upon the right side of a horsedrawn
wagon or vehicle, or if such vehicle be an automobile of any kind, then such sticker shall be placed upon the lower right hand side of the windshield as
near to the base of the same as possible; and it shall be unlawful for any person to use or cause or permit any agent or employee to use any such
wagon or vehicle, although duly licensed, upon the streets, alleys or avenues of the village unless such sticker is affixed as above provided. Village
vehicle plates issued for motorcycles or motor driven cycles shall be affixed to the rear license plate on the lower right hand side thereof in such a
manner as not to obstruct the state of Illinois license plate. (1970 Code § 26.04; amd. Ord., 10-9-1973)
B. Failure To Display Sticker: Any person who violates this section by failure to display a necessary vehicle sticker, or who violates any of the provisions of
this chapter, and who obtains the necessary license for his motor vehicle, may pay a fine without prosecution by mailing or delivery of the sum of
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 176/493
twenty five dollars ($25.00) by check, money order or currency to the department of police of the village. Such remittance must be accompanied by a
signed plea of guilty and waiver of hearing, and must be made within five (5) village business days after receipt of notice of the violation, or after such
notice is placed on the vehicle. (Ord. 96-21, 8-26-1996)
6-2-5: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not less than the amount set out in section 1-12-3 of this code nor more than the
maximum provided in section 1-4-1 of this code for each and every offense, and each day any wagon or vehicle is used upon the streets, alleys or
avenues of the village without having procured a license and without having complied with the provisions of this chapter shall be considered a separate
and distinct offense. (Ord. 96-21, 8-26-1996; amd. 2009 Code; Ord. 2014-9, 4-28-2014)
Chapter 3
BICYCLES
6-3-1: PURPOSE:
For the purpose of promoting public welfare and safety, and for the prevention of theft of bicycles, the regulations and restrictions hereinafter set forth are
hereby enacted governing the ownership and operation of bicycles in the village. (1970 Code § 27.01)
6-3-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
From and after the effective date hereof, no person shall operate upon any public street, alley or sidewalk within the village, any bicycle owned by a
resident of the village unless:
A. The ownership of the bicycle has been registered as hereinafter provided.
B. A license for the operation of the bicycle has been obtained as hereinafter provided.
C. The license plate is attached to the bicycle as hereinafter provided.
D. The mechanical condition of the bicycle is such that it can be safely operated.
E. The bicycle is equipped as hereinafter provided. (1970 Code § 27.02)
6-3-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; CONDITIONS FOR ISSUANCE; FEE:
A. Application:
1. Application for registration and license for each bicycle shall be made by the owner in writing, in duplicate, upon blank forms furnished by the village
clerk.
2. Such application shall be signed by the owner, and if the owner is a person under eighteen (18) years of age, the signature shall be witnessed by a
parent of the owner, or if no parent is living, then by the legal guardian of the owner. The application shall state the full name and address of the
owner of the bicycle, the name of the manufacturer, the serial number of the frame thereof, the approximate date when the owner obtained title
thereto, and if not new when obtained, the name and address of the person from whom it was obtained.
B. Examination Of Bicycle:
1. Such application shall be presented to the chief of police at the police station of the village. The bicycle to be registered and licensed shall be
brought to the police station at the time of presenting the application for the purpose of examination by the chief of police.
2. The chief of police shall examine the bicycle, and if he finds the mechanical condition thereof such that it can be safely operated, and that it is
equipped with reflectors as herein provided, and further finds that the statements made in the application are true, he shall mark the application and
duplicate "approved", attach his signature, and return the same to the applicant. (1970 Code § 27.03)
C. Filing Application; Fee: The applicant shall thereupon file the application with the village clerk and pay to the clerk a license fee as set out in section 1-
12-3 of this code, under the category "license fees". (Ord., 10-27-1975; amd. 2009 Code)
D. Issuance Of License: The village clerk shall, upon receiving such application and license fee, issue to the owner of the bicycle a registration card which
shall contain the name and address of the owner and the description of the bicycle contained in the application. The applicant shall affix his signature to
the registration card when issued in the presence of the village clerk; said clerk shall, with said certificate, also issue to the owner a license plate which
shall contain the words "Lake Bluff Bicycle License", and the number of the license. The registration card and the license plate shall have the same
number. The license plate shall be attached to the bicycle on the front thereof immediately below the steering bar or wheel.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 177/493
E. Endorsement; Keep On File: After the issuance of the registration card and license plate, the village clerk shall endorse upon the application and
duplicate the date of the issuance and the number thereof. The original application shall be kept on file in the office of the village clerk, and the
duplicate thereof shall be delivered to the chief of police, which shall be kept on file in his office. (1970 Code § 27.03)
6-3-4: TERM OF LICENSE:
The license so issued shall be effective so long as the applicant shall continue to be the owner of the bicycle. (1970 Code § 27.04)
6-3-5: TRANSFER REGISTRATION AND PLATE; FEE:
When any bicycle which has been registered and licensed, as herein provided, is sold, or is otherwise disposed of or destroyed, the licensee shall
immediately surrender to the chief of police the registration card and the license plate issued therefor, with the name and address of the new owner, if any,
written on the back of the registration card, and the chief of police shall immediately make proper endorsement thereof on his records, and thereupon
deliver the card and plate to the village clerk, who shall immediately make proper endorsements on his records and retain the card and plate. Upon the
sale or other transfer of a licensed bicycle, the licensee may, upon proper application, have the said plate assigned to another bicycle owned by the
applicant and shall pay to the village clerk a transfer fee in the amount as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code, under the category "license fees". (1970
Code § 27.05; amd. Ord., 10-27-1975; 2009 Code)
6-3-6: REPORT LOSS OF LICENSE PLATE; DUPLICATE LICENSE FEE:
A. Issue Duplicate License; Fee: The licensee shall report immediately to the chief of police the loss or destruction of the license plate of the licensee, and
the circumstances surrounding the loss or destruction thereof. With the approval of the chief of police, the village clerk shall issue a duplicate license
upon payment to the village clerk by the licensee of a fee as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code, under the category "license fees". (1970 Code
§ 27.06; amd. Ord., 10-27-1975; 2009 Code)
B. Denial Of Duplicate License Plate: If the chief of police shall not approve the issuance of a duplicate license plate, the licensee shall be required to
make a new application for registration and license, and attach to such application the existing registration card or satisfactory account for the inability
to do so. (1970 Code § 27.06)
6-3-7: DISPOSITION OF REVENUES:
The village clerk shall pay over to the village treasurer the license fees received. The fees shall be used for the purpose of improving, paving, repairing or
maintaining the streets and other public roadways within the village; provided, that the actual cost in connection with the issuance of such licenses and the
collection of the fees may be deducted from the total amount collected as provided by statute. (1970 Code § 27.17)
6-3-8: OPERATING REGULATIONS AND RESTRICTIONS:
Every person operating a bicycle upon any street, alley or sidewalk in the village shall obey strictly the following regulations and restrictions pertaining
thereto:
A. Riding In Double Or Single File: When more than two (2) persons in a group are operating bicycles on a roadway, they shall ride in double file or in
single file.
B. Clinging To Vehicles: No person operating a bicycle shall cling to or attach himself or herself or the bicycle to any other moving vehicle.
C. Emerging From Alleys, Driveways And Garages: The operator of a bicycle emerging from an alley, driveway, garage or private sidewalk shall stop the
bicycle immediately prior to driving onto or across a public sidewalk, or onto or across a public sidewalk line projected across an alley, and shall
exercise extreme care in these cases.
D. Extra Passenger: No person operating a bicycle shall carry another person on the same bicycle. This restriction shall not apply to tandem bicycles
which are built for two (2) riders.
E. Intoxication; Drug Use; Physical Inability: No person shall operate a bicycle while under the influence of liquor or drugs or while physically or mentally
unfit to safely operate the same. (1970 Code § 27.07)
F. Lights And Reflectors: No bicycle shall be operated between the hours of sunset and sunrise without having securely attached one white lamp on the
front, and a red reflector on the rear thereof, each of which shall be not less than one inch (1") in diameter. Such lighted lamp and reflector shall be
clearly visible under normal atmospheric conditions for a distance of at least two hundred feet (200') ahead and to the rear respectively. No other lights
shall be used on a bicycle; except, that a red light similarly visible may be substituted for a red reflector on the rear of any bicycle. The above
mentioned white front headlamp, and red rear lamp when provided, shall be lit and illuminated at all times when riding between the hours of sunset and
sunrise. (Ord., 1-12-1971)
G. Mechanical Condition: No person shall operate a bicycle which is not in such mechanical condition that the same can be safely operated.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 178/493
H. Operating On Sidewalks: Bicycles may be operated on sidewalks in public parks and in the residence district, but in single file only. Under all
circumstances, the rider shall yield the right of way to pedestrians using the sidewalk, and due and proper care shall at all times be exercised by the
rider for the pedestrians. When approaching a pedestrian on the sidewalk, the speed of the bicycle shall be reduced to a speed which is no greater
than necessary to continue the operation of the bicycle without the rider dismounting, and shall not be increased until the pedestrian has been passed.
I. Parking Bicycles: Bicycles, when parked in the business district, shall be parked in zones, parking racks, or other places officially designated for that
purpose. Bicycles shall not, at any time, in any place, be indiscriminately parked by anyone along buildings in such a manner as to interfere with
pedestrians, or along roadways where they may interfere with traffic, or with persons getting into or out of motor vehicles. No person shall move or in
any manner interfere with any bicycle properly parked, nor shall any person interfere or in any manner hinder any person from properly parking a
bicycle; except, that a member of the police department or fire department may move, or in proper cases prevent the parking of the bicycle, when, in
the judgment of the police officer or firefighter, his action is necessary in order to properly safeguard persons or property.
J. Keeping To Right: All bicycles, when operated on roadways, shall be kept to the right and shall be operated as near as practicable to the right hand
edge of the roadway.
K. Signaling Device: Each bicycle shall be equipped with a signaling device, in good working order and audible at a distance of fifty feet (50') when
sounded.
L. Speed: No bicycle shall be operated at any time faster than is reasonable or proper, and every bicycle shall be operated with reasonable regard to the
safety of the rider and of other persons and property.
M. Traffic Regulations: Every person operating a bicycle shall strictly observe all traffic signs and signals and all other traffic rules and regulations
applicable thereto, and shall obey the orders and directions of every officer of the village authorized to direct or regulate traffic.
N. Trick Riding: No person shall operate a bicycle in any manner except through the use of both hands upon the handlebar thereof or otherwise to indulge
in any kind of trick or unsafe riding.
O. Method Of Turning; Signals: The operator of a bicycle on a roadway, when making a right turn, shall follow the right hand edge of the roadway, and the
operator of a bicycle on a roadway when making a left turn, shall approach the point of turning in the traffic lane nearest the center of the roadway and
shall not cut the left hand corner. No operator of a bicycle shall suddenly start, slow down, stop or attempt to turn without first giving the standard signal
required by state law for the operation of motor vehicles under the same circumstances.
P. Following Firetruck; Operation Near Fires: No person operating a bicycle within the village shall follow or attempt to follow any firetruck, nor shall any
person operate a bicycle within one block of a fire which is being extinguished by the fire department.
Q. Compliance With State Traffic Laws: Every person operating a bicycle upon a roadway shall be subject to the provisions of the act of the legislature of
the state of Illinois, entitled "an act in relation to the regulation of traffic", approved July 9, 1939, and all amendments thereto1, insofar as the provisions
of said act by their nature can have application to the operation of a bicycle, except as otherwise provided herein. (1970 Code § 27.07)
6-3-9: RENTAL AGENCIES:
Bicycles offered for rent by a rental agency shall be equipped by the rental agency as required by this chapter and shall be kept in good and safe working
condition. Rental agencies shall comply, in all respects, with the provisions of this chapter and shall be responsible for the condition of the bicycles they
rent. The chief of police shall make periodical inspections of rental agencies to ascertain that they are complying with the provisions of this chapter. (1970
Code § 27.08)
6-3-10: INSPECTION OF BICYCLES:
Each member of the police department is hereby authorized to inspect any bicycle, at any reasonable time, for the purpose of making a checkup of the
license plate, license number, and serial number for the purpose of determining the mechanical condition of the bicycle. No person shall in any manner
interfere with or hinder the making of such inspection. (1970 Code § 27.09)
6-3-11: REMOVAL OF SERIAL NUMBER OR LICENSE PLATE:
It shall be unlawful for any person wilfully or maliciously to remove, destroy, mutilate, or alter the serial number of any bicycle licensed pursuant to this
chapter or to remove, destroy, mutilate or alter any license plate or registration card during the time in which the license plate or registration card is in
force. The chief of police is hereby authorized to stamp numbers on the frame of a bicycle in a distinguishable manner, for identification purposes, upon
which no serial number can be found, or upon which the serial number is illegible or insufficient for identification purposes. (1970 Code § 27.10)
6-3-12: USE OF BICYCLE WITHOUT CONSENT OF OWNER:
It shall be unlawful for any person to use or operate any bicycle within the village without the consent of the owner. (1970 Code § 27.11)
6-3-13: ACQUIRING BICYCLE WITH MISSING SERIAL NUMBER:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 179/493
It shall be unlawful for any person residing in the village, or any dealer in bicycles operating in the village, to purchase, receive in trade, or otherwise
acquire any bicycle from which the serial number on the frame has been removed, destroyed, mutilated or altered, without first reporting the same to the
chief of police. (1970 Code § 27.12)
6-3-14: BICYCLE DEALERS REPORT TO POLICE CHIEF:
Every person engaged in the business of selling, buying or trading new or used bicycles within the village is hereby required to make a written report to the
chief of police, at the end of each month, or more often if requested by said chief of police; such report shall contain the following information:
A. The name and address of all persons to whom and from whom a bicycle was sold, purchased or traded during the period covered by the report, not
including, however, purchase of new bicycles from regularly established jobbers or wholesalers.
B. A description of the bicycle involved in each such transaction consisting of the name of the manufacturer, the serial number on the frame, and the
license number of the bicycle, if the bicycle has been registered and a license issued to the owner by the village.
C. Such additional information as the chief of police may require. (1970 Code § 27.13)
6-3-15: ENFORCEMENT; LICENSE REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION:
The chief of police is hereby authorized, empowered and directed to enforce the provisions of this chapter. The chief of police is hereby authorized and
empowered to suspend, for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days, or to revoke any license issued under the provisions of this chapter for the violation of
any of the provisions of this chapter and to impound for a period of not to exceed thirty (30) days any unregistered or improperly registered bicycle, or the
bicycle of any person with which a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter has been committed. The action of the chief of police in suspending or
revoking any license or revoking or impounding any bicycle, as provided in this section, shall be conclusive and final. The suspension or revocation of a
license or the impounding of a bicycle shall not preclude the prosecution of the offender for the violation of this chapter and the infliction of any other
penalty provided herein. (1970 Code § 27.14)
6-3-16: PENALTY:
Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be, upon conviction, punished by a fine of not more than the maximum provided in
section 1-4-1 of this code for each and every offense. (1970 Code § 27.15; amd. 2009 Code)
Chapter 4
PARKING REGULATIONS
6-4-1: DISPLAYING VEHICLE OR MERCHANDISE FOR SALE:
It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle upon any street for the purpose of displaying it for sale, or to park any vehicle upon any business street from which
vehicle merchandise is peddled. (1970 Code § 25.49)
6-4-2: PARKING FOR PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES:
A. Parking Prohibited: It is unlawful to park any motor vehicle which is not bearing registration plates or decals issued pursuant to the Illinois motor vehicle
code to a handicapped person, as defined in the Illinois motor vehicle code, in any parking place, including any private or public off street parking
facility specifically reserved for handicapped or disabled persons by the posting of an official sign. (Ord. 87-28, 8-10-1987; amd. 2009 Code)
B. Penalty: Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of subsection A of this section shall be fined one hundred dollars ($100.00) in addition to any
costs or charges connected with the removal or storage of any such motor vehicle. The fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) may be paid without
prosecution in accordance with the provisions of subsection 6-1-4B of this title, as amended; except, that the amount of the fine shall be one hundred
dollars ($100.00), and no notices need be sent for failure to pay such fine before action is taken for further prosecution. (Ord. 96-21, 8-26-1996)
6-4-3: UNION PACIFIC COMMUTER STATION PARKING LOT:
A. Obstructing Pedestrian Areas: It shall be unlawful for any person to park upon, block or otherwise obstruct for any period of time any pedestrian areas
adjacent to or designated for pedestrian access to or egress from the depot building of Union Pacific. (Ord. 86-2, 2-24-1986; eff. 4-1-1986; amd. Ord.
2014-21, 10-27-2014)
B. Parking Areas For Persons With Disabilities: It shall be unlawful for any person, except a handicapped driver possessing a motor vehicle bearing
handicapped plates issued by the secretary of state of Illinois, to park such motor vehicle in any place specifically reserved for handicapped individuals.
C. Prohibited Parking; Vehicle Removal And Costs: It shall be unlawful for any person to park, permit, cause or procure to be parked or to suffer any motor
vehicles to remain within the parking lot described herein, at any time between the hours of three o'clock (3:00) A.M. and five o'clock (5:00) A.M.,
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 180/493
except by an overnight parking permit as provided in subsection D of this section. Any such motor vehicle so parked or which shall be permitted to
remain in any such area during the hours aforesaid may be removed by the village and shall be stored at the expense of the owner thereof. The cost of
removal and storage of any such motor vehicle so removed shall constitute a lien upon the motor vehicle, which shall be repaid to the village before
delivery thereof to the owner or operator thereof.
D. Parking Rates; Restrictions:
1. Overnight Parking Permit Issuance: Upon application and payment of the fee as hereinafter provided, the office of the village clerk shall issue an
overnight parking permit which shall be valid for the period shown thereon. However, an overnight parking permit shall not be used in lieu of an all
day parking sticker or decal in those lots where such sticker or decal is required for parking from six o'clock (6:00) A.M. to six o'clock (6:00) P.M.
(Ord. 86-2, 2-24-1986, eff. 4-1-1986)
2. Fee; Nighttime Hours; Areas: The fee to be paid for an overnight permit shall be as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code, under the category "permit
fees", paid in advance to the office of the village clerk or the police department. Overnight parking shall be permitted during the hours from six o'clock
(6:00) P.M. to six o'clock (6:00) A.M. the following morning. Overnight parking shall be permitted only in those areas designated therefor. Overnight
parking shall be permitted on the east side of the lot on even numbered days and on the west side of the lot on odd numbered days. The date on
which said twelve (12) hour overnight parking begins shall be determinative of whether the day is an even or odd numbered day. (Ord. 86-2, 2-24-
1986, eff. 4-1-1986; amd. 2009 Code)
3. Disposition Of Revenue; Overnight Parking Permits: All revenue derived from the sale of overnight parking permits shall be kept in a special parking
fund and used for the purpose of improving, paving, repairing, maintaining said parking lot, for other related expenses, and the administration
therefor.
4. Parking Within Designated Parking Space Lines: When the village shall cause lines or marks to be placed in any parking area designating individual
parking space, it shall be unlawful for any person to park or allow to be parked or placed any such motor vehicle in such parking area except within
the lines so designated or so as to encroach upon an adjacent designated space. It shall further be unlawful for any person to park or place any
motor vehicle in any part of such parking area marked and indicated by lettering "No Parking" or otherwise prohibited parking.
5. Duty To Lock Vehicles; Nonliability Of Village: It shall be and is hereby declared to be the duty of any person who shall park or permit the parking of
any motor vehicle in any such parking area to lock and secure the said motor vehicle for the prevention of theft of the vehicle or its contents, and the
village shall not be liable in the maintenance of such parking area to any person for loss or damage to any motor vehicle or contents of any motor
vehicle placed in said parking area, nor for the injury to persons or property arising from the use and maintenance of any such parking area.
6. Following Proper Direction Of Travel: When signs are erected giving notice thereof, or when lines or markings have been placed upon the pavement
or parking lot surface indicating the direction of travel to be followed, it shall be unlawful for any person (except when emerging from a marked
parking space) to operate a motor vehicle in any direction other than that indicated by such lines, markings, or signs, or to disregard the instructions
of any such signs with respect to ingress or egress to such areas, lots, tracts, or parcels of land.
7. Backing Into Parking Spaces: When signs are erected giving notice thereof, it shall be unlawful for any person to back into any parking space.
8. Days And Times Parking Prohibited: When signs are erected giving notice thereof, it shall be unlawful for any person to park any motor vehicle in
such parking lot, hereinafter designated, between the hours of six o'clock (6:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) P.M. daily except Saturday and Sunday,
such holiday periods or other times which may be exempted by special village board direction, unless such motor vehicle has affixed thereto, in the
manner specified, a daytime parking sticker or decal issued by the village.
9. Daytime Parking Permit Issuance: Upon application and payment of the fee, the village clerk shall issue a daytime parking sticker or decal which
shall be valid for the period shown thereon in such parking lot. (Ord. 86-2, 2-24-1986, eff. 4-1-1986)
10. Daytime Parking Sticker Fee: The daytime parking sticker or decal fee shall be due and payable annually on or before May 1 of each year. For new
daytime parking stickers or decals purchased after May 1, the initial purchase fee shall be reduced at the time of purchase by one-twelfth (1/12) of the
annual amount for each full month lapsed since May 1. Refunds shall be made only upon return of the sticker or decal and shall be in the amount
paid for the sticker less a reduction of one-twelfth (1/12) of the annual fee for each full month lapsed since the purchase date. No refunds shall be
made for stickers or decals on or after February 1 of each year. No reduction of any purchase price and no refund shall be made for partial months.
(Ord. 2014-21, 10-27-2014)
11. Replacement Sticker; Fee: When an owner or operator who has purchased a daytime parking sticker or decal in accordance with the provisions of
this section sells or disposes of his motor vehicle prior to the date on which such daytime parking sticker or decal shall expire and purchases or
acquires a replacement motor vehicle upon proper application and payment as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code, under the category "permit
fees", the village clerk shall issue a replacement daytime parking sticker or decal.
12. Daily Fee: Unless otherwise restricted by parking limits of this section, parking shall be permitted only by daytime parking sticker or decal or by
daily fee. The daily fee for a parking space shall be per day, per vehicle, as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code, under the category "permit fees".
(Ord. 86-2, 2-24-1986, eff. 4-1-1986; amd. 2009 Code)
13. Disposition Of Revenue; Daytime Parking: All revenues derived from the sale of daytime parking stickers or decals or from daily fees shall be kept
in the parking fund and used for the purpose of improving, paving, repairing, and maintaining said parking lot, and related access areas, for other
related expenses, and the administration therefor. (Ord. 86-2, 2-24-1986, eff. 4-1-1986)
14. Annual Fee For Daytime Parking: The annual fee to be paid for a daytime parking sticker or decal shall be as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code,
under the category "permit fees". (Ord. 97-9, 4-24-1997, eff. 5-1-1997; amd. 2009 Code)
15. Sticker Affixed To Windshield: The sticker or decal shall be affixed to the inside lower left hand corner of the rear window of the vehicle unless the
vehicle is backed into a parking space, in which event, every effort should be made to affix the sticker or decal to the lower left hand corner of the
front windshield. Stickers or decals shall not be obstructed from view from the exterior of the vehicle. (Ord. 88-11, 3-28-1988)
16. CBD Permits: Effective June 1, 2015, vehicles displaying a valid central business district parking permit ("CBD permit holders") shall only be
allowed to park in those portions of the train station depot parking lot designated for parking for CBD permit holders. Those portions of the train
station depot parking lot designated for parking for CBD permit holders shall be the northerly end of the parking lot and the eastern perimeter of the
parking lot as designated with appropriate signs by the village administrator. (Ord. 2015-3, 3-23-2015)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 181/493
E. Spaces Reserved For Persons With Disabilities: An appropriate number of parking spaces shall be reserved for handicapped parking on the westerly
portion of said commuter parking lot adjacent to pedestrian access and egress points to said depot.
F. Offense By Person Other Than Registered Owner: Every person in whose name a vehicle is registered pursuant to law and who permits usage of such
vehicle by another, or who leases the same to another, after receiving notice of a violation of this section involving such vehicle, shall, upon request,
provide such police officers as have authority of the offense, and the court having jurisdiction thereof, with a written statement of the name and address
of the operator of the said motor vehicle at the time of such offense and the identifying number upon registration plates and registration sticker of such
vehicle. Upon any failure to do so, within five (5) days after such written notice is transmitted by mail or otherwise, the village clerk may, in addition to
other remedies provided herein, revoke all decal and sticker privileges, and no refunds shall be made therefor.
G. Sign Placement: The village administrator is hereby directed to cause the placement of parking signs designating the restrictions, terms and conditions
of parking on said commuter parking lot. (Ord. 86-2, 2-24-1986, eff. 4-1-1986)
H. General Penalty: Any person who violates any of the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined in an amount of not less than
twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). Each day that any violation exists or continues shall be deemed a separate
offense for which a separate fine may be levied. (Ord. 86-2, 2-24-1986, eff. 4-1-1986; amd. 2009 Code)
I. Payment Of Fine; Notice:
1. Fine Without Prosecution: Any person violating any of the provisions of this section, except for parking in a handicapped space, and who removes
his or her vehicle before the same is impounded, may pay a fine without prosecution by mailing or delivery of the fine by check, money order, or
currency to the department of police of the village. The fine shall be twenty five dollars ($25.00) if paid within five (5) days after receipt of the
notification of the violation. Upon the failure of the violator to pay said fine within five (5) days, a second notice may be sent, no earlier than ten (10)
days after the first notification of violation, and the fine therefor may be paid in the same manner, but shall be in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00),
provided said fine is paid within ten (10) days after the date of the second notice of violation. Upon the failure of the violator to pay said fine after a
second notice within ten (10) days thereafter, a final notice may be sent, no earlier than twelve (12) days after the second notice of violation, and the
fine therefor may be paid in the same manner, but shall be in the amount of seventy five dollars ($75.00), provided the same is paid within ten (10)
days after the date of any such notice. Nothing contained herein shall be deemed to require the giving of any additional notice after the first
notification is made. The transmittal of a notice by registered or certified mail shall be deemed sufficient notice, if mailed to the last known address of
the violator, and notice shall be deemed to have been accomplished even if there is a failure or refusal of the individual to whom the notice is sent, to
receive or accept the same. All fines paid pursuant to the provisions contained herein shall be accompanied by a signed plea of guilty and a waiver
of hearing. Each day that any violation exists or continues to exist shall be deemed a separate offense for which a separate fine shall be paid. (Ord.
96-21, 8-26-1996)
2. Penalty: Any person who violates any of the provisions of this subsection shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined in an amount of not less than
twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than the maximum provided in section 1-4-1 of this code. Each day that any violation exists or continues to exist
shall be deemed a separate offense for which a separate fine shall be paid. (Ord. 88-3, 2-8-1988; amd. 2009 Code)

vehicles to remain within the parking lot described herein, at any time between the hours of three o'clock (3:00) A.M. and five o'clock (5:00) A.M.,
except by an overnight parking permit as hereinafter provided. Any such motor vehicle so parked or which shall be permitted to remain in any such

shall be paid in advance to the office of the village clerk or the police department. Overnight parking shall be permitted during the hours from six
o'clock (6:00) P.M. to six o'clock (6:00) A.M. the following morning. Overnight parking shall be permitted only in those areas designated therefor.
Overnight parking shall be permitted on the east side of the lot on even numbered days and on the west side of the lot on odd numbered days. The
date on which said twelve (12) hour overnight parking begins shall be determinative of whether the day is an even or odd numbered day. (Ord. 86-3,
2-24-1986, eff. 4-1-1986; amd. 2009 Code)

corporate fund of the village and used for the purposes as deemed necessary and advisable by the corporate authorities of the village.

parking spaces, it shall be unlawful for any person to park or allow to be parked or placed any such motor vehicle in such parking area except within

12. Daily Fee: Unless otherwise restricted by parking limits of this section, parking shall be permitted only by daytime parking sticker or decal or by

parking sticker or decal shall be for motor vehicles licensed by the village (resident).
b. Review Of Fee: The above prescribed fee shall be reviewed at least annually by the village board and may be revised in accordance with the
findings of such review.
c. Nonresidents: Motor vehicles (nonresidents) not licensed by the village are prohibited from parking in the lot designated in this section. (Ord. 97-9,

6-4-5: TEMPORARY PARKING REGULATIONS:
The village administrator, upon determining that temporary parking regulations are necessary to address an emergency or other special condition or event,
is authorized to make and enforce parking regulations that temporarily supersede the permanent parking regulations in this chapter. Such temporary traffic
regulations may be in effect only during the period of the emergency or special condition or event, as determined by the village administrator, but in no
event longer than ninety (90) days without approval by resolution of the village board of trustees. The village administrator or his designee must install and
maintain appropriate signage at the locations affected by the temporary traffic regulations advising motorists of those regulations. (Ord. 2009-21, 9-14-
2009)
Chapter 5
TRAFFIC SCHEDULES
6-5-1: THROUGH STREETS:
Every driver of a vehicle traversing any street intersecting with any street designated as a through street shall stop such vehicle before entering upon such
through street unless a go signal is given at such intersection by a traffic officer or a traffic sign. (1988 Code § 9-4-10)
A. North Terrace Subdivision Residential Streets: At any time, it shall be unlawful to utilize Garfield Avenue, West Washington Avenue, Pine Court,
Hancock Avenue, Lincoln Avenue, Rockland Avenue, Mawman Avenue, or Main Street, or any combination thereof, as through streets to travel from
West Scranton Avenue to Green Bay Road or from Green Bay Road to West Scranton Avenue. (Ord. 97-2, 1-13-1997)
B. Through Streets Designated: The following streets and parts of streets are designated as through streets:
Green Bay Road, except where the same intersects with State Route 176, throughout its length in the Village.
Sheridan Road, throughout its length in the Village.
State Route 176, throughout its length in the Village. (1988 Code § 9-4-10)

6-5-5: SPEED LIMITS:
A. First Division Vehicles: No person shall drive a vehicle of the first division, as described in state statute, upon any public highway at a speed greater
than is reasonable and proper, having regard to the traffic and the use of the way, or so as to endanger the life or limb or injure the property of any
person. If the rate of speed of any motor vehicle of the first division through the business district of the village exceeds twenty (20) miles per hour, or if
the rate of speed of any motor vehicle operated on any public highway where the same passes through a residence district of the village exceeds
twenty (20) miles per hour, or if the rate of speed of any motor vehicle operated on any public highway in a suburban district exceeds thirty five (35)
miles per hour, such rates of speed shall be prima facie evidence that the person operating such motor vehicle is running at a rate of speed greater
than is reasonable and proper, without having regard for the traffic and use of the way, or so as to endanger the life or limb or injure the property of any
person.
B. Second Division Vehicles: The speed of all vehicles of the second division, as described in state statute, shall always be reasonable and safe and be
governed, as near as may be, by the general requirements of subsection A of this section, but such speed shall not exceed the following rates: (1988
Code § 9-4-8; amd. 2009 Code)
1. Vehicles having a gross weight of fifteen thousand (15,000) pounds and less, including the weight of the vehicle and maximum load:
a. If equipped with pneumatic tires, twenty five (25) miles per hour.
b. If equipped with two (2) or more solid rubber tires, ten (10) miles per hour.
2. Vehicles having a gross weight of more than fifteen thousand (15,000) pounds, including the weight of the vehicle and maximum load:
a. If equipped with pneumatic tires, twenty (20) miles per hour.
b. If equipped with two (2) or more solid rubber tires, ten (10) miles per hour.
C. Duty To Decrease Speed:
1. The fact that the speed of a vehicle is lower than the foregoing prima facie limits shall not relieve the driver from the duty to decrease speed when
approaching and crossing an intersection, when approaching and going around a curve, when approaching a hillcrest, when traveling upon any
narrow or winding roadway or when special hazards exist with respect to pedestrians or other traffic or by reason of weather or highway conditions,
and speed shall be decreased as may be necessary to avoid colliding with any person or vehicle or on entering the highway in compliance with legal
requirements and the duty of all persons to use due care.
2. Notwithstanding the establishment of any maximum speed limit in this section, the driver of any motor vehicle shall decrease the speed of his vehicle
whenever a special hazard exists for traffic, pedestrians or property upon any roadway.
D. Speed Limits On Specific Streets: Subject to the restrictions set forth in this section, except as to restrictions upon speed for vehicles of the first division,
and pursuant to an engineering survey made pursuant to law to ascertain the proper speed limit upon certain streets, the following speed restrictions
for certain streets are hereby established in the village:
30/first division vehicles
Green Bay
Road
From the intersection with Rockland Road, formerly known as State Route
176, to the southern village limits

6-5-9: WEIGHT LIMITS:
A. Specific Streets: It shall be unlawful to drive or operate any truck in excess of the weight limits hereinafter set forth, upon the streets designated herein,
at any time:
Mawman Avenue, between West Scranton Avenue and West Blodgett Avenue, any truck in excess of two (2) tons. Any person violating this provision
shall be fined not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than the maximum provided in section 1-4-1 of this code for each and every offense. Each
usage of any roadway upon which such truck traffic is prohibited shall be considered a separate offense, whether committed on the same day or
another day. (Ord. 80-6, 4-8-1980; amd. 2009 Code)
B. Union Pacific Railway Bridge, Green Bay Road:
1. Definitions: Definitions of any terms or words used herein shall be in accordance with the provisions of the Illinois motor vehicle code, 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/1-101 et seq. (Ord. 81-17, 9-8-1991)
2. Weight Restriction: It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or move on, upon or across, or for the owner or operator to cause or knowingly permit
to be driven or moved on, upon or across a certain bridge over the Union Pacific railway right of way located on Green Bay Road in the village,
designated as bridge number 0496800 by the department of transportation of the state of Illinois, any vehicle of any nature and description which,
together with its load, exceeds ten (10) tons in weight. (Ord. 81-17, 9-8-1981; amd. Ord. 2014-21, 10-27-2014)
3. Exception; Emergency Vehicles: The foregoing weight limitation shall not apply to fire apparatus, equipment used for snow and ice removal
operations, vehicles involved in providing paramedic and rescue services, and other vehicles owned, operated or requested by the village. Said
usage is required for emergency reasons, provided such usage is approved by the structural engineer as an exception to his inspection report of
March 1980 on said bridge (Del Leuw, Cather And Company or Illinois department of transportation). (Ord. 81-17, 9-8-1981)
4. Posting Of Signs: The village administrator or his authorized representative is hereby authorized and directed to post weight limitation signs at both
approaches to said bridge crossing in accordance with the standards for such construction.
5. Most Restrictive Provisions Apply: Notwithstanding anything contained herein to the contrary, whenever a more restrictive weight limitation is
imposed by any other governmental body or agency having jurisdiction over said bridge structure, or by the owner, person or entity responsible for
the maintenance of said bridge structure, the most restrictive provisions shall apply.
6. Penalty: Any person violating any of the provisions of this subsection shall be fined not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than the maximum
provided in section 1-4-1 of this code for each and every offense. Each usage of said bridge structure in violation of the weight limits established
herein shall be considered a separate offense, whether committed on the same day or another day. (Ord. 81-17, 9-8-1981; amd. 2009 Code)
6-5-10: INTERSECTION CLOSURES AND TRAFFIC RESTRICTIONS:
A. Closure Of Intersection: Northern Avenue, at its intersection with Illinois Route 41, shall be permanently closed to all vehicular traffic except for
emergency vehicles and equipment. (Ord. 95-05, 3-13-1995)
B. Traffic Restrictions: All vehicular traffic, including bicycles, on or along the streets designated as traffic restricted, except pleasure traffic of a
nonautomotive nature, and except such traffic as is necessary for maintaining such streets when performed under the supervision of a duly authorized
Street

and maintained, at or near the intersection of such streets, such structures or signs as he deems necessary to enforce the provisions of this
