6-5-11: YIELD RIGHT OF WAY STREETS:
The intersections designated as yield right of way intersections shall be established by the village board of trustees from time to time. (2009 Code)
6-5-12: USE OF CERTAIN STREETS BY BICYCLES AND PEDESTRIANS:
A. Riding Bicycles: The riding of bicycles shall be prohibited on those streets in the village designated from time to time by the village board of trustees.
B. Use By Pedestrians: Pedestrians shall be prohibited on those streets in the village designated from time to time by the village board of trustees. (2009
Code)
C. Lillian Dells Drive: The use by any person of that portion of the public right of way extending from the intersection of North Avenue and Maple Avenue
on the west to Lake Michigan on the east and commonly known as Lillian Dells Drive shall be permitted only during the hours between sunrise and
sunset and shall be prohibited at all other times. (Ord. 2012-17, 8-13-2012)
Chapter 6
PEDESTRIANS
6-6-1: RIGHT OF WAY:
A. It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to drive into any crosswalk without the exercise of due and proper care in view of the special use made
thereof by pedestrians.
B. It shall be unlawful to drive any vehicle into any crosswalk while there is in such crosswalk upon the half of the roadway upon which such vehicle is
traveling any pedestrian engaged in crossing the roadway until such pedestrian shall have passed beyond the path of such vehicle, when the
pedestrian shall indicate his intention to cross.
C. The driver of a vehicle shall stop before entering any crosswalk when any other vehicle proceeding in the same direction is stopped at such crosswalk
for the purpose of permitting a pedestrian to cross. (1970 Code § 25.09)
6-6-2: USE OF ROADWAYS; SOLICITING RIDES:
A. Most Direct Route: At no place shall a pedestrian cross any roadway other than by the most direct route to the opposite curbing, and when crossing at
any place other than a crosswalk he shall yield the right of way to all vehicles upon the roadway.
B. Interference With Traffic: No person shall stand or loiter in any roadway if such act interferes with the lawful movement of traffic.
C. Soliciting Rides: It shall be unlawful for any person to stand in a roadway for the purpose of soliciting a ride from the driver of any vehicle1. (1970 Code
§ 25.10)
6-6-3: OBEY SIGNALS:
At intersections where traffic is directed by a police officer or by a stop and go signal, it shall be unlawful for any pedestrian to cross the roadway, other
than with released traffic, if such crossing interferes with the lawful movement of traffic. (1970 Code § 25.11)
Chapter 7
VEHICLE EQUIPMENT AND CONDITION
6-7-1: CLEAR VISION:
It shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle which is so loaded or in such a condition that the operator does not have a clear vision of all parts of the
roadway essential to the safe operation of the vehicle. Any vehicle that is so constructed or loaded that the driver's view of the roadway to the rear is
obstructed shall be equipped with a mirror so attached as to give him a view of the roadway behind him. (1970 Code § 25.34)
6-7-2: UNNECESSARY NOISE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 193/493
It shall be unlawful to operate a vehicle which makes unusually loud or unnecessary noise on the streets. (1970 Code § 25.35)
6-7-3: EMISSIONS:
It shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle which emits dense smoke or such an amount of smoke or fumes as to be dangerous to the health of persons or
as to endanger the drivers of other vehicles. (1970 Code § 25.37)
6-7-4: PROJECTING LOADS:
A. Width:
1. The maximum width of any vehicle and its load shall not exceed eight feet (8') excepting loads of loose hay, straw, corn fodder, or similar farm
products, agricultural implements and threshing machines.
2. No passenger type vehicle shall be operated on the streets with a load extending beyond the line of the fenders on the left side of the vehicle nor
extending more than six inches (6") beyond the line of the fender on the right side thereof.
B. Length:
1. No vehicle, unladen or with load, shall exceed a length of thirty five feet (35') extreme overall dimension. A truck tractor and a semitrailer shall be
regarded as one vehicle for the purpose of determining length.
2. No combination of vehicles coupled together shall consist of more than two (2) units, and no such combination of vehicles, unladen or with load,
shall exceed a total length of forty feet (40'); but such length limitation shall not apply to vehicles operated in the daytime when transporting poles,
pipes, machinery or other objects which cannot be readily dismembered, nor to such vehicles operated at nighttime by a public utility when engaged
in emergency repair work; but such loads carried at night shall be clearly marked with sufficient lights to show the full dimensions of the load.
3. No part of the load of a vehicle shall extend more than three feet (3') in front of the extreme front portion of the vehicle. (1970 Code § 25.38)
6-7-5: SIZE, WEIGHT AND LOAD:
A. Definitions: Definitions of any terms or words used herein shall be in accordance with the provisions of the Illinois motor vehicle code, and weight
computations shall be computed in accordance with the Illinois motor vehicle code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes.
B. Permit Required For Overweight Vehicles: It shall be unlawful for any person or entity to drive, operate, move on, upon or across, or for the owner to
cause or knowingly permit to be driven, operated or moved on, upon or across any street in the village, under the jurisdiction and control of the village,
any vehicle of any nature and description exceeding four (4) tons per axle, or twenty four thousand (24,000) pounds per vehicle, when there will be two
(2) or more such movements of such vehicles in the village during any twenty four (24) hour period, without a permit approved by the village
administrator. Such permits shall set forth the routes of travel permitted for such vehicles, the speed limit permitted, the maximum number of vehicles
permitted in any day, week, or month, the days of the week, and times during which such vehicles may be operated.
C. Security Or Insurance: To ensure against injuries to the public or property damage, the village administrator shall require the posting of a bond or other
security or insurance which he may approve in an amount of not less than twenty five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) running in favor of the village.
D. Covering Materials Susceptible To Spilling: Whenever such vehicles contain any type of material susceptible to spillage, and blowing of debris or
materials therefor, either during the movement, or the loading or unloading thereof, the village administrator may also require that the material being
transported be covered in such manner as to prevent such spillage or blowing, or be sprinkled with water or other safe solution, or direct such other
preventative measures be implemented to minimize or eliminate such condition from occurring.
E. Authority To Restrict Use Of Roadways: Whenever it is determined by the village administrator that any roadway under the jurisdiction of the village, by
reason of deterioration, rain, snow or other climatic conditions, will be seriously damaged or destroyed unless the use of vehicles thereon is prohibited,
or the permissible weights thereon reduced, or other reasonable regulations adhered to, the village may, by ordinance or resolution, direct the village
administrator to erect or cause the erection of signs on such roadways for a period not to exceed ninety (90) days in any one calendar year, restricting
and regulating vehicular traffic thereon.
F. Vehicles Excepted From Restrictions: The foregoing weight limitations shall not apply to fire apparatus, equipment used for snow and ice removal
operations by the village or any village owned or village operated vehicle. Upon approval of the village administrator, vehicles in excess of such weight
limits or in excess of the length limits hereinafter set forth may be allowed on village streets subject to such terms and conditions as may be imposed
by said administrator.
G. Vehicle Length Restriction: No vehicle in excess of fifty five feet (55') in length shall be allowed on any roadway under the jurisdiction of the village
except for municipally owned and operated vehicles and fire apparatus equipment used for firefighting purposes.
H. Posting Signs: The village administrator is hereby authorized and directed to post weight limitation signs at all entrances to village streets and roadways
affected by the terms of this section and any other ordinance or resolution enacted pursuant hereto for the restrictions in effect from time to time.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 194/493
I. More Restrictive Provisions Govern: Notwithstanding anything contained herein to the contrary, whenever a more restrictive weight or length limitation is
imposed by any other governmental body or agency having jurisdiction over a street or roadway located in the village, the more restrictive provisions of
such other governmental body or agency shall apply.
J. Responsibility For Damage To Streets: Any person violating any of the provisions of this section or ordinance or resolution enacted pursuant hereto shall
be responsible and liable for any and all damages to village streets and roadways and for all costs and expenses of repair or replacement. This liability
shall not relieve any such person from any other penalty provisions of this title that would otherwise be applicable. (Ord. 91-12, 8-26-1991)
6-7-6: METAL TIRED VEHICLES:
A. Protecting Pavement: No tractor, traction engine or other metal tired vehicle, weighing more than four (4) tons including the weight of the vehicle and its
load shall drive up, onto, off or over the edge of the paved roadway of any improved street without protecting such edge by putting down solid planks or
other suitable device to prevent such vehicle from breaking off the edges of such pavement. (1970 Code § 25.45)
B. Projections On Tires: No metal tired vehicle, including tractors, motor trucks, traction engines and other similar vehicles, shall be operated over any
improved street if such vehicle has on the periphery of any of the road wheels any block, stud, flange, cleat, ridge, lug or any projection of metal or
wood which projects radially beyond the tread or traffic surface of the tire; except, that this prohibition shall not apply to tractors or traction engines
equipped with what is known as caterpillar tracks, when such caterpillar does not contain any projection of any kind likely to injure the surface of the
road. Provided, however, that tractors, traction engines and similar vehicles may be operated which have upon their road wheels V-shaped, diagonal or
other cleats arranged in such a manner as to be continuously in contact with the road surface; and provided further, that the gross weight upon such
wheels per inch of width of such cleats in contact with the road surface, when measured in the direction of the axle of the vehicle, does not exceed
eight hundred (800) pounds. (1970 Code § 25.46)
6-7-7: EQUIPMENT REQUIRED:
A. Horn:
1. Every motor vehicle shall be equipped with a good and sufficient audible signaling device in efficient working condition. Such signaling device shall
be sounded when necessary to give timely warning of the approach of a vehicle, but such horn or other signaling device shall not be sounded for any
purpose other than as a warning of impending danger.
2. No motor vehicle other than an emergency vehicle shall be equipped with a siren or gong signaling device. (1970 Code § 25.36)
B. Brakes: It shall be unlawful to drive any motor vehicle upon any street unless such vehicle is equipped with good and sufficient brakes in good working
condition, as required by the state traffic law, or to operate any vehicle which is so loaded that the operator does not have ready access to the
mechanism operating the brakes of such vehicle. (1970 Code § 25.39)
C. Muffler: No motor vehicle shall be operated on any street unless such vehicle is provided with a muffler in efficient actual working condition; the use of a
cutout is prohibited. (1970 Code § 25.40)
D. Lights: When upon any street in the village, during the period from sunset to sunrise, every motorcycle shall carry one lighted lamp showing white lights,
or lights of a yellow or amber tint, visible at least five hundred feet (500') in the direction toward which such motorcycle or motor vehicle is proceeding,
and each motor vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer shall also exhibit at least one lighted lamp which shall be so situated as to throw a red light visible for at
least five hundred feet (500') in the reverse direction. (1970 Code § 25.41)
E. Tires: It shall be unlawful to operate on any street any motor vehicle which is not equipped with tires conforming to the requirements of the state traffic
law. (1970 Code § 25.43)
6-7-8: NONSKID DEVICES PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful to operate any motor vehicle upon any street equipped with any nonskid device so constructed that any rigid or nonflexible portion
thereof comes into contact with the pavement or roadway. (1970 Code § 25.42)
Title 7
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
Chapter 1
STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC WAYS
7-1-1: COMPLIANCE WITH SPECIFICATIONS:
All street and sidewalk pavements shall be constructed and laid in conformity with specifications laid down or approved by ordinance, or in the absence
thereof, as directed by the village administrator; provided, however that any construction performed in the public rights of way by utilities shall be
specifically governed by the provisions of chapter 3 of this title. (Ord. 2008-01, 1-14-2008)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 195/493
7-1-2: CONSTRUCTION PERMIT REQUIRED; APPLICATION:
It shall be unlawful to construct or lay any pavement on any public street, sidewalk, alley or other public way, or to repair the same without first having
secured a permit therefor. Applications for such permits shall be made to the village, and shall state the location of the intended pavement or repair, the
extent thereof, and the person or firm who is to do the actual construction work. (1988 Code § 5-3A-2)
7-1-3: BOND:
Each applicant shall file a bond, with surety to be approved by the village administrator, conditioned to indemnify the village for any loss or damage
resulting from the work undertaken or the manner of doing same. (1988 Code § 5-3A-3)
7-1-4: DEPOSIT REQUIREMENTS:
A. Deposit Required: Prior to the commencement of any building or construction project of a total construction value in excess of ten thousand dollars
($10,000.00); or any construction project requiring a permit from the building department which includes any significant exterior alterations or site work,
including, but not limited to, additions, decks, utility line installations, pools, patios, or driveways; or any project requiring the delivery of construction
materials by the use of vehicles larger than passenger vehicles or pickup trucks (collectively "work"), the property owner or the person intending to do
or undertake such work ("the principal") shall be required to make a cash deposit with the village in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) to
protect and indemnify the village against any and all damage or injury to any village or public property, structure, equipment or facility including, but not
limited to, streets, curbs, sidewalks, parkway trees and vegetation.
B. Procedure To Remedy Damage: If at any time the building commissioner determines that the principal caused damage to public property, structure,
facility or equipment as a result of work, the building commissioner shall, in writing by certified mail, return receipt requested, notify the principal and the
owner of the subject property of such damage and the requirements for correction of such damage. If the damage has not been corrected within thirty
(30) days of the mailing of the building commissioner's request for correction, a second request for correction shall be sent by certified mail, return
receipt requested, to the principal and the owner of the subject property.
C. Abatement By Village: Unless full compliance is achieved within thirty (30) days from the date of receipt of the second certified mail, the village may
proceed to perform or cause to be performed such work as the building commissioner deems necessary, utilizing the cash deposit to offset the village
costs; provided, however, any such damage or injury in excess of the sum of such cash deposit shall remain and continue to be the joint and several
obligation of the principal and the owner of the subject property. The village may, in addition to utilizing the cash deposit required hereby, take any and
all additional actions that may be available to enforce all applicable codes, ordinances, and regulations of the village and to recover any damages done
by the principal or by any subcontractor of the principal or by the work.
D. Recovery For Damages Unlimited: The cash deposit provided herein is in addition to any other such actions and shall not be construed as a limit on the
amount of damages that may be recovered by the village or any other person or as a limit on any other remedy or penalty provided by any code,
ordinance, or regulation of the village or otherwise by law. Upon satisfactory completion of the work, the village shall refund the balance of the deposit
less amounts required to pay damages or injury. (Ord. 96-22, 8-26-1996)
7-1-5: REPAIRS:
All public street, alley and sidewalk pavements shall be kept in good repair. Such repair work, whether done by the village or by the abutting owner, shall
be under the supervision of the director of public works. (1988 Code § 5-3A-5)
7-1-6: REPORTS OF DEFECTS:
It shall be the duty of every village officer or employee becoming cognizant of any defect in any street, alley or sidewalk, or any obstruction thereof, to
report the same to the director of public works. (1988 Code § 5-3A-6)
7-1-7: OWNER, OCCUPANT DUTY TO MAKE IMPROVEMENTS:
A. Compliance With Order: Whenever the owner or occupant of any lot in the village shall be notified by order of the village administrator to install, raise,
lower, repair or relay any sidewalk in front of, adjacent to, or upon any premises owned or occupied by him, it shall be the duty of such owner or
occupant to cause the said improvement to be made, in the manner and within the time prescribed by such order. (1988 Code § 5-3A-7)
B. Penalty: If any such owner or occupant shall neglect or refuse to comply with any such requirement, he shall be subject to a penalty of not less than five
dollars ($5.00) nor more than the maximum provided in section 1-4-1 of this code for each day's neglect. (1988 Code § 5-3A-7; amd. 2009 Code)
7-1-8: EXCAVATIONS:
A. Tunneling Under Streets: Except in the event of an emergency, or as otherwise herein provided, it shall be unlawful for any person to make any
excavation, open cut or open ditch in any paved street for the purpose of making any connections to, replacements or repairs to any sanitary or
stormwater sewers or water mains or laterals of any nature or description. All such connections shall be made by tunneling under any such paved
street. No such tunneling may be accomplished until a building permit therefor has been issued by the village. (Ord. 2008-01, 1-14-2008)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 196/493
B. Application For Permit: Application for such permit shall be made to the building commissioner for issuance of such permit, and shall state thereon the
location of the intended excavation, the purpose thereof, and the person, firm or corporation for whom the work is being done. (1988 Code § 5-3A-8)
C. Permit Fee: The fee for such permit for tunneling and other excavation shall be as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code, under the category "permit
fees". (Ord. 89-15, 3-20-1989; amd. 2009 Code)
D. Bond: Each applicant for such a permit shall file a bond conditioned that the permittee will suitably guard or protect any tunneling or excavations or
obstructions maintained or created by such permittee, and shall indemnify the village for any loss or damage resulting from injury to any person or
property caused by such tunneling, excavation or obstruction. Any such request shall be accompanied by a good and sufficient surety or performance
bond of a reputable insurance company authorized to transact business in the state of Illinois insuring the prompt completion of the work for which a
permit is issued, in the amount of the cost of such work.
E. Compliance With Conditions Of Permit: All work accomplished shall be in strict accordance with the terms and conditions of the application and permit
authorizing the work to be done. Sufficient barricades and lights shall be maintained to protect persons, vehicles and animals from injury by or because
of the tunneling or excavations being made.
F. Restoration Of Public Ways: Promptly upon the completion of the work for which the tunneling or excavation was made, the permittee shall restore the
said street, alley or public way to its original condition. All permits issued hereunder shall be further conditioned upon the permittee being responsible
for further restoration required by his work for a period of one year from the date of completion of the work for which a permit is issued, and said
obligation shall also be covered by bond furnished to the village.
G. Open Cut Excavations: Notwithstanding any provision contained herein to the contrary, the village administrator may, for good and sufficient cause,
permit open cut excavation of a paved street. Such authorization shall be limited to those circumstances where the public interest would be served, or
when the relative benefit to the permittee is substantial, and the detriment to the village is minimal. (1988 Code § 5-3A-8)
7-1-9: BARRICADES:
A. Required:
1. Excavations: Any person laying or repairing any pavement on a street, sidewalk or other public place, or making an excavation in any such place
shall maintain adequate and complete barricades to prevent injury to any person or vehicle by reason of the work; such barricade to be protected by
plainly visible lights at night.
2. Defects: Defects in any such pavement shall be barricaded to prevent any injury, and any person maintaining by proper authority any opening or
excavation shall guard such opening or excavation while the same remains open by proper barricades and lights.
B. Interference Prohibited: It shall be unlawful to disturb or interfere with any barricade or lights lawfully placed to protect or mark any new pavement or
excavation or opening in any public street, alley or sidewalk. (1988 Code § 5-3A-9)
7-1-10: INJURING PAVEMENTS:
A. Newly Laid Pavement: It shall be unlawful to walk upon or drive any vehicle or animal upon, or injure any newly laid street or sidewalk pavement while
the same is guarded by a warning sign or barricade, or to knowingly injure any soft newly laid pavement.
B. Pavements Generally: It shall be unlawful to damage any sidewalk, street or alley pavement. (1988 Code § 5-3A-10)
7-1-11: OBSTRUCTIONS:
A. Drains: It shall be unlawful to obstruct any drain in any public street or alley. (1988 Code § 5-3A-11)
B. Public Ways; Bond: Except as provided in section 7-1-16 of this chapter, it shall be unlawful for any person to cause, create or maintain any obstruction
of any street, alley, sidewalk or other public way except by authority of this chapter after application therefor made to the village administrator and upon
the filing of a street obstruction bond in the penal sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) in a form prescribed by the village, which form shall be
available at the village hall, and which the applicant shall execute as principal and upon which there shall be a corporate surety authorized by law to
execute and become liable upon such bond. (Ord. 94-13, 4-25-1994)
7-1-12: DRIVEWAYS:
A. Construction Permit Required: No person shall construct or maintain a driveway for vehicles or animals in or across any public sidewalk or parkway in
the village without having obtained a permit therefor from the building commissioner.
B. Approval By Board Of Trustees: No permit for the construction of a driveway for commercial use or the habitual use of any other than the owner or
occupant of the premises served shall be issued except on approval by the board of trustees.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 197/493
C. Street Grades1: All driveways shall be so constructed that the grade shall be the same as that of the adjoining sidewalk at their points of intersection.
Such driveways shall meet the gutter of the street at the grade thereof.
D. Construction Materials: All driveways or parkways where they cross sidewalks shall be constructed of concrete, asphalt or of such other materials as
may be approved by the village administrator. All driveways shall be constructed and maintained in such a manner that no undue amount of gravel,
cinders or dirt shall wash down into the gutter or onto the pavement of the street. (1988 Code § 5-3A-12)
E. Permit Fees; Bond:
1. Driveway Construction: Permit fees for the construction of a driveway or the approach thereto shall be as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code, under
the category "permit fees". In addition thereto, a surety bond or cash in the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) shall be deposited with the
village treasurer for issuance of a driveway permit requiring breaking of any curbing. Said deposit shall be returned to the person depositing the
same upon completion of the work and restoration of the adjoining curb, gutter, roadway, property, parkway and sewer and water facilities to their
original condition prior to the construction.
2. Resurfacing Driveway: Permit fees for the resurfacing of a driveway or the approach thereto shall be as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code, under
the category "permit fees".
3. Damage In Excess Of Deposit: The deposit of said sum shall not relieve the applicant and the person undertaking the work from damages in excess
of said deposit.
4. Sealcoating: Sealcoating of a driveway shall not be considered construction or require a permit therefor. (1988 Code § 5-3A-12; amd. 2009 Code)
7-1-13: TREES2, BUSHES AND SHRUBS:
A. Permit Required:
1. Planting: It shall be unlawful to plant any tree or bush in any public street, parkway or other public place owned or controlled by the village without
having first secured a permit therefor. All trees and shrubs so planted shall be placed subject to the direction and approval of the village
administrator, or his or her designee.
2. Removal: It shall be unlawful to remove or cut down any tree or shrub in any street, parkway or other public place without complying with the
provisions of title 10, chapter 11 of this code.
B. Height Requirement:
1. The owner or occupant of any lot or parcel of land in the village shall trim all branches of any tree or shrub now or hereafter growing on said
premises which overhang any street, sidewalk, alley or public highway, so that there shall be a clear height of twelve feet (12') above the surface of
the street, alley or highway unobstructed by branches, and a clear height of not less than eight feet (8') over any sidewalk; and such owner or
occupant shall remove any tree or branch of a tree which is dead or decayed or has become likely to fall on or across any street, sidewalk or public
way.
2. The village administrator, or his or her designee, may cause to be trimmed or removed any tree or shrub overhanging any street, sidewalk, alley or
public way in violation of the provisions of this subsection.
C. Planting Program:
1. There is hereby established for the village a planting program subject to the terms and provisions of this chapter.
2. To the extent deemed necessary and practicable, the village will annually plant trees, shrubs, and bushes in such public places deemed appropriate
and approved by the board of trustees or the village administrator, or his or her designee.
3. The village hereby encourages participation by property owners in such planting program in other areas not designated by the village for immediate
plantings. Owners desirous of having plantings on public property or parkways adjacent to their property may apply annually, in such years that this
program is in effect, for such participation. Applications therefor shall be made on forms provided by the village for the plantings available for that
year, and shall show thereon the proposed plantings desired, the size, species, variety, quantity and site locations therefor. Only those trees, shrubs
and bushes as approved by the board of trustees or the village administrator, or his or her designee, shall be permitted to be planted on streets,
parkways or public places in the village.
4. Applications of participating property owners will require an agreement on their part to pay one-half (1/2) of the costs of planting. Each application
shall be accompanied by a check in the amount therefor.
5. All plantings will be accomplished by the village or a contractor employed by the village.
6. The village administrator, or his or her designee, shall, prior to such planting for a property owner, advise the participating owner as to the placement
approved for the planting, if different from that requested by the property owner. Forty eight (48) hours after such notice by the village administrator,
or his or her designee, the planting placement shall be deemed approved by the property owner. In the event of disapproval by the property owner,
the village may, at its sole expense, without participation by the property owner, install any such plantings at locations deemed appropriate by the
village. (1988 Code § 5-3A-13; amd. 2009 Code)
7. Applications shall specify the assumption of risk of the property owner for any and all such plantings and the growth of plantings except to the extent
there are nursery guarantees.
8. No plantings shall be permitted where the same interfere with sight and safety requirements or other ordinances of the village.
9. All plantings shall be maintained as required by ordinances of the village.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 198/493
10. Whenever trees, shrubs or bushes are sought to be planted by a property owner at the owner's sole expense, the plantings shall be of only items
approved by resolution of the board of trustees or the village administrator; provided, further, that all street trees shall be at least three inches (3") in
diameter at the time of planting, measured at a point six inches (6") above ground level. Trees with an ultimate height of thirty feet (30') and a spread
of less than twenty five feet (25') shall be planted no less than fifteen feet (15') from the ultimate spread of the nearest tree. Trees with an ultimate
height of fifty feet (50') and a spread of over twenty five feet (25') but less than forty feet (40') shall be planted no less than twenty five feet (25') from
the ultimate spread of the nearest tree. Trees with an ultimate height in excess of fifty feet (50') and a spread in excess of forty feet (40') shall be
planted no less than thirty five feet (35') from the ultimate spread of the nearest tree. (1988 Code § 5-3A-13)
7-1-14: CLEAR VIEW AT INTERSECTIONS:
In order that the view of persons driving along the public streets of the village near the intersections thereof may not be obstructed, nor the usefulness and
convenience of such streets impaired, nor the public safety jeopardized thereby, no hedge, wall or fence of any material or consistency which tends or
might tend to impair such view shall be constructed or permitted to exist, and no shrubs, bushes, weeds or foliage which tend or might tend to impair such
view shall be permitted to exist on any lot or parcel of land within fifty feet (50') of the intersection of the adjacent curb lines of any two (2) streets in the
village, of a greater height than four feet (4') above the level of the center of the adjoining street; provided, that a hedge, wall or fence, or shrubs, bushes
or foliage exceeding the height fixed in this section may be erected or allowed to exist or maintained on any premises within a diagonal line running from a
point on the curb line of one street fifty feet (50') from the intersection of said curb lines to a point on the curb line of the other street equally distant from
said intersection. (1988 Code § 5-3A-14)
7-1-15: DEPOSITING MATERIAL ON PUBLIC WAYS:
A. Leaves And Garbage: It shall be unlawful to deposit, throw, cast, drop or leave in or on or rake or put onto any street, alley, sidewalk or public place in
the village any stones, missiles, nails, glass, metal, snow, grass, leaves, branches of trees, garbage, peelings, paper, boards or any article that may do
injury to any person, animal or property; except, that ashes or cinders free from any foreign substances may be spread on unimproved streets or alleys.
B. Merchandise And Building Materials: Merchandise, building materials or other articles may be deposited on sidewalks or public ways preparatory to
delivery; provided, that the usable width of the walk or public way is not thereby reduced to less than four feet (4'); and provided, that no such articles
shall remain on such walk for more than one-half (1/2) hour. (1988 Code § 5-3A-15)
7-1-16: USE OF STREETS AND SIDEWALKS FOR DISPLAYING, SELLING OR ADVERTISING:
A. Display Or Sale Of Goods: Except as provided in subsection B of this section, it shall be unlawful for any person to use any street, sidewalk or other
public place as space for the display or sale of goods, merchandise or advertising signs, or to write or mark any signs or advertisements on any such
pavements, unless approved in advance by the board of trustees by resolution duly adopted.
B. Outdoor Eating; Farmers' Markets; Outdoor Service Areas: Public rights of way within the village may be used for outdoor eating, farmers' markets,
outdoor service areas as defined in section 3-2-1 of this code, and other similar activities; provided, that advance written approval is granted therefor as
follows:
1. For activities that will, or are anticipated to, occur for thirty (30) or less consecutive days, advance written approval by the village administrator shall
be required.
2. For activities that will, or are anticipated to, occur for more than thirty (30) consecutive days, advance approval by the board of trustees by resolution
duly adopted shall be required. (Ord. 2011-6, 4-11-2011)
7-1-17: RESTRICTED AND PROHIBITED ACTS AND CONDITIONS:
A. Encroachments: It shall be unlawful to erect or maintain any building or structure which encroaches upon any public street or property.
B. Poles; Wires: It shall be unlawful to erect or maintain any poles or wires on or over any public street, alley or other public way without having first
secured permission from the board of trustees.
C. Gasoline Pumps, Tanks: It shall be unlawful to erect, install or maintain any gasoline or oil storage tank in any public street or alley.
D. Games: It shall be unlawful to play any games upon any street, alley or sidewalk where such games cause unnecessary noise or interfere with traffic or
pedestrians. (1988 Code § 5-3A-17)
E. Awnings: All awnings hereafter erected shall be in compliance with subsection 10-10-14B1 of this code. (1988 Code § 5-3A-17; amd. 2009 Code)
F. Driving On Sidewalks: No person shall lead, drive or cause to go or be driven or led, any horse, wagon, cart, motorized vehicle of any nature,
motorcycle, automobile, motor truck or other vehicle upon or across any public sidewalk except at a permanent driveway unless it be at a temporary
crossing to go into a yard or lot where no other crossing or means of access is provided, in which case, adequate protection to said sidewalk shall be
provided. (1988 Code § 5-3A-17)
G. Skateboard Use Regulated: No person shall ride or use a skateboard on: 1) the public sidewalks on either side of Scranton Avenue from Sheridan
Road to Evanston Avenue, on either side of East Center Avenue from the village hall to Scranton Avenue, on the sidewalk along Oak Avenue adjacent
to the public library; or 2) the property currently utilized as the village railroad station; provided, however, that skateboard use shall not be prohibited on
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 199/493
the bicycle path that runs through and along the railroad station property. For the purposes of this code, a "skateboard" shall be defined to be a device
with two (2) or more tandem axles and a combination of wheels connected by a platform designed for standing and which is propelled by human power.
(Ord. 96-31, 11-12-1996)
7-1-18: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter, where no other penalty is provided, shall, upon conviction, be fined not less than twenty five
dollars ($25.00) nor more than the maximum provided in section 1-4-1 of this code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed
on each day on which the violation occurs or continues. (1988 Code § 5-3A-18; amd. 2009 Code)
Chapter 2
SIDEWALK REPAIR/REHABILITATION PROGRAM
7-2-1: ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established within the village a program for encouraging repair/rehabilitation of sidewalks on village property. A village public sidewalk
repair/rehabilitation program, with joint village property owner cost participation, is hereby established under policy and procedural guidelines contained
herein. (1988 Code § 5-3B-1)
7-2-2: APPLICABILITY OF PROGRAM:
Applications shall be restricted to replacement of sidewalks which, in the opinion of the village administrator, are in need of replacement and shall not be
approved for new construction where sidewalks do not presently exist. (1988 Code § 5-3B-2)
7-2-3: PRIORITY OF REPLACEMENTS:
Except where circumstances dictate to the contrary, approval for replacement of sidewalks shall be based on need and sequence of applications, and
funds made available during the budget year. When priorities must be established due to applications on hand exceeding funding limitations, public safety
and degree of pedestrian hazard shall be the principal considerations in establishing sidewalk replacement priorities. For long range planning, the following
additional guidelines are established:
A. Priority 1: Sidewalks on streets serving as approaches to public and private schools and abutting such schools.
B. Priority 2: Sidewalks on streets used as principal walkways to schools.
C. Priority 3: Sidewalks on streets used as principal walkways to the railroad commuter station and central business district.
D. Priority 4: Sidewalks on other streets. (1988 Code § 5-3B-3)
7-2-4: PROGRAM FUNDING ALLOCATION:
The board of trustees may allocate funds as considered available to support village property owner cost participation in this sidewalk repair/rehabilitation
program. The board of trustees may from time to time designate the applicable cost sharing program to which the funds shall be applied and may annually
establish the "per square foot" dollar amount or percent of village participation. (1988 Code § 5-3B-4)
7-2-5: REIMBURSEMENT ELIGIBILITY:
A. Application; Inspection: Under the village reimbursement program, the owner shall initially submit an application for cost reimbursement eligibility. An
inspection shall then be accomplished by the director of public works or his duly authorized representative to determine eligibility.
B. Agreement With Property Owner: Once eligibility is established, the village administrator, subject to fund availability, shall, on behalf of the village, enter
into a reimbursement agreement with the property owner. Thereupon, the property owner is advised he may proceed by contract or other arrangements
to replace the sidewalk in accordance with specifications and procedures established herein.
C. Request Village Inspections: The property owner will be required to request village inspections by the director of public works when forms are installed
and base is prepared for pouring concrete, and when the pour has been completed and concrete has been finished.
D. Request For Reimbursement: Once such work has been completed, the inspections made and approved, the property owner submits his request for
reimbursement. All such requests shall be accompanied by a receipt for payment of any contractor's costs along with a contractor certificate certifying
construction complies with the requirements of this chapter. In circumstances when a contractor is not used, the owner shall submit a certificate of
compliance together with a "paid in full" receipt for any labor costs or ready mix purchased, or materials purchased for use in the project.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 200/493
E. Approval Of Payment: When approval of payment is recommended by the village administrator and approved by the board of trustees, the property
owner shall then be reimbursed to the extent provided herein. (1988 Code § 5-3B-5)
7-2-6: REPLACEMENT BY VILLAGE; PROPERTY OWNER DEPOSIT:
The director of public works, based upon petition of property owner and/or an inspection of sidewalks, shall establish an eligibility list. The village
administrator, subject to fund availability and allocated and manpower availability, may enter into agreement for sidewalk replacement with property
owners. Upon property owners entering into agreement with the village, and his concurrent deposit of a sum of money in an amount per square foot
established from time to time by resolution of the board of trustees, the village may cause such sidewalk to be replaced, using said deposit and paying all
costs of said replacement in excess thereof. (1988 Code § 5-3B-6)
7-2-7: NO CONFLICT WITH SPECIAL ASSESSMENT PROVISIONS:
Nothing contained in this chapter is intended to conflict with the construction of sidewalks as may be provided by special assessment or special taxation,
or prevent the village from adopting such procedures. (1988 Code § 5-3B-7)
7-2-8: COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
It shall be and is hereby declared unlawful for any person to reconstruct, repair or rehabilitate any sidewalk in the village unless the same shall be
constructed, reconstructed, repaired or rehabilitated in accordance with the standards and methods of construction set forth herein. (1988 Code § 5-3B-8)
7-2-9: SIDEWALK SPECIFICATIONS:
All public sidewalks repaired or rehabilitated in the village shall be of Portland cement concrete, constructed in accordance with section 624 of the Portland
cement sidewalk standard, adopted by the Illinois department of transportation on October 1, 1979, and the following additional specifications, directions
and provisions:
A. Thickness Of Sidewalks: The thickness of all sidewalks in all residence districts shall be not less than six inches (6"), except where said sidewalk
intersects a driveway, in which case, the thickness shall be not less than seven inches (7") for the full width of said driveway. The thickness of all
sidewalks in all nonresidential districts shall be six inches (6") reinforced with steel. All sidewalks shall be poured in one course.
B. Alignment And Width Of Sidewalks: Width shall be a minimum of five feet (5') unless approved by the director of public works or village administrator.
(1988 Code § 5-3B-9)
7-2-10: REPAIR OF SIDEWALKS:
Wherever any sidewalk shall become broken or shall be in need of repair for any reason whatsoever, the entire slab or slabs broken or in need of repair
shall be removed and replaced with a new slab constructed in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. No patching with Portland cement concrete
or any other materials will be permitted, except when, in the opinion of the village administrator, it is unreasonable to require the replacement of slabs at
the time because of unfavorable weather conditions or for other reasonable cause. (1988 Code § 5-3B-10)
7-2-11: IMPROPER CONSTRUCTION; ABATEMENT:
No reimbursement shall be paid for any sidewalk replaced contrary to this chapter. Any improperly constructed sidewalk, if deemed appropriate and
necessary, shall be removed and replaced by the person, either as principal or agent responsible for the construction, after having received notice from the
village administrator to remove same. If such removal and reconstruction is not accomplished within the period specified, it shall become the duty of the
village administrator to cause such walk to be removed and replaced with a properly constructed walk, and the cost of said removal and replacement shall
be assessed against such person responsible for same. (1988 Code § 5-3B-11)
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 2019-7 - SMALL WIRELESS FACILITIES . Go to new ordinance.
Chapter 3
CONSTRUCTION OF UTILITY FACILITIES IN PUBLIC RIGHTS OF WAY
7-3-1: PURPOSE; SCOPE; INTERPRETATION:
A. Purpose: The purpose of this chapter is to establish policies and procedures for constructing facilities on rights of way within the village jurisdiction,
which will provide public benefit consistent with the preservation of the integrity, safe usage, and visual qualities of the village rights of way and the
village as a whole.
B. Intent: In enacting this chapter, the village intends to exercise its authority over the rights of way in the village and, in particular, the use of the public
ways and property by utilities, by establishing uniform standards to address issues presented by utility facilities, including, without limitation:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 201/493
1. Prevent interference with the use of streets, sidewalks, alleys, parkways and other public ways and places;
2. Prevent the creation of visual and physical obstructions and other conditions that are hazardous to vehicular and pedestrian traffic;
3. Prevent interference with the facilities and operations of the village utilities and of other utilities lawfully located in rights of way or public property;
4. Protect against environmental damage, including damage to trees, from the installation of utility facilities;
5. Protect against increased stormwater runoff due to structures and materials that increase impermeable surfaces;
6. Preserve the character of the neighborhoods in which facilities are installed;
7. Preserve open space, particularly the tree lined parkways that characterize the village residential neighborhoods;
8. Prevent visual blight from the proliferation of facilities in the rights of way, and require site appropriate landscaping around such facilities; and
9. Assure the continued safe use and enjoyment of private properties adjacent to utility facilities locations.
C. Scope: This chapter applies to all facilities on, over, above, along, upon, under, across, or within the rights of way within the jurisdiction of the village. A
facility lawfully established prior to the effective date hereof may continue to be maintained, repaired and operated by the utility as presently
constructed and located, except as may be otherwise provided in any applicable franchise, license or similar agreement.
D. Franchises, Licenses Or Similar Agreements:
1. The village, in its discretion and as limited by law, may require utilities to enter into a franchise, license or similar agreement for the privilege of
locating their facilities on, over, above, along, upon, under, across, or within the village rights of way. Utilities that are not required by law to enter into
such an agreement may request that the village enter into such an agreement. In such an agreement, the village may provide terms and conditions
inconsistent with this chapter.
2. In the event that a utility other than a telecommunications provider has a franchise, license or similar agreement with the village, such franchise,
license or similar agreement shall govern and control during the term of such agreement and any lawful renewal or extension thereof.
3. In the event of any conflict with, or inconsistency between, the provisions of this chapter and the provisions of any franchise, license or similar
agreement between the village and any telecommunications provider, the provisions of such franchise, license or similar agreement shall govern and
control during the term of such agreement and any lawful renewal or extension thereof.
E. Conflicting Provisions:
1. This chapter supersedes all chapters or parts of chapters adopted prior hereto that are in conflict herewith, to the extent of such conflict.
2. In the event that applicable federal or state laws or regulations conflict with the requirements of this chapter, the utility shall comply with the
requirements of this chapter to the maximum extent possible without violating federal or state laws or regulations.
F. Sound Engineering Judgment: The village shall use sound engineering judgment when administering this chapter and may vary the standards,
conditions, and requirements expressed in this chapter when the village so determines. Nothing herein shall be construed to limit the ability of the
village to regulate its rights of way for the protection of the public health, safety and welfare. (Ord. 2008-01, 1-14-2008)
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 2019-7 - SMALL WIRELESS FACILITIES . Go to new ordinance.
7-3-2: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter and unless the context clearly requires otherwise, the words and terms listed shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this
section. Any term not defined in this section shall have the meaning ascribed thereto in 92 Illinois administrative code section 530.30, unless the context
clearly requires otherwise.
AASHTO: American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials.
ANSI: American National Standards Institute.
ASTM: American Society for Testing and Materials.
APPLICANT: A person applying for a permit under this chapter.
BACKFILL: The methods or materials for replacing excavated material in a trench or pit.
BORE OR BORING: To excavate an underground cylindrical cavity for the insertion of a pipe or electrical conductor.
CABLE OPERATOR: As defined in 47 USC section 522(5).
CABLE SERVICE: As defined in 47 USC section 522(6).
CABLE SYSTEM: As defined in 47 USC section 522(7).
CARRIER PIPE: The pipe enclosing the liquid, gas or slurry to be transported.
CASING: A structural protective enclosure for transmittal devices such as carrier pipes, electrical conductors, and fiber optic devices.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 202/493
CLEAR ZONE: The total roadside border area, starting at the edge of the pavement, available for safe use by errant vehicles. This area may consist of a
shoulder, a recoverable slope, a nonrecoverable slope, and a clear runout area. The desired width is dependent upon the traffic volumes and speeds and
on the roadside geometry. Distances are specified in the AASHTO "Roadside Design Guide".
COATING: Protective wrapping or mastic cover applied to buried pipe for protection against external corrosion.
CODE: The municipal code of the village of Lake Bluff.
CONDUCTOR: Wire carrying electrical current.
CONDUIT: A casing or encasement for wires or cables.
CONSTRUCTION OR CONSTRUCT: The installation, repair, maintenance, placement, alteration, enlargement, demolition, modification or abandonment
in place of facilities.
COVER: The depth of earth or backfill over buried utility pipe or conductor.
CROSSING FACILITY: A facility that crosses one or more right of way lines of a right of way.
DEPUTY BUILDING COMMISSIONER: The village deputy building commissioner or his or her designee, other than the village administrator.
DISRUPT THE RIGHT OF WAY: Any work that obstructs the right of way or causes a material adverse effect on the use of the right of way for its intended
use. Such work may include, without limitation, the following: excavating or other cutting; placement (whether temporary or permanent) of materials,
equipment, devices, or structures; damage to vegetation; and compaction or loosening of the soil, and shall not include the parking of vehicles or
equipment in a manner that does not materially obstruct the flow of traffic on a highway.
EMERGENCY: Any immediate maintenance to the facility required for the safety of the public using or in the vicinity of the right of way or immediate
maintenance required for the health and safety of the general public served by the utility.
ENCASEMENT: Provision of a protective casing.
ENGINEER: The village engineer or his or her designee.
EQUIPMENT: Materials, tools, implements, supplies, and/or other items used to facilitate construction of facilities.
EXCAVATION: The making of a hole or cavity by removing material, or laying bare by digging.
EXTRA HEAVY PIPE: Pipe meeting ASTM standards for this pipe designation.
FACILITY: All structures, devices, objects, and materials (including, but not limited to, track and rails, wires, ducts, fiber optic cable, antennas, vaults,
boxes, equipment enclosures, cabinets, pedestals, poles, conduits, grates, covers, pipes, cables, and appurtenances thereto) located on, over, above,
along, upon, under, across, or within rights of way under this chapter. For purposes of this chapter, the term "facility" shall not include any facility owned or
operated by the village.
FREESTANDING FACILITY: A facility that is not a crossing facility or a parallel facility, such as an antenna, transformer, pump, or meter station.
FRONTAGE ROAD: A roadway, usually parallel, providing access to land adjacent to the highway where it is precluded by control of access to a highway.
HAZARDOUS MATERIALS: Any substance or material which, due to its quantity, form, concentration, location, or other characteristics, is determined by
the deputy building commissioner to pose an unreasonable and imminent risk to the life, health or safety of persons or property or to the ecological
balance of the environment, including, but not limited to, explosives, radioactive materials, petroleum or petroleum products or gases, poisons, etiology
(biological) agents, flammables, corrosives or any substance determined to be hazardous or toxic under any federal or state law, statute or regulation.
HIGHWAY: A specific type of right of way used for vehicular traffic including rural or urban roads or streets. "Highway" includes all highway land and
improvements, including roadways, ditches and embankments, bridges, drainage structures, signs, guardrails, protective structures and appurtenances
necessary or convenient for vehicle traffic.
HIGHWAY CODE: The Illinois highway code, 605 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-101 et seq., as amended from time to time.
HOLDER: A person or entity that has received authorization to offer or provide cable or video service from the ICC pursuant to the Illinois cable and video
competition law, 220 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/21-401.
ICC: Illinois commerce commission.
IDOT: Illinois department of transportation.
JULIE: The joint utility locating information for excavators utility notification program.
JACKING: Pushing a pipe horizontally under a roadway by mechanical means with or without boring.
JETTING: Pushing a pipe through the earth using water under pressure to create a cavity ahead of the pipe.
JOINT USE: The use of pole lines, trenches or other facilities by two (2) or more utilities.
MAJOR INTERSECTION: The intersection of two (2) or more major arterial highways.
OCCUPANCY: The presence of facilities on, over or under a right of way.
PARALLEL FACILITY: A facility that is generally parallel or longitudinal to the centerline of a right of way.
PARKWAY: Any portion of the right of way not improved by a street or sidewalk.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 203/493
PAVEMENT CUT: The removal of an area of pavement for access to a facility or for the construction of a facility.
PERMITTEE: That entity to which a permit has been issued pursuant to section 7-3-4 of this chapter.
PETROLEUM PRODUCTS PIPELINES: Pipelines carrying crude or refined liquid petroleum products including, but not limited to, gasoline, distillates,
propane, butane, or coal slurry.
PRACTICABLE: That which is performable, feasible or possible, rather than that which is simply convenient.
PRESSURE: The internal force acting radially against the walls of a carrier pipe expressed in pounds per square inch gauge (psig).
PROMPT: That which is done within a period of time specified by the village. If no time period is specified, the period shall be thirty (30) days.
PUBLIC ENTITY: A legal entity that constitutes or is part of the government, whether at the local, state or federal level.
RESTORATION: The repair of a right of way, highway, roadway, or other area disrupted by the construction of a facility.
RIGHT OF WAY OR RIGHTS OF WAY: Any street, alley, other land or waterway, dedicated or commonly used for pedestrian or vehicular traffic or other
similar purposes, including utility easements, in which the village has the right and authority to authorize, regulate or permit the location of facilities other
than those of the village. "Right of way or rights of way" shall not include any real or personal village property that is not specifically described in this
definition and shall not include village buildings, fixtures and other structures or improvements, regardless of whether they are situated in the right of way.
ROADWAY: That part of the highway that includes the pavement and shoulders.
SALE OF TELECOMMUNICATIONS AT RETAIL: The transmitting, supplying, or furnishing of telecommunications and all services rendered in connection
therewith for a consideration, other than between a parent corporation and its wholly owned subsidiaries or between wholly owned subsidiaries, when the
gross charge made by one such corporation to another such corporation is not greater than the gross charge paid to the retailer for its use or consumption
and not for sale.
SECURITY FUND: That amount of security required pursuant to subsection 7-3-5C of this chapter.
SHOULDER: A width of roadway, adjacent to the pavement, providing lateral support to the pavement edge and providing an area for emergency vehicular
stops and storage of snow removed from the pavement.
SOUND ENGINEERING JUDGMENT: A decision(s) consistent with generally accepted engineering principles, practices and experience.
TELECOMMUNICATIONS: Includes, but is not limited to, messages or information transmitted through use of local, toll and wide area telephone service,
channel services, telegraph services, teletypewriter service, computer exchange service, private line services, mobile radio services, cellular mobile
telecommunications services, stationary two-way radio, paging service and any other form of mobile or portable one-way or two-way communications, and
any other transmission of messages or information by electronic or similar means, between or among points by wire, cable, fiber optics, laser, microwave,
radio, satellite, or similar facilities. "Private line" means a dedicated, nontraffic sensitive service for a single customer that entitles the customer to exclusive
or priority use of a communications channel, or a group of such channels, from one or more specified locations to one or more other specified locations.
"Telecommunications" shall not include value added services in which computer processing applications are used to act on the form, content, code and
protocol of the information for purposes other than transmission. "Telecommunications" shall not include purchase of telecommunications by a
telecommunications service provider for use as a component part of the service provided by such provider to the ultimate retail consumer who originates
or terminates the end to end communications. "Telecommunications" shall not include the provision of cable services through a cable system as defined in
the cable communications act of 1984 (47 USC section 521 and following), as now or hereafter amended, or cable or other programming services subject
to an open video system fee payable to the village through an open video system as defined in the rules of the federal communications commission (47
CFR section 76.1500 and following), as now or hereafter amended.
TELECOMMUNICATIONS PROVIDER: Any person that installs, owns, operates or controls facilities in the right of way used or designed to be used to
transmit telecommunications in any form.
TELECOMMUNICATIONS RETAILER: Means and includes every person engaged in making "sales of telecommunications at retail" as defined in this
section.
TRENCH: A relatively narrow open excavation for the installation of an underground facility.
UTILITY: The individual or entity owning or operating any "facility" as defined in this section.
VENT: A pipe to allow the dissipation into the atmosphere of gases or vapors from an underground casing.
VIDEO SERVICE: As defined in section 21-201(v) of the Illinois cable and video competition law of 2007, 220 Illinois Compiled Statutes 21-201(v).
VILLAGE: The village of Lake Bluff.
VILLAGE TREE PRESERVATION ORDINANCE: Title 10, chapter 11 of this code.
WATER LINES: Pipelines carrying raw or potable water.
WET BORING: Boring using water under pressure at the cutting auger to soften the earth and to provide a sluice for the excavated material. (Ord. 2008-
01, 1-14-2008; amd. 2009 Code)
