This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 2019-7 - SMALL WIRELESS FACILITIES . Go to new ordinance.
7-3-9: LOCATION OF FACILITIES:
A. General Requirements: In addition to location requirements applicable to specific types of utility facilities, all utility facilities, regardless of type, shall be
subject to the general location requirements of this subsection.
1. Interference With Village Facilities Prohibited: No utility facilities shall be placed in any location if the deputy building commissioner determines that
the proposed location will require the relocation or displacement of any of the village utility facilities or will otherwise interfere with the operation or
maintenance of any of the village utility facilities.
2. Minimum Interference And Impact: The proposed location shall cause only the minimum possible interference with the use of the right of way and
shall cause only the minimum possible impact upon and interference with the rights and reasonable convenience of property owners who adjoin said
right of way.
3. Interference With Travel Prohibited: No utility facility shall be placed in any location that interferes with the usual travel on such right of way.
4. Limitations On Visibility Prohibited: No utility facility shall be placed in any location so as to limit visibility of or by users of the right of way.
5. Size Of Utility Facilities: The proposed installation shall use the smallest suitable vaults, boxes, equipment enclosures, power pedestals, and/or
cabinets then in use by the facility owner, regardless of location, for the particular application.
B. Parallel Facilities Located Within Highways:
1. Overhead Parallel Facilities: An overhead parallel facility may be located within the right of way lines of a highway only if:
a. Lines are located as near as practicable to the right of way line and as nearly parallel to the right of way line as reasonable pole alignment will
permit;
b. Where pavement is curbed, poles are as remote as practicable from the curb with a minimum distance of two feet (2') (0.6 m) behind the face of
the curb, where available;
c. Where pavement is uncurbed, poles are as remote from pavement edge as practicable with minimum distance of four feet (4') (1.2 m) outside the
outer shoulder line of the roadway and are not within the clear zone;
d. No pole is located in the ditch line of a highway; and
e. Any ground mounted appurtenance is located within one foot (1') (0.3 m) of the right of way line or as near as possible to the right of way line.
2. Underground Parallel Facilities: An underground parallel facility may be located within the right of way lines of a highway only if:
a. The facility is located as near the right of way line as practicable and not more than eight feet (8') (2.4 m) from and parallel to the right of way line;
b. A new facility may be located under the paved portion of a highway only if other locations are impracticable or inconsistent with sound engineering
judgment (e.g., a new cable may be installed in existing conduit without disrupting the pavement); and
c. In the case of an underground power or communications line, the facility shall be located as near the right of way line as practicable and not more
than five feet (5') (1.5 m) from the right of way line, and any above grounded appurtenance shall be located within one foot (1') (0.3 m) of the right
of way line or as near as practicable.
C. Facilities Crossing Highways:
1. No Future Disruption: The construction and design of crossing facilities installed between the ditch lines or curb lines of village highways may require
the incorporation of materials and protections (such as encasement or additional cover) to avoid settlement or future repairs to the roadbed resulting
from the installation of such crossing facilities.
2. Cattle Passes, Culverts, Or Drainage Facilities: Crossing facilities shall not be located in cattle passes, culverts, or drainage facilities.
3. Ninety Degree Crossing Required: Crossing facilities shall cross at or as near to a ninety degree (90°) angle to the centerline as practicable.
4. Overhead Power Or Communication Facility: An overhead power or communication facility may cross a highway only if:
a. It has a minimum vertical line clearance as required by ICU rules entitled, "Construction Of Electric Power And Communication Lines" (83 Illinois
administrative code 305);
b. Poles are located within one foot (1') (0.3 m) of the right of way line of the highway and outside of the clear zone; and
c. Overhead crossings at major intersections are avoided.
5. Underground Power Or Communication Facility: An underground power or communication facility may cross a highway only if:
a. The design materials and construction methods will provide maximum maintenance free service life; and
b. Capacity for the utility's foreseeable future expansion needs is provided in the initial installation.
6. Markers: The village may require the utility to provide a marker at each right of way line where an underground facility other than a power or
communication facility crosses a highway. Each marker shall identify the type of facility, the utility, and an emergency phone number. Markers may
also be eliminated as provided in current federal regulations (49 CFR section 192.707 (1989)).
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 210/493
D. Location Within Particular Rights Of Way: The village may require that facilities be located within particular rights of way that are not highways, rather
than within particular highways.
E. Freestanding Facilities:
1. The village may restrict the location and size of any freestanding facility located within a right of way.
2. The village may require any freestanding facility located within a right of way to be screened from view.
F. Aboveground Facilities: Aboveground facilities may be installed only if:
1. No other existing facilities in the area are located underground;
2. New underground installation is not technically feasible; and
3. The proposed installation will be made at a location, and will employ suitable design and materials, to provide the greatest protection of aesthetic
qualities of the area being traversed without adversely affecting safety. Suitable designs include, but are not limited to, self-supporting armless, single
pole construction with vertical configuration of conductors and cable. Existing utility poles and light standards shall be used wherever practicable.
The installation of additional utility poles is strongly discouraged.
G. Facility Attachments To Bridges Or Roadway Structures:
1. Facilities may be installed as attachments to bridges or roadway structures only where the utility has demonstrated that all other means of
accommodating the facility are not practicable. Other means shall include, but are not limited to, underground, underwater, independent poles, cable
supports and tower supports, all of which are completely separated from the bridge or roadway structure. Facilities transmitting commodities that are
volatile, flammable, corrosive, or energized, especially those under significant pressure or potential, present a high degrees of risk, and such
installations are not permitted.
2. A utility shall include in its request to accommodate a facility installation on a bridge or roadway structure supporting data demonstrating the
impracticability of alternate routing. Approval or disapproval of an application for facility attachment to a bridge or roadway structure will be based
upon the following considerations:
a. The type, volume, pressure or voltage of the commodity to be transmitted and an evaluation of the resulting risk to persons and property in the
event of damage to or failure of the facility;
b. The type, length, value, and relative importance of the highway structure in the transportation system;
c. The alternative routings available to the utility and their comparative practicability;
d. The proposed method of attachment;
e. The ability of the structure to bear the increased load of the proposed facility;
f. The degree of interference with bridge maintenance and painting;
g. The effect on the visual quality of the structure; and
h. The public benefit expected from the utility service as compared to the risk involved.
H. Appearance Standards:
1. The village may prohibit the installation of facilities in particular locations in order to preserve visual quality.
2. A facility may be constructed only if its construction does not require extensive removal or alteration of trees or terrain features visible to the right of
way user or to adjacent residents and property owners, and if it does not impair the aesthetic quality of the lands being traversed. (Ord. 2008-01, 1-
14-2008)
7-3-10: CONSTRUCTION METHODS AND MATERIALS:
A. Standards And Requirements For Particular Types Of Construction Methods:
1. Boring Or Jacking:
a. Pits And Shoring: Boring or jacking under rights of way shall be accomplished from pits located at a minimum distance specified by the deputy
building commissioner from the edge of the pavement. Pits for boring or jacking shall be excavated no more than forty eight (48) hours in advance
of boring or jacking operations and backfilled within forty eight (48) hours after boring or jacking operations are completed. While pits are open,
they shall be clearly marked and protected by barricades. Shoring shall be designed, erected, supported, braced, and maintained so that it will
safely support all vertical and lateral loads that may be imposed upon it during the boring or jacking operation.
b. Wet Boring Or Jetting: Wet boring or jetting shall not be permitted under the roadway.
c. Borings With Diameters Greater Than Six Inches: Borings over six inches (6") (0.15 m) in diameter shall be accomplished with an auger and
following pipe, and the diameter of the auger shall not exceed the outside diameter of the following pipe by more than one inch (1") (25 mm).
d. Borings With Diameters Six Inches Or Less: Borings of six inches (6") or less in diameter may be accomplished by either jacking, guided with
auger, or auger and following pipe method.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 211/493
e. Tree Preservation: Any facility located within the drip line of any tree designated by the village to be preserved or protected shall comply with the
village tree preservation ordinance.
2. Trenching: Trenching for facility installation, repair, or maintenance on rights of way shall be done in accordance with the applicable portions of
section 603 of IDOT's "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction".
a. Length: The length of open trench shall be kept to the practicable minimum consistent with requirements for pipeline testing. Only one-half (1/2) of
any intersection may have an open trench at any time unless special permission is obtained from the deputy building commissioner.
b. Open Trench And Excavated Material: Open trench and windrowed excavated material shall be protected as required by chapter 6 of the "Illinois
Manual On Uniform Traffic Control Devices". Where practicable, the excavated material shall be deposited between the roadway and the trench as
added protection. Excavated material shall not be allowed to remain on the paved portion of the roadway. Where right of way width does not allow
for windrowing excavated material off the paved portion of the roadway, excavated material shall be hauled to an off road location.
c. Drip Line Of Trees: The utility shall not trench within the drip line of any tree designated to be preserved pursuant to the village tree preservation
ordinance.
3. Backfilling:
a. Any pit, trench, or excavation created during the installation of facilities shall be backfilled for its full width, depth, and length using methods and
materials in accordance with IDOT's "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction". When excavated material is hauled away or is
unsuitable for backfill, suitable granular backfill shall be used.
b. For a period of three (3) years from the date construction of a facility is completed, the utility shall be responsible to remove and restore any
backfilled area that has settled due to construction of the facility. If so ordered by the deputy building commissioner, the utility, at its expense, shall
remove any pavement and backfill material to the top of the installed facility, place and properly compact new backfill material, and restore new
pavement, sidewalk, curbs, and driveways to the proper grades, as determined by the deputy building commissioner.
4. Pavement Cuts: Pavement cuts for facility installation or repair shall be permitted on a highway only if that portion of the highway is closed to traffic.
If a variance to the limitation set forth in this subsection A4 is permitted under section 7-3-15 of this chapter, the following requirements shall apply:
a. Any excavation under pavements shall be backfilled and compacted as soon as practicable with granular material of CA-6 gradation, as
designated by the deputy building commissioner.
b. Restoration of pavement, in kind, shall be accomplished as soon as practicable, and temporary repair with bituminous mixture shall be provided
immediately. Any subsequent failure of either the temporary repair or the restoration shall be rebuilt upon notification by the village.
c. All saw cuts shall be full depth.
d. For all rights of way which have been reconstructed with a concrete surface/base in the last seven (7) years, or resurfaced in the last three (3)
years, permits shall not be issued unless such work is determined to be an emergency repair or other work considered necessary and unforeseen
before the time of the reconstruction or unless a pavement cut is necessary for a JULIE locate.
5. Encasement:
a. Casing pipe shall be designed to withstand the load of the highway and any other superimposed loads. The casing shall be continuous either by
one piece fabrication or by welding or jointed installation approved by the village.
b. The venting, if any, of any encasement shall extend within one foot (1') (0.3 m) of the right of way line. No aboveground vent pipes shall be located
in the area established as clear zone for that particular section of the highway.
c. In the case of water main or service crossing, encasement shall be furnished between bore pits unless continuous pipe or village approved jointed
pipe is used under the roadway. Casing may be omitted only if pipe is installed prior to highway construction and carrier pipe is continuous or
mechanical joints are of a type approved by the village. Bell and spigot type pipe shall be encased regardless of installation method.
d. In the case of gas pipelines of sixty (60) psig or less, encasement may be eliminated.
e. In the case of gas pipelines or petroleum products pipelines with installations of more than sixty (60) psig, encasement may be eliminated only if:
1) extra heavy pipe is used that precludes future maintenance or repair; and 2) cathodic protection of the pipe is provided.
f. If encasement is eliminated for a gas or petroleum products pipeline, the facility shall be located so as to provide that construction does not disrupt
the right of way.
6. Minimum Cover Of Underground Facilities: Cover shall be provided and maintained at least in the amount specified in the following table for
minimum cover for the type of facility:
Type Of Facility Minimum Cover
Electric lines 30 inches (0.8 m)
Communication, cable or video service lines 18 to 24 inches (0.46 m to 0.6 m, as determined by village)
Gas or petroleum products 30 inches (0.8 m)
Water line Sufficient cover to provide freeze protection
Sanitary sewer, storm sewer, or drainage line Sufficient cover to provide freeze protection
B. Standards And Requirements For Particular Types Of Facilities:
1. Electric Power Or Communication Lines:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 212/493
a. Code Compliance: Electric power or communications facilities within village rights of way shall be constructed, operated, and maintained in
conformity with the provisions of 83 Illinois administrative code part 305 (formerly general order 160 of the Illinois commerce commission) entitled
"Rules For Construction Of Electric Power And Communications Lines", and the national electrical safety code.
b. Overhead Facilities: Overhead power or communication facilities shall use single pole construction, and where practicable, joint use of poles shall
be used. Utilities shall make every reasonable effort to design the installation so guys and braces will not be needed. Variances may be allowed if
there is no feasible alternative and if guywires are equipped with guy guards for maximum visibility.
c. Underground Facilities:
(1) Cable may be installed by trenching or plowing, provided that special consideration is given to boring in order to minimize damage when
crossing improved entrances and side roads.
(2) If a crossing is installed by boring or jacking, encasement shall be provided between jacking or bore pits. Encasement may be eliminated only
if: a) the crossing is installed by the use of "moles", "whip augers", or other approved methods which compress the earth to make the opening
for cable installation; or b) the installation is by the open trench method which is only permitted prior to roadway construction.
(3) Cable shall be grounded in accordance with the national electrical safety code.
d. Burial Of Drops: All temporary service drops placed between November 1 of the prior year and March 15 of the current year, also known as "snow
drops", shall be buried by May 31 of the current year, weather permitting, unless otherwise permitted by the village. Weather permitting, utilities
shall bury all temporary drops, excluding snow drops, within ten (10) business days after placement.
2. Underground Facilities Other Than Electric Power Or Communication Lines: Underground facilities other than electric power or communication lines
may be installed by:
a. The use of "moles", "whip augers", or other approved methods which compress the earth to move the opening for the pipe;
b. Jacking or boring with vented encasement provided between the ditch lines or toes of slopes of the highway;
c. Open trench with vented encasement between ultimate ditch lines or toes of slopes, but only if prior to roadway construction; or
d. Tunneling with vented encasement, but only if installation is not possible by other means.
3. Gas Transmission, Distribution And Service: Gas pipelines within rights of way shall be constructed, maintained, and operated in a village approved
manner and in conformance with the federal code of the office of pipeline safety operations, department of transportation, part 192 - transportation of
natural and other gas by pipeline: minimum federal safety standards (49 CFR section 192), IDOT's "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge
Construction", and all other applicable laws, rules, and regulations.
4. Petroleum Products Pipelines: Petroleum products pipelines within rights of way shall conform to the applicable sections of ANSI standard code for
pressure piping (liquid petroleum transportation piping systems ANSI-B 31.4).
5. Water Lines, Sanitary Sewer Lines, Stormwater Sewer Lines Or Drainage Lines: Water lines, sanitary sewer lines, stormwater sewer lines, and
drainage lines within rights of way shall meet or exceed the recommendations of the current "Standard Specifications For Water And Sewer Main
Construction In Illinois".
6. Ground Mounted Appurtenances: Ground mounted appurtenances to overhead or underground facilities, when permitted within a right of way, shall
be provided with a vegetation free area extending one foot (1') (305 mm) in width beyond the appurtenance in all directions. The vegetation free area
may be provided by an extension of the mounting pad, or by heavy duty plastic or similar material approved by the deputy building commissioner.
With the approval of the deputy building commissioner, shrubbery surrounding the appurtenance may be used in place of vegetation free area. The
housing for ground mounted appurtenances shall be painted a neutral color to blend with the surroundings.
C. Materials:
1. General Standards: The materials used in constructing facilities within rights of way shall be those meeting the accepted standards of the
appropriate industry, the applicable portions of IDOT's "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction", the requirements of the Illinois
commerce commission, or the standards established by other official regulatory agencies for the appropriate industry.
2. Storage On Right Of Way: No material shall be stored on the right of way without the prior written approval of the deputy building commissioner.
When such storage is permitted, all pipe, conduit, wire, poles, cross arms, or other materials shall be distributed along the right of way prior to and
during installation in a manner to minimize hazards to the public or an obstacle to right of way maintenance or damage to the right of way and other
property. If material is to be stored on right of way, prior approval must be obtained from the village.
3. Hazardous Materials: The plans submitted by the utility to the village shall identify any hazardous materials that may be involved in the construction
of the new facilities or removal of any existing facilities.
D. Operational Restrictions:
1. Construction operations on rights of way may, at the discretion of the village, be required to be discontinued when such operations would create
hazards to traffic or the public health, safety, and welfare. Such operations may also be required to be discontinued or restricted when conditions are
such that construction would result in extensive damage to the right of way or other property.
2. These restrictions may be waived by the deputy building commissioner when emergency work is required to restore vital utility services.
3. Unless otherwise permitted by the village, the hours of construction are those set forth in section 9-2-3 (3313) of this code.
E. Existing Facilities: Any utility proposing to construct facilities in the village shall contact JULIE and ascertain the presence and location of existing
aboveground and underground facilities within the rights of way to be occupied by its proposed facilities. The village will make its permit records
available to a utility for the purpose of identifying possible facilities. When notified of an excavation or when requested by the village or by JULIE, a
utility shall locate and physically mark its underground facilities within forty eight (48) hours, excluding weekends and holidays, in accordance with the
Illinois underground facilities damage prevention act, 220 Illinois Compiled Statutes 50/1 et seq. (Ord. 2008-01, 1-14-2008)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 213/493
7-3-11: VEGETATION CONTROL:
A. Compliance With Tree Preservation Regulations: All work pursuant to this chapter shall be subject to the requirements of the village tree preservation
ordinance.
B. Chemical Use:
1. Except as provided in subsection B2 of this section, no utility shall spray, inject or pour any chemicals on or near any trees, shrubs or vegetation in
the village for any purpose, including the control of growth, insects or disease.
2. Spraying of any type of brush killing chemicals will not be permitted on rights of way unless the utility demonstrates to the satisfaction of the deputy
building commissioner that such spraying is the only practicable method of vegetation control. (Ord. 2008-01, 1-14-2008)
7-3-12: REMOVAL, RELOCATION OR MODIFICATIONS OF UTILITY FACILITIES:
A. Within ninety (90) days following written notice from the village, a utility shall, at its own expense, protect, support, temporarily or permanently
disconnect, remove, relocate, change or alter the position of any utility facilities within the rights of way whenever the corporate authorities have
determined that such removal, relocation, change or alteration is reasonably necessary for the construction, repair, maintenance, or installation of any
village improvement in or upon, or the operations of the village in or upon, the rights of way.
B. Within thirty (30) days following written notice from the village, any utility that owns, controls, or maintains any unauthorized facility or related
appurtenances within the rights of way shall, at its own expense, remove all or any part of such facilities or appurtenances from the rights of way. A
facility is unauthorized and subject to removal in the following circumstances:
1. Upon expiration or termination of the permittee's license or franchise, unless otherwise permitted by applicable law;
2. If the facility was constructed or installed without the prior grant of a license or franchise, if required;
3. If the facility was constructed or installed without prior issuance of a required permit in violation of this chapter; or
4. If the facility was constructed or installed at a location not permitted by the permittee's license or franchise.
C. The village retains the right and privilege to cut or move any facilities located within the rights of way of the village, as the village may determine to be
necessary, appropriate or useful, in response to any public health or safety emergency. If circumstances permit, the village shall attempt to notify the
utility, if known, prior to cutting or removing a facility and shall notify the utility, if known, after cutting or removing a facility.
D. Upon abandonment of a facility within the rights of way of the village, the utility shall notify the village within ninety (90) days. Following receipt of such
notice, the village may direct the utility to remove all or any portion of the facility if the deputy building commissioner determines that such removal will
be in the best interest of the public health, safety and welfare. In the event that the village does not direct the utility that abandoned the facility to
remove it, by giving notice of abandonment to the village, the abandoning utility shall be deemed to consent to the alteration or removal of all or any
portion of the facility by another utility or person.
E. In the event that all or part of a public right of way is: 1) closed to utilities; or 2) vacated, or if ownership of the land under the affected public right of way
is otherwise transferred to a party other than the village, a utility must remove its facilities from the public right of way at its own cost and expense. If a
closing, vacation, or transfer of a public right of way is undertaken for the benefit of any private person, the village may condition its consent to such
closing, vacation, or transfer of the public right of way on the agreement of the private person to: 1) grant all utilities having facilities in the public right of
way the right to continue to occupy and use such public right of way; or 2) reimburse the utilities for their reasonable costs to relocate their facilities.
The village shall provide not less than ninety (90) days' prior notice to a utility of any such closing, vacation, or transfer to allow the utility to remove its
facilities where the right to continue to occupy and use such public right of way is not reserved for the utility. (Ord. 2009-3, 2-9-2009)
7-3-13: CLEANUP AND RESTORATION:
The utility shall remove all excess material and restore all turf and terrain and other property within ten (10) days after any portion of the rights of way are
disturbed, damaged or destroyed due to construction or maintenance by the utility, all to the satisfaction of the village. This includes restoration of
entrances and side roads. Restoration of roadway surfaces shall be made using materials and methods approved by the deputy building commissioner.
Such cleanup and repair may be required to consist of backfilling, regrading, reseeding, resodding, or any other requirement to restore the right of way to a
condition substantially equivalent to that which existed prior to the commencement of the project. The time period provided in this section may be extended
by the deputy building commissioner for good cause shown. (Ord. 2008-01, 1-14-2008)
7-3-14: MAINTENANCE AND REPAIRS:
A. General Maintenance Requirements: Facilities on, over, above, along, upon, under, across, or within rights of way are to be maintained by or for the
utility in a manner satisfactory to the village and at the utility's expense.
B. Emergency Maintenance Procedures: Emergencies may justify noncompliance with normal procedures for securing a permit.
1. If an emergency creates a hazard on the traveled portion of the right of way, the utility shall take immediate steps to provide all necessary protection
for traffic on the highway or the public on the right of way including the use of signs, lights, barricades or flaggers. If a hazard does not exist on the
traveled way, but the nature of the emergency is such as to require the parking on the shoulder of equipment required in repair operations, adequate
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 214/493
signs and lights shall be provided. Parking on the shoulder in such an emergency will only be permitted when no other means of access to the facility
is available.
2. In an emergency, the utility shall, as soon as possible, notify the deputy building commissioner or his or her duly authorized agent of the emergency,
informing him or her as to what steps have been taken for protection of the traveling public and what will be required to make the necessary repairs.
If the nature of the emergency is such as to interfere with the free movement of traffic, the village police shall be notified immediately.
3. In an emergency, the utility shall use all means at hand to complete repairs as rapidly as practicable and with the least inconvenience to the traveling
public.
C. Emergency Repairs: The utility must file with the village, in writing, a description of the repairs undertaken in the right of way within forty eight (48) hours
after an emergency repair. (Ord. 2008-01, 1-14-2008)
7-3-15: VARIANCES:
A. Request For Variance: A utility requesting a variance from one or more of the provisions of this chapter must do so in writing to the deputy building
commissioner as a part of the permit application. The request shall identify each provision of this chapter from which a variance is requested and the
reasons why a variance should be granted.
B. Authority To Grant Variances: The deputy building commissioner shall decide whether a variance is authorized for each provision of this chapter
identified in the variance request on an individual basis.
C. Conditions:
1. The deputy building commissioner may authorize a variance only if the utility requesting the variance has demonstrated that:
a. One or more conditions not under the control of the utility (such as terrain features or an irregular right of way line) create a special hardship that
would make enforcement of the provision unreasonable, given the public purposes to be achieved by the provision; and
b. All other designs, methods, materials, locations or facilities that would conform with the provision from which a variance is requested are
impracticable in relation to the requested approach.
2. As a condition for authorizing a variance, the deputy building commissioner may require the utility requesting the variance to meet reasonable
standards and conditions that may or may not be expressly contained within this chapter but which carry out the purposes of this chapter.
D. Appeals: Any utility aggrieved by any order, requirement, decision or determination, including denial of a variance, made by the deputy building
commissioner under the provisions of this chapter shall have the right to appeal to the village administrator. The application for appeal shall be
submitted in writing to the village clerk within thirty (30) days after the date of such order, requirement, decision or determination. The village
administrator shall timely decide the appeal. (Ord. 2008-01, 1-14-2008)
7-3-16: PENALTIES:
A. Any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to fine in accordance
with section 1-4-1 of this code. There may be times when the village will incur delay or other costs, including third party claims, because the utility will
not or cannot perform its duties under its permit and this chapter. Unless the utility shows that another allocation of the cost of undertaking the
requested action is appropriate, the utility shall bear the village costs of damages and its costs of installing, maintaining, modifying, relocating, or
removing the facility that is the subject of the permit. No other administrative agency or commission may review or overrule a permit related cost
apportionment of the village. Sanctions may be imposed upon a utility that does not pay the costs apportioned thereto.
B. Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as limiting any additional or further remedies that the village may have for enforcement of this chapter. (Ord.
2008-01, 1-14-2008)
Chapter 4
PUBLIC PARKS
7-4-1: PARK DISTRICT PROPERTY, LIQUOR OR DRUGS PROHIBITED1:
A. Definitions:
ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR: Includes alcohol, spirits, wine and beer, and any other liquid or solid which is defined as an "alcoholic liquor" by the Illinois liquor
control act2.
CONTROLLED SUBSTANCE: Any substance so defined under the statutes of the state of Illinois3.
B. Sale Or Possession Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, deliver, consume or possess for consumption any alcoholic liquor or controlled
substance in the following facilities or grounds, which are owned, operated or maintained by the Lake Bluff park district:
Artesian park
Beachfront Ravine park
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 215/493
Blair park
Mawman park
Sunrise park
C. Application For Exception: The park district may grant exceptions to the consumption of alcohol in a park above designated, upon application by a
resident of the park district, for such reasons as may be in the best interest of the district and the residents thereof. Every resident applying for an
exception, whether an individual, group or organization, must satisfy the following requirements:
1. Applications must be in writing, must specify the date for which an exception is requested, and must be made not less than five (5) days in advance
of the specified date.
2. The applicant must obtain dramshop liability insurance in maximum insurance coverage limits so as to save harmless the park district from all
financial loss, damage or harm, and must deposit a certificate of such insurance with the district. (1988 Code § 5-4-1)
D. Penalty: The penalty for violation of this section shall be a fine not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than the maximum provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for any one offense. (1988 Code § 5-4-1; amd. 2009 Code)
7-4-2: VILLAGE PARKS, LIQUOR OR DRUGS PROHIBITED:
A. Definitions: See subsection 7-4-1A of this chapter.
B. Sale Or Possession Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, deliver, consume or possess for consumption any alcoholic liquor or controlled
substance in the following facilities or grounds which are owned, operated or maintained by the village:
Pedestrian paths
The Skokie River nature preserve trail
Village green
Washington park
All other unnamed neighborhood parks
C. Penalty: See subsection 7-4-1D of this chapter. (1988 Code § 5-4-2; amd. 2009 Code)
7-4-3: SKOKIE RIVER NATURE PRESERVE TRAIL REGULATIONS:
A. Hours Of Usage: It shall be unlawful for any person to enter, use, or occupy the Skokie River nature preserve trail at any time before sunrise or after
sunset of every day of the year except as expressly authorized herein. This subsection shall not apply to:
1. Emergency situations;
2. The after hours entry, usage, or occupancy of the Skokie River nature preserve trail by an authorized licensee of the village, or its agent, in
connection with the construction, maintenance, or landscape management of the Skokie River nature preserve trail pursuant to a license agreement
with the village; or
3. The members of occasional after sunset guided tours for bird and sky watching and other similar passive purposes conducted by an authorized
licensee of the village, or its agent, pursuant to a license agreement with the village; provided, that:
a. Such after sunset tours originate and terminate only at the JAWA access point; and
b. The village administrator is advised of any such tour at least three (3) business days prior to the day on which such tour is scheduled to occur.
B. Vehicles: It shall be unlawful to use or operate bicycles, automobiles, snowmobiles, motorcycles, minibikes, and all other motorized vehicles at any time
on the Skokie River nature preserve trail. This subsection shall not apply to emergency vehicles or to construction and maintenance vehicles used in
connection with the construction, maintenance and management of the Skokie River nature preserve trail pursuant to a license agreement with the
village.
C. Littering: It shall be unlawful to litter or create waste on the Skokie River nature preserve trail at any time.
D. Prohibited Activities: It shall be unlawful to conduct or participate in hunting, trapping, game shooting, camping, campfire, bonfire, picnicking and related
activities at any time on the Skokie River nature preserve trail.
E. Damage To Vegetative Life: It shall be unlawful to cut, dig up, remove, or in any way damage or destroy plant or other vegetative life on the Skokie
River nature preserve trail. This subsection shall not apply to authorized damage or destruction that occurs as part of the construction, maintenance, or
management of the Skokie River nature preserve trail pursuant to a license agreement with the village.
F. Burning: It shall be unlawful to burn landscape waste or related material or to conduct any activity involving fire or burning for any purpose at any time
on the Skokie River nature preserve trail; provided, however, that the village administrator may authorize such activities, but only in accordance with
the standards and guidelines adopted by the board of trustees, as such standards and guidelines may, from time to time, be amended. Unless and until
such standards and guidelines have been adopted by the board of trustees, such activities shall not be permitted at any time.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 216/493
G. Hazardous Substances: It shall be unlawful to use hazardous substances at any time on the Skokie River nature preserve trail. For purposes of this
subsection, the term "hazardous substances" shall mean and include petroleum products and their constituents and substances defined as "regulated
substances", "hazardous waste", "hazardous materials", "toxic substances", "pollutants", "toxic pollutants", "herbicides", "fungicides", "rodenticides",
"insecticides", "contaminants", or "pesticides" in any federal, state or local law or regulation pertaining to the public health or environment. This
subsection shall not apply to hazardous substances used as part of the authorized construction, maintenance or management of the Skokie River
nature preserve trail pursuant to a license agreement with the village.
H. Established Walking Paths: It shall be unlawful for any person to leave the established walking paths of the Skokie River nature preserve trail at any
time and for any reason except as expressly authorized herein. This subsection shall not apply to: 1) emergency situations; 2) construction,
maintenance or landscape management activities undertaken by an authorized licensee of the village, or its agent, pursuant to a license agreement
with the village; or 3) members of guided tours conducted by an authorized licensee of the village, or its agent, pursuant to a license agreement with
the village. (Ord. 95-08, 3-27-1995)
I. Penalty: The penalty for violation of this section shall be a fine not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than the maximum provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for any one offense. (Ord. 95-08, 3-27-1995; amd. 2009 Code)
Title 8
UTILITIES
Chapter 1
WATER REGULATIONS
ARTICLE A. GENERAL PROVISIONS
8-1A-1: WATER DIVISION OF PUBLIC WORKS DEPARTMENT:
The water division of the public works department shall be under the supervision of the village administrator. (1988 Code § 5-1A-1-1)
8-1A-2: PERMITS:
A. Water Use:
1. Required: No person except a regularly appointed agent of the village shall take water from any hydrant, plug, hose, pipe or fountain, except for use
in case of fire or emergency, or shall in any way use or take any water for private use, drinking at public fountains excepted, unless such person has
first paid the village for the same and received a permit from the village. (1988 Code § 5-1A-2-1)
2. Fee: The fee for a water permit shall be as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code, under the category "construction/building fees". No person except
one duly authorized by the director of public works shall be permitted under any circumstances to tap the village street main or insert stopcocks or
connections therein. The village authorities shall tap the street main and furnish the corporation cock, curb cock, curb box and meter. The charge for
said tapping performed, and materials furnished by the village, shall be as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code, under the category
"construction/building fees". (1988 Code § 5-1A-2-1; amd. 2009 Code)
B. Water Connection: Any person owning or occupying premises adjacent to the water distribution system of the village and desiring water service shall
sign an application for such service in the form prescribed by the village, and no connection shall be made with the water system of the village without
a permit having first been issued therefor by the village. No permits shall be issued for the installation, repair or connection to water pipes unless the
person applying therefor shall be a duly bonded and licensed plumber. (1988 Code § 5-1A-2-2)
8-1A-3: METERS:
A. Required: All water furnished and sold by the village from the public water system of the village shall be measured by water meters and paid for at water
rates as herein fixed and determined. With the exception of meters replaced at village expense due to normal wear and tear1, water meters shall be
purchased from the village and installed and sealed, and thereafter kept in repair, all at the expense of the water taker or property owner. All meters
shall be equipped with an operating outside reading service, unless the village administrator or his/her designee determines otherwise. (Ord. 95-27, 8-
14-1995)
B. New Service: All new water service shall be metered. New services include, but are not limited to, water service in new construction of all types. (1988
Code § 5-1A-3-2)
C. Installation; Upkeep:
1. Meter Connection Required: All water takers or parties desiring to use water from the village water system shall be required to cause a meter of such
make as shall be approved by the village administrator to be connected with the service pipe, furnishing the supply in such manner that all water so
furnished or supplied shall pass through said meter and be measured and registered.
2. Location: The location of meters shall be determined by the director of public works, or someone duly authorized by him, and shall be so placed as
to be easily accessible for the purpose of making repairs, inspection or taking statements of the index thereof. (1988 Code § 5-1A-3-3)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 217/493
3. Obstructions; Turn Off For Violation; Fee: In case obstructions are so placed that a meter is not easily accessible, the director of public works shall
notify the party controlling the same to remove the obstruction, and in case of failure, refusal or neglect to do so within a reasonable time, to be
stated in the notice, the director shall turn off the supply, or instruct his duly authorized representative so to do, and it shall not be turned on again
until the obstructions have been removed and the fee for turning on and off the water set out in section 1-12-3 of this code, under the category "user
charges and connection fees", is paid. (1988 Code § 5-1A-3-3; amd. 2009 Code)
D. Right To Inspect; Inaccurate Meters:
1. Meters Accessible: All meters and reading devices shall be installed by the property owner under the supervision and direction of the director of
public works, or his duly authorized representative, and sealed by him, and so placed and maintained as to be accessible to the director of public
works, or someone duly authorized by him, at all reasonable hours.
2. Inaccuracy: If a meter at any time fails to accurately register and measure the quantity of water used, the amount used shall be determined and
charges made therefor by the director of public works on the average quantity registered and measured for a period similar in time and character
when such meter was accurately registering and measuring water. No deduction shall be made on account of leakage after water has passed
through a meter. (1988 Code § 5-1A-3-4)
E. Repairs; Removal: No water meter shall be repaired, changed, altered, disconnected or in any way disturbed except by an authorized representative of
the village; provided, however, that in the event of freezing, dangerous leak or other emergency, a licensed plumber may, without first obtaining a
permit, remove such meter from the line, but in no case from the premises. Notice of such removal shall be given by such plumber to the village within
twenty four (24) hours thereafter. (1988 Code § 5-1A-3-5)
F. Meter Readings; Estimated Bills: Whenever access to any premises furnished water by the village cannot be gained for the purpose of an annual meter
reading, a meter card will be left on the premises for the consumer to enter his current actual readings of his water meter and return to the village. In
the event such meter card or a verbal report of the current reading is not received by the village within five (5) days after the card is left on the
premises, an estimated bill, based upon usage for a corresponding period of the previous year, will be billed to the consumer. (1988 Code § 5-1A-3-6)
G. Separate Meters Required: Not more than one residence, house, business building or one main edifice shall be permitted to measure water from one
meter except necessary appurtenances to such main building, and in no case shall two (2) dwellings be allowed to be metered from one meter. (1988
Code § 5-1A-3-7)
H. Use Of Additional Meters: Where more than one meter is used in supplying water to one residence or house, not including, however, apartment or
business buildings, the water thereby supplied shall be measured through such meters as a single unit, and only one minimum charge shall be made,
and the balance of water measured through such meters shall be billed as water used in excess of the minimum charge as hereinafter provided. (1988
Code § 5-1A-3-8)
8-1A-4: VILLAGE POWERS:
A. Director Of Public Works:
1. The director of public works and his authorized agents shall have free access Monday through Friday with appropriate authorization, between seven
o'clock (7:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) P.M., to all parts of every building or premises in which water is delivered and consumed, to examine the
pipes and fixtures and to ascertain if there is any unnecessary waste of water, and to examine and read meters. In the event of the refusal of the
owner or occupant of any such premises to allow such access and inspection, the village shall have the right to seek a search warrant therefor.
2. All work done on the street and contemplated by this chapter must be done under the supervision of the director of public works, and subject to his
direction and approval.
B. Suspend Or Limit Use Of Water: The village administrator shall have the power to suspend or limit the use of water supplied by the village water system
as in his judgment the public exigency may require.
C. Cross Connections: The village administrator, or his designee, shall have the power to enforce the village cross connection regulations as set forth in
article E of this chapter. (Ord. 2009-14, 4-13-2009)
8-1A-5: HYDRANTS:
A. Private Hydrants: No private hydrant shall be located on the sidewalk or elsewhere beyond the limits of the lot of the party to whom the permit is issued.
No private hydrant in a lot shall be allowed to be used as a public hydrant, unless by a special permit from the board of trustees.
B. Placement On Street; Drinking Fountains: No hydrant, except public drinking fountains, shall be placed within the limits of any street, and no drinking
fountain shall be erected for public use which has openings by which it can be used as a source of domestic supply. (1988 Code § 5-1A-5)
8-1A-6: SEPARATE CONNECTIONS REQUIRED:
A consumer or water taker, who has installed a meter and who shall observe all provisions required, may thereby use water for any purpose on his own
premises, but will not be permitted to supply any other person with water, and shall not permit any other person to take water from his premises by any
means whatever, and shall in all things observe the provisions of this chapter. (1988 Code § 5-1A-6)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 218/493
8-1A-7: SALE OF WATER BY PARK DISTRICT AUTHORIZED:
A. Compliance Waived: The provisions of this chapter, with regard to the sale of village water and water connections, are hereby waived with respect to
the sale of water by the Lake Bluff park district only to the owners of property commonly known as 119 and 121 Rockland Road, Lake Bluff, Illinois.
B. Terms And Conditions Of Waiver: This waiver is subject to the following specific terms and conditions:
1. Separate Meters: Within sixty (60) days from the effective date hereof, the Lake Bluff park district shall install separate water meters at both 119 and
121 Rockland Road in such locations as approved by the village administrator.
2. Purchase By Park District: Said meters and component parts thereof shall be purchased from the village as in the case of other village water
customers and shall be paid for by the Lake Bluff park district.
3. Maintenance By Park District; Village Inspection: Said meters shall be maintained by the Lake Bluff park district and shall be subject to the same
inspection as water meters in the village.
4. Connection To Village Lines When Available: Upon the installation of a water service line on Rockland Road, within three hundred feet (300') of 119
and 121 Rockland Road, which can supply family residences with water service therefrom, the owners of said 119 and 121 Rockland Road shall
install service lines thereto and be metered from said Rockland Road and shall disconnect service from the Lake Bluff park district. (Ord. 89-37, 8-
28-1989)
8-1A-8: CISTERNS AND WELLS:
A. Use Prohibited For Human Consumption: No cistern or well within the limits of the village shall be used for obtaining or storing water for human
consumption; provided further, that such restrictions shall not apply to any well servicing any residential dwelling where such residential dwelling is
located one thousand two hundred fifty feet (1,250') or more from any public water line and which complies with all health and sanitation requirements
of governing bodies having jurisdiction. (1970 Code § 42.01)
B. Metal Covers Required: A metal or other substantial cover shall be provided and at all times kept on each cistern or well, which cover shall be of
sufficient weight or shall be fastened to the walls of the well or to the ground, so as to prevent the same from being removed by children. (1970 Code
§ 42.02)
C. Penalty: The owner or occupant of the premises maintaining such a cistern or well as aforesaid in violation of this section shall be liable to a fine of not
more than the maximum provided in section 1-4-1 of this code. (1970 Code § 42.03; amd. 2009 Code)
8-1A-9: PROHIBITED ACTS:
A. Damaging Village Property: No person shall wilfully or carelessly break, injure, mar or deface any machinery, apparatus, fixture, attachment or
appurtenance of the village, or any public or private hydrant or stopcock, stopcock box, water supply or service pipe or any part thereof. (1988 Code
§ 5-1A-7)
B. Wasting Water: Hydrants, taps, hose, water closets, urinals, baths and other fixtures will not be permitted to be kept running when not in actual use. All
faucets connected with service pipes must be of such pattern as may be approved by the director of public works. (1988 Code § 5-1A-5)
8-1A-10: VIOLATIONS; DISCONTINUING SERVICE; FEES:
For a violation of any of these provisions or any rules and regulations as the board of trustees may hereafter adopt, the board of trustees reserves the right
to stop the supply of water without any preliminary notice, nor will it be restored until all back bills, charges for water consumed at the rates set out in
section 1-12-3 of this code, under the category "user charges and connection fees", of this code, costs and damages shall be paid, together with an
amount for the expense of turning off the water and an amount for turning the water on again, both amounts as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code, under
the category "user charges and connection fees", and upon a satisfactory understanding with the party that no further cause of complaint shall arise. The
board of trustees hereby reserves to itself the full right, power and authority to cut off the supply of water at any time, without incurring any liability or cause
of action for damages of any kind, any permit granted or regulation to the contrary notwithstanding. In case of a second violation of the regulations by any
person, the board of trustees may cause the connection with the service pipe to be plugged. Should this be done, a charge as set out in section 1-12-3 of
this code, under the category "user charges and connection fees", will be made for reinserting it. (1988 Code § 5-1A-8; amd. 2009 Code)
8-1A-11: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter, where no other penalty is provided, shall, upon conviction, be fined not less than twenty five
dollars ($25.00) nor more than the maximum provided in section 1-4-1 of this code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed
on each day on which the violation occurs or continues. (1988 Code § 5-1A-9; amd. 2009 Code)
ARTICLE B. RATES AND CHARGES
8-1B-1: RATES AND CHARGES ESTABLISHED:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 219/493
A. Separate Water Service And Sanitary And Storm Sewer Maintenance And Collection Service Rates: The rates at which: 1) water service; and 2)
sanitary and storm sewer maintenance and collection service will be sold and furnished to consumers by the village shall be as set out in section 1-12-
3 of this code, under the category "user charges and connection fees". For the purposes of this article, all references to "water" and "water service"
shall be deemed to include "sanitary and storm sewer maintenance and collection" and "sanitary and storm sewer maintenance and collection service",
respectively. (Ord. 93-12, 7-12-1993; amd. 2009 Code)
B. Rates Not Provided; Assessment By Administrator: Water supplied to any place for which the rates are not provided by other rules shall be assessed by
the village administrator in accordance with guidelines established from time to time by the board of trustees. (1988 Code § 5-1B-1)
8-1B-2: DEPOSIT REQUIREMENTS:
A. Amount Of Deposit: If any applicant for water service is not the legal or equitable owner of the premises for which water service is requested, the
applicant shall, as a condition precedent, make a cash deposit in advance to ensure payment of final bills, in an amount equal to the estimated
maximum quarterly bill of the applicant, as determined by the village treasurer after giving consideration to the average consumption of similar
consumers. (Ord. 2003-16, 11-24-2003)
B. Apply To Delinquent Bill: If a consumer having made a cash deposit allows a water bill to become delinquent, the deposit may be applied to liquidate the
bill, and water service may be shut off as provided in section 8-1A-10 of this chapter. Water service shall not be turned on again until the deposit is
restored to its original amount. If the deposit does not liquidate the water bill, then water service shall not be restored until the balance of the water bill
is paid, the entire original deposit restored, and the fees as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code, under the category "user charges and connection
fees", for discontinuing and turning on the water service are paid. (Ord. 2003-16, 11-24-2003; amd. 2009 Code)
C. Receipt For Deposit: The village shall issue a receipt for each deposit showing the date of deposit and the amount received. The receipt shall be
surrendered by the depositor upon application for the refund of the deposit and shall not be transferable.
D. Final Disposition Of Deposit: Each deposit made under the provisions of this section shall be delivered to the village treasurer, or the treasurer's
designee, to be held in the water fund. Upon the discontinuance of a consumer's water service, the deposit shall be refunded without interest, less any
amounts still due and owing the village for water service up to the time of discontinuance.
E. Additional Deposit: The village treasurer may require an additional deposit in an amount up to the sum of two (2) average bills from any customer that
has been more than thirty (30) days' delinquent twice within a billing year or from any customer that has filed for bankruptcy within seven (7) years prior
to the date of the most current water bill. (Ord. 2003-16, 11-24-2003)
8-1B-3: QUARTERLY BILLS; PAYMENT DATE:
A. All water bills shall be computed on a quarterly basis and due and payable on or before the due date shown on the bill, whether the bill is a quarterly bill,
or one for discontinuance of any service. Failure to receive a water bill shall not relieve the owner, tenant, or occupant of liability under any of the
provisions of this title. (Ord. 2003-16, 11-24-2003)
B. All bills must be paid promptly when due. (1988 Code § 5-1B-3)
8-1B-4: RESPONSIBILITY OF PROPERTY OWNER FOR CHARGES:
A. Liability For Payment: Property owners shall be charged with and held liable for all water bills, charges, and benefits accruing by reason of the
provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 2003-16, 11-24-2003)
B. Failure Of Occupant To Pay: Water bills, if not paid by the occupant of the premises when due, shall then be paid by the owner of said premises. (1988
Code § 5-1B-4)
8-1B-5: FAILURE TO PAY BILLS:
A. Notice; Appeal:
1. Notice Of Delinquency: If any property owner or occupant fails or refuses to pay a bill for water service forty five (45) days after the original billing
due date, the village treasurer, or the treasurer's designee, is hereby authorized and directed to give written notice of the delinquency ("delinquency
notice") to the owner or occupant and the party or person shown on the books and records of the water department to be responsible for the
payment of the bill for the relevant period. The delinquency notice shall be sent by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested.
2. Discontinuance Of Service; Request For Hearing:
a. The delinquency notice shall demand payment in full of all delinquent amounts within fifteen (15) days after the date of the notice. All payments of
delinquent amounts shall be made by cash, credit card, or other certified funds. The delinquency notice shall also state that the water service to
the premises in question shall be cut off automatically without further notice unless payment is made in full within the fifteen (15) day period.
b. If the customer disagrees with the delinquency notice, the customer shall notify the village treasurer within five (5) days after the date of the
delinquency notice and request that the village treasurer review the disputed water bills. The village treasurer shall have the power to rectify errors
or to confirm the delinquency. If confirmed in whole or in part, the water bill shall be paid within five (5) days after the date of the confirmation
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 220/493
notice sent by the village treasurer ("confirmation notice"). The confirmation notice shall advise the customer of his or her right to appeal the
decision of the village treasurer and shall be sent by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested.
c. Any customer may appeal the decision of the village treasurer by requesting a hearing before the village administrator. All requests for hearings
must be in writing and made within the five (5) day period after the date of the confirmation notice. The village shall notify of the time and place for
the hearing by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested.
d. All hearings shall be conducted by the village administrator who shall make written findings of fact and a written determination. The decision of the
village administrator shall be sent to the customer by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested.
e. The customer shall pay all delinquent amounts within five (5) days after the date of the village administrator's written decision, or water service
shall be terminated.
f. The failure of a customer to accept registered or certified mail shall not extend any of the time periods for notice or payment as provided in this
subsection.
3. Appeal To Administrator: In the event of an appeal to the village administrator, no action will be taken by the village unless and until the appeal has
been heard and acted upon by the village administrator.
4. Costs Of Replacement Parts: Costs of any parts that must be replaced for any reason whatsoever shall be paid by the delinquent party as a
prerequisite to the restoration of water service. (Ord. 2003-16, 11-24-2003)
5. Water Turn On By Village Only: No plumber or other person shall turn on the water supply to any building or premises from which the supply has
been shut off by order of the village administrator. (1988 Code § 5-1B-5-1)
B. Discontinuing Service; Reinstatement: Should any consumer fail to pay a delinquent bill after notice or decision as set forth in subsection A of this
section, water service may be discontinued until all overdue amounts, penalties, and the expense of discontinuing the water service as provided for in
section 8-1A-10 of this chapter shall have been paid in full, together with costs, if any, paid by the village and arising from the filing of a water lien claim,
and other costs, charges, and reasonable attorney fees incurred in the enforcement of such water lien or collection of overdue amounts. (Ord. 2003-16,
11-24-2003)
C. Additional Penalty: For each thirty (30) day period or part thereof after the due date of a water bill, a penalty as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code,
under the category "user charges and connection fees", shall be added to the amount due until the total amount is paid in full. This penalty shall not be
proratable for a portion of a thirty (30) day period. Payment of this additional penalty shall be a condition precedent to restoration of water service to the
customer. (Ord. 2003-16, 11-24-2003; amd. 2009 Code)
8-1B-6: LIEN PROVISIONS:
A. Continuing Lien: The village shall have a continuing lien for all delinquent water bills, charges, or benefits upon the premises and real estate upon or for
which such the water is used or supplied. Every lien shall, upon compliance with the conditions of this section, become and be prior to the rights and
interests of creditors, encumbrancers, purchasers, and other parties in interest in the premises and real estate.
B. Enforcement: Liens imposed pursuant to this section may be preserved and enforced in the following manner: The village administrator shall, within six
(6) months after the due date of delinquent water bills, charges, or benefits, file or cause to be filed with the recorder of deeds of Lake County a claim
of lien. The claim of lien shall be verified by affidavit of the village administrator or other village officer with knowledge of the facts. The affidavit shall
consist of a brief statement of the facts of the claim, the balance due after allowing all credits, and a legal or other sufficient description of the premises
in question. No lien shall be defeated to the proper amount thereof because of an error on the part of the village, nor shall any such lien be defeated
upon proof that the water was used or contracted for by a tenant or occupant of the premises other than the owner.
C. File Petition Or Complaint: If water bills, charges, or benefits are not paid when due as provided in this article, the village may file or cause to be filed a
petition or complaint in the circuit court of Lake County for a foreclosing of the lien, or upon becoming a defendant in any pending suit affecting the
lands or property in question, by answer to the bill or petition in the nature of an intervening petition, or by cross bill, and the village may proceed in its
corporate name to foreclose the lien in like manner and with like effect as provided by the statutes of the state in foreclosure of mortgages. The
proceeds of the foreclosure sale, after deducting costs, shall be applied to the payment of the water bills, charges, and penalties due. Foreclosures
shall be commenced, or answers or cross bills filed, within two (2) years after the accrual of the water bills, charges, or benefits. Any decree rendered
in court may be enforced and collected as other decrees or judgments rendered in the same court.
D. Additional Means Of Collection: The remedy provided in this section is an additional means to enforce payment of delinquent water bills, charges, or
benefits and shall not abridge or interfere with the right and power of the village to enforce the collection of delinquent water bills, charges, or benefits
by an action at law or as otherwise provided in this chapter. (Ord. 2003-16, 11-24-2003)
ARTICLE C. CONSTRUCTION; INSTALLATIONS; CONNECTIONS
8-1C-1: TAP AND PIPE SPECIFICATIONS:
A. Record Kept: The connection for the distributing pipe and the service pipe laid shall be of the size specified in the permit and order. The director of
public works shall keep a complete record and map showing the exact location and number and size of all taps inserted, and the length of the service
pipe laid, the tapper being hereby required to make immediate returns to the director of public works on such details.
B. Individual Taps; Pipe Dimensions: No more than one tap shall be made in the water distribution system for each house, residence, apartment building,
business building or other private or public building. The size of the tap shall be in proportion to the size of the water main tapped, and shall not exceed

8-1C-2: MATERIALS SPECIFICATIONS:
A. Service Connections: No other material except copper, cast iron or brass shall be used for service connections between the water main and the water
meter.
B. Pipe Size: No smaller pipe than three-fourths inch (3/4") shall be laid underground, and each material shall conform to the specifications as given in
subsection C of this section.
C. Copper Pipe: No copper pipe smaller than three-fourths inch (3/4") internal diameter shall be laid underground, and all copper pipe used for water
service connections shall be soft, annealed, seamless copper tubing or pipe having the following properties and specifications:
1. Chemical Properties: The copper shall be deoxidized with phosphorous and shall have a purity of at least ninety nine and nine-tenths percent
(99.9%) as determined by electrolytic assay. Samples for chemical analysis shall consist of clean drillings or millings taken from tubes selected for
testing purposes.
2. Bending Test: Full sections of annealed tube shall withstand being bent cold through one hundred eighty degrees (180°) without cracking on the
outside of the bent portion, around a pin the diameter of which is one and one-half (11/2) times the inside diameter of the pipe.
3. Dimensions: Standard dimensions and weights of copper service tubes shall be as shown below:

FOR COPPER SERVICE TUBE

Per Foot Pressure Test

11/2 1.36 580
2 2.06 520
4. Workmanship And Finish: Tubes shall be sound and of uniform thickness throughout. They shall be free from cracks, seams, slivers, scale and other
surface defects. (1988 Code § 5-1C-2)
8-1C-3: CORPORATION AND GROUND COCK SPECIFICATIONS:
A corporation cock shall be placed at the main where a connection is made, equal in quality to H. Mueller's figure G-10001 with wiped joint connection. A
ground key curb cock with solid tee handle equal to H. Mueller's figure G-10235 with wiped joint connection shall be placed eighteen inches (18") from the
sidewalk on the street side, and not less than five feet (5') below the surface of the sidewalk. There shall be screwed to this curb cock a Minneapolis
pattern curb box equal in quality and style to H. Mueller's figure G-10300, one and one-half inch (11/2") diameter, with extension overall from five feet (5') to
six feet (6'). (1988 Code § 5-1C-3)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 222/493
8-1C-4: SERVICE LINES:
A. Separate Line Required: In all cases, each and every consumer of water shall have a separate and distinct private service line from the village main to
the meter. In the event of the subdivision of a tract of land already provided with water service, the then existing service may not be extended to provide
service for the lots as subdivided. New and separate services with curb cock shutoff must be provided for each consumer with a meter installed as
hereinabove provided to measure such separate service.
B. Repair Or Replace: In the event it should be necessary to replace or repair old service pipes, the requirements hereof as to new service shall apply
thereto.
C. Location: The line of service pipe shall be at right angles to the main, and the curb cock shall be located directly opposite the tap in the main.
D. Trenches; Pipe Inspection: All trenches shall be dug and all connections except tapping shall be made by a contractor or plumber. Service pipe installed
must be laid in a trench and left uncovered for inspection by the director of public works. If pipe is covered before inspection is made, the contractor or
plumber shall completely expose such pipe for inspection at his own expense. All excavations must be sufficient to ensure proper tapping on the upper
quarter of the street main. (1988 Code § 5-1C-4)
8-1C-5: WATER USING FIXTURE SPECIFICATIONS:
A. Fixture Flow Rates: In all new construction and in all repair and/or replacement of water using fixtures, only fixtures not exceeding the following flow
rates and/or water usage shall be installed. These ratings are based on a pressure at the fixture of forty (40) to fifty (50) psi.
Fixture Gallons Per Flush
Water closets:
Tank type 3.5
Flushometer type 3.0
Urinals:
Tank type 3.0
Flushometer type 3.0
Shower heads 3.0
B. Lavatories For Public Use: In addition to the requirements in subsection A of this section, in all new construction and in all repair and/or replacement of
fixtures, faucets of lavatories located in restrooms intended for public use shall be of metering or self-closing type.
C. Car Wash Installation: In all new construction and replacement of fixtures, car wash installations shall be equipped with a recycling system on the wash
unit and the rinse cycle unit.
D. Air Conditioning And Refrigeration Systems: All air conditioning or industrial refrigeration systems using water as a part of the cooling system shall be
constructed, altered or remodeled as a closed system whereby the water used therein will be recirculated. (1988 Code § 5-1C-5)
8-1C-6: FLUSHING SANITARY SEWERS:
Flushing of sanitary sewers with potable water shall be performed through the use of a high velocity type sewer jet. (1988 Code § 5-1C-6)
8-1C-7: CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTORS; WATER USE FEES:
A charge shall be made for the usage of water during the period of construction. Contractors shall install all temporary meters under the supervision of the
building commissioner or his duly authorized representative. Costs for water used during construction shall be as set out in section 1-12-3 of this code,
under the category "user charges and connection fees", for all water used or consumed in any manner. (1988 Code § 5-1C-7; amd. 2009 Code)
8-1C-8: RETURN OF PERMIT AFTER CONNECTION:
Within forty eight (48) hours after completing any attachment or connection, the tapper or plumber shall make a true return in writing, on the back of the
permit, showing in detail in what manner he has made the installation and done the work authorized in said permit, and shall file the same with the village,
and the water shall not be turned on at any premises until such return is made and filed as aforesaid. (1988 Code § 5-1C-8)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 223/493
8-1C-9: TURNING WATER ON; FEE:
Water service will not be turned on into any house or private service pipe except upon the order of the director of public works, or someone duly authorized
by him, nor until the said return has been made and the permit fee and any charges for tapping or meters or parts shall have been paid. A charge as set
out in section 1-12-3 of this code, under the category "user charges and connection fees", shall be made for turning on water into any house or private
service pipe. (1988 Code § 5-1C-9; amd. 2009 Code)
8-1C-10: RESPONSIBILITIES OF WATER USERS AND OWNERS:
A. Maintenance Of Pipe And Fixtures: Owners of premises using water must, at their own expense, keep their service pipe and all fixtures connected
therewith, including the meter, in good repair and protected from frost, and must prevent all unnecessary waste of water, or the water may be shut off.
Responsibility of the property owner begins at the water main tap by the village.
B. Negligence Of Owner Or Occupant: Where the negligence of the owner or occupant of any property has caused the village expense in adjusting any
water service pipes, such expense shall be paid by the owner or occupant, as the case may be, of such property upon which repair may have been
made necessary by such negligence aforesaid. (1988 Code § 5-1C-10)
ARTICLE D. OUTSIDE WATER USE RESTRICTIONS
8-1D-1: DEFINITIONS:
IRRIGATION: The dispersion of water to prevent arid soil conditions and/or promote landscape growth.
LANDSCAPE: Sodded and seeded lawns, gardens, trees, shrubs and other living plants. (Ord. 90-8, 7-9-1990)
8-1D-2: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
The mandatory water conservation regulations contained herein shall be applicable to all water service customers of the village. (Ord. 90-8, 7-9-1990)
8-1D-3: EMERGENCY WATER SHORTAGE:
A. Declaration: The declaration of a chronic water shortage situation will be issued by the village president, or in the absence of the village president, by
the village administrator, to ensure maintenance of an adequate supply of water to meet internal residential, business and firefighting requirements. No
such additional, immediate or total water use restrictions shall remain in force beyond the next regular meeting of the board of trustees at which a
quorum is present, unless the emergency restrictions determined by the village president or, in the absence of the village president, by such other
person designated herein, are ratified by said board of trustees at such meeting.
B. Restrictions: Upon the declaration of a chronic shortage situation, the following restrictions will be immediately imposed:
1. Occupants with even numbered residences or other structures will be permitted to water lawns and gardens, wash cars and vehicles and use water
for outside use only on even numbered days. Occupants with odd numbered residences or other structures will be permitted to water lawns and
gardens, wash cars and vehicles and use water for outside use only on odd numbered days.
2. By proclamation of the village president, or in the absence of the village president, by the village administrator, following the initial declaration, all
lawn and garden use, washing of vehicles and outside usage of water may be limited to specific hours or totally prohibited.
C. Administration: The administration of this section shall be the responsibility of the office of the village administrator.
D. Major Industrial And Commercial Water Users: The office of the village administrator will review water consumption records and identify the major
industrial and commercial water users. The latter will be consulted in advance, and its assistance solicited for the development of alternative water
conservation measures, which may be voluntarily implemented during shortage situations. When a shortage arises, these heavy water users will be
required to implement their previously prepared plans to such reasonably practical degree as will not impose serious economic hardship.
E. Municipal Conservation Programs: All village departments will be enjoined to restrict activities calling for heavy water consumption. Included in this
category are the testing and clearing of fire hydrants, the cleaning of water mains, the conduct of fire drills, street washings (except in emergencies),
sewer flushing and the watering of public areas.
F. Variances: Variances from the regulatory standards of this section may be granted in accordance with the requirements noted below. No variance shall
be granted unless the applicant for the variance can demonstrate that:
1. An exceptional economic or other hardship would result without the variance;
2. The relief granted is the minimum necessary;
3. There will be no additional threat to public health, safety or welfare or the creation of a nuisance; and
4. No additional public expense will result.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=805 224/493
G. Emergency Water Use Plan: The village shall establish an emergency water use plan to be on file in the office of the village administrator for imposition
during such declared emergency water shortages and adopted by reference. (Ord. 90-8, 7-9-1990)
8-1D-4: IRRIGATION RESTRICTIONS:
